column2: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 14 -Don't count Dancer's Image out yet as the official record-book winner of the 1968 Kentucky Derby.
TOKYO, May 14 -- Premier Eisaku Sato has told the United States that Japan can no longer permit American nuclear vessels to call at her ports unless their safety is guaranteed.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI) -- The Army conceded today it might have saved as much as $20-million on a M-16 rifle contract, but argued that speed of delivery to South Vietnam justified the extra cost.
PANAMA, May 14 -- An uneasy calm returned to this steaming capital today, but the situation was explosive.

ATLANTA, May 14 -- Fran Tarkenton shot a 90 today at the East Lake Country Club, a score that was not so good for him. One of his playing companions was a vice president of Delta Airlines, Tom Miller.

Another title in the omnibus crime-control bill is intended to regulate interstate commerce in firearms. But Title IV is merely a popgun approach to the problem. At best, it would only reduce access to handguns (pistols and revolvers). Shotguns and rifles are deliberately excluded. Score another bullseye for the rifle lobby, the best marksmen in Washington.

IN this electronic era imaginative people have used computers to project the results of sports events. In one instance, whirring wheels produced a victory for Citation over Man o' War in a horse race and, in another, Rocky Marciano knocked out Jack Dempsey in a heavyweight fight -- two mechanical fantasies that jarred traditionalists back onto their heels.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The Senate approved today a crime-bill amendment under which the Federal Government would help pay the cost of special youth units established by communities as a link between police departments and slum areas.
The Ford Foundation yesterday named the panel of judges who will select recipients of its grants for cultural and public affairs programs.
The disturbances at Columbia University are full of curious anomalies -- at least they are curious to me. Students, who presumably want an education, are destroying the possibility of getting one.
PARIS, May 14 -- "The negotiations?" said Nguyen The Hung. "They cannot result in anything worse than the war."

The city's Housing and Development Administration said yesterday that it was making a "feasibility study" of a plan for an apartment, industrial and recreational project for the area along the Hudson River between 125th and 135th Streets.
When Peace Comes."
WASHINGTON, May 14 -The Johnson Administration appealed without apparent success today to organized labor to restrain voluntarily its wage demands.
TAIPEI, Taiwan -- Have you read any good best sellers lately? They are all available here, in English, at bargain rates.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -The proposal to lower the voting age to 18 years, a perennial loser in Congress in recent decades, has taken on new life following recent campus revolts.

MOSCOW, May 14 -- Plans in Finland for the celebration Thursday of the 50th Anniversary of the victorious ending of the Finnish Civil War of 1918 by the White Guard forces of Baron Carl Gustaf Mannerheim were assailed tonight by Izvestia.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -President Johnson voiced hope today that the negotiations in Paris between the United States and the North Vietnamese would "silence the guns in a free Vietnam."
Although several agencies were interviewed, Presidential aspirant Hubert H. Humphrey put his eggs (as expected) in Doyle Dane Bernbach's basket yesterday.

ODDLY enough I never intended to make the comparison, but fortuitous cast changes in George Balanchine's "The Jewels" and a new cast in the Royal Ballet's version of "Swan Lake" last night had me scurrying backward and forward across Lincoln Center plaza, seeing parts of New York City Ballet's "The Jewels" at the State Theater and most of "Swan Lake" at the Metropolitan Opera House.

DAMASCUS, Syria, May 14 (AP) -- President Qahtan al-Shaabi of Southern Yemen announced tonight that anti - Government elements had seized control of three parts of the country in a "full-fledged rebellion."
ALBANY, May 14 -- Governor Rockefeller vetoed today a bill that would have prohibited speech and writings encouraging or inciting violence against any racial, religious or ethnic group.
LINCOLN, Neb., May 14 -Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said tonight that despite his defeat here by Senator Robert F. Kennedy, "we'll go on to Oregon and also to California."
The trustees of Columbia University yesterday rejected a proposal by student strike leaders for a meeting to discuss a settlement of the protest that has crippled the institution since April 23.

McLean Industries made public yesterday plans for two major new transportation projects -- construction of a fleet of 14 to 20 new containerships and the construction of a mail-handling terminal in New Jersey.

CHICAGO, May 14 (AP) -Officials of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad, told stockholders today they were confident the Interstate Commerce Commission would approve a merger with the Chicago North Western Railroad, possibly by the end of this year.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 14 -- Gov. Albert P. Brewer announced today that he had appointed as head of Alabama's law enforcement agency a man who won the acclaim of Negro leaders seven years ago for his role in putting down white violence against Freedom Riders.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -The Defense Department disputed today a statement attributed to Senator Robert F. Kennedy concerning the percentage of paratroopers in Vietnam who are Negroes.

On Aug. 30, 1924, The New York Times published a front-page dispatch from its Moscow correspondent, Walter Duranty, who was one of the three newsmen permitted to attend the final session of the trial of Boris Savinkov.
Three song cycles by American composers were given their premieres last night by Carolyn Reyer, a mezzosoprano who gave a recital at Carnegie Recital Hall.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 14 (AP) -- An Alaskan public health official was shot five times in the head early yesterday, a physician disclosed today, but did not seek aid until 15 hours later because he thought he had only been mugged.
The 26-story building south of Columbus Circle in which the General Motors Corporation has maintained financial headquarters for many years has been sold.
DETROIT, May 14 -- The Ford Motor Company reported today that its dealers had retailed 58,879 new cars from May 1 to 10, down 3 per cent from 60,579 a year ago.

PARIS, May 14 -- In a spirit of joy and revolutionary exultation, thousands of students occupied the Sorbonne today. They told the French Government in countless speeches and posters that they would not permit courses to resume unless at least two Cabinet ministers and the Paris police commandant were removed.
BRUSSELS, May 14 -- A Sovietcontrolled oil company in Belgium has taken a long-term lease on 60 acres in the Antwerp port area to construct a tank farm for storing imported Soviet petroleum.
PHILADELPHIA, March 14 (AP) -- The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy said today: "The outpouring of poor people and the support we have gotten for our march has far exceeded our expectations."

DETROIT, May 14 -- Mayor Jerome P. Cavanagh today publicly apologized to members of the Poor People's March for a brief outbreak of violence last night in which mounted police rode horses into a crowd of marchers.
Two more companies made initial public offerings of common stock yesterday and both were received with enthusiasm.

" Some reduction" in the dividend will be called for when the board of the Granite City Steel Company meets next Tuesday, Nicholas P. Veeder, chairman, told the annual meeting yesterday in Granite City, Ill.
OMAHA, Wednesday, May 15 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy won his second successive Presidential primary last night in convincing fashion, rolling up more than half the votes of Nebraska Democrats.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 14 (UPI) -- Franklin Mieuli, owner of the San Francisco Warriors, said today he had hired George Lee as head coach without a contract.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 14 -- India said today that the draft of the treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons submitted by the United States and the Soviet Union for General Assembly endorsement was discriminatory and divisive, and generated tensions.
PARIS, May 14 -- South Vietnam, eager not to be overlooked as world attention is focused on the talks here between North Vietnam and the United States, moved purposefully into public view today.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- A leading spokesman for the shipbuilding industry urged Congressional maritime policy planners today to consider a plan that could make the ship construction subsidy dollar go farther.
ALBANY, May 14 -- Legislative leaders agreed today on a compromise bill to raise the interestrate ceiling on home mortgage loans from the present 6 per cent to 7.5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -The Communications Satellite Corporation may be in a position to vote an initial dividend by the end of this year, James McCormack, chairman, told about 400 stockholders at the fifth annual meeting in Constitution Hall here today.
BUCHAREST, May 14 -- President de Gaulle invited Rumania today to march with France toward a Europe that would be united and undominated by any ideology or hegemony.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI) -- The House Veterans Affairs Committee recommended today a $235-million-a-year increase in compensation for injuries or illnesses incurred by servicemen on duty.

" Billy," a musical suggested by Herman Melville's short novel "Billy Budd," is planned for Broadway presentation next March by Bruce W. Stark and Arthur A. Seidelman, who also will direct. The show has been budgeted at $550,000 and half the capital has been committed, Mr. Seidelman said yesterday.
The Greater New York Fund, now conducting its 30th annual appeal, was founded in 1938, in a period when New York was still struggling the Depression.

The need for an immediate and careful re-evaluation of the plans for school decentralization was considerably heightened by the arbitrary dismissals of supervisory personnel and teachers by the governing board of Intermediate School 55.
Yale University's School of Drama has received a $100,000 grant to continue and expand its filmmaking program, "Writing for the Camera," from Joseph E. Levine, president of Embassy Pictures.
Following is the text of a statement by Mayor Lindsay on the Ocean Hill-Brownsville school situation:

The Texas Gas Transmission Corporation announced here yesterday a major realignment of top executives in conjunction with the acquisition of American Commercial Lines, Inc., which becomes effective at the close of business today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 14 -- Reaction here to Secretary General Thant's call for an unconditional cessation of United States bombing of North Vietnam ranged today from angry denunciation by South Vietnam's observers to worried questioning by several Western representatives on the timeliness of the statement.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI) -- Before the primaries today, the standing of the Democratic and Republican Presidential contenders in states that have selected national convention delegates, by votes committed or "leaning," was as follows:

Net income of American Airlines, Inc., in April fell to $2,806,000 from $3,882,000 in the comparable month the year before, George A. Spater, president, told the annual meeting yesterday in Wilmington, Del. Mr. Spater said that revenues in April rose to $77,407,000, from $66,127,000 a year ago, an increase of 17 per cent, but expenses rose 22 per cent.

NEW ORLEANS, May 14 (UPI) -- The attorney for H. Rap Brown said today that the black power militant did not know he was under indictment in Maryland last year when he carried a rifle on an airplane across state lines.
The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, a large forest products concern based in Portland, Ore., announced yesterday a wideranging timber development program in Ecuador.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 14 -- Wesleyan University will begin admitting undergraduate women this fall in order to become a more "realistic reflection of the larger society."
" The Cancer Ward," a novel by Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn that has been banned in the Soviet Union, will not be published in the United States as planned.

Two service station attendants called by the prosecution testified yesterday that Mrs. Crimmins had bought gasoline at their station at 6 P.M. the night before her two children disappeared. The children were later found murdered.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- A one-year extension of the Food for Freedom program was voted today by the House after a ban on participation by exporters dealing with North Vietnam was spelled out.
SESIMBRA, Portugal, May 14 -- Some observations at end of a couple of thousand miles on the road in Europe:

BONN -- The international students revolt is already an important factor on the scene in West Germany, Poland, Spain and France, to say nothing of the United States. It seems so violent, so flamboyant, so disorganized, so poignantly poetic and so genuinely leftist that it threatens the Communist Establishment quite as plainly as the bourgeois world.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -The radiation contamination hazard in a nuclear submarine, if any, comes from the cooling water that circulates in a closed system through the submarine's reactor. As the water passes through the reactor, it picks up trace amounts of corrosion, containing small amounts of radioactivity, from the metal surfaces of the reactor.

The Treasury Department announced yesterday that 13 companies -- 11 banks, one stockbroker and one metals trading company -- had been licensed to deal in gold in the United States since the establishment of a two-tier price system for gold on March 17.

LINCOLN, Neb., May 14 -Senator Eugene J. McCarthy accepted today an invitation from nine university and college presidents in Oregon to debate Senator Robert F. Kennedy before the Oregon primary of May 28.

The Episcopal Diocese of New York adopted a resolution yesterday urging that funds that are being held for the completion of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine be transferred to "ghetto area" banks, including those in Harlem and other distressed areas.

BALTIMORE, May 14 (UPI) -- Dancer's Image, disqualified as the winner of the Kentucky Derby, had one of his rare speed trials at Pimlico today when he breezed three furlongs in 36 2-5 seconds and galloped out a half-mile in 53 2-5. He is expected to race in the Preakness Saturday.
Investors maintained a lively trading pace yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market.

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo Republic, May 14 (Reuters) -A Government announcement said today that a group of foreign mercenaries failed last night in an attempt to overthrow the Government of President Alphonse MassambaDebat.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -The State Department said today that the United States and Pakistan had begun discussions about the future of the large American electronic surveillance base near Peshawar in northwest Pakistan.
Atlantic City elected its first Negro Commissioner yesterday.
ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 14 (AP) -- The 15,024 -ton Dutch liner Maasdam has been sold to the Polish Ocean Lines, it was announced today.

CAT admirers presumably were in feline heaven last night as the National Broadcasting Company devoted a full hour to a photographic essay on all varieties of the four-legged animal, including the spoiled pet, the independent predator in city alleys, the cheetah trapped for ex hibition purposes in a zoo and an African lioness downing a beast to feed her cubs.

STOCKHOLM, May 14 -The world's oldest central bank, the Swedish Riksbank, celebrates its 300th anniversary tomorrow. The birthday party, which will be attended by 65 central bank managers from all over the world, will last three days.
Two foreign-made taxicabs will soon be cruising city streets as part of Mayor Lindsay's search for the ideal cab design.
Barry Goldwater stated yesterday that his $2-million libel suit against Ralph Ginzburg, the publisher, was based on four categories of defamations in the defendant's magazine.
Speculative buying pushed silver futures prices up by several cents an ounce yesterday, but trading was only moderately active at 1,404 contracts.

CLEVELAND, May 14 -- One horrible inning, the sort that once helped make the Mets famous, enveloped the New York Yankees tonight and led to a 4-2 loss to the Cleveland Indians, who have won 11 of their last 12 games.

There appears to have been considerable misunderstanding in your May 13 editorial of the facts and of the issues involved in the cancellation of the Sigma Xi convocation at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn last week.

A year's free rent on an apartment, a cocktail party for 80 guests at a private home, a tonsilectomy by President Johnson's physician and a week at a private villa in Italy will be offered at the second annual "Wildest Auction in Town."
" THERESE AND ISABELLE" is a film about those failures of love and excesses of sensuality on the part of adults toward their children that seem to create severe sexual problems in the young.
Two men involved in the Neighborhood Youth Corps were arrested yesterday and charged with fraudulently cashing more than $1,600 of the youth employment program's paychecks.
CAIRO, May 14 -- President Abdel Gamal Nasser received a letter from President Johnson today, linking peace on Vietnam and the Middle East as two objectives that he said he hoped could be achieved.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -The chief of the Justice Department's organized crime section has the physique of a marine sergeant, the calm manner of a criminal lawyer and the occasionally strident voice of one who contends with evil forces.

In a letter published April 18 Robert Moir characterized Hubert Humphrey's candidacy as merely a "Stop-Kennedy movement." Mr. Moir noted that Vice President Humphrey had made a large number of positive contributions to America but could no longer make any such "positive" efforts.
ALBANY, May 14 -- The Assembly passed and sent to Governor Rockefeller today a bill to authorize wiretapping and other eavesdropping in strictly controlled circumstances.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -The head of the Federal Government's organized crime unit said today that more than 120 members of the Cosa Nostra were engaged in major loan-shark activities in the New York metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The commander of a destroyer wrecked during a storm off the island of Rhodes has been court-martialed and sentenced to a reprimand.
PITTSBURGH, May 14 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers traded a quarterback, Bill Nelsen, Tuesday in return for defensive help and a quarterback, Dick Shiner.

MOSCOW, May 14 -- Hostility and fear in the Soviet Union over democratic reforms in Czechoslovakia were underlined here today by a scathing attack on Dr. Thomas G. Masaryk, founder of the Czechoslovak Republic.

The central issue posed by the opening round of the Paris peace conference is whether Hanoi means what it says when it says it favors an "independent South Vietnam" pending ultimate reunification. Neither a settlement nor even the initiation of meaningful negotiations is possible without accord on this point, which assumes that North Vietnamese as well as American troops will be withdrawn from the South.
The Board of Education postponed yesterday its selection of a president to succeed Alfred A. Giardino until Mayor Lindsay named a replacement for Mr. Giardnio as a board member.
Mayor Lindsay proposed last night to expand the Council Against Poverty, the city's anti-poverty policy-making agency, from its present 33 members to 51 members.
The New York Police Department has equipped about 300 of its men with an incapacitating spray gun called the Federal Streamer.
Mayor Lindsay's budget planning has been brought to a standstill by the refusal of the City Council and the State Legislature to act on the Mayor's tax proposals.
Earnings of the United Aircraft Corporation for the first quarter rose to $1.16 a share from 89 cents in the 1967 period, the company reported yesterday.

John M. Stuckwish, 62 years old, who faced death on the operating table May 7, but was brought back to life with the transplanted heart of a 36-year-old homicide victim, died at 11:51 P.M. today in Houston.
MARY McCARTHY felicitously calls Melinda a Lorelei Lee of the Space Age. That will give you a fine, invigorating idea of the company she keeps.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Wednesday, May 15 -- After scandal -rocked campaigns, the major parties chose candidates for Governor yesterday but the races were so close that the results may be inconclusive until the last precinct is recorded.

A wage-increase deadlock in contract negotiations between Danish ship officers and Danish shipowners halted work on three ships here yesterday, two Danish cargo ships, the Lica Maersk and Effie Maersk, and an American freighter, the Attleboro Victory, which happened to be at the same pier in Brooklyn.
Primary contests in most of the city's 19 Congressional districts took shape yesterday as bulky nominating petitions were filed in the Board of Elections office at 80 Varick Street.
Shani Wallis and her fluiddrive voice -- it can amplify from Wee Bonny Baker to Ethel Merman in nothing flat -opened Monday night at the Waldorf-Astoria's Empire Room.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -Derrick Morris poked at a stone with his tennis shoes. His shirttail was out. His hands were in his pockets and he said he was tired.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 14 -Vice President Humphrey has surged into the lead over Senators Robert F. Kennedy and Eugene J. McCarthy as the choice of the nation's rank-andfile Democratic voters for the 1968 Presidential nomination, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

ALBANY, May 14 -- The leaders of the Legislature, acting under pressure from Governor Rockefeller and the State Board of Regents have agreed to strengthen their plan for decentralization of the New York City school system.

At 11:30 A. M. yesterday two men wearing the uniforms of Wells Fargo armored-car guards walked into a branch of the First National City Bank in Brooklyn. After signing the apparently proper releases, they walked out with $198,000 in bills.

A proposal to expand its routes in Manhattan to encompass midtown hotel and business districts was filed with the city yesterday by Carey Transportation, Inc., operator of bus services between the city and major airports.
Seymour Poe, who joined Cinerama, Inc., last August, has been replaced as president of the film company.
ROME, May 14 (AP) -- Bob Hewitt had to struggle today to reach the quarter-finals of the Italian tennis tournament.

TRENTON, May 14 -- A special legislative investigation of public authorities moved quickly tonight to give Gov. Richard J. Hughes veto power over decisions made by officials of the Garden State Parkway.
FORT WORTH, May 14 -- A new goal of the Professional Golfers' Association tournament committee will be a string of $200,000 tournaments in the summer of 1969.

A $1.5-million program to train advanced graduate students at 75 archeological excavation sites in Europe, Africa, Middle East, Southeast Asia and Latin America was announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.

DAYTON, Ohio, May 14 (AP) -- A steerable parachute, looking something like an inflated airplane wing, safely brought Army Sgt. Robert McDermott down from 35,000 feet in a parachute demonstration today.
HONOLULU, May 14 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan was "gratified and surprised" tonight at the size of his vote in the Nebraska Presidential primary.

MOSCOW, May 14 (Reuters) -- More money for workers, more computers for industrial planning and more jobs for housewives were set as goals for the Soviet Union today as 2,000 economists gathered here for a conference on economic development.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., May 14 -- Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson said today that he was convinced that he was "pulling ahead" in the race for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate.

ATHENS, May 14 -- The Government today revised Greece's civil defense legislation to empower the Premier to proclaim a civil mobilization not only if there was a threat of war, but if the nation's "economic and social life" was threatened.

Earnings of Roosevelt Raceway, Inc., probably will increase at least 10 per cent this year compared to those of 1967, George Morton Levy, president, said yesterday in an interview after the annual meeting of the company at the racetrack in Westbury, L. I.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -The deficit in United States international payments was $600-million in the first quarter of this year -- much smaller than the huge deficit at the end of 1967 but still far larger than the Government considers safe.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The growth of business inventories slowed further in March as declines in retail and wholesale stocks partly offset an increase in manufacturing, the Commerce Department reported today.
The American Broadcasting Company will televise this summer a series of six hour long documentaries dealing with racism in America.

The omnibus crime control bill is coming to a climax in the United States Senate this week. Seldom has a potential law that would affect the courts, the police and fundamental concepts of justice in every community in the country been so charged with sectional politics, facile solutions and clearly discernible prejudice against the ignorant and the poor.

LONDON, May 14 -- A small improvement in Britain's foreign trade position for April was reported today. At the same time the Government grappled with Parliamentary and labor union threats to its wage restraint program.

THE Penn Central, which is eager to buy up Pittsburgh Lake Erie stock, is now making its formal exchange offer to shareholders of that profitable line, which chugs West Virginia coal through the hills to Pennsylvania and Ohio steel mills.
DETROIT, May 14 -- Vice President Humphrey suggested today that Negroes be made partners in white-owned businesses in Negro areas through subsidized, low-interest loans.
The Beatles, who have succeeded admirably as a foursome, announced yesterday the establishment of an organization to serve as a catchall of the entertainment business.

The uneasy truce between the Bronx regular Democratic organization and the Reform wing of the party, which has prevailed most of the time since the death of Boss Charles A. Buckley, has been shattered. A fullscale war is now under way between the two groups, with three Congressional seats and control of the party machinery at stake.
The bond market ran into increased resistance from investors yesterday, resulting in slow sales for the corporate and tax-exempt new issues.

ALBANY, May 14 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that "the great majority" of delegates to the Republican National Convention Aug. 5 were not firmly committed to supporting Richard M. Nixon for the party's Presidential nomination.

PRAGUE, May 14 -- Premier Oldrich Cernik and two Deputy Premiers announced at a news conference here today a far-ranging program of political and economic reforms. They also said Czechoslovakia would welcome foreign investment in industry.

Judith Jacobs, an aspiring choreographer, presented a program called "Focus on Five" at the Donnell Library Center of the New York Public Library last evening. The five were Miss Jacobs plus four instrumentalists.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -Robert C. Weaver, the first Negro Cabinet member, said, in a telephone interview today that he planned to leave the Johnson Administration after the November election regardless of who was elected President.

At the Interpublic Group of Companies, where they used to say, "We've got a friend at Dillon, Read," or "We've got a friend at E. F. Hutton," the saying yesterday was "We've got a friend at Chase Manhattan."
Defiant Negro parents and their supporters took over Junior High School 271 in Brooklyn yesterday, barricading the doors and preventing five "dismissed" teachers from entering.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- President Johnson's 24-year-old daughter, Mrs. Charles S. Robb, is expecting her first baby in late October, the White House announced today.

PARIS, May 14 -- Forty-three-year-old Mrs. Vu Thi Dat describes herself as a Hanoi housewife with a job to do there, but she is not a typical one. Mrs. Vu, who looks 10 years younger than her age, is the chief of protocol for the North Vietnamese delegation in Paris for the peace talks.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI) -- The leaders of Vice President Humphrey's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination said today that there were no surprises in the Nebraska primary results.

" What's My Line?" is coming back. The popular game show, which went off the air in September after a 17 1/2-yearrun on the Columbia Broadcasting System, will return this fall on Channel 9 as a fivetimes-a-week syndicated series.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 15 -- Five civilians were killed early this morning and 27 were wounded during a Vietcong mortar and rocket attack in a residential section of Cholon, the Chinese section of Saigon.

Until he became a professional, Roy Emerson had never played a tennis match on boards, had played indoors only sparingly and, as top-seeded in most major tournaments, rarely had had a difficult first-round match.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The White House announced today the names of 10 high school students who have won special scholarships to attend a 12-day international science school in Sydney, Australia. The scholarships include round - the - world trips this summer.
DANNEMORA, N.Y. -- There was only a hazy awareness of barred windows and bolted doors in the day hall of Clinton State Prison's Diagnostic and Treatment Center here.

I am a teacher of twelve years' experience in the New York City school system. The comments, plans and recommendations as presented in the advertisement in The New York Times on May 8 of the United Federation of Teachers: "Give Our Schools a Chance," was misleading in many instances.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 15 -- United States pilots have reduced the number of air raids against targets in North Vietnam during the last seven days, despite the best flying weather of the year.

FUN furs have come a long way since Fred Gompertz started glorifying them eight years ago at Fur and Sport. Then they were mainly long-haired rabbit coats designed to lure women who wouldn't be caught dead in mink. Now they encompass bare-shouldered evening dresses in curly lamb, pinstriped pants in broadtail, and tweedy-looking suits that happen to be muskrat. It's even possible to consider mink and sable fun.

The vice president of Columbia University declared yesterday that the leftist Students for a Democratic Society had sought throughout the academic year to provoke "a confrontation" with the institution's administration.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Vice President Humphrey discounted today the significance of Senator Robert F. Kennedy's victory in yesterday's Democratic primary in Nebraska.
The TV spot opens with a simple print message. "Send your kid to a ghetto for the summer."
TOKYO, Thursday, May 16 (AP) -- A severe earthquake shook a 600-mile stretch of Japan's eastern seaboard today touching off tidal waves and causing widespread but apparently minor damage.

BOSTON, May 15 -- A Negro psychiatrist with extensive experience in integration efforts said today that the black power movement resembled an adolescent's attempt to achieve autonomy and independence from resistant parents.

The New York Generals, led by the scoring of George Kirby and the precise passing of Julio Alas and Co Prins, defeated the St. Louis Stars, 4-0, in a North American Soccer League match at Yankee Stadium last night.

TRENTON, May 15 -- The State Division on Civil Rights charged a prominent New Jersey businessman today with violating the the state's antidiscrimination laws by allegedly blocking the sale to a Jewish lawyer of an expensive house next door to his own.

NEWARK, May 15 -- John W. Smith, the Negro cab driver whose arrest triggered the start of five days of rioting here last July, was sentenced today to two to three years in the state prison for assaulting one of the two policemen who arrested him.
OMAHA, May 15 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy's advisers said today the Nebraska primary results demonstrated that their candidate had the breadth of appeal needed for a national campaign.

BOSTON, May 15 -- The Soviet Union's penetration into Middle East affairs is a "very serious threat to security of the United States," Michael L. Haider, chairman of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) told the company's annual meeting today in Boston.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- A New York City man, wearing a black hood to protect his identity, told a Senate Committee today how he had paid loan sharks $14,000 in a vain attempt to repay $1,900 in borrowings.

ROME, May 15 (UPI) -- Barry Phillips-Moore, a left-handed 29-year-old Australian, scored the biggest upset of the 25th Italian tennis championships today when he beat the defending champion, Martin Mulligan, 1-6, 7-5, 6-1, 3-6, 6-4.

THE smart place to be in New York was in Brooklyn last night. The Academy of Music was full of black ties, writers, painters, musicians, directors, champagne, the Velvet Underground, and, most important of all, Merce Cunningham and his dancers.

Directors of the Sinclair Oil Corporation yesterday designated O. P. Thomas, president, as chief executive officer and elected a slate of officers as part of a planned reorganization of the company's operating structure.

GREAT NECK, L. I. -- Nobody would be more surprised than the members of the Great Neck North High School track team to learn that two of their number are among the keenest, most enthusiastic and adventurous cooks on Long Island.

Robert C. Weaver, Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, was named president yesterday of the City University's new Bernard M. Baruch College, a four-year school that is expected to be built in a Brooklyn renewal area.
William Manchester's "The Death of a President," which caused a controversy between the Kennedy family and the author, will be issued in paperback by Harper Row on June 4.
PARIS, May 15 -- Ambassador at Large W. Averell Harriman attempted today to move the Vietnam talks into what he termed areas of possible common ground, but the response was negative.
Drilling will begin in July on an oil prospect in Israel, Jack Wilder, president of the United States Smelting Refining and Mining Company, told the annual meeting here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The General Accounting Office reported to Congress today that there was still no way to determine whether commodities sent to South Vietnam as economic aid reached their intended destinations.
Watched by sleepy-eyed, sometimes skeptical neighbors and an audience of squirming young schoolchildren, city officials opened New York's first neighborhood service center yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, May 15 -- Declaring that "the guilty should not go free simply because of legal technicalities," Gov. Ronald Reagan proposed today a seven-point program of judicial innovations aimed at strengthening law enforcement.
Lives there a man so self confident that he hasn't bought something and later said, "I think I've been gypped. I would like to stop payment on my check."
Defiance Industries, Inc., won a $3,199,297 judgment yesterday against its president, Victor Muscat, and a member of its board of directors, R. L. Huffines Jr.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (Reuters) -- The five major aspirants for the Presidency agree that there is a United States commitment to the preservation of Israel and that Israel should receive United States arms vital to her self-defense.
FLASHES of emotionalism and long periods of calm reasoning have characterized the rule of Habib Ben Ali Bourguiba since Tunisia's independence from France was proclaimed on March 20, 1956.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The American Automobile Association urged today more travel on holiday weekends, not less. It contended that some safety groups had been frightening Americans off the highways.

ALBANY, May 15 -- The Republican - controlled Senate passed a bill today that would prevent any person from servin as a United States Senator or Representative from New York unless he had been a resident of the state for the five years preceding his election.

The nightmare of tape-recorded television struck at last night's presentation of "News in Perspective," with Lester Markel, associate editor of The New York Times, as moderator, and staff members of The Times.

Senator Clifford Case introduced an important little bill the other day to ban sonic booms by aircraft flying over the United States pending further study of their effects. While technical and budgetary difficulties have slowed development of an American supersonic aircraft, the British and French are progressing with their joint-venture model. It is important to have some protection on the law books before the booms come crashing down on the nation's ears.

Roman-striped medallions of pink, green, yellow and white adorned the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza last eehifig 'for a :dinner dance given 'by the Society of Memorial Slo//n Kettering .Cancer Center. Mrs. John R. Fell and Mrs. William L. Hutton were chairmen.

JACKSON, Miss., May 15 (AP) -- Mississippi Democrats have elected Negroes as delegates to next week's conventions in many counties, the first step toward meeting the national party's requirement that Negroes be allowed to take part freely in party business.

Julius F. Klein received a minimum five-to-six-year sentence for his embezzlement conviction yesterday, despite a request for the maximum 5-to-20-year sentence from Suffolk Assistant District Attorney Carl Spitznagel.

Mayor Lindsay's budget for the next fiscal year, due April 15 under the City Charter but twice postponed because of legislative delays, is again being held up. This time a ridiculous procedural squabble between the City Council and the Legislature, each anxious to evade responsibility for tax increases, is at the bottom of the trouble.

TOKYO, May 15 -- Premier Thanom Kittikachorn declared today that Thailand expects to disprove the validity of the domino theory in relation to the ability of Southeast Asian countries to resist Communist assault.
OTTAWA, May 15 -- The Canadian Government plans to offer newly refined gold to the United States industrial market in the next few months.
The Grosvenor Neighborhood House will benefit from "A Racing Afternoon" on May 24 at the New Belmont Park in Elmont, L. I.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- More than 60 Negro students left the six-story Administration Building at the University of Chicago late today 3 1/2 hours after seizing it in support of demands similar to those made at other universities in recent weeks.

CLEVELAND, May 15 -- Heavy rain, just as the Cleveland Indians were going to bat in the home half of the eighth inning, forced the New York Yankees and Indians to settle for a 2-2 tie today at Municipal Stadium.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 15 -- It's official. Forward Pass remains the record-book winner of the Kentucky Derby -- at least until the next hearing.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 15 -- San Francisco's two merged metropolitan newspapers are the targets of two antitrust suits in United States District Court.

RAPID CITY, S. D., May 15 -- For the last week Senator Eugene J. McCarthy had been telling courthouse crowds in Nebraska that he had challenged Senator Robert F. Kennedy to meet him "at high noon in Scottsbluff" and that the New Yorker had refused.

PEKING, May 15 (Agence France-Presse) -- The Shanghai branch of the Chinese People's Bank is still paying dividends to shareholders who have fled to the United States and taken out American citizenship, the Shanghai paper Wen Hui Pao reported today.

" Once again we note with concern the rising level of American Stock Exchange volume relative to volume on the New York Stock Exchange," runs an appraisal of the cur rent stock-market outlook by Bache Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The Defense Department issued today a draft call for 15,000 Army inductees in July, the lowest monthly call since April, 1967. It also forecast lower than normal draft calls for the July-December period.
A bond issue rated as a higher medium grade investment was sold yesterday at a yield of 8 per cent.
PARIS, May 15 -- A dispute arose today over the accreditation of North Vietnamese journalists to attend the briefings given by the United States delegation.

ATLANTA, May 15 -- Professional football this summer will do away with the routine point-after-touchdown kick and require scoring teams to run or pass the ball to gain the extra point. This rules change, the most significant since the adoption of unlimited substitution two decades ago, will be tried out in the 23 preseason games matching American and National League teams.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Young voters have shifted sharply in the last month from Senator Robert F. Kennedy to Vice President Humphrey as their choice for the Democratic Presidential nomination, George Gallup Jr. told Congress members today.

PRAGUE, May 15 -- The Czechoslovak press reacted with outrage today to a Soviet polemic against the late Thomas G. Masaryk, founder and first president of the Czechoslovak republic, who is considered the spiritual father of his country.

The present crisis at Columbia University is a paradigm of our basic national crisis and at the same time an incident in that national crisis: a test of whether our institutions can succeed in transforming themselves in response to real and inescapable pressures, both internal and external, without either collapsing or hardening into instruments of totalitarian repression.
A wage dispute between Danish ship officers and ship owners continued to halt cargo operations on two Danish freighters here for a second day yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Members of a new safety commission were sworn in by Vice President Humphrey today with a prediction that they would conduct "a healthy investigation without a spirit of incrimination."
Low-priced issues remained in demand yesterday on the American Stock Exchange where trading remained lively.
Ornithology as well as gravity exerted a strong pull in the titles Paul Sanasardo and Manuel Alum gave to their choreography last night at the Hunter College Playhouse.
STOCKHOLM, May 15 -- A new Nobel Prize, in economics, has been added to the five distributed since 1901 under the will of Alfred Nobel, the Swedish inventor of dynamite.
CHICAGO, May 15 (AP) -- Roosevelt University officials said today that an agreement had been reached with student representatives that aims to end a week of student protest demonstrations.
The City Planning Commission yesterday designated for urban renewal an 11-block, 38-acre area of the Fulton Fish Market and surrounding waterfront property.
TAD MOSEL, who won a Pulitzer Prize for his stage adaptation of "All the Way Home," returned to television last night with an original drama entitled "Secrets."

The Friends of the Children's Blood, Foundation will attend the May 23 performance of the Bolshoi Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House and a champagne supper dance afterward at the Pierre Hotel. The evening is being underwritten by the Helena Rubinstein Foundation.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Government investigators concluded today that the fatal crash of a Braniff Airways plane near Falls City, Neb., Aug. 6, 1966, probably resulted from extreme turbulence and not an equipment fault as suspected by the airline and by killed.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 15 -- Peter W. Powers, 27-year-old son of Frederic B. Powers, the Westchester County Republican chairman, was killed at 3:25 A.M. today in a highway accident here near his home.

Federal Judge Inzer B. Wyatt issued a temporary restraining order yesterday against eight of 13 defendants in a Securities and Exchange Commission lawsuit filed here Monday against the American Beryllium and Oil Corporation and 12 other defendants.

Karen Beswick, the brunette "hostess" at Walter Reade's De Mille Theater, where the two-part six and one-half hour, Soviet film of "War and Peace" is playing, stood in the theater's lobby the other afternoon answering the questions of confused and anxious patrons.

MADISON, Wis., May 15 -- A car carrying Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey to an armed forces recognition day luncheon speech today was splattered with a barrage of eggs as he drove through a chanting line of antiwar protesters.

LONDON, May 15 -- Prime Minister Wilson won impressive backing today from the Labor members of Parliament for his prices and incomes policy. The 205-to-42 vote came while more than 600,000 engineers throughout the country were out on a one-day token strike against that policy.
DETROIT, May 15 -- With three Presidential primary victories to his credit, Senator Robert F. Kennedy came out today with a strong new attack on Vice President Humphrey's "politics of happiness."

PARIS, May 15 -- Following are the texts of the statement made today by W. Averell Harriman of the United States and, in official translation, that by Xuan Thuy of North Vietnam at the second session of their talks here:

WILMINGTON, Del., May 15 (AP) -- The Southern Pacific Company had a rise in earnings for the first quarter this year, but the profits were still inadequate in relation to the financing needed for improvements and equipment, Benjamin F. Biaggini, president, said today.

AN Italian and German co-production, a tired package of Minsky leftovers called "How to Seduce a Playboy," opened on the circuits yesterday. The film, in sloppy color and atrociously dubbed, managed to put to sleep at least two middle-aged playboys who were observed in one showcase, the 42d Street Liberty Theater.
NEWARK, May 15 (AP) -- The Port of New York Authority endorsed today the formation of an international trade zone in Bayonne despite the presence of a similar zone in Staten Island.
ALBANY, May 15 -- The State's highest court ruled today that the police may hold a person for questioning even if they do not have "probable cause" to believe he has committed a crime.
WHEN seeking striped bass or bluefish during the daylight hours look for terns as well as for fish.

A new analysis and translation of a long-discredited inscription has led an authority on the ancient Phoenicians to conclude that they landed in Brazil some 2,000 years before Columbus reached the New World.
THE last of the five productions to be offered this season by the City Center Gilbert and Sullivan Company turns out to be the best. In fact, "Patience" is practically perfect.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- In the shadow of the Wright brothers' airplane and the Spirit of St. Louis, pioneer airmail pilots gathered here today to commemorate the start of the United States airmail service 50 years ago.
LONDON, May 15 -- The free market price for gold today broke through what some observers regard as the psychologically dangerous level of $40 an ounce.

The 70th running of the Fashion Stakes provided the backdrop for a memorable occasion for both Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Show Off and for Jesse Davidson, her jockey, before a crowd of 27,541 at Aqueduct yesterday.
A professional pollster testified in Federal Court yesterday that Fact magazine had conducted a "loaded" aid "slanted" poll on Barry Goldwater's fitness when he was running for President in 1964.
ADEN, Southern Yemen, May 15 (Reuters) -- Aden was tense but quiet today after an announcement by President Qahtan alShaabi of a rebellion 45 miles northeast of here.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Military observers asserted today that the cessation of American bombing raids against all of North Vietnam, without some matching restraint by the North Vietnamese, could mean an increase or 15 to 20 per cent in the rate of infiltration of men and supplies into the south.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Some members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee believe the United States again is becoming involved in the arms race in the Indian subcontinent, this time using Italy as an intermediary to supply tanks to Pakistan.

Five meet records fell yesterday as Jamaica High School won the Queens Public Schools Athletic League track and field championship at Randalls Island. Jamaica had 56 points to Jackson's 36 1/3, followed by, Edison's 31 1/3, Newton's 26 and Adams's 19.
Investors continued yesterday to snap up offerings of companies selling shares publicly for the first time.

MONTREAL, May 15 (Canadian Press) -- The Power Corporation of Canada, Ltd., was given the go-ahead by shareholders today on a proposed take-over of the Trans-Canada Corporation Fund. The move would create the largest investment company in Canada.

YONKERS, May 15 -- Ten harness races, each offering a minimum gross purse of $100,000, will be staged in this country this year. The first of these, the Hilltop Trot, a 1 1/4-mile event exclusively for 4-year-olds, is set for tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway, and more than a few observers hardly would be surprised if the Billy Haughton Stable entry of Flamboyant and Keystone Pride finished 1, 2 in the field of 10.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 15 -- President de Gaulle stepped up his appeal to Rumanian nationalism today with a pointed attack on the system of blocs and an emphasis on France's break from "subordination" to another power.

WHEN he was a teen-ager, Anthony Colecchio of Jersey City studied for the priesthood at Seton Hall University. Then he switched to acting and almost landed the part of Tony in "West Side Story." Then, in 1963, he opened a boutique on Madison Avenue.
Sharp gains by a few active issues sparked an otherwise mixed and indecisive stock market yesterday.
Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan ordered yesterday that three schools in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville section of Brooklyn be closed today and tomorrow to help reduce tension in the area.

The city's Housing and Development Administration disclosed plans yesterday for a $25-million project for 1,000 new apartments in the Columbia University area. Plans have been worked out with community leaders and the city is hoping for Columbia support.
With computer-like efficiency, Rod Laver, Ken Rosewall, Andres Gimeno and Roy Emerson reached the semi-final round of the $30,000 Madison Square Garden professional tennis tournament last night.

HEBRON, Israeli-occupied Jordan, May 15 -- The Israeli Government is reported to have decided to accept the presence of a group of Jewish settlers who have been living for a month in this occupied town on the west bank of the Jordan River.

The poverty which afflicts the nation today is not a general poverty spread evenly across the mass of citizenry, but a minority group poverty which is all the more unacceptable because it persists in the midst of general prosperity.

TRENTON, May 15 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes said tonight he would submit a bill to the Legislature on Monday to provide stiffer penalties for persons engaging in the "paramilitary'' activities of "vigilante" groups.
The Xerox Corporation introduced yesterday a new duplicating machine that can produce one copy per second without a master and with improved quality over previous models.
The election of John W. Gardner and Charles T. Fisher 3d to the board of directors of American Airlines, was announced yesterday.
THE following games are contrasts in winning methods. The first is a triumph of raw violence and the second, a point gained through hypnotic suggestion.

WASHINGTON, May. 15 (AP) -- Strikes in the first three months of 1968 cost the nation's economy 9.9 million man-days of working time, highest first-quarter figure in 18 years, the Labor Department reported.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Ralph Nader told the Senate Commerce Committee today that many X-ray technicians gave Negroes 25 to 50 per cent more radiation exposure than that given to white persons.

TRENTON, May 15 (AP) -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes, conceding that his call for a state income tax is running into stiff resistance in the Legislature said today that he thought New Jersey would get a one per cent increase in the sales tax, coupled with the elimination of some exemptions.
The American Insurance Association raised yesterday to $67-million its estimate of insured losses caused by riots early last month following the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

Insurance companies will pay at least $67-million, as a result of the rioting and looting that followed the slaying, on April 4, of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the American Insurance Association estimated yesterday.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 15 -Representative Arch A. Moore Jr., a six-term member of the House, defeated former Gov. Cecil H. Underwood in the Republican primary for Governor yesterday. Incomplete returns gave Mr. Moore 94,837 votes to Mr. Underwood's 69,442.

PRAGUE, May 15 -- The liberal Communist party regime headed by Alexander Dubcek has authorized dissolution of the pro-Communist Catholic Peace Movement here, it was disclosed today. The Prague radio described the movement in a commentary as "discredited."

HONOLULU, May 15 -- A resolution by Gov. Ronald Reagan of California criticizing Federal actions was significantly amended today in the face of a threatened floor fight at the concluding session of the annual Western Governors Conference.

TORONTO, May 15 (Canadian Press) -- Following a strong denial of take-over rumors today, Massey-Ferguson shares lost a four-point morning gain on the Toronto Stock Exchange and finished the day at 20 with a loss of half a point.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 15 (UPI) -- The police ordered 22 members of Laos's large colony of foreign hippies to leave the country and closed two of their 5-cent marijuana "bars" today.

CAIRO, May 15 -- The Egyptian Government announced a plan today to build an $800-million industrial complex with Soviet aid. It also said that it would accept a settlement in the Middle East in which other steps, possibly Arab concessions, might precede the withdrawal of Israeli troops from the Arab lands they occupy.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 15 -- When enemy troops moved into her neighborhood last week, Mrs. Nguyen Thi Bai hurried from her home in fright to find a taxi driver willing to take her household goods to safety.
PRAGUE, May 15 -- The Yugoslav Foreign Minister today hailed Czechoslovakia's movement away from Soviet-guided orthodox Communism.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Leaders of the Poor People's Campaign made their first significant contact with Congress today.
Dozens of tornadoes skipped across the Midwest and South last night, and at least 35 persons were reported killed.
The Maritime Administration had the last word in the long and sometimes stormy dispute on crew size aboard three modern Gulf and South American Steamship Company freighters.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Johnson Administration reiterated today that it seeks a peace in South Vietnam in which all South Vietnamese would be free to chart their political future without outside interference.

BONN, May 15 -- Strikes, demonstrations and sit-ins took place at universities throughout West Germany today as Parliament moved toward passage of controversial legislation to curtail constitutional guarantees in times of national emergency.

Lehman Brothers, one of the giants of the Wall Street investment banking fraternity, has become ensnared in its "cage," or back-office, paperwork. So much so, a spokesman conceded yesterday, that the house has informed the New York Stock Exchange that it would refrain from expanding its stock-brokerage business until the clerical problems are resolved.

At noon yesterday workmen were stretching a long green and white awning over the clubhouse entrance at Belmont Park in Elmont, L.I. Gardeners, plumbers, painters, carpenters and workers from every other conceivable building trade were also busy racing the clock to put the finishing touches on the stands and grounds of the 63-year-old track, which has undergone a $30.7-million reconstruction.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 15 (AP) -- Rhode Island Republicans elected tonight a 14-member delegation to the Republican National Convention unpledged to any Presidential candidate but apparently at this time solidly for Governor Rockefeller of New York.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., May 15 -- Negotiators reached agreement on a contract early this morning in the ninth day of a teachers' strike in the Huntington public schools. The negotiators were prodded through the night by an angry judge.

BERLIN, May 15 -- The East German Communists renewed their attacks today on Czechoslovak reformers, calling on the Communist party of the country to halt or overthrow all "antisocialist" and " counter-terrevolutionary" developments.

The Mets produced nine innings of almost equally dull sameness -- they didn't score in any of them -- and so helped George Culver of the Cincinnati Reds earn his first major league shutout last night.

H. Rap Brown, the black power leader, has accepted an invitation to speak at a benefit performance to be given for the Black Panther party, under the sponsorship of the Radical Theater Repertory, at the Fillmore East Theater, Second Avenue and Sixth Street.

OAKLAND, Calif., May (AP) -The Franciscans, a Roman Catholic order, announced plan today to shift a majority of their priests in the West to poverty areas, migrant worker projects, peace movements and special ministries.

PARIS, May 15 -- Two thousand workers, imitating the rebellious students of the Sorbonne, have occupied the aircraft construction plant of Sud-Aviation at Nantes, on the Atlantic coast, and are holding the plant manager and his principal aides prisoner.

The Northrop Corporation, engaged in aerospace, aircraft, communications, and ordinance operations, reported yesterday from Beverly Hills, Calif., the highest earnings for any quarter in its history. The company also showed record results for the nine months ended April 30.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- A move by the Justice Department to extend the delay on a merger of three big Northwestern railroads was granted here late today by a special three-judge Federal panel.

A 12-story office and labora-Z tory building In Harlem once owned by Pathe Laboratories Inc., has been sold for $2-million by the Perfect Film and Chemical Corporation, which then leased it back for 25 years.

HONG KONG, May 15 (UPI) -- Members of an unofficial Italian peace mission were held in Communist China by the police for 24 hours and then expelled today on the ground that their trip had been blessed by Pope Paul VI, whom China regarded as "a criminal in the service of Western imperialist powers."

PANAMA, May 15 (UPI) -- The two major condidates for President in last Sunday's general election each renewed claims to victory today in the wake of political rioting.

ALBANY, May 15 -- A defiant bloc of more than 20 legislators, hinting at a possible physical demonstration such as a sit-in in Governor Rockefellor's office, began a campaign today to try to win passage of a strong plan for decentralizing the New York City school system.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Senate-House conferees agreed today on a landmark bill requiring that borrowers be told the true cost of credit on consumer transactions that total about $100-billion a year.

In a decision that strikes at the traditional relationship between the garment producer and his salesmen, a hearing examiner for the Federal Trade Commission ruled yesterday in Washington that two trade groups and some of their members conspired to restrain and monopolize trade in the wholesale women's and children's apparel industry.

The DWG Corporation, which sold its cigar business last Jan. 1 and is now a holding company, is making an exchange offer for all of the outstanding common stock of the Southeastern Public Service Company for securities involving about $35 - million, Victor Posner, chairman of DWG announced yesterday.
PIMLICO, Md., May 15 (UPI) -- Francie's Hat, the third-place finisher in the Kentucky Derby, was withdrawn today from Saturday's Preakness by his trainer, Jimmy Conway.

Silver, platinum and palladium traders keep a calculating eye on the price of gold -- and act accordingly. Yesterday an early dispatch from London put the price at about $41.31 an ounce, quite a jump from recent levels.

Nebraska Democrats gave Senator Robert F. Kennedy the relatively solid victory he has been seeking. Unlike his showing in Indiana, where he came in first but not by a convincing margin, Mr. Kennedy won the Nebraska primary with a bare -- but clear -- majority. Equally important is the fact that he ran well among farmers and in small towns as well as in the cities, thereby demonstrating widespread support.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- It is a beautiful May morning. Sunlight streams through the window. Birds chatter, the heady odor of wisteria floats on the exhaust fumes. Suddenly, for no logical reason at all, you feel good.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Airline officials forecast today a virtual end to most flight delays caused by fog. New techniques may even bring the day when whole cities can be "defogged," they said.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Robert Kennedy must be doing something right. The polls knock him down, analysts keep saying he's unpopular and too controversial, the Democratic pros keep clutching at Hubert Humphrey, and Eugene McCarthy refuses to bend the knee.

LANSING, Mich., May 15 UPI) -- Gov. George Romney of Michigan said today that supporters of Mr. Reagan were spending "a lot of money -- and I don't mean chicken feed" to promote the California Governor for President.

Morris (Mushky) Salow, who was denied a New York boxing manager's license five months ago, agreed yesterday to "disassociate himself from any further activities at Grossinger's Country Club." His light-heavyweight challenger, Bob Foster, is training there for the title bouth May 24 with Dick Tiger at Madison Square Garden.
MONTREAL, May 16 -- In Expo 67's United States Pavilion, a yellow-crusted cockatoo perched and blinked where a huge poster of Marilyn Monroe once attracted attention.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -Industrial production held steady in April at the record March level, which was revised upward, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The Most Rev. Terence J. Cooke has sent a letter to the 1,265 priests in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York asking them to submit confidential nominations of priests to fill "various diocesan offices."

HANOVER, Germany -- Bob Murphy, who became an outstanding American diplomat, was Vice Consul in Munich when Adolf Hitler made his first grab for power in 1923. After the unsuccessful beerhall Putsch, young Murphy asked Munich's Papal Legate, Monsignor Pacelli, how he appraised the event.

ATLANTA, May 16 -- Georgia Democrats voted today to send an uncommitted delegation to the national convention this year, opening the way to a first-ballot vote for Vice President Humphrey rather than a favorite-son candidate.
FORT WORTH, May 16 -Marty Fleckman, a rookie on the pro tour, scored a 68 to share the opening-round lead with Billy Casper in the Colonial National Invitation golf tournament today.

CAIRO, May 16 -- Western diplomats reported today that the United Arab Republic was ready to end its state of war with Israel and to cede to Israeli shipping the right to use the Strait of Tiran if Israel promised to withdraw her troops from Arab territory.

Insurgent Republicans have tried petitions to oppose candidates of Representative Paul A. Fino's Bronx organization in primaries for all public and party posts in the county. WASHINGTON, May 16 -- El Al Israel Airlines has disclosed vast expansion plans that would add five major cities in the United States to its routes and link the Middle East, Africa and South America.

The New York Stock Exchange will set into motion today its long-awaited Central Certificate Service, an automation program aimed at reducing substantially the physical movement of securities between brokerage firms.

The International Harvester Company, the farm machinery manufacturer, had a sharp decline in profits for the second fiscal quarter, resulting in halfyear earnings of $1.13 a share, compared with $1.70 a share in the six months to April 30, 1967.

PARIS, May 16 -- The North Vietnamese today dismissed as a "smokescreen" Ambassador W. Averell Harriman's statement that he had found areas of possible agreement between the two sides in the peace talks.

CRAIOVA, Rumania, May 16 (AP) -- President Nicolae Ceausescu said today that he had reached agreement with President de Gaulle to establish a French - Rumanian Government commission for consultations on political and economic issues.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The United Automobile Workers was suspended from the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations today because of its failure to pay dues.

A dozen icebergs have been sighted unusually far south in the Atlantic sea lanes, the Coast Guard reported yesterday. As a result, its International Ice Patrol has been ordered to maintain an especially close watch on concentrations off the coast of Newfoundland.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UPI) -- The House Appropriations Committee cut $30-million to day from Administration plans to spend $130-million on land acquisition next year for parks and other recreation areas.
In Salt Lake City, he was introduced as "Mr. Hamandeggs." At a posh Miami Beach hotel, the tennis poster read "Jimeno." Last Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden, the umpire called him "Gimenyo."
PARIS, May 16 -- In the opening rounds of their Vietnam talks, the United States and North Vietnam have been engaged more in public relations than private diplomacy.
CHICAGO, May 16 -- Liberals and black militants are joining the "new South" in adopting traditional Republican thinking, Richard M. Nixon said today.

On May 3 and 4 black students at Northwestern University occupied the bursar's office while negotiations on a list of fifteen "minimum" demands continued with the administration. One of the demands was "that the university provide us with a black living unit or commit themselves immediately to getting rid of the present fraternity and sorority housing arrangements.''

Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy, voiceless from laryngitis and breathless from the pace of her schedule, smiled, shrugged, gestured and whispered her way through a fast campaign swing for her husband here yesterday.

NEWARK, May 16 -- The Duke and Duchess of Windsor will be guests of honor at the May 25 dinner dance arranged by the Junior Committee of the New Jersey Symphony to assist the symphony's en- dowment fund.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The securities industry and the Government have reached agreement on the outlines of a law that would extend existing margin regulations to widely held over-the-counter-securities.

DURBAN, South Africa, May 16 -- A special group of specialists of the South African Reserve Bank has been studying world money markets to determine whether South Africa should sell its gold on the free market.

TRENTON, May 16 -- The New Jersey Anti-Defamation League of B'nal B'rith today called on a New Jersey businessman charged with violating the state's antidiscrimination laws to resign from his official post on the Legalized Games of Chance Control Commission.
A steady downward drift, accented by a sag in the final half hour of trading, left stock prices at their lowest levels of the day at the close yesterday.

The Hudson Review, one of the major literary quarterlies in the United States, is celebrating its 20th anniversary tomorrow with a nocturnal boat ride up the Hudson River. From the evidence it was much easier to organize the cruise than it was to launch the magazine.

HOMINY FALLS, W. Va., May 16 (UPI) -- Six coal miners trapped deep in a water-filled mine for 10 days and given up for dead, were found alive and well today. For a week they had existed without food and with only brackish, scum-covered mine water to drink.

WHITE PLAINS, May 16 -The head football coach of White Plains High School resigned today because, he said, he could not develop teams under the Board of Education's current policy of settling disputes with students by negotiation.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -The Senate rejected repeated attempts today to ban mail order sales of rifles and shotguns. It tentatively adopted, however, tighter Federal controls over the sale of hand guns.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 16 (AP) -- A high-ranking Vietcong defector said today the allies should intensify the war in Vietnam to improve their bargaining position at the negotiations in Paris.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -New York's Mayor Lindsay and the chief executives of 23 other cities called on Congress today to reject proposed cuts of $6billion in Federal spending.
The acting president of the Board of Education rebuked Mayor Lindsay yesterday for his implied criticism of the board's role in the events leading up to the Ocean HillBrownsville school controversy.
Short-term interest rates soared to record levels as the Federal Reserve's tight credit policy continued to bear down hard on the money market, banking data released yesterday indicated.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -The United States has halted all development aid loans to Peru for the current fiscal year.

"Chorica," a program of drama and dance performed by a Greek dance troupe of the same name headed by Madame Zouzou Nicoloudi, was given at Town Hall last night under the auspices of New York University.

THE New York City Ballet was in all its glory at the New York State Theater last night. All its glory is a deliberately provocative phrase, for its program, "Harlequinade" and "Western Symphony," was not calculated to register any great score on intellectual or establishment appeal.
The newest conglomerate corporation on the American business scene will be called Norton Simon, Inc.

BOSTON, MAY 16 -- A psychiatrist who spent three months observing a Green Beret team in action in Vietnam described its members today as continually risking death in a struggle to gain and maintain control of the group.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.
ROCHESTER, May 16 -- The Xerox Corporation changed its top management today. C. Peter McColough, who had been president and chief operations officer, was named chief executive officer.

TOKYO, May 16 -- The number of known deaths in the severe earthquake that rocked northern Japan this morning rose to 37 tonight, according to the National Police Agency. Ten persons were reported missing and 217 injured as a result of the quake.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The House shouted approval today of a $1.3-billion Colorado River Basin development plan intended to end a half-century of conflict among Western states over water rights.

The New York Historical Society, a haven for scholars and students of the American scene, is opening new galleries today, showing a wealth of paintings that only lately have returned to collecting favor.

ROME, May 16 -- The man who has governed Italy for the last four and a half years and seems likely to go on doing it for a good part of the next five -- 51-year-old Premier Aldo Moro -- probably is the least publicized leader of any major Western nation.
The Dallas Symphony's newly appointed associate conductor, Paul Freeman, should have suspected right from the first that his career was going to be a trifle unusual.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- A Senate inquiry to determine whether the Supreme Court is exceeding its powers was announced today by Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., chairman of the Subcommittee on Separation of Powers.

Tom Seaver, who has been accustomed to mini-support from New York batters this season, was treated to a more stylish eight-hit attack and a two-out ninth-inning rally yesterday at darkly overcast Shea Stadium.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 16 -Nearly 900 Presbyterians from every section of the country recited in unison today these words:

Egypt's declaration that she is prepared to move toward a Middle East settlement in which Arab concessions might precede the withdrawal of Israeli troops from Arab lands is, on the face of it, a positive step toward peace. Heretofore, the Arabs have insisted on prior withdrawal of Israeli forces.
Following is the text of "A Declaration of Confidence in Columbia's Future" signed by 35 teachers and administrators of the Columbia Law School:

WASHINGTON, May 16 -The World Bank, under Robert S. McNamara, has made its first five-year lending projection, and this already indicates a substantial increase in the bank's loans over the years ahead.

I read with astonishment in The Times of May 8 that Dr. Yosef ben-Jochannan, history teacher at Harlem Prep, includes Caracalla in his list of "group heroes," which he uses to "stimulate a sense of pride" in his pupils.

During the nine months of its existence, the governing board of the Ocean Hill-Brownsville Demonstration School District has experienced little but agony and frustration, according to its members and supporters.

Starting at East Fifth Street, where names and slogans were scrawled on the scarred brick wall, Park Commissioner August Heckscher, Gloria Wu and Rosita Ayala strolled south yesterday through the alley behind Junior High School 71.

BOSTON, May 16 -- After scoring 10 runs in the preceding six games, the New York Yankees scored 10 in the first six innings tonight -- and wound up losing to the Boston Red Sox, 11-10, when the American League champions rallied for six runs in the eighth inning.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Informal and exploratory conversations have taken place recently on the possibility of membership by Rumania in the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 12 -Four miles north of this dusty, tumbledown capital, there is an almost-perfect replica of a Long Island suburb.

For 15-year-old Miguel Amador of the Bronx, school was nearly a nightmare. "You were afraid to answer," he said, reflecting on his ninth-grade studies last year, "and the teacher always gave you a bad mark."

GROSSINGER, N. Y., May 16 -- Bob Foster's children wrote a letter to Santa Claus last Christmas and made one fervent plea. "Please bring our daddy a Tiger for Christmas," they asked. Santa was late in his delivery but Foster will get his Tiger (Dick Tiger) in the Madison Square Garden ring next Friday.

For the credit markets, news that Congress had postponed action on the tax increase was almost a knockout blow. Prices of all maturities of fixed-income securities dropped sharply and a mood of discouragement pervaded Wall Street's bond firms.

LONDON, May 16 -- The gold price soared by more than $1 an ounce today to $41.375 in the London and Zurich free markets. The pound fell to a new low of $2.38675, and the dollar weakened against Continental currencies.
American Standard, Inc., moved a step toward acquiring the Westinghouse Air Brake Company yesterday when its shareholders voted to approve the merger.

FOGGIA, Italy, May 16 -Premier Aldo Moro returned to his native southern province of Puglia today to put the finishing touches on a long, exhausting campaign to win a new mandate for his Christian Democratic party and center-left coalition government.

SAIGON, May 16 (AP) -- North Vietnamese troops advanced in darkness about 20 miles west of the city of Kontum today and opened fire with mortars, rocket-propelled grenades, flamethrowers and small arms on a patrol base and an outpost of the United States Fourth Infantry Division.
Silver, platinum and palladium traders, once again influenced by the strength of cash gold prices in Europe, pushed up prices of futures contracts in precious metals here yesterday.

ATLANTA, May 16 -- The New York Giants will move back to the Century Division of the National Football League in 1969 and repeat their 1967 schedule in which they played the Green Bay Packers among others.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UPI) -- Vice President Humphrey's campaign managers maneuvered today to avoid a psychological confrontation with Senator Robert F. Kennedy in the remaining Presidential primaries in which the New Yorker's name is entered but Mr. Humphrey's is not.

PARIS, May 16 -- Following, in unofficial translation, are the texts of a broadcast address by Premier Georges Pompidou tonight and of a communique issued by the French Government on the current demonstrations:
WALL STREET ticked off block trades like so many bags of potatoes yesterday and it was hard to say just why.

ALBANY, May 16 -- Legislative and Rockefeller administration officials broke the stalemate over New York City school decentralization today by reaching general agreement on a compromise plan for giving local residents a greater voice in running their schools.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -The railroads are adding to their payrolls hundreds of trainmen they say are not needed.

PARIS, May 16 -- Premier Georges Pompidou, faced with growing unrest among students and workers in many parts of the country, said today that a handful of troublemakers were out to "destroy the nation and the very foundations of our free society."
EDINBURGH, Scotland, May 16 (Reuters) -- Europe's first lung transplant patient was reported in "satisfactory" condition at the Royal Infirmary here today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 16 -- The military command reported today that 562 Americans died in South Vietnam during the week that ended last Saturday. It was the highest American death toll for any week of the war.

The Chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System recently stated that the United States is in the midst of its worst financial crisis since 1931. This pronouncement is so wide of the mark that it affords a pertinent example of the misconceptions embodied in the traditional monetary theory so dear to the hearts of businessmen and economists alike.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UPI) -- Allowing young men to bring lawyers to their draft boards would "offer literally millions of opportunities for delays" in inducting draftees, Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey said today.

BONN, May 16 -- The Bundestag, or lower house of Parliament approved today the second and decisive reading of West Germany's controversial emergency legislation despite continued student protests and angry resistance by the Opposition Free Democratic party.
