That loneliness is found most easily in a crowd was masterly demonstrated last night in Merce Cunningham's urban landscape, "Place." It was the first performance of the work in his current New York season.
YONKERS, May 16 -- Clearly the best, as any 2-to-5 favorite should be, Flamboyant sped to a length-and-a-half victory over Dazzling Speed tonight in the $100,000 Hilltop Trot at Yonkers Raceway.

ALBANY, May 16 -- The Legislature, thwarted in its drive to adjourn this week, passed dozens of noncontroversial bills today -- including one requiring reflectorized automobile license plates -- before recessing until Monday.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -More and more upper-income Negroes here are mobilizing volunteer organizations and offering their time and services, as well as money, to the Poor People's Campaign. They have decided that their checkbooks are not enough.
Duty collections on imports by ship and air last month registered a 30.5 per cent increase over April, 1967, Michael Stramiello Jr., Regional Commissioner of Customs, has announced.

THE wildlife of East Africa's plains appears to be facing the fate of television's early comedians: overexposure. One more documentary on the animals of the KenyaTanzania border was presented last night by the National Broadcasting Company under the title "Man, Beast and the Land."

The Swiss National Bank announced yesterday that last week it had purchased $24.5-million in gold from the United States. It was the first announced purchase of gold from the United States by a foreign central bank since the gold crisis last March.

WARSAW, May 16 -- The Polish Communist party has approved changes in college entrance requirements to increase party control and to favor the admission of children from worker, peasant, police and military backgrounds, it was announced today.
A house built in Brooklyn before the Revolutionary War, a lighthouse on Staten Island, and a fountain brought to the Bronx Zoo from Italy are among 10 landmarks newly designated by the city.

The undersigned members of the National Society of Film Critics wish to express the gravest concern over current anti-Semitic actions in Poland. This concern extends, naturally, to all Poles who are oppressed, in every field. But we are more familiar with the careers of film people and, through them, we are made keenly aware of the injustices that are being committed generally.

AFTER a two-month absence, Leonard Bernstein returned to his post as conductor of the New York Philharmonic last night in Philharmonic Hall and led a program of two works as opposed in mood as is conceivable.

LISBON, May 16 -- A mass movement got under way here today for the liberation of Mario Soares, democratic opposition leader, and the revocation of the decree that enables the Government to deport political adversaries without trial or judicial inquiry for an unlimited period.

MADRID, May 16 (AP) -Eight hundred University of Madrid students, shouting slogans against the Government, stoned the police today during a demonstration that left the campus littered with burned furniture and broken glass.

PITTSBURGH, May 16 -- A special meeting of Westinghouse Air Brake Company stockholders adjourned today until Tuesday so ballots could be counted for the proposed merger of Wabco into American Standard, Inc. The merger is bitterly opposed by the Crane Company.

LONDON, May 16 -- The Royal Ballet's, new production of "Giselle," given its premiere at Covent Garden last night, helps to establish a remarkable record. The Royal Ballet already has two versions of "Swan Lake" in its repertory -- one by the main company and one by the British road troupe.

TAMPA, Fla., May 16 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, reiterating his plea for "a new set of citizens' rights for Americans," brought his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination to Florida today.

ROME, May 16 (AP) -- Thirdseeded Bob Hewitt of South Africa and Alexander Metreveli, the 15th seeded entry, from the Soviet Union, moved today into the semi-finals of the Italian tennis championships.

PRAGUE, May 17 -- The Soviet Premier, Aleksei N. Kosygin, arrived in Prague late this afternoon in the midst of the mounting dispute with Czechoslovakia. The purpose of the visit was described officially as a "continuation of the exchange of views with the Czechoslovak leaders."
" How do you deal with strikes by municipal employes in Russia?" said the Mayor of New York yesterday to the Mayor of Moscow.
The initial step in the first large-scale venture to involve union members with the arts was announced yesterday by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
PITESTI, Rumania, May 17 -- President de Gaulle toured rural Rumania today as France was being swept by internal unrest.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 17 (UPI) -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy's campaign managers said today that it was all a "misunderstanding" -- their candidate will not be able to share a platform Monday night with Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 17 -- Operation Delaware the offensive aimed at clearing North Vietnamese troops from the Ashau Valley, has been concluded, the military command said today.

PARIS, May 17 -- A Columbia student visited the Sorbonne this week and found the scene much like the one at home. But that was only because a revolution was under way.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 17 (UPI) -- President Joaquin Balaguer's Reformist party Government was officially ruled today an easy winner of Thursday's municipal elections, but by a slimmer margin than Dr. Balaguer's 1966 electoral sweep.
The market boom in new stock issues continued this week as half a dozen companies sold shares for the first time. Three of the issues quickly doubled and all showed good gains by the end of trading.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, May 18 -- Premier Nguyen Van Loc and his Cabinet submitted their resignations today to President Nguyen Van Thieu.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) -- The first fatal shooting of a Washington bus driver led today to a walkout of about 100 drivers during the morning rush hour and a demand by the union leadership that the city put armed guards on the buses after dark.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Corporate profits soared to a record annual rate of $88.8-billion in the first quarter of 1968, the Department of Commerce reported today. This is the third straight quarterly advance and $3.7-billion above the previous high, in the fourth quarter of 1967.

NEWARK, May 17 -- The Public Service Electric and Gas Company demonstrated here today its new $2-million computerized information and control system. WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The expected money crunch in June caused by extra corporate tax payments will not occur.
ROME, May 19 -- Pope Paul VI called today for prayers for the Italian parliamentary elections and for peace in the world.

LAST fall Tran Van Huong, a stocky 64-year-old nationalist who wears his white hair crew-cut and likes to be called "Uncle," vowed that he would not serve as Premier if Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu were elected President.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., May 19 -- A stylish English-bred wire fox terrier, Ch. Wintor Caracus Call Boy, became best in show today in the 68th event of the Long Island Kennel Club. It was a limited-entry show of 1,200 dogs and the last that will be held at the Piping Rock Club, where it has been a fixture for 14 years.
Predatory, often senselessly savage, the mugger looms as the most menacing figure in the public concern over crime.

DETROIT, May 19 (UPI) -- Homers by Al Kaline and Ed Mathews led the league-leading Detroit Tigers to a 7-0 victory over the Washington Senators in the finale of a double-header today, after Gates Brown's pinch single in the eighth inning had won the opener for the home team, 5-4.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Senate liberals, disorganized since Hubert H. Humphrey left in 1965 to go to the Vice-Presidency, appear at last to have found a leader in Senator Philip A. Hart of Michigan.
PRAGUE, May 20 -- Pan American Airways reopened its office in Prague today, with the blessings of the Czechoslovak Government, 18 years after the office was closed under Communist pressure.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Leaders of the Poor People's Campaign postponed tonight the mass march on Washington that they had called for Memorial Day.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Earnings of Sears, Roebuck Co. increased 18.6 per cent in the first quarter ended April 30 on a rise of 13.9 per cent in sales, Gordon M. Metcalf, chairman, told shareholders at the annual meeting here today.

WHEN the Dodgers switched to Los Angeles, they soon were engulfed by the Hollywood penchant for wildly extravagant claims. No sooner had they signed the huge Frank Howard for a bonus of $108,000 in 1958 than they tossed aside all discretion and immodestly hailed him as "the next Babe Ruth." Oddly enough, it did not seem too unreasonable an assumption at the time.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Positive statistics, so long absent from chronicles of the New York Yankees, popped up in diverse forms tonight as Jim Bouton pitched a 6-1 victory over the Washington Senators before a crowd of 9,380 in D.C. Stadium.

Angry stockholders of the Merritt - Chapman Scott Corporation, the once-mighty construction company now in liquidation, were told yesterday that they could expect their first liquidating dividend as early as July.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 20 -- Mrs. Nguyen Thi Ba, who does a brisk business as a bread vender in downtown Saigon, looked startled one recent afternoon when a customer asked her what she thought about the "Paris talks."

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 20 -- Viktor Korchnoi, a two-time Soviet chess champion, triumphed over Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., a six-time United States champion, in their 10-game quarter-final knockout match, when the contenders drew their eighth game here today.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- The Army may have acted illegally when it awarded multi-million-dollar contracts for M-16 rifles without weighing the price of other bids. Representative Richard H. Ichord, chairman of a special House Armed Services subcommittee, said today.
Undoubtedly Shari Anderson, the soprano who made her recital debut late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, had debut nerves. But it was a mark of her careful preparation that she didn't show them.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 20 -- Curtis Gans, national political operations director for Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, said today that he offered his resignation to the Senator during the weekend but it was not accepted.
With a bemused look on their faces, a small crowd of fans from the grandstand craned their necks and peered out toward the walking ring a few minutes after high noon at Belmont Park yesterday.

City Investigation Commissioner Arnold G. Fraiman, who has called for the abolition of the 300-year old marshal system here, was given broad legal powers yesterday to regulate the operations of the marshals.

Sarcastic and often bitter exchanges ruffled the annual meeting of the Pacific Insurance Company of New York yesterday as a group of insurgent stockholders, including Hambros Bank, Ltd., of London, sought unsuccessfully to get representation on the board. Hambros is a major British private banking house.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 20 -- The general assembly of the 3.2 million-member United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. pledged today a down payment of $100,000 toward a $10-million Poor People's development fund established in memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
A WARNING to those who accept statistical "averages" of water pollution appears in the May issue of the monthly bulletin issued by the Sport Fishing Institute of Washington.
The 1964 issue of Fact magazine, which led to a $2-million libel action by Barry Goldwater, was an honest effort to appraise his fitness for the Presidency, the defense contended yesterday.

A trustee of Columbia University charged yesterday that former Parks Commissioner Thomas P. F. Hoving "was the one who stimulated" opposition to the Morningside Park gymnasium that became a focus of student uprisings at Columbia.
Trans-Atlantic transportation officials and tourists here seemed to be taking the strikes in France with relative calm.

LOS ANGELES, May 20 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy, in a tumultuous motorcade through miles of streets in suburban Los Angeles, rode for nearly three hours tonight past tens of thousands of whooping supporters. His car was mobbed at virtually every major intersection by clamoring supporters.

BETHPAGE, L. I., May 20 -- The Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation, which derives more than half of its annual sales from defense contracts, told its shareholders here today that an end of the Vietnam war would not lead to a serious reduction in company income or its work force.
FIVE well-known women had a small dinner dance at the St. Regis Roof last night. They did it in the nicest way. Someone else did almost all the work and signed all the bills.
ALBANY, May 20 -- Governor Rockefeller appointed a 33-member committee today to "explore ways to expand opportunities for persons in minority groups in the mass communications industry."
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Haitian Embassy said today that a World War II style B-25 bomber dropped several bombs on Port-au-Prince this morning.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange declined sharply for most of the session yesterday, but many losses were trimmed in late trading.

Charles E. Luce, former Under Secretary of the Interior, who became chairman and chief executive officer of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., last August, emerged unscathed yesterday, from his first annual meeting of stockholders.
HOLLYWOOD, May 20 (AP) -- Jack Lemmon, who earns as high as a million dollars a picture, donated half his salary on his next film deal to the Poor People's Campaign.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 20 (AP) -- An opinion poll shows that California Republicans prefer Richard M. Nixon over Governor Rockefeller for President, although neither can win a single vote in the state's Presidential primary on June 4.

FIFTY women ranging in age from the threshold of voting to social security had a date with Kenneth Battelle yesterday. Mr. Battelle, who prefers to be known during working hours as Kenneth (unprefixed by mister), is the hairdresser to Mrs. John F. Kennedy and Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller among others.

BONN, May 20 -- Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger, today called off a visit to Spain and Portugal that had been scheduled for the end of the month, saying that he had to attend to urgent affairs troubling the coalition Government.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- The American Bar Association registered its opposition today to efforts in the Senate to counteract the Supreme Court's stand on the legality of confessions.

YONKERS, May 20 -- The Empire Pace, a 1 1/4-mile test exclusively for 4-year-olds going for a gross purse of $100,000, will be a nonbetting race on Thursday night's closing card at Yonkers Raceway. Permission to shut the mutuel windows for that event was granted today by the New York State Harness Racing commission after only six horses were named to start.

Stock prices firmed in late trading yesterday, taking some of the bite out of another broad decline.

The ouster of nineteen New York school personnel has brought into focus one vital issue, but not a second, equally or perhaps more significant. The whole matter of due process and control has properly emerged as a serious concern. But very little discussion or concern is voiced for the crucial variable of teacher effectiveness and evaluation.

A six-month power struggle within the narrow elite that runs Panama has now culminated in a fraud-ridden Presidential election, sporadic violence and a delayed vote-count -- all of which threaten what passes in Panama for constitutional government. The country's 350,000 voters went to the polls a week ago Sunday, but it will be several weeks more before the official results are tallied and certified.

ALBANY, May 20 -- Legislative officials and the Rockefeller administration, reportedly nearing a final accord on a New York City school decentralization plan, decided today in favor of enlarging the city's Board of Education instead of replacing it with a three-man paid commission.
Prices on the London stock market closed moderately firmer yesterday after initial uncertainty.
The conviction that the credit markets are headed for crisis intensified yesterday, driving key interest rates to record highs.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., May 20 (UPI) -- The United States Lawn Tennis Association announced today it has picked Longwood Cricket Club's grass courts as the site of the 1968 national amateur singles championships formerly staged at Forest Hills, Queens.
"I SYMPATHIZE with students wanting change, but what they're doing is a mindless approach to the problem," George August Peck, dean of administration at Brooklyn College, said yesterday.
The short interest in stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange, as of last Wednesday, dropped to 19,437,197 shares from 19,923,868 shares a month earlier, the exchange reported yesterday.

The Black Panther benefit at Fillmore East last night -- still rolling when I left at midnight -- was in itself a theater piece. The speakers, especially the brilliant and dismaying LeRoi Jones, displayed a rhetoric composed of racial paranoia, political jargon, Utopian idealism, unprintable threats, gutty "soul" talk and shrewd humor.

President Johnson flew unannounced into New York last night to argue against "the diagnosis of fatal sickness in our society" and to serve notice that he would "refuse to follow those" who make that diagnosis.

ROME, Tuesday, May 21 -- National election returns from about half of Italy's polling places early this morning indicated gains for both the Christian Democrats, leaders of the governing center-left alliance, and their allied enemies of the extreme left.
Mutual funds held liquid reserves of $3.92-billion at the end of April, their largest cash position in history, despite heavy purchases of stocks last month.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- Student uprisings on university campuses can be attributed partly to the abdication by faculties of their full responsibilities, William S. Paley, chairman of the Columbia Broadcasting System, said here today.
Ed Charles led off the last of the ninth inning with his second home run of the game and the New York Mets beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 2-1, in wind-chilled Shea Stadium last night.
ATHENS, Ohio, May 20 (UPI) -- Gov. James A. Rhodes ordered 650 National Guardsmen on standby alert here today in a move to avert a second night of campus violence at Ohio University.
PARIS, May 20 -- The schedule for the week's events has been set. President de Gaulle's strategy is beginning to emerge.

To Brooklyn College's administration, yesterday's demonstrators were engaged in calculated deceit. To the leader of the college's Negro students who said that "the American capitalist ruling class" was exploiting Negroes and Puerto Ricans, the all-white demonstrators were exposing "white racism."
C. R. Smith, the Secretary of Commerce, warned yesterday that protectionist trade bills pending in Congress would damage the United States as much as other countries.
SAIGON, South Vietnam May 20 -- United States marines killed 109 North Vietnamese soldiers yesterday as new fighting broke out near the Khesanh outpost in northern South Vietnam.

Youth has a lot to be said for it -- the absence of age, for instance. So a recital such as Jeanne Patterson and Christian Petrowsky gave last night at Carnegie Recital Hall can afford immense pleasure purely on the ground of its unclouded innocence and youthful gusto.
DES PLAINES, Ill., May 20 -- Roman Catholic priests formed a national organization today to seek a stronger voice in church affairs.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department urged the Interstate Commerce Commission today to turn down a plea for a $461-million-a-year rail freight-rate increase and to investigate the proposal.
A panel of experts agreed yesterday that great strides were being made in the development and use of drugs that could relieve the pain of arthritis and slow the progress of the disease.
GLEN COVE, L. I., May 20 -- Tom Nieporte, with a 36-hole score of 140, led the Long Island qualifiers today in the first elimination round for berths in the United States Open golf championship.
In a nostalgia - drenched equine happening, hailed by management as the "return of an era," Belmont was reborn yesterday as the nation's most magnificent race track.

HARVARD paid tribute to its retiring baseball coach, Norm Shepard, at a dinner at the Harvard Club in Boston last night. But the biggest tribute the Crimson could bestow upon the man who has coached Cantab baseball for the last 14 years would be to permit the team to take part in the National Collegiate baseball championship this year.

SALEM, Ore., May 20 -- The development that leaders of Ronald Reagan's Oregon campaign wanted least was today's meeting in New Orleans between the California Governor and Governor Rockefeller of New York.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- How to tell if you are under thirty:
The land of the Bible, and the influences of neighboring civilizations upon it, is the theme of an exhibition opening tomorrow at America-Israel Culture House, 4 East 54th Street.

PARIS, May 20 -- The French radio pleaded against hoarding today, but housewives could be seen lugging huge shopping baskets and carts into food stores and supermarkets and grabbing boxes of sugar, canned foods and staples off the shelves with both hands.

Some years ago one American aid official in Eastern India was good-naturedly referred to by Bengali bureaucrats as the pugla sahib -- crazy gentleman -- because he kept rushing about the countryside calling for instant revolutionary changes in age-old agricultural practices.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Mayor Lindsay suggested today a system of appointed "temporary judges" who would serve as volunteers for a month at a time to help meet rising case loads and shortages of judicial manpower.
PARIS, May 20 -- Paris was not a pleasant place for tourists today -- nor has it been for the last four days.
KARACHI, Pakistan, May 20 -- Pakistan has given notice to the United States to close down its communications unit near Peshawar, in West Pakistan, Foreign Minister Arshad Husain announced today.
Continued uncertainties, especially the crisis in France, spurred more buying of silver futures here yesterday and higher prices.

ARRAS, France, May 20 -- The school system of this northern city disintegrated today in a series of student revolts that left five schools occupied by teen-age girls and boys, with the full support of their disgruntled teachers.

The Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, Herbert B. Halberg, on behalf of Mayor Lindsay, yesterday officially opened the 24th annual spring book drive of the American Merchant Marine Library Association.

WARSAW, May 20 -- Political analysts said today that Wladyslaw Gomulka, the Polish Communist leader, was trying to reinforce his authority by citing Czechoslovakia's difficulties with her neighbors as an example of the dangers of internal change.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 20 -- President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia proposed today a three-point plan for the settlement of the Middle Eastern crisis.

A Queens housewife testified yesterday that on the night the children of Mrs. Alice Crimmins disappeared she heard Mrs. Crimmins say, "Don't do that to her," as a man tossed a blanket-wrapped "bundle" into the back seat of a parked automobile.

NOTHING has changed in baseball at Bryant High in Queens, except the coach. In the 21 years that Vinny Starace coached the Owls, they won 20 division and four Public Schools Athletic League championships.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The 91-day Treasury bill rate rose to a record level at today's auction, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The 182-day bill rate rose to the highest level since September, 1966.

The body of Theresa' Riccio, a 4-year-old girl missing from her Queens home since May 10, was found last night in a suitcase in crawl space under the room a two-family house around the corner from where she lived.

TRENTON, May 20 -- F. Lee Bailey, the criminal lawyer, was scathingly rebuked by the Chief Jusice of the State Supreme Court today for "insolence and arrogance unequaled by anything I have ever seen."
AMERICA'S racing Establishment was back at what it has always called "Beautiful Belmont' here yesterday after 5 1/2 years and $30.7-million in reconstruction, and it liked what it saw.

ALBANY, May 20 -- The State Senate passed a bill today creating 125 new state judgeships in a move that Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges termed "a major legislative accomplishment of the decade." The unanimous move in the Senate marked the first break in a political deadlock that for years has prevented adding new judges despite growing Iogjams in the state courts.
OULLINS, France, May 20 -- Two thousand cheering railroad workers seized control of the vast rail yards in this suburb of Lyons today as a fresh wave of strikes erupted.
LONDON, May 20 -- French strikes brought confusion to European financial markets today and helped push the price of gold to another new high of $42.30 an ounce.

THE sign on the door, spelled out with painted posies, says: "Welcome Apartment. "Inside, the three rooms, are furnished to give ideas to the more than 100 new tenants who are starting to move into a new Housing Authority building specially designed for the elderly.
BIG Ma Bell touched its lowest point since 1962 yesterday and stayed there in big volume that put the stock in fifth place on the active list.
The Avco Corporation expects its newest subsidiary, the Embassy Pictures Corporation, to generate about 50 cents a share in earnings this year.
Can-Am is a sort of anagram for money -- more than half a million dollars in six road races for sports-racing cars.
McCall's says that Mrs. John F. Kennedy was on a secret mission for the United States Government when she visited Cambodia last fall.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Communist party of France has been so successful in acquiring an aura of respectability that it is having to struggle to keep from being on the wrong side in the present unrest.
TRENTON, May 20 -- The State Assembly approved tonight a controversial proposal authorizing a November referendum on a state-operated lottery.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) Four veterans' benefit bills were passed without opposition today by the House and sent to the Senate.

BOSTON, May 20 -- A trial that may define the limits of allowable dissent against the Vietnam war began here today in Federal Court.

Jack Montgomery of Fort Worth, Tex., shot a seven-under par 137 at Dallas yesterday to lead a contingent of professionals through a local qualifying round for the United States Open golf tournament.

ALBANY, May 20 -- The Legislature voted today to raise the interest rate ceiling on home mortgages to 7.5 per cent from the present 6 per cent.
Your daily coverage of the crisis at Columbia University constantly repeats what I believe to be a serious error about the issues which precipitated it.

LAST night saw the end of Broadway -- for a season at least. The final play of the season opened at the Broadhurst Theater. It was called "The Only Game in Town," was written by Frank D. Gilroy (and how many playwrights do you know who have achieved real distinction with a middle initial?) and starred Tammy Grimes, Barry Nelson and Leo Genn. Mr. Nelson directed.
The new Metropolitan Opera House received a stamp of approval yesterday from some people who ought to know.

Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon expressed the belief the other day that "a profound change has taken place in American politics." A new alignment consisting of Republicans, new liberals, the new South, and black militants has developed, he asserted in a nationwide radio address, and is already the new majority in this country.

AREMARICABLY complete evening devoted to the agonizing realities and distant hopes of resolving racial tensions was carried last night in a joint effort by Group W -Westinghouse Broadcasting Company and station WNEW-TV Chancalled "One Nation, Indivisible."

Pete Pascale, the gray-haired assistant director of La Guardia House in East Harlem, walked into the nursery there at lunchtime the other day. He stopped in the middle of the room, gave the children a long smile and called out, "Who's going to the country this year?"
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Supreme Court broadened the rights of criminal defendants and convicted persons today in five decisions overturning its own more restrictive precedents.

MADRID, May 20 -- Miguel Mateo, the 29-year-old bullfighter who performs under the name of Miguelin, was fined 40,000 pesetas (about $575) and released last night after 36 hours in security police headquarters for creating a disturbance on Saturday in the Madrid bullring.
About 40 Brooklyn College students seized the registrar's office on campus yesterday and held it for more than 16 hours before the police broke in early today and led them out under arrest.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Administration called today for the phasing out of the United States' fleet of 13 passenger liners.
NANTES, France, May 20 -France's worker - occupation movement began here, behind the gates of this giant branch plant of Sud-Aviation.
Mihajlo Mihajlov, the Yugoslav writer who is serving a four-year prison sentence for having derided the Yugoslav Government. has written a letter denouncing the Communist penal system.
Administration proposals for a new Federal maritime policy, advanced yesterday by Secretary of Transportation Alan S. Boyd, prompted sharp reaction from a generally stunned maritime community.
The California Savings and Loan League, which represents savings associations with more than $28-billion in assets, is exploring the possibility of its members entering the mutual fund business.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 20 (UPI) -- The Kentucky State Racing Commission will consider appeals by Dancer's Image trainer, Lou Cavalaris, following the Churchill Downs stewards ruling at a regular meeting here Thursday.

TEAMS representing the Grumman Aircraft Corporation won both stages of the 1967-68 Long Island Industrial Bridge Championships completed recently. Alan Van Gelder of Syosset, L. I., Bob Reiss of Great Neck, L. I., Alvin Levy of New York, and Mike Pick of Smithtown, L. I., headed a field of 15 teams to win the eight-session qualifying stage, but another Grumman team captured the title at the end of three knockout rounds.
PARIS, May 20 -- France headed toward virtual paralysis today as millions more of her workers occupied factories, mines and offices.

The completely rebuilt Belmont Park had its opening yesterday with the featured race, the $55,800 Carter Handicap, a race made famous more than 20 years ago at old Aqueduct when it resulted in a triple dead heat.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- More than $100-million in United States development loans to Brazil have foundered on undependable technical and economic analyses, a failure to consider rampant Brazilian inflation and other management errors, the General Accounting Office says.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Illegitimate children are entitled to equal treatment by the law, the Supreme Court ruled today.

A community group in Brooklyn ended a three-day boycott of eight schools yesterday, but the teachers union refused last night to accept the formula that led to the boycott's cancellation.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Dr. George B. Kistiakowsky, science adviser to former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, has expressed concern to Congress that a "pronounced estrangement" has developed between the Defense Department and the academic community on scientific policy matters.

The American Broadcasting Company announced yesterday the names of 19 guest commentators who will appear on its 7 P.M. newscasts' with Frank Reynolds when the program changes its format on Monday to include more features.

A 69-year-old former chef who spent more than 14 years as an inmate in Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminally Insane was awarded $300,000 in damages yesterday by a judge who called the practices at the hospital "incredible."

INDIANAPOLIS, May 20 -- Two of the legendary works of the 19th century were on the closing program of the Festival of Romantic Music last night at Clowes Hall. WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decided today that a privately owned shopping center was essentially a public area, and to prohibit picketing there would violate constitutional guarantees of free speech.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Dr. James L. Goddard, commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, resigned today after 28 months in the job.

DENIS HULME gets around the world as fast as he drives. The New Zealander is planning to cross the Atlantic Ocean four times in less than a week. Late yesterday he left Indianapolis, where he had been practicing for the 500-mile race on Memorial Day, on his way to Monte Carlo.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Senate deleted today from the omnibus crime control bill provisions designed to strip the Supreme Court and lower Federal courts of power to review defendants' claims that state courts had violated their constitutional rights.

Passage by the State Senate of a bill creating 125 new judgeships -- 85 in New York City, the rest elsewhere in the state -- is a legislative milestone. If the Assembly concurs, as seems highly probable, the expansion of the judiciary will go far toward relieving the calendar congestion that has long retarded justice in many areas.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., May 21 -- American troops in Vietnam are using thousands of electronic "starlight scopes" enabling them to see the Vietcong as well at night as during the day, the Army said today.

THE United Jewish Appeal charity tournament at the Essex House, Central Park South, Monday night, fulfilled its accustomed role as the most successful social bridge event of the year. Milton Petrie of New York played with veteran expert Harry Fishbein of New York to head the field of 74 tables, with Mr. and Mrs. Lester Bachner of New York in second position.
Prices declined yesterday for the high-flying precious metals, silver, platinum and palladium.

WOLFSBURG, West Germany May 21 -- A few miles east of this prosperous Volkswagen town, where watchtowers and minefields mark the boundary between the two Germanys, the East Germans are making new territorial claims on West Germany.

LONDON, May 21 -- Prime Minister Wilson won a 35-vote victory in the House of Commons tonight for the Labor Government's unpopular bill to hold down wages.

PARIS, May 21 -- In the dossiers of the Finance Ministry there is an economic forecast glowing with optimism. It was to be published a few days from now. It is a safe bet that it will never appear.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Shah of Iran is seeking to buy about $600-million worth of arms from the United States to help modernize the Iranian armed forces, Congressional sources disclosed today.

Canada, long distinguished for her documentary films and for the multiscreen and multi-image audio-visual exhibitions at Expo 67 last year, is about to start a program to promote her feature entertainment-film industry.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Andy Kosco's ninth - inning homer and Mel Stottlemyre's air-tight pitching enabled the New York Yankees to end an eight-game trip with their third straight victory tonight, 2-1, over the Washington Senators.
As it must to all baseball teams, victory finally came to the New York Mets in extra innings yesterday when they outlasted the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-3, in 17 long ones.

PITTSBURGH, May 21 -- Mayor Lindsay warned 2,000 Duquesne University students today that campus rebellions could lead the nation into chaos and tyranny unless young rebels were willing to plan and work for a new and better society.

While there is as yet no reason to suppose that the Soviets are conducting more than a war of nerves against the liberalizing government in Prague, nevertheless, behind the maneuvering of Warsaw Pact forces along the Czechoslovak frontiers and behind the equivocal editorials in the Soviet, Polish and East German press lies an implied threat of force.

Larry Gallo, the gang leader, was buried in Brooklyn's Greenwood Cemetery yesterday morning near the grave of Albert Anastasia, assassinated head of Murder, Inc., after a funeral with the Prohibition-era trappings.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 21 -- An emergency program to continue the education of 3,000 students dispossessed last Friday when an $8-million fire destroyed New Rochelle High School was smoothly put into effect today.

Eva Robins, a deputy chairman in the city's Office of Collective Bargaining, has been called in to serve as mediator in the wage dispute between Actors Equity and the League of New York Theaters. Their four-year contract expires June 2.

LONDON, May 21 -- The price of gold hit another new high of $42.60 an ounce this morning and then fell back to $42.40 amid continued uncertainties in European financial markets. Sterling fell to another low of $2.3848.

MARSEILLES, France, May 21 -- The workers of Marseilles, the second city of France and her greatest port, are exhibiting even more enthusiasm today for the nationwide industrial sit-in than their colleagues in Paris and other major industrial centers.

Claims against the city for damage in the rioting that followed the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. last month have passed the $2-million level, Controller Mario A. Procaccino announced yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, May 21 -- "We had a good year in 1967," W. M. Batten, chairman of the J. C. Penney Company, told about 600 stockholders at the department store chain's annual meeting at the Century Plaza Hotel today.

After singing his first number at La Maisonette Monday night, Earl Wilson Jr., the 25- year-old son of The New York Post's Broadway columnist, thanked everyone for being there. He paused, then added: "Those of you who came on your own," and, after another pause, "those who came out of fear."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 17 -- President Tito hailed the democratization in Czechoslovakia during the course of a long interview with this correspondent today. He said the process was eliminating old forms that had been hampering progress.

A "brilliant" 22 - year - old graduate student in sociology at Columbia University received a two-year suspended prison sentence and was placed on probation for two years yesterday in Federal Court here for possessing 18 pounds of marijuana.
Successes in recent underground thermonuclear tests have encouraged a number of corporations to step up their research in the field of practical, peaceful uses of atomic explosives.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The White House announced today that Gen. William W. Momyer, chief of American bombing operations against North Vietnam, was being reassigned to Langley Air Force Base in Virginia to head the Tactical Air Command.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The nation's railroads contended today that the Interstate Commerce Commission had no authority to set standards for cleanliness or services abroad passenger trains.

ROME, May 21 -- Italy's governing center-left coalition under Premier Aldo Moro of the Christian Democratic party emerged today from national elections numerically stronger but with its prestige and internal unity threatened by new Communist gains.

Mayor Lindsay would be required to obtain the advice and consent of the City Council for all top-level appointments in the city government, under an amendment to the City Charter introduced into the Council yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 21 -- The United Presbyterian Church has authorized a comprehensive study of "glossolalia," or the "speaking in tongues" phenomenon that has been slowly gaining a foothold in some of the major Protestant bodies.

BELGRADE -- History will write that the disintegration of monolithic Communism began in 1948 when Tito split with Stalin and faced down the Soviet bloc in a taut cold war that transcended ideology. Tito's stubborn leadership appealed even to his opponents among the vigorously independent Yugoslavs.

NEW ORLEANS, May 21 -- High bids totaling more than $602-million for Federal leases to mineral-rich offshore tracts were made here today by petroleum companies. A total of 552 sealed bids amounting to $1,607,193,714 was submitted to the Bureau of Land Management of the United States Department of the Interior.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Vice President Humphrey told other candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination today that "you do yourself, your party and your President and your country a disservice by constantly downgrading your President, your party and your country."

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- President Johnson sent to Congress today two requests for large supplemental appropriations to cover increased costs of the war in Vietnam and military and civilian pay increases.

The Brooklyn College administration has provided an object lesson in how to deal with disruptive students who try to impose their will by force without concern for the welfare of the majority or of the institution. After fair and unmistakable warning had been given to the insurgents -- fewer than fifty among a student body of 24,000 -- the college expelled them as students and had them evicted from the offices they had occupied illegally.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Johnson Administration urged Communist China today to reconsider its stance of international isolation and accept United States offers of new contacts and exchanges.
SANTA CRUZ, Bolivia, May 21 -- Five South American nations have agreed to work cooperatively in the economic development of a vast area drained by the Rio de la Plata.

PARIS, May 21 -- In a huge amphitheater classroom at the Sorbonne today, students in shirtsleeves waved their fists and shouted their ideas on how to bring about "la revolution." The jammed semicircular rows of seats, the passionate faces -- it all looked like a mural of 1789 come to life.

DENVER, May 21 -- Gov. John A. Love, a leader in the moderate wing of the Republican party, said today he thought that racial violence might turn the Republican Presidential nomination to Gov. Ronald Reagan of California.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 21 -- Harvard University was advised today by a committee of senior professors to offer better starting salaries to scholars. The school was also told to improve the lot of established faculty members in order to maintain its prestige in an era of increasing competition for educational talent.

Long-standing efforts of the Federal Administration to get legislation to repeal a 117-year-old limitation on liability in cases of death or injury at sea, may result in Congressional action this session.

Leonard H. Goldenson, president of American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., declared at the company's annual meeting yesterday that earnings for the second quarter should be ahead of those for the same period a year ago.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 21 -- Half the people polled in a Government-sponsored popularity survey believed that Brazil is worse off after the first year under the regime of President Arthur da Costa e Silva.
A do-it-yourself adaptation of "Fiddler on the Roof," acted by homemade puppets worked by puppetmasters whose age averaged in the low seventies opened yesterday in the northeast Bronx.

THE specter of serious hunger in the United States -- 30 million persons living on an inadequate diet and a third of these not being reached by any kind of Federal aid -- was visually detailed last night on "C.B.S. Reports."
PARIS, May 21 -- The French workers' strike movement spread today to the Bank of France, the nation's nuclear installations and les Halles, the old central market.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Administration has proposed a new airport and airways modernization plan that would force users of aviation to pay more of their own way.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- New orders received by durable-goods manufacturers declined somewhat in April, but the drop was mainly attributable to a decline in orders for aircraft, the Commerce Department reported today.
Americans can be forgiven if they savor for a moment the retributive justice implied in the troubles now besetting Charles de Gaulle.

DETROIT, May 21 -- The Upjohn Company, a major drug maker, said today that it was prepared to sell a birth control agent that is effective for three months as soon as its use is approved by the Food and Drug Administration.
PANAMA, May 21 -- A break is believed to have occurred between the leadership of the National Guard and President Marco A. Robles over who won the May 12 presidential election.
Volume and prices expanded yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

Manuel F. Cohen, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, warned yesterday that public confidence in the fairness of securities markets could be undermined by improper use of inside information.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 21 (UPI) -- John W. Galbreath, a race-horse owner and a millionaire, offered today to finance an intensive research program in equine medicine with the goal of preventing recurrence of the Dancer's Image incident in the Kentucky Derby.

CORVALLIS, Ore., May 21 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said tonight that in the event he could not win the nomination, his decision on whom to support would depend on how Senator Robert F. Kennedy "conducted his campaign" and where Vice President Humphrey stood on the issue of the Vietnam war.

DORADO BEACH, P. R., May 21 -- Concern that new financial storms -- both domestic and international -- may be brewing dominated conversation here today at the opening of the 15th annual monetary conference of the American Bankers Association.
PARIS, May 21 -- The problems facing Parisians on the second day of the virtually general strike now include rats.
Two speakers at yesterday's conference of the Maritime Management Institute at Fort Schuyler in the Bronx took issue with Administration maritime policy, but on differing counts.

LONDON, May 21 -- The first indisputable triumph of this year's World Theater Season (at the Aldwych Theater) is a production of Dion Boucicault's "The Shaughraun," brought over from Dublin by the Abbey Theater despite Irish protests.
The mother and grandmother of a 16-year-old boy accused of killing Theresa Riccio collapsed yesterday at his arraignment in Queens Adolescent Court.

Governor Rockefeller's strategists decided at a secret meeting in a New York hotel Sunday night that he must wage a more aggressive campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination, authoritative sources disclosed yesterday.

An offbeat concert of vocal music was given at Carnegie Recital Hall last night by Frederick D. Mayer, tenor, and Craig Timberlake, bass, who sang duets all evening and kept a good-sized audience attentive and responsive from start to finish.
GANDHI. By Geoffrey Ashe. 404 pages. Stein and Day. $8.95.
DETROIT, May 21 -- The Ford Motor Company announced today that it would offer a skid control device as optional equipment on some expensive 1969 cars.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., May 21 -- Matthew G. Carter, a Negro, was sworn in today as Mayor of this predominantly white, generally well-to-do suburban town.

Happy Monday, ($39.80 for $2) arrived in the winner's circle at Belmont Park a day late yesterday. For most of the hard-core horseplayers in the crowd of 24,391, Happy Monday had already given way to Harried Tuesday.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy said today that he must win all the Presidential primaries to be a "viable" candidate and described a "new politics" that appeared to include supporters of his major opponent in California.
Interest rates continued to climb yesterday, causing New York City to reject bids for $71-million of notes and Philadelphia to cancel a $29,375,000 bond sale scheduled for noon today.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., which operates the Gimbels department stores and the Saks Fifth Avenue chain, had a 7.9 per cent gain in sales and a 16.1 per cent gain in net income in the first quarter ended April 30, Bruce A. Gimbel, president, told the annual meeting yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Congressional unhappiness with the Administration's merchant marine program may produce a more far-reaching shipping policy than that desired by the Administration.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 21 -- The North Vietnamese kept up their pressure in the northern provinces of South Vietnam today with rocket and mortar attacks on three major American military installations.

Bill Collins, a 6-foot-3-inch professional from the Brae Burn Country Club in Purchase, N.Y., was the low qualifier yesterday at trials in Westchester and New Jersey for the United States Open golf championship.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The Air Force has grounded 42 of its F-111A fighter bombers for repair of a defective hydraulic valve, officials said today.
MACON, France, May 21 -- The wave of strikes sweeping France has opened vistas of greater profit for French vintners, who are gathered here for the annual French national wine fair.

St. John's University, New York University, Rutgers and Temple were named yesterday to represent District II in the National Collegiate Athletic Association baseball playoffs at Princeton, N. J., May 30 through June 1.

About 250 chanting student protesters invaded Hamilton Hall on the troubled Columbia University campus yesterday but were removed from the building by the police at about 3 o'clock this morning, nearly 10 hours later.

Dr. Jerome H. Holland, president of the Hampton Institute, Hampton, Va., has been elected a director of the Firemen's Insurance Company of Newark, it was announced yesterday by the Continental Insurance Companies, New York, of which Firemen's is a unit.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Haiti declared today that she had crushed an invasion attempt by about 35 Haitian exiles operating from Great Iguana Island, in the nearby Bahamas.

CHANNEL 13 presented last night the first of a five-part series on sex education for teen-agers and their parents entitled "Sons and Daughters." Produced by educational station WITF-TV in Hershey, Pa., the series employs professional actors in dramatized vignettes showing youngsters questioning, in the argot of the day, the sexual prudery and hypocrisy of their elders and receiving intelligent and sensitive replies from a parental representative, played by the host, Steve Meyer.
A two-day conference on unemployment among the city's one million Puerto Ricans ended yesterday with a question: "Is 'Brown Power' -- parallel to 'Black Power' -- the only way to get results?"
He's old and he's short, but he's a prizefighter and sometimes that's all that matters.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- President Johnson said today he found in the nation "a degree of intolerance and almost totalitarian vehemence" among people who wanted their own way.
The First Empire State Corporation, a proposed bank holding company in New York State, plans to take in a fourth member bank -- the First National Bank in Yonkers, which has assets of $124-million.
A live and lively report of the campus demonstration at Columbia University was provided throughout the evening by WKCR, the university's radio station, which is operated by students.
ALBANY, May 21 -- The Assembly, over scattered Republican opposition, approved bills today to raise benefit payments by $10 a week for workers who are ill, injured or unemployed.

A burly California astronomer, his pocket bulging with photographs taken the day before, marched into a scientific conference here yesterday, apologized for his appearance after several sleepless nights and then confronted his audience with a new pulsar mystery.
CHICAGO, May 21 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan took a long step today toward making explicit his availability, if not his outright desire, for the Republican Presidential nomination.

The Whitney Museum has a bear by the tail. Five weeks ago it started an experimental series of informal Tuesday evening concerts. The music was intended to supply background for strolling through the galleries.

IN the canyons of lower Manhattan, "crash" is a dirty word. And the Wall Street veteran who used the word yesterday in speaking of present dangers is old enough to remember vividly the disintegration that the word suggests.

BERNARD LANVIN took a walk along Fifth Avenue yesterday in his "new classic" suit of brown-striped tan worsted. The four-button, close-fitting jacket had narrow lapels and diagonal pockets; the vest was cut straight across, rather than angled; the slim trousers were shorter in the front than in the back, and a fractional flare began a few inches from the bottom.
David A. (Sonny) Werblin has sold his share of the New York Jets to his four partners, Townsend B. Martin, a partner, confirmed last night, according to The Associated Press.
Ann L. Lathrop, in her letter published May 14, questions lowering the standards for Negroes. As a Negro American I agree.
A decision by the United States Lines to operate a new fleet of containerships at Elizabeth, N. J., rather than at the line's Hudson River piers, resulted in labor troubles at both places yesterday.

DO you like the Bolshoi Ballet or do you also like the Bolshoi's sumptuous dancing? I make a distinction because the troupe called Stars of the Bolshoi Ballet, which opened last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, is fewer than 40 dancers and could not and does not pretend to offer what is represented by the Muscovite grandeur of the Bolshoi Ballet.

Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan, canceling his earlier order, sent all 13 "ousted" teachers back to their schools in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration district in Brooklyn yesterday.
The Lindsay administration completed work yesterday on the long-delayed city expense budget, but the impasse over the taxes needed to balance it continued.
TWO rug events held within 10 blocks of each other yesterday morning represented the alpha and omega of the carpet world.
BOSTON, May 21 -- Dr. Benjamin M. Spock conspired openly with four co-defendants to disrupt the draft and then invited arrest, a Government prosecutor said today.

The most significant characteristic of the epidemic of strikes in France is the spontaneous, grass-roots manner in which it has come about and spread. No factor will be more important in tonight's censure vote at the National Assembly and, whatever its outcome, in the critical decisions that will still face President de Gaulle.
The Western Union Telegraph Company, which has been trying to block a take-over attempt by the University Computing Company, yesterday agreed in principle to merge with Computer Sciences Corporation.

A dinner dance at the Waldorf-Astoria on Tuesday will celebrate the 35th anniversary of United States diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union and honor a small group that visited the Soviet Union in the early nineteenthirties.

THE listing the other day of qualifying standards for the track and field events of the Olympic Games at Mexico City in October gives renewed emphasis to the growing excellence of the world's finest athletes in each of these quadriennial international shows.

Negotiators representing the United Parcel Service and 4,600 striking members of the Teamsters Union met again yesterday after a recess of several days in an effort to settle the walkout affecting deliveries for about 400 stores in the metropolitan area.
The stock market snapped its latest losing streak yesterday as prices advanced in more active trading.
LONDON, May 21 -- European capitals are seriously concerned that the continued unrest in France could lead to economic troubles that could infect other European countries.

Net income and sales of the General Foods Corporation set records for the 16th consecutive year, C. W. Cook, chairman and chief executive officer, announced yesterday, in reporting results for the fiscal year ended March 30.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -Most of nearly 300 demonstrators of the Poor People's Campaign were denied admission to the House Visitors Gallery today because they did not have the required passes.
ALBANY, May 21 -- Governor Rockefeller today predicted passage of the controversial compromise plan for decentralization of the New York City school system.
ALBANY, May 22 -- Governor Rockefeller reached agreement with the legislative leadership today on the distribution of $290-million in special state aid to cities over the next three years.
Investors maintained a buying mood again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, pushing prices ahead on a broad front and volume above the eight million share mark.

Things were pretty lively down at the Henry Street Playhouse last night. Dancers all over the place. Popping through exit doors. Running up aisles. Careening over a pit piano lid, mercifully closed. Sliding down cellar-door-like structures propped between the stage rim and auditorium floor.
Common stock of the Clorox Company, a large producer of household bleach, reached the market in a $33-million first public offering yesterday and investors bid the issue to a 10 per cent premium.
An agreement in principle has been signed for Tenneco, Inc., to acquire Newport News Shipbuilding Dry Dock Company, the nation's leading builder of Navy vessels, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- United States trade with the Soviet Union and its European allies declined in 1967 despite the Johnson Administration's efforts to increase trade with Eastern Europe.

MARSEILLES, France, May: 22 -- A thousand barge and tugboat crewmen went on strike today, completing the paralysis of Marseilles harbor, France's largest port and her main gate way to Africa and the Far East.
At a time when speculative fever is rampant, some Wall Streeters are reminding their customers of special stocks -- described as stocks with special tax treatment.
W J SLOANE'S room settings make it obvious that at least some interior designers are back on the gold standard.

Northwest Industries, Inc., the Chicago holding company, took a giant step into the insurance field by acquiring 838,350 of the 8,654,642 shares of the Home Insurance Company, one of the nation's oldest and biggest property and casualty underwriters.
Vince Lombardi of the Green Bay Packers has been offered more than once the position of coach or general manager or both of the New York Jets. Each time he has turned down the offer.
PARIS, May 22 -- High in the press gallery of the Chamber of Deputies last night a British correspondent lamented the good old days when, as he recalled, one speech could bring down the Government.

NEW ORLEANS, May 22 -- Thomas P. F. Hoving, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, called on the nation's museum directors today to find a "fully contemporary and responsible role to play in the ferment of the times."

Shareholders of the Grand Union Company were told at their annual meeting in Paramus, N. J., yesterday that sales rose to $206,274,000 for the first 11 weeks of fiscal 1968, 12.6 per cent higher than in the like period of last year.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People accused today two Mississippi employers and four unions of racial discrimination and asked for Federal protection of the complainants.
Lightning struck one of Belmont Park's prized trees yesterday just before the $28,100 Liberty Belle Handicap, preventing some patrons from getting down bets on the horses that finished 1, 2, 3.

The second battle of Columbia University, in which policemen pummeled unresisting students and students smashed policemen with bricks early yesterday morning, only reaffirmed for many at Columbia what the first battle on April 30 had shown:
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Spanish Government has agreed to the nomination of Robert F. Wagner, former Mayor of New York City, as Ambassador to Spain.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 22 -- Every time Wayne Zahn cashes a check from a bowling tournament, he helps pay back the former manager of Echo Lanes in Milwalkee, who used to let him bowl an extra game or two.

THE final of the 1968 Intercollegiate Championship, played earlier this month at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, Wis., resulted in a victory for Jon Richards and Jeff Hand of the University of Maryland.
DETROIT, May 22 -- The principals in Detroit's six-month-old newspaper strike appeared today to be moving toward a settlement.
HOUSTON, May 22 (AP) -- Louis John Fierro of Elmont, N. Y., the world's 15th heart transplant patient, was described as in excellent condition today by his doctors at St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital.

Once again Morningside Heights has been the scene of a bloody battle between Columbia students and the police -- particularly tragic and particularly unnecessary because of the exemplary manner in which an hour or two earlier Hamilton Hall had been cleared of those who were illegally occupying it.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 22 -- Sweden has called for a worldwide conference of scientists, administrators, conservationists, health officials and industrial experts to study the effects of material and scientific advances on man's environment.
Ian K. MacGregor and Thomas P. Forbath have been elected to the board of directors of the American Cyanamid Company, Wayne, N. J.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 22 -- The predominantly white United Bermuda party swept to an unexpectedly easy victory tonight in Bermuda's first one-man-one-vote election.

ALBANY, May 22 -- The Rockefeller-legislative leaders' accord on a strong compromise school decentralization plan for New York City collapsed today, apparently because of diminishing support by legislators under pressure from groups opposed to the plan.

DENVER, May 22 -- A Kennedy-McCarthy campaign merger has been effected in the Colorado in an atempt to keep Vice President Humphrey from winning six convention delegates with less than a majority vote.

THE sudden jangle of the telephone startles a visitor who has settled into the stillness of the Axe Castle. The hilltop castle glowers at the Hudson River near Tarrytown, N.Y., while the Knights of Axe Houghton stealthily lance "interesting situations" for the concern's four mutual funds.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- United States officials, who have been irritated at times by the policies of the Gaullist Government, are following events in France with close interest and without gloating.
PARAMOUNT, Calif., May 22 -- A chartered helicopter taking passengers to Los Angeles after a day at nearby Disneyland, crashed in flames today, killing all 23 persons aboard.
American steamship operators and Federal ship policy planners came in for sharp criticism yesterday as the nation observed National Maritime Day.

GEORGE STEELE of Detroit is an ordinary villain. He has a closely cropped, baldish, fat head; matted hair on his chest and back, and the slack mouth of a cowardly bully. But at Madison Square Garden Monday night, while wrestling an exhibition with the uninspired but unbeataable Bruno Sammartino, George Steele created a masterpeiece.

" Episodes" are the fragments of experience that slyly cumulate into one's life and also the title of the New York City Ballet's accumulation of the whips and scraps of Anton Webern's orchestral works into a delicately structured dance.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Leaders of the Poor People's Campaign devoted today to the "self-purification" and expansion of "Resurrection City, U.S.A."
PARIS, May 22 -- The great haute-couture house of Cristobal Balenciaga will close next month. A spokesman for the salon, which is on Avenue George V, finally confirmed the closing.
The Board of Estimate decided yesterday that 12.5-acre Steeplechase Park at Coney Island should be used for recreation and not for the housing development that had been proposed for it.
The synthesis of five members of a family of hormone-like chemicals that some scientists believe to be of potential therapeutic value was reported yesterday by a team of Harvard chemists.

Five hundred delegates, ranging from the composers Milton Babbitt and Luciano Berio to Paul Williams, editor of the rock magazine Craw-daddy, will gather in New York on Sept. 9 for an international conference "Music and Communication."

NEW HAVEN, May 22 -- Those pesky Ivy League regulations that sometimes appear to hamper the workings of an otherwise excellent intercollegiate football program came in for mild criticism from the eight Ivy coaches who staged their annual spring meeting at Yale this week.

HUNTINGDON VALLEY, Pa. -- There are collectors with hangups on champagne corks, posters, playbills, ticket stubs, racing cars and antique clocks. Not to mention those with a singular passion for old planes, new boats, bottles, bird cages and chewing gum wrappers.
CLEVELAND, May 22 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan, winding up a five-state tour tonight, called on admirers to join a Republican "crusade" and assailed Democratic military policies.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Administration's crime control bill appeared today to be heading for rejection in a Senate-House conference committee unless Senate provisions overturning Supreme Court decisions are removed from it.

The University Computing Company extended its tender offer yesterday for stock in the Western Union Telegraph Company to Friday. At the same time it said it would not favor the merger of Western Union with Computer Sciences Corporation of El Segundo, Calif.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Are you feeling left out during the spring social upheavals? Does life seem gray and drab because you have no cause to riot, demonstrate, march, strike, confront or sit-in for? Are you one of those drab millions who sit home nights asking, "But what in the world do they want?" while others are out burning cities, marching on the Establishment, strangling France and rifling the college president's mail?

MIAMI, May 22 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board has approved the transfer of a coast-to-coast route formerly operated by Slick Airways to Airlift International, Inc., the latter company announced here today.

Plans for a campus-like redevelopment near the United Nations were stalled by a City Council committee yesterday after the majority leader said angrily that his name had been used without his permission on a lavish brochure describing the project.

MERCE CUNNINGHAM -- and one can say this only with the deliberate diction appropriate to lapel buttons -- is Establishment! I am joking, of course -- or rather I am half-joking, of course -- but Cunningham's current season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music (it runs through Sunday afternoon) has established him as a crowd-puller and, in some obscure sense, respectable.
The board of directors of the City Center of Music and Drama will meet today to appoint Norman Singer to the newly created post of general administrator, it was learned on high authority last night.

At about 2:45 yesterday morning, a young man -- his hair shaggy, his face unshaven, his safari jacket and blue jeans wrinkled and his cowboy boots scuffed -- walked over to Mark Rudd and placed him under arrest.

DETROIT, May 22 -- New-car sales picked up steam in mid-May. The four major United States manufacturers reported 239,433 sales, up from 236,402 in the comparable period a year ago. But the May 11-20 period this year had only eight selling days, which meant the dealers reached 29,929 deliveries a day, up 14 per cent from a 26,267-a-day sales average last year in nine selling days.
ALBANY, May 22 -- The next Governor of New York would receive an annual salary of $85,000 under a measure quietly introduced in the Legislature today with approval of the Rockefeller administration.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 22 -- Haiti asked today for a Security Council meeting to consider the threat to international peace posed by a small, airborne invasion band that landed in that Caribbean island republic Monday.
LA GRANDE, Ore., May 22 (AP) -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy challenged Vice President Humphrey today to take his Presidential campaign to the American people.
To the Editor: With reference to your May 21 editorial "Panama's Shame," I wish to inform you that in Panama on election day more than 350,000 persons freely voted for the candidate of their choice.
The chief of the city's new Environmental Protection Administration told the Board of Estimate yesterday that he favored universal water metering for New York City.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 22 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said tonight that Senator Robert F. Kennedy had played "a prominent role" in formulating foreign policies in the early nineteen-sixties "which resulted in disastrous adventures."

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, May 22 -- King Faisal said today that United States "neglect" of the Arabs and support for Israel had led to rampant Communism in the Middle East and had convinced many Arabs that the Americans are their enemies.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Mry 22 -- The South Vietnamese Army officer, his fatigues wet with perspiration and his face smeared with dirt, lifted his arm and pointed to a block of buildings along a dark, winding alley.

JACKSON, Miss., May 22 -- For the first time since 1876, Negro delegates have been named to the Mississippi state Democratic convention to be held here July 2, but white control of the party machinery is hardly in danger.
Off Broadway's Circle in the Square is establishing a Broadway branch next season at Henry Miller's Theater.
TRENTON, May 22 -- The Republican legislative majorities adopted a fiscal program tonight that cut Gov. Richard J. Hughes's urban-aid and capital-construction recommendations virtually in half.
PARIS, May 22 -- Black markets sprang up throughout Paris today, and the spreading national strike touched the lives of almost everyone.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 22 -- A belated write-in campaign for Governor Rockefeller was started in Oregon tonight.
DORADO BEACH, P.R., May 22 -- Interest rates on savings accounts will be likely to rise unless Congress increases taxes within the next few weeks, Federal officials said here today.

AMONG the early American settlers in the basenji breed of hounds were three dogs that arrived in a shipment of gorillas and chimpanzees from the Belgian Congo. They were brought in for Henry Trefflich, whose Trefflich Bird and Animal Company on Liberty Street in New York deals mostly in wild creatures.

The return of labor peace to four Hudson piers used by the United States Lines appeared assured yesterday as the line and the International Longshoremen's Association reached tentative agreement on cargo operations.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Congress sent to the White House today a comprehensive "truth in lending" bill regarded by supporters as one of the strongest consumer protection measures in recent history.

Three gunmen forced 12 employes of a Franklin National Bank office in Long Island City, Queens, behind the grill of the bank's vault early yesterday afternoon and escaped with loot estimated at $300,000.

MOSCOW, May 22 -- Foreign Secretary Michael Stewart of Britain arrived by plane today for consultations with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko toward a future Soviet-British role on a Vietnam peace settlement.
Prices on the London stock market pushed ahead moderately yesterday after losing ground in early trading. Volume was light but picked up near the close.

HARTFORD, May 22 -- The Trinity College faculty voted today to ignore the disciplinary probation that the board of trustees had ordered for 168 students who tied up the college in a sit-in demonstration last month.
PARIS, May 22 (AP) -- Britain, Bulgaria, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, the Netherlands, Poland and Italy advanced today as the Federation Cup women's tennis matches got off to a damp start today.
LONDON, May 22 -- The price of gold here dropped by more than $1 an ounce today as the recent brisk buying slackened and some earlier buyers became sellers. The pound strengthened in quiet dealings.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- A high official of the Johnson Administration said today that the combined tax increase and $6-billion spending reduction package pending before Congress would impose "somewhat more restraint on the economy than we need" but would still "do us a great deal of good."

By today's rapidly changing standards, Miriam Gideon and Mark Brunswick, who had a concert devoted to music written by them last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, are relatively conservative.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- President Johnson's drive to find jobs for 100,000 hard-core unemployed over the next year appears assured, but the Government is worried about a "grave" jobless problem among youth this summer.

To the Editor: Dr. Grayson Kirk's refusal to drop the charges of criminal trespass against the Columbia students suggests that the administration intends to make no concessions to student demands unless those demands are coupled with the kind of protest activity which has already disrupted the functioning of the university.
ALBANY, May 22 -- Governor Rockefeller today signed a bill permitting interstate certification of school teachers.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- Otto F. Otepka, former security chief for the State Department, said today he would appeal the Civil Service Commission's verdict upholding the department in its disciplinary action against him.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI) -- Agriculture Secretary Orville L. Freeman said today that the nation's hungry often got only half a loaf of bread because of public indifference, especially among middle-class Americans.

The New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday that it is presiding over the liquidation of Pickard Co., Inc. a small member firm with a general brokerage clientele, thus marking the second time in its 176-year history that the Big Board has undertaken such a role.

CAIRO, May 22 -- An Egyptian Government spokesman said today that the United States was "allowing itself to be deceived again by Israeli maneuvers."

PARIS, May 22 -- Ambassador at Large W. Averell Harriman urged today that both sides reduce the public polemics at the preliminary peace talks in order to get meaningful negotiations started, but he was rebuffed by the North Vietnamese.

PRAGUE, May 22 -- President Ludvik Svoboda flew to Slovakia today for a three-day visit, apparently to try to keep Slovak members of the national Communist party's Central Committee from slipping into the ranks of the regime's conservative opponents.

The American Express Company has leased 202,000 square feet of floor space in the former International Telephone Building at 67 Broad Street between William and Beaver Streets, in a transaction involving aggregate rents of $20million.

BOSTON, May 22 -- In a darkened courtroom, the jury in the conspiracy trial of Dr. Benjamin M. Spock and four other men watched today a television film showing the burning of draft cards by youths in Boston's Arlington Street Unitarian Church last Oct. 16.

Money, the root of all odds, has established Bob Foster as a surprising 12-to-5 favorite over the world light-heavyweight champion, Dick Tiger, in tomorrow night's title bout at Madison Square Garden.

LA BASSE-INDRE, France, May 22 -- When the men at the Caunard tin smelter here went on strike three days ago, it was a decision that touched the livelihood of everyone in this small, one-company town.

WHITE PLAINS, May 22 -- A Westchester County reapportionment plan that would substitute a 35-member board of legislators for the 45-member Board of Supervisors was approved today by State Supreme Court Justice John J. Dillon.

MEMPHIS, May 23 (AP)--B. R. McLendon, winner of the Magnolia Classic last week in his first professional tournament, shot an eagle 3 on the 18th hole for a five-under-par 65 today and shared the firstround lead with Bob Lunn in the $100,000 Memphis open golf tournament.

BOSTON, May 23 -- An aide to Attorney General Ramsey Clark described to a Federal jury today how Dr. Benjamin Spock, 65 years old, and three co-defendants in a conspiracy trial invited arrest by bringing to the Justice Department last Oct. 20 a briefcase stuffed with hundreds of draft cards.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 23 -- More Americans were killed in combat in the two weeks ended May 11 -- during the enemy's latest offensive -than in any other two-week period in the Vietnam war, according to information made public by the United States military command tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -The Treasury Department borrowed $1.5-billion yesterday, paying the highest interest rates the Federal Government has paid on its direct debt since the Civil War.
In an otherwise dull trading day for commodity futures, wheat and oats caused a little surprise.
One cold morning last December, Epifanio Ortiz, a 9year-old Cub Scout, and his dog sat for more than two hours in front of a store in a South Bronx slum.

TRW, Inc., and the Reda Pump Company announced yesterday that they had reached a preliminary merger agreement involving an exchange of stock valued at about $103.4-million.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Dick Gregory, the Negro entertainer, who is an announced candidate for the Presidency, asked a Federal Court today to order the President and top State Department officials to include him in any national security briefings for candidates.

PARAMOUNT, Calif., May 23 (UPI) -- The worst civilian helicopter crash in United States history has taken 23 lives, including a mayor, a professor of mathematics and a stockbroker and nine vacationers from Ohio.
PARIS, May 23 -- Spokesmen for the French police told the Government today that there was a limit to their obedience.

LONDON, May 24 -- Twelve years after introducing the first of the angry young men in "Look Back in Anger" John Osborne offers us an angry young woman. His "Time President," a two-act tirade for a corrosive protagonist and attendant stooges is being staged at the Royal Court Theater, with Mr. Osborne's wife, Jill Bennett, in the lead.

PARIS, May 24 -- The hundreds of thousands of French farmers who staged a "day of warning" today were seeking to defend a way of life threatened by modern competition.
