WASHINGTON, May 24 -With a new camera, several hundred different pictures can be made on one negative. The exact number, normally between 300 and 400, depends on lighting conditions and the degree of resolution desired.
ASTORIA, Ore., May 24 -Senator Robert F. Kennedy stripped to his undershorts and plunged into the breakers for a brief swim today off a magnificent beach along Oregon's unspoiled Pacific Coast.

SAARBRUCKEN, Germany, May 24 -- Waving red flags and shouting "Down with de Gaulle!" about 800 West German left-wing students escorted the militant French student leader Daniel Cohn-Bendit to the French border here today to measure the seriousness of the French Government's expulsion order against him.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 24 -- After morning rain and winds ceased, Mark Stuart Jr., a former Metropolitan amateur champion, carried off the medal today with a one-over-par 74 in the Walter J. Travis memorial golf tournament.
The police in Brooklyn asked yesterday that the public help in finding three young sisters who have been missing since last Wednesday.

OTTAWA, May 24 (AP) -- A Canadian military attache has been expelled from the Soviet Union after he and his wife were manhandled by Soviet officials who broke into their train compartment in Eastern Siberia May 11, the Government announced today.

THE turn-of-the-century brownstones off Central Park West in the 90's didn't cost much a few years ago -yet the price was too high. While something could be done about the safety of the rotting houses, not much could be done about the ferment on streets that had been called among the worst in the city.

KAMPALA, Uganda, May 24 -- Nigerian and Biafran delegates ended the second day of their peace negotiations here today by agreeing on procedure but disagreeing on the formula with which to express their agreement.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- President Johnson's drive to find jobs for 100,000 hard-core unemployed over the next year appears assured, but the Government is worried about a "grave" jobless problem among youth this summer.

PARIS, May 24--A North Vietnamese spokesman here accused the United States negolators today of dodging Hanoi's demand for a cessation of the bombing of the North. At the same time, he charged that American forces in the field were intensifying the war.

Although Mayor Lindsay's operating budget for New York City's next fiscal year will not be made public until Monday, answers to some of its most difficult problems have now become at least conditionally available. OLD WESTBURY, L.I., May 24 -- There is a rustic approach to this area that is not quite as picturesque as Marie Antoinette in a shepherdess costume but is, nevertheless, charming. Part of it is having a ball in a tent decorated with 3,000 imported tulips, dancing to Peter Duchin's orchestra and supping on roast filet of beef.

Belmont Park passed its first test of inclement weather with a better than adequate mark yesterday. Considering the steady rain in the morning, and the clammy cold all day, the turnout of 20,041 wasn't bad at all.

The head of the New York City Mission Society charged yesterday that the major Protestant denominations were miserly in meeting the needs of the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, "the nation's largest ghetto."

Reviewing Martha Graham is rather like being called upon to review the Grand Canyon. WASHINGTON, May 24, (UPI) -- The House Appropriations Committee set aside its goals of economy today to vote $245-million -- more than twice what President Johnson requested -- to subsidize next year's construction work on United States merchant ships.

Observations of Venus by four of the world's most powerful radars have cast doubt on the Soviet report that its spacecraft sent data to earth from the surface of that planet last October. It now appears that temperature and pressure on Venus may be far more extreme than were implied by the Soviet data.

NORFOLK, Va., May 31 -- A hulk found in 180 feet of water 100 miles east-northeast of here was identified by divers today as a sunken World War II submarine and the search for the nuclear submarine Scorpion and her 99-man crew centered on an undersea mountain range 300 miles south of the Azores.
A Canadian and an Argentine received hearts yesterday in the world's 18th and 19th heart transplant operations. Surgeons in both cases were cautious in their estimates of success.

THE Reisinger Knockout Team Championship at the Eastern Regionals at the New York Hilton goes into its semi-final stage today. The quarter-final round was played last night.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 2 -- Reliable reports reaching here say that the Yemeni royalists have decided on sweeping changes in their Government that deprive the Imam, Mohamad al-Badr, of all powers and leave him a mere figure-head.
The fastest outdoor mile ever run in the East, 3 minutes 56.8 seconds, belongs to Dave Patrick of Villanova.
NEWARK, June 2 -- The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers ratified a new three-year contract today with New Jersey Bell Telephone Co., ending a 49-day strike.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 2 -- The United States Women's Lacrosse Association chose the best 24 players in the country here today.
MONTREAL, June 2 -- Gordon Roy McGregor spent his last day in office Friday as president of Air Canada, carrying on as the same controversial figure that he has been in the last 20 years.
The country's first national park for the performing arts will open next May in Vienna, Va., in the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains.
Four years ago, signs of restiveness began to appear among the congregants of the First Presbyterian Church of Chandler, Ariz.

PARIS, June 2 -- Jubilant Gaullist party strategists today predicted a Gaullist landslide in the general election on June 23. They set their target at 300 seats in the 487-seat National Assembly, an increase of 50 per cent over their present strength.

A 43-year-old Housing Authority patrolman, bleeding and unconscious from wounds suffered in a hail of police bullets, was found slumped over the wheel of his car yesterday after a chase that began when he allegedly held up a Bronx diner.

HOUSTON, June 2 -- The nomination of Preston E. Smith for Governor in the Democratic runoff primary yesterday will put conservatives back in control of the Texas Democratic party after six years under Gov. John B. Connally Jr., a moderate.

The California primary is not so significant as it appears. What is at stake tomorrow is whether Senator Eugene J. McCarthy or Senator Robert F. Kennedy gains a tactical advantage over the other. But what really matters is whether in alliance they can stop Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey at the Democratic convention.

The revolt of Bergen and Essex County Republican legislators against their party's uncompromising opposition to the urban-aid and capital-construction programs proposed by Gov. Richard J. Hughes is an encouraging sign of a growing awareness of the Garden State's great and urgent needs. But it gives no assurances that these needs will be met.

PLYMOUTH, England, June 2 (AP) -- Lieut. Erie Tabarly of the French Navy who wa,s first across the starting line here yesterday, in the 3,130-mile trans-Atlantic race to Newport, R. I., turned back his 65-foot yacht, Pen Duick IV, from the ocean today and headed for port with steering troubles, British Coast Guards reported.

A group opposed to the 59th-floor heliport on the Pan Am Building announced last week that it had asked Donald H. Elliott, chairman of the City Planning Commission, to withdraw a permit for the midtown site, and to hold hearings on its projected reopening.

JERICHO, L. I., June 2 -- Valiant Hawk, who is making a determined effort to unseat Silver Lady as the Long Island high-score award champion, won the regular working hunter championship-today at the 0ld Mill Farms horse show.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -President Johnson appears to be turning increasingly to the Inter-American Development Bank as his chosen instrument for United States policy in Latin America.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 2 -- Inverness, Bob McCullough's black-hulled 47-foot yawl from the Riverside Yacht Club, enhanced a formidable reputation today by becoming the main corrected-time winner in the race around Block Island conducted by the Storm Trysail Club.

CONCORD, Calif., June 2 -Robert F. Kennedy said today he hoped that he and Eugene J. McCarthy could join forces after the California Presidential primary in an effort to stop Vice President Humphrey from winning the nomination.

WOLFSBURG, West Germany, June 2 -- A symbol of West Germany's rise from the ashes of war, the sprawling Volkswagen works here, entered the 31st year of its existence on May 26, but there were no celebrations to mark the anniversary.

The May 21 editorial "Petition on the Potomac" does not grasp completely the aspects and reasons for the Poor People's March on Washington. Its fallacy lies in the "fear clause" that if things get out of hand, the people and Congress will become reactionary.

THE American dance lover right now hardly knows which way to go even if he knows which way to turn. He has not only -- almost as a bonus -- the Stars of the Bolshoi at the Metropolitan Opera House, but also in residence the two most creative American companies, George Balanchine's New York City Ballet and the Martha Graham Dance Company.

Archbishop Terence J. Cooke and Mayor Lindsay broke with tradition yesterday at an ecumenical service in the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, "invoking the aid of the Holy Spirit" in the nation's urban crisis.

IF a Schrafft's waitress, that symbol of tearoomy propriety, now bats false eyelashes at a customer, it is with her boss's blessing. He bought those eyelashes for her and hired an instructor to teach her how to put them on.
J. M. Mathes, Inc., has notified it biggest client, Somerset Importers, Ltd., a division of Canada Dry, that it has "rejected a requirement to merge as a condition of retaining" the business.
The Gaullist election effort to run against the Communists is an attempt to cash in on a self-fulfilling prophecy.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 2 -Robert Johnson, a biology instructor at Hofstra University, bent down today and carefully ran his fingers through the base of a clump of broom sedge grass to uncover the furrows made by the tiny vole, commonly known as the meadow mouse.
The police said yesterday that the 17-year-old girl whose nude body was found in a steamer trunk off a Staten Island shore last week died of an overdose of barbiturates, and was not a murder victim.

MEXICO CITY, June 2 -The Council of the International Coffee Organization has failed to agree on how to set up a $150-million fund to help 42 producing nations cut down coffee output and diversify into other export crops.

PITTSBURGH, Jnne 2 (UPI) -- Deron Johnson's two-run single marked a five-run seventhinning rally that paced the Atlanta Braves to a 10-5 victory today after Willie Stargell drove in four runs in leading the Pittsburgh Pirates to an 8-4 triumph in the first game.

Mayor Lindsay's office made it clear last night that alternate-side-of-the-street parking regulations would be suspended for Rosh ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur as well as for Christmas.

TROON, Scotland, June 2 (AP) -- Bill Hyndman of Philadelphia and Dale Morey of High Point, N.C., withdrew today from the British Amateur golf championship, leaving 39 Americans to compete in the tournament that opens here tomorrow.
ATLANTA, June 2 -- Bob Lunn made it two in a row today.

LOS ANGELES, June 2 (UPI) -- Juan Marichal became the first nine-game winner in the major leagues today by hurling the San Francisco Giants to a 5-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers. He gave up three hits.

HONG KONG, June 2 -- One year ago a campaign of local Communist agitation against the British authorities was gaining momentum with some encouragement from Peking that created temporary concern here about Hong Kong's future.
The New York State Freedom and Peace party ended its two-day organizing convention here yesterday by nominating Dr. Benjamin Spock, the baby doctor and opponent of the war in Vietnam, for President.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 -- Senators Eugene J. McCarthy and Robert F. Kennedy resumed campaigning today in the California Presidential primary, after an apparently inconclusive debate last night on a national television network.

Your May 27 editorial "Mr. Boyd's Shipping Program" is a product of the same willful blindness to the significance of the United States merchant marine which The New York Times has been demonstrating for years.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The airline industry has completed the formation of an Airport Security Council to do a policing job at airports in the New York Metropolitan area that have been plagued by thefts and racketeering.
Two regular Republican candidates for State Senate and Congress disclaimed yesterday the use of posters joining them with a regular candidate for Assemblyman.

The hour-long television panel discussion in which Senators Eugene J. McCarthy and Robert F. Kennedy participated on Saturday evening was a model of civilized political discourse. It was a conversation rather than a debate and it demonstrated that the two rivals are in substantial agreement on every major issue. The one unfortunate note was the obfuscation created around the question of forcing Saigon to accept a postwar coalition regime in South Vietnam.

THE MONEY GAME. By 'Adam Smith.' 302 pages. Random House. $6.95.
The publisher of a successful investment magazine is the author of a humorously irreverent book about Wall Street, "The Money Game," published by Random House last week under the pen name Adam Smith.

LUBBOCK, Tex., June 2 -- "This is the real colorful candidate," Preston Smith said genially when he picked up the telephone this afternoon at his home here. An independent sort of conservative, he had breezed to victory yesterday in a primary runoff for the Democratic nomination for Governor -- "without working up a sweat," said the report in today's Lubbock Avalanche-Journal -- over Donald H. Yarborough, a liberal.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 2 -- St. John's University won the District 2 National Collegiate baseball championship on Princeton's Clarke Field today, beating New York University, 1-0, on an unearned run.
TOKYO, June 2 -- Japanese leftists appear to have won a victory in the controversy over calls here by nuclear-powered submarines of the United States Navy.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday.

The bond market, which late last week was cheered by President Johnson's decision to accept a $6-billion spending cut in return for enactment of his tax surcharge plan, faces a rather heavy calendar of new fixed-income securities this week.

HOPES for an American to become the next chess champion of the world were squelched when Viktor Korchnoi, the 37-year-old Soviet grandmaster, defeated the veteran Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., by 5 1/2-2 1/2 in a best-out-of-ten-games match in Amsterdam, the Netherlands. This was one of a series of quarter-finals eliminations to decide the next challenger for the title, now held by Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union.

NHOMAN, South Vietnam, June 2 -- The midday sun quivered over the parched rice fields in this tiny hamlet as children picked through the rubble of shacks and brick homes that were shattered four months ago.

QUITO, Ecuador, June 2 -Two former Presidents of this agricultural country were locked in a tight battle to resume leadership tonight as Ecuador held her first direct national elections in eight years.
HONG KONG, June 2 -- After months of setbacks and delay, a compromise has been reached among contending political factions in Communist China's most populous province, Szechwan.
PARIS, June 2 -- A Spanish butler named Paco who works in Paris felt lonely today and deprived of a drama that had brightened his life for more than four weeks.

DETROIT, June 2 -- The Chrysler Corporation has imported thousands of cars in recent months that do not meet American safety standards.

ROME, June 2 -- The Italian Republic celebrated its 22d birthday today amid unusual economic prosperity marred by a political crisis and student unrest. True, the money raised by their weekend shows doesn't go for salaries but for production expenses. But "amateur" suggests to Mr. Feist a lack of standards and seriousness. He submits that his company has both.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether city and state voters have the right to nullify open housing ordinances.

ALBANY, June 3 -- Governor Rockefeller has signed a bill authorizing the State Banking Board to establish mortgage interest rates as high as 7.5 per cent. The present limit of 6 per cent had been in effect in the state for 88 years.

PARIS, June 3 (AP) -- Two members of the women's professional troupe, Rosemary Casals of San Francisco and the defending champion, Francoise Durr of France, were upset today in the French open tennis championships.

PARIS, June 3 -- Le Duc Tho, a ranking leader in North Vietnam, arrived today to join Hanoi's negotiating delegation and issued a firm restatement of his Government's demand for an "unconditional halt" in American bombing of North Vietnam.
DETROIT, June 3 (AP) -- Bill Gadsby, one of only five men to play 20 years in the National Hockey League, was named coach of the Detroit Red Wings today.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Treasury bill rate fell at today's auction from last week's levels, the Treasury disclosed today.

" IT COSTS $100," said Mrs. Bernard Aisenberg of a McCarthy button pinned on her watermelon pink dress, "but we expect anyone to get four years' wear out of it." She thought a minute and then said, "I mean, eight."

The Puerto Rican antipoverty agency here said yesterday that it would demand direct appropriations from the city's Human Resources Administration budget because it was being discriminated against in the distribution of such funds.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- New factory orders dropped 1.3 per cent during April, to $48.53-billion, largely reflecting a decline in orders for commercial aircraft, the Commerce Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- One of the top Negroes in public office said today that proposals for a separate, self-sustaining Negro community were an "illusion."
TRENTON, June 3 -- A co-chairman of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy's Presidential nomination campaign in New Jersey today predicted a large turnout in the Democratic primary election tomorrow.

Mayor Lindsay and 500 leaders in industry, finance, Government and the arts attended the premiere last night at the Mark Hellinger Theater of "New York City -- The Most," a color documentary celebrating the color and variety of the city.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) -- The Defense Department today identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:
JACQUES TIFFEAU may have had the last word on the hemline situation right at the beginning of the fall fashion season on Seventh Avenue.
Two gunmen held up a Fifth Avenue coin dealer yesterday and got away with $50,000 to $100,000 worth of $1, $5 and $10 bills.

Andy Warhol, the artist who brought a bewildering new dimension to American pop culture through his films, sculptures and paintings, was shot and critically wounded in his film studio yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- The nation's money managers voted unanimously in early March to tighten their rein on credit and discussed the prospects of an increase in the discount rate even before the gold crisis reached its peak.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The last-day-of-school address:
Retail sales of leading New York department stores dipped last month as a result of the 4-week strike of the United Parcel Service.
THE BAG. By Sol Yurich. 476 pages. Trident. $6.95.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 3 -- If Senator Robert F. Kennedy wins by even a single percentage point in the California Presidential primary tomorrow he will claim his victory and go on trying to win the Democratic nomination, his strategists said today.

RICHMOND, June 3 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit upheld today a ruling by the National Labor Relations Board stating that management had urged shutting down a Darlington, S. C., cotton mill 12 years ago to "chill" union advances in the area.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Public school teachers may not be discharged for good-faith criticism of school officials, even if some of the charges are false, the Supreme Court ruled today.
The governing board for the Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration school district in Brooklyn rejected yesterday a proposal that the bitter school controversy be submitted to arbitration.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- The Supreme Court upset today the narcotics conviction of a Los Angeles man because Federal customs officers who made the arrest entered a closed but unlocked door.
PARIS, June 3 -- Premier Georges Pompidou declared today that in the coming election French voters would have to cast their ballots "for or against totalitarian Communism."

WASHINGTON, June 3 (Reuters) -- The first formal step in the creation of "paper gold" to supplement real gold and dollars in national monetary reserves has been completed, an International Monetary Fund spokesman said today.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 3 (AP) -- Richmond Flowers lay in a hospital bed today and wondered if his luck had run out almost on the eve of the Olympic track team tryouts.

The Continental Insurance Company moved quickly yesterday to head off United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company's tender offer for the stock of the Glens Falls Insurance Company. Continental offered $60 a share in cash, or $7.50 more than was offered by Fidelity last Wednesday.
TORONTO, June 3 -- Canada fattened her foreign exchange reserves by a hefty $279.4-million in May, partly by borrowing and partly by taking advantage of the returned strength of the Canadian dollar.
Volume continued strong and prices moved up yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

BOSTON, June 3 -- Two Roman Catholic priests and a Protestant minister testified today at the trial of Dr. Benjamin Spock that it was a group of clergymen and not the five defendants who had sponsored the turn-in of draft cards by young men at the Arlington Street Unitarian Church last Oct. 16.
Consumer confidence has dipped a bit since January and February, the National Industrial Conference Board said yesterday.

TRENTON, June 3 -- The Federal Government estimated today that floods had caused $140-million worth of damage in six counties of northern New Jersey, according to the State Commissioner of Conservation and Development.

A student-faculty-administration disciplinary committee at Columbia University recommended yesterday the immediate suspension of all students arrested in the second occupation of Hamilton Hall on May 22.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that if credit continue to tighten, it might reduce the reserve requirements of the nation's savings-and-loan associations to keep mortgage money flowing to home builders and buyers.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The American Booksellers Association was told today that "the American general book store represents a classic picture of an industry in trouble."

BONN, June 3 -- The East German Government today released Ronald Wiedenhoeft, an instructor of art history at Columbia University who had been imprisoned in East Berlin since last September on charges of espionage.
QUITO, Ecuador, June 3 -- Dr. Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra, who has been elected President of Ecuador four times over the last 34 years, was returned for a fifth term today.

PRAGUE, June 3 -- Alexander Dubcek, the Czechoslovak Communist leader, today accused his predecessor, Antonin Novotny, of having lied to stave off his expulsion from the Central Committee and his suspension from the party last week.

TROON, Scotland, June 3 (AP) -- Twelve Americans moved into the second round of the British Amateur golf championship today as the weather switched from clear skies to heavy rain and strong winds and back to sunshine.

WEST BABYLON, L. I., June 3 -- A Negro school administrator who had sought "a place of quiet and acceptance" in the suburbs has abandoned plans to buy a house in an all-white neighborhod here because it was set afire last month in a racial incident.

A pro-Humphrey slate of convention delegates asked the City Board of Elections yesterday to include on the June 18 primary ballot the names of the Presidential candidates the would-be delegates support.

SAIGON, June 4 (AP) -- Samuel D. Berger, the Deputy Ambassador, has paid calls on President Nguyen Van Thieu and Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky, whose brother-in-law was among the six high - ranking South Vietnamese officials killed on Sunday, "to express personal and oficial regrets."

The president of the New York State Society of Newspaper Editors attacked as "vague" and "dangerous" yesterday a bill now before Governor Rockefeller that would make it illegal to publish "improperly obtained information."

Neil Fabricant, in his May 23 letter, speaks like a layman of Dr. Grayson Kirk's "refusal to drop the charges of criminal trespass against the Columbia students." Moreover, he labels "nonsense" Dr. Kirk's stated reason: that the decision to terminate prosecution is "in the hands of the judge and prosecutor."

PRAGUE, May 30 -- Revisiting Prague after 18 years is an uncanny experience. The town is as beautiful as ever, probably the loveliest medieval city in central Europe. The statues brood on Charles Bridge and the 12 Apostles appear in the clock in the Old Town Hall every hour on the hour. But most of the people have changed.
The credit markets, more convinced than ever that Congress will enact a $16-billion tax increase and spending reduction bill next week, continued to move up in price yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
Shepherd Mead, the successful agency dropout, is in town to be interviewed.
A nine-story research pavilion, stocked with sophisticated equipment to spur breakthroughs in rehabilitation medicine was dedicated here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to consider a contention of Dick Gregory, the Negro entertainer, that the police cannot constitutionally suppress a peaceful demonstration because hecklers threaten to start a riot.
The board of directors of the General Motors Corporation elected Earl R. Bramblett and Louis H. Bridenstine as vice presidents yesterday.
SEOUL, South Korea, June 3 -- Kim Jong Pil, regarded as the most likely successor to President Chung Hee Park in 1971, announced yesterday that he was retiring from politics.
June began on a bright note for investors yesterday as the stock market made a broad advance in heavy trading.

ROGER MARIS reacted with bitter resentment during his epic home run year of 1961 when Commissioner Ford Frick ruled that Babe Ruth's revered record of 60 homers in a 154-game season could not be erased from the books if the Yankee slugger were to go past it over a longer span of the 162-game schedule.
JERUSALEM, June 3 -- As a by-product of the Arab-Israeli war last June, a brisk and profitable black market has sprung up here in old pots.

The Management of the Delaware Hudson Company, a holding company, began making plans yesterday to convey the Delaware Hudson Railroad to the Norfolk Western Railway in exchange for 412,627 N. shares and a $1-million 6 per cent five-year N. W. note.
Sonata programs that begin with music by Mozart and end with music by Nuncio Mondello are not common -- in fact, last night's duo recital at Town Hall may very well mark a first for this cosmopolis.
The New York Stock Exchange, in a significant move to facilitate its institutional trading, plans to establish a computer-fed information center for large blocks of stock.
The Federal Maritime Commission has ordered an investigation of container terminal arrangements at the ports of Los Angeles and Oakland.

Vice President David B. Truman of Columbia University recently expressed the view that the war in Vietnam had created the current restlessness among students and that if the war did not end "it is debatable if the university could continue."
KABUL, Afghanistan -- Asia's newest experiment with democracy is approaching a critical juncture in the unlikely setting of this mountainous, landlocked kingdom.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court today ordered a new election under government supervision by a New York City union local that had restricted eligible candidates to those who had held prior office.

An all-male, all-white jury was chosen yesterday to try Herman B. Ferguson, former assistant principal of Public School 40 in Queens, and a co-defendant on a charge that they had conspired to murder Roy Wilkins and Whitney Young, the Negro leaders.

Mead Johnson and Ogilvy Mather will part company officially on Aug. 31. The big brand name involved is Metrecal -- the umbrella covering food and drink dietary products whose advertising ran about $7-million last year.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) -- The Agriculture Department announced today that the Federal Government would operate food-donation programs in 42 counties that refused to handle the program.

SAN FRANCISCO June 3 (AP) -- Roberto Pena singled home an unearned run in the seventh inning and Chris Short hurled a five-hitter today as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the San Francisco Giants, 1-0.
Anger, disappointment and a certain shame were added at Columbia University yesterday to the mixture of emotions that parents feel when a child graduates from college.

PARIS, June 4 -- France went through the 17th day of economic paralysis today. The nationwide strike continued, with only scattered breaks despite the recent appeals and warnings issued by President de Gaulle, Premier Georges Pompidou and other leaders.

About 300 students in light blue academic robes and mortarboards walked out of the Columbia University commencement exercises at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine yesterday to bring to a climax the campus protest that began on April 23.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Bus drivers for this city's transit system have voted to resume night service and to accept a scrip plan for making change.

ROME, June 4 (AP) -- Striking factory workers rioted in Lanciano and new student violence erupted in Turin today while armed policemen kept order at the University of Rome, a scene of turmoil during the weekend.
Harlem residents opened a new cooperative supermarket yesterday to the ooh's and aah's of happy housewives.
PIERRE, S. D., June 4 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy scored a decisive victory today over Vice President Humphrey and Senator Eugene J. McCarthy in South Dakota's Presidential primary.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Americans increased their installment credit by $542-million during April, down slightly from March because of a slowdown in new car sales, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

PLYMOUTH, England, June 4 (AP) -- Lieut. Eric Tabarly of the French Navy, his role as favorite in the trans-Atlantic single-handed yacht race all but gone, set out for a second time today to try to retain the trophy he won four years ago.

IT is not true that inside every bad play there is a good one struggling to get out. But certainly inside every indifferent play there seems to be a far better one at least making a fight of it. With "Daddy Goodness," given last night at the St. Marks Playhouse as the last production of the Negro Ensemble Company's inaugural season, the better play inside offered quite a struggle before finally giving up.
Last season's tryouts will become staples when the new television season gets under way in September.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 4 -- The General Assembly took up today a resolution sponsored by 48 countries calling on the Security Council to use its enforcement powers to end South Africa's administration of South-West Africa.

A police undercover agent testified yesterday that Herman B. Ferguson, the suspended assistant school principal charged with conspiracy to commit murder and anarchy, had mentioned President Johnson as a possible assassination target.

Stockholders of Loew's Theatres, Inc., approved yesterday a management proposal to acquire the common stock of the Commercial Credit Corporation, a Baltimore-based financing, insurance and manufacturing concern.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 4 -Pat Schwab, a 254-pound professional with a sturdy swing, led the Metropolitan District qualifiers for the United States Open golf championship today with a 36-hole aggregate of 141.

PRAGUE, June 4 -- Authoritative Czechoslovak sources said today that Soviet tanks had arrived in a military training area in Moravia to participate in what are officially described as staff exercises of the Warsaw Pact forces.

LOS ANGELES, June 4 -- Senator Thomas H. Kuchel held a sizable but dwindling lead over Dr. Max Rafferty, State Superintendent of Public Instruction, in the slow tallying of California's Republican primary tonight.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 4 (AP) -- Desertions from the South Vietnamese armed forces were nearly 40 per cent above the 1967 rate in the three months after the start of the Vietcong's Lunar New Year offensive this year.

TROON, Scotland, June 4 (AP) -- Mark McCormack, the manager of golf's big three of Arnold Palmer, Jack Nicklaus and Gary Player, led a band of five Americans into the third round of the British Amateur golf championship today.

JERUSALEM, June 4 -- Israeli and Jordanian forces fought a day-long battle across the Jordan River with artillery and aircraft today, on the eve of the first anniversary of the six-day war. Israel reported that her jet fighters had pounded artillery positions on the east bank of the river and had struck at long-range gun emplacements near Irbid, an Arab town about 12 miles east of the cease-fire line.

Regardless of the outcome of yesterday's voting, in California, the primaries have not proved decisive in the selection of this year's Democratic nominee.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- The Bureau of Reclamation said today it had developed an automatic trouble spotter that should help prevent local power failures from becoming widespread blackouts.

RYE, N. Y. June 4 -- Curtis Person, a young whippersnapper by the standards of some of his opponents, took a seven-stroke lead in the first round of the United States Seniors Golf Association championship with a 5-under-par 67.

In his Charles Boyer voice, Bernard Joseph Andre Geoffrion, whose thudding slap-shots earned him the nickname of Boom Boom, predicted, with mixed emotions, that the New York Rangers "can do better and we are going to" following his installation yesterday as the team's coach.
Twice within this past month the United Parents Associations has been attacked in The Times -- editorially on May 8 and by Dr. Kenneth Clark in a news story on May 28.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -President Johnson's chief scientific adviser told leaders of the electric utility industry here today that the Administration's Electric Power Reliability Act was the best possible way to assure uninterrupted electric service for the nation.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- They drove 600 miles from the dairy farms of Appleton, Minn., to the high rises of Chicago, some having left after their chores last night and having arrived here this morning, squinting in the daylight.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -There was a double generation gap between two authors prominent at the American Booksellers' Association convention today. The senior side scored through its representative, Frances Parkinson Keyes, 82 years old, here to discuss her 50th book.
What Columbia University's first rump commencement exercise lacked in dignity yesterday it made up for in color and enthusiasm.
The National Association of Securities Dealers is expected to announce plans soon to close the over-the-counter market on one day a week.
MADRID, June 4 -- The Spanish Government has announced that it will reduce the number of high banking and industry posts that any one person can hold.

TRIPOLI, Libya, May 31 -- The shock and humiliation that swept the Arab world after Israel's victory last June have been replaced by an almost desperate desire for strength, solidarity and, above all, revenge.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- The nation's airlines set new highs in traffic and revenues last year but their profits dropped 3 per cent below 1966 levels, the Air Transport Association said today.

Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the often unconventional analyst of urban problems, deplored the trend toward ethnic quotas in jobs and education in a speech last night at the 32d commencement exercises of the New School for Social Research.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -The Johnson Administration has concluded, "At present we have more to lose than gain" by taking direct action, such as special import surcharges, to try to improve the nation's trade balance, the House Ways and Means Committee was told today.
LONDON, June 4 -- European financial markets had a brighter look today. The franc and the pound strengthened, and the free-market price for gold tumbled to its lowest level in two weeks.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 4 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that Ray C. Bliss, the Republican national chairman, had made "a very great mistake in selecting the platform committee for the party's National Convention.

THE grim and unpublicized routine of the war in Vietnam -- the dangerous assignment of an American company to penetrate the jungle and take Hill 943 -was related with unusual intimacy in last night's news special of the Columbia Broadcasting System.
The Association of Industrial Advertisers has completed a survey of its members to see how they are doing -- financially, that is.

PARIS, June 4 (AP) -- Ion Tiriac, a Rumanian amateur, thrilled an unbelieving crowd of 6,000 at Roland Garros Stadium today by capturing the first two sets against Rod Laver the king of the professionals, in the French open tennis championships. But Laver recovered and won by 4-6, 4-6, 6-3, 6-3, 6-0.
Vice President Humphrey said yesterday that he did not have "the time or the finances to make a full effort" in the June 18 primary in New York State.

An uncommitted slate of New Jersey delegates to the Democratic national convention led by Gov. Richard J. Hughes took a commanding lead last night over an insurgent slate pledged to Senator Eugene J. McCarthy in the state's Democratic primary.
The stock market made its best advance in almost two months yesterday in the third heaviest trading session in history.

GLASSBORO, N. J., June 4 -- Glassboro, some 40 miles east of Wilmington, Del., and 15 miles south of Philadelphia, has changed little since President Johnson and the Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin made it famous in their meetings here last June 23 and 25.

Today is high noon in the House for the omnibus crime-control bill that was overwhelmingly approved by the Senate. As a practical parliamentary matter, it may be the last chance to revise the bill's most objectionable sections.

Now that the primary elections are over, the battle for standing in the popularity polls begins. Senator Kennedy of New York has swept all the primaries he entered except Oregon, including California, which has more votes than all the other primary election states combined, but even so, the battle for convention delegates from now on is likely to be decided by the polls.
The fragile advance in the credit markets of the past week and a half wavered yesterday. Interest rates on major new bond issues were lowered slightly, and then they sold relatively slowly.

HIS wife entered the livingroom part of the suite modeling a casual green dress from Peck Peck. "Like it?" she asked. "Mmmm," he answered, "how much?" This from a man fresh from winning more more than $180,000 last Thursday in the Indianapolis 500.

PARIS -- The tide unloosed by this May's formidable events in France has by no means run its course and although it is difficult yet to discern its true significance it is not at all hard to see that a movement has been started that must ultimately have profound effect.
LONDON June 4 -- Britain's agreement to guarantee Hong Kong against losses from holding sterling as a reserve asset has again spotlighted the question of sterling's future role as a reserve currency.
LOS ANGELES, June 4 (AP) -- Don Drysdale set a major league record of six consecutive shutouts tonight and ran his scoreless-inning string to 54 by defeating the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5-0.
Seven thousand people at the Queens College commencement were told yesterday that the college had undergone a "peaceful revolution" as a result of "responsible student petitioning."
PORTLAND, Ore., June 4 -- The Republican party chose a young Governor, a Negro Senator and two Congressional leaders today as the principal officers for the party's national convention.

BOSTON, June 4 -- Mitchell Goodman, author and teacher, testified today that the antidraft demonstration at the Justice Department in Washington last Oct. 20 was the work of "rank amateurs" rather than the fruit of a conspiracy, as the Government maintains.
Jim Merritt pitched the Minnesota Twins to a 3-0 victory over the New York Yankees last night in another one of those pitching masterpieces that have become routine during baseball's silent spring.
JACKSON, Miss., June 4 (AP) -- Four Democratic Representatives easily won renomination today in Mississippi's primary election. A fifth was unopposed. Voting was light.

DETROIT, Jan. 4 -- The Ford Motor Company reported today strong car sales at the end of May and for the full month. The Ford report, combined with sales announcements by other companies yesterday, showed industry sales last month at a record.

On April 23 Pennsylvania had a Presidential preference primary which Senator McCarthy won by a rather large majority. Yet a news announcement on May 30 revealed that about 100 of Pennsylvania's National Democratic Convention delegates pledged their support to Vice President Humphrey, contrary to the wishes of the electorate.

After five trips to Africa by a social scientist and seven years of preparation here by a corps of artists and artisans, the American Museum of Natural History will open today a permanent exhibition, the Hall of Man in Africa.

LOS ANGELES, Wednesday, June 5 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy was shot and critically wounded by an unidentified gunman this morning just after he made his victory speech in the California primary election.
BIANCO, a designer who has worked at one time or another for Simonetta and Fabiani, Veneziani and Baratta of Rome, is not one to trifle with the established precepts of haute couture.
BALBOA, C. Z., June 4 -Oceangoing ships using the Panama Canal route in the last 11 months have topped the tonnage record set for a full 12-month period a year ago.

" MY wife says that if I use my first initial my name comes out glamour," Griswold Moeller, the city's new Sanitation Commissioner, said yesterday after disclosing, with a slightly embarrassed smile, that his middle name was Lamour.

Supporters of International House are being asked to wear their favorite kimonas, saris and nehru, guru and mao jackets on Friday night at the 10th annual dinner dance benefiting the student center at 500 Riverside Drive.

Investigators were checking yesterday the instrument landing system on Runway 22 at La Guardia Airport, where a jetliner with 102 occupants struck approach lights Monday during an attempted landing in fog.
PARIS, June 4 -- The haute-couture houses are feeling more cheerful today about the prospects for showing their collections in July and August as scheduled.
The Lindsay administration used the opening of three days of budget hearings yesterday to urge again that its controversial neighborhood City Halls program be approved.
QUITO, Ecuador, June 4 -Dr. Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra, the President-elect of Ecuador, said today that his government would have "room for all ideologies."
One of the most satisfying experiences an artist can have is to come upon something produced years ago, look it over with a relatively objective eye and decide that it stands up.

THE Reisinger Knockout Team Championship, an event of great age and high prestige, ended late Monday night in a resounding victory for Ralph Chafetz, Ross Dorfman and John Solodar of New York and Mrs. Barbara Rappaport of East Orange, N. J.

JERUSALEM, June 4 -- A year after her victory in the six-day war, Israel appears determined to maintain her occupation in full until she can conclude treaties with one or all of the defeated Arab states.
NEWARK, June 4 -- The Federal Government announced today that special lowcost disaster loans would be made available to victims of flood damage in seven North Jersey counties.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, June 5 -- The Vietcong fired mortars into the southern edge of Saigon last night as entrenched Vietcong units fought South Vietnamese marine and airborne reinforcements in scattered parts of this uneasy capital.

The United States Smelting Refining and Mining Company said yesterday that a list of shareholders filed at a special meeting in Cleveland of the Clevite Corporation was not the same list given to it by Clevite for the solicitation of proxies.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 4 -- The Government banned public demonstrations, meetings and parades in Belgrade today following two days of fighting between students and the police.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -Tooth decay, a disease that afflicts at least 98 per cent of Americans, may be completely preventable within 10 years, the director of the National Institute of Dental Research said today.

PARIS, June 4 -- North Vietnam's chief military strategist, in an interview published here today, dismissed President Johnson's restrictions of American bombing of North Vietnam five weeks ago as a tactic undertaken for American political and military convenience rather than a gesture toward peace.

Economists for the Irving Trust Company predicted yesterday that a condition of "chronic excess demand" is likely to characterize the American economy over the next five or six years.

ALBANY, June 4 -- All meat processing in New York City will be brought within the control of the state's inspection system under the terms of a bill that Governor Rockefeller has signed.

DEAUVILLE, France, June 10 -- The United States team had a big day in the World Bridge Team Olympiad here today, winning 13-7 against the strong Dutch team and scoring maximum points against Portugal and Sweden.

The Board of Education will meet again today with representatives of the teachers union and the governing board of the Ocean Hill-Brownsville Demonstration School District in another effort to end the dispute that has disrupted classes in the district since May 7.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Governor Rockefeller reopened his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination today with an almost apolitical commencement address and a two-hour visit to the White House.

Andy Warhol, the pop artist and filmmaker who was shot and seriously wounded last Monday, was reported "much better and on his way to complete recovery" yesterday by Dr. Massimo Bazzini, medical director of Columbus Hospital.
A tract of land for an industrial complex that will stretch about a mile along the New Jersey Turnpike in Cranbury Township has been sold to an investing group known as Middlesex-Cranbury Associates.

DON Grant serves as the Grand Vizier for Mrs. Charles Shipman Payson in her New York Met emirate. On a recent plane trip to Chicago, he came up with an idea for splitting the expanded National League into two divisions. His scheme would produce an annual shuffle because the standing of the teams the previous year would determine who lands in which division.

By upholding the right of the Federal Communications Commission to regulate community antenna television systems (CATV), the Supreme Court has given the F.C.C. a green light to safeguard the public's interest in this new technology.

The Allied Stores Corporation has selected Herbert Wittkin, a sales promotion vice president of its marketing and buying subsidiary, to become president of Stern Brothers, Allied's New York store division.

The Woodward Corporation, a producer of iron, coal, coke and other materials, has another suitor -- the Jim Walter Corporation, Tampa, Fla., home builder, producer of building materials and other interests. Last week, Combustion Engineering, Inc. made a bid for Woodward.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Supreme Court struck down today a section of the New York City Charter that requires the dismissal of public employes who refuse to sign waivers of immunity from prosecution before testifying to a grand jury.

Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, who performed a signal public service by ousting Charles A. Buckley from Congress four years ago, is in danger of losing his seat in next Tuesday's Democratic primary. That danger arises out of the outrageous gerrymander of the 23rd Congressional District, perpetrated by a bipartisan coalition in the Legislature last winter.
LEVITTOWN, L.I., June 10 -Six thousand pupils in public schools in this school district were sent home this morning after teachers went on strike in a dispute over a new contract.

The Ford Foundation announced yesterday 18 grants totaling almost $5-million to go to public television stations and networks -- including Channel 13 in New York -- under its recently announced Project for New Television Programming.

DETROIT, June 10 -- Bishop Dwight E. Loder, Methodist Bishop of Michigan, today denouunced a local television station for withdrawing a series of programs on the racial crisis from prime viewing time on Monday evenings.
The Fluor Corporation, Ltd., the Los Angeles-based engineering and construction company, had lower sales and earnings in the quarter and six months ended April 30, the report disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (Reuters) -- The Supreme Court limited the liability of Air France today to $8,300 a person in a crash at Orly Airport, Paris, that killed 130 persons, most of them from Atlanta.

Despite pleas by Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the Soviet author, against publication of his works abroad without his personal authorization, Western publishers are preparing to come out with translations of two of the novels.

Kennedy. The program, seen locally over Channel 13, was not always a model of clear organization, but noncommercial TV did demonstrate how foresight and alertness can shorten the delay between the time a news issue arises and its documentary presentation on the home screen.
TOKYO, June 10 -- The Japanese Government advised Japanese in South Vietnam today to leave the country because of the intensification of fighting in and around Saigon.

LONDON, June 10 -- Bow Street Magistrates' Court issued today a provisional extradition warrant on the ground of murder, the first step toward bringing James Earl Ray to trial in Memphis, Tenn., for the slaying of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

The trans - Siberian land bridge so far has not posed a serious competitive threat to the North American land bridge for the movement of container cargoes between the Far East and Europe, a transportation industry official said yesterday.

PARIS, June 10 -- Ambassador W. Averell Harriman, the chief American negotiator, returned to Paris tonight after meeting with President Johnson this weekend and sounded a note of caution about the next stage of negotiations with North Vietnam.

After a brief and uneasy truce, the Bronx's regular Democratic organization and its Reform Democrats are waging another bitter battle for control of the party machinery. The Reformers' prospects for winning control in the June 18 primary are not considered good.

Miss Moorman was arrested on the same stage on Feb. 9, 1967, for playing a cello in public in such a way as to incite men to temporary insanity -- topless, that is -- as part of Nam June Paik's "Mixed Media Opera."

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Rebel dealers in the Midas International Corporation's chain of muffler shops won Supreme Court backing today in their battle to loosen the restrictions imposed by their franchise agreements.

Saigon, South Vietnam, Tuesday, June 11 -- At least 15 rocket rounds smashed into downtown Saigon shortly after dawn today, hitting several apartment houses and stores.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -Just before the Oregon primary, Senator Eugene McCarthy committed what appeared to be a classic political goof. Although his staff later said it was a joke that didn't come off, McCarthy remarked that even in the primaries he had lost to Robert Kennedy there was the consolation that the well-educated were voting for McCarthy while those with less education were backing Kennedy.

An obscure dispute between the Justice Department and the First National City Bank has become a cause celebre in international banking that could, bankers say, seriously harm both their foreign business and the nation's balance-of-payments position.

PARIS, June 10 -- Ballgowns never worn before, new coats knocked down $500 and dozens of suits and dresses were snatched off the racks today at Givenchy, squashed into big, pale brown paper bags and whisked away, often on the subway.

The stock market ended mixed yesterday after profit taking in the afternoon erased many of the earlier gains.

The United States Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that a civilian rather than a military court should decide whether to discharge a young Navy man who said he became a conscientious objector after enlisting in the service.

MOSCOW, June l0 -- Sergei P. Pavlov, leader of the Young Communist League, was appointed today to a nonpolitical job as head of Soviet athletic activities.

A Supreme Court jury of 12 men yesterday found James E. Branigan not guilty of manslaughter in the death of Police Lieut. Edward J. Drum.

Prices advanced in reduced trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

A plea to the four major Presidential candidates to avoid the Arab-Israeli conflict as a campaign issue was voiced yesterday by the Action Committee on American-Arab Relations.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) -- The Navy presented the Medal of Honor today to the skipper of the U.S.S. Liberty, which was nearly destroyed by Israeli warplanes and torpedo boats in the Mediterranean Sea last year.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that extensive city investigations had produced no evidence of wrongdoing by any of his past or present commissioners except James L. Marcus.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- An industrialist and spokesman for one of the nation's leading trade-policy committees said today the American consumer would pay a heavy price if Congress took a protectionist stance by imposing import quotas.
The honorary degree of Doctor of Science was awarded by the Rockefeller University yesterday to Dr. J. George Harrar, an author, biologist and the president of the Rockefeller Foundation.
MONTREAL, June 11 (AP) -- A flurry of deals before tomorrow's intraleague draft marked the National Hockey League's annual meeting today. The champion Montreal Canadiens were involved in five.

DETROIT, June 11 (UPI) -Tom Matchick scored on Cesar Tovar's wild throw with two out in the ninth inning tonight to give the Detroit Tigers a 3-2 victory over the Minnesota Twins and a sweep of a double-header. Jim Price drove in two runs in a 3-1 triumph in the opening game.
BERLIN, June 11 -- East Germany introduced a set of traffic regulations today requiring West Germans traveling to and from West Berlin to obtain transit visas to cross East German territory.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman, stressing he had developed a deeper awareness of poverty in America urged today a $100-million increase in food-stamp funds.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
BOGOTA, Colombia, June 12 -- The Senate, by a vote of 74 to 31, refused early today to accept President Carlos Lleras Restrepo's resignation from office.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 12 -- Eldridge Cleaver, the Black Panther leader, was released from the California medical facility prison at Vacaville this afternoon on a court order that criticized the cancellation of his parole.
PRAGUE, June 12 -- Czechoslovakia will enact soon, perhaps this month, the most liberal travel law in the Soviet bloc.

The Rev. Dr. Ernest T. Campbell, who as a boy played baseball on what was to be the site of Riverside Church, was formally approved last night as the new preaching minister of the church, at Riverside Drive and 122d Street.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Federal Government charged eight state agencies in Alabama today with employment discrimination against Negroes in the first suit of its kind ever brought against a state.
Strange as it may seem to the unscientific mind, warm weather makes healthy women all over the United States break out with an increasingly common ailment known as "minkitis."

ATHENS, June 12 -- Greece said today that the draft of a new constitution that is to be submitted to a plebiscite next September will be "one of the most democratic and progressive charters in Europe."
ATLANTA, June 12 (AP) -- Twenty-one hostages walked out free and unharmed today from the Federal Penitentiary after 28 hours under the guns of four long-term prisoners.
A heavy downpour yesterday rained out the 43d commencement exercises of Brooklyn College.
Governor Rockefeller is having difficulty finding a successor to the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy from among his top choices.

Victor Muscat, the financier who once headed Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., was indicted in Federal District Court yesterday on charges of lying about $385,000 in loans to the company's law firm, Saxe, Bacon Bolan.

BRISTOL, England, June 12 (AP) -- Three top United States players -- Charlie Pasarell, Arthur Ashe and Cliff Richey -- overcame stubborn opposition today and reached the quarterfinals of the West of England lawn tennis championship.

A FEW months ago Paul J., 15 years old, was regarded as the "holy terror" of his Bronx neighborhood. He screamed at his parents, terrorized his younger brother so often that the boy began hiding in closets, and hung out with the toughest boys on the block.
VINEYARD SOUND, Mass., June 12 -- "It looks like the moon," said Luciano Rebay when the bleak, eastern tip of Pasque Island, one of the Elizabeths, showed dimly through the swirling fog.

Plans for about 5,800 units of new and rehabilitated housing in four blighted areas were approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission. Approval by the Board of Estimate is required before the action is final.

WHEN the Robert Herrmanns sit down to eat on their family boat, the Why Not, a 16-foot Boston whaler, you'd think they were on a luxury liner. The menu might include veal with truffles, cheese pancakes with creamed fish or lobster Grand Marnier with herbed rice.
The Marcus kickback conspiracy trial was adjourned yesterday until tomorrow morning because of the illness of a defense lawyer.

LOS ANGELES, June 12 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller of New York said today that he would welcome a nationally televised debate with Richard M. Nixon, his opponent for the Republican Presidential nomination.

Laird Properties, Inc., a realty firm, has leased 8,500 square feet of space in the Bankers Trust Building annex, which is rising on the block bounded by Park and Madison Avenues and 48th and 49th Streets.
The first thing Mrs. Bea Rubin baked in the oven at the Alfred E. Smith Recreation Center was a fierce African mask, green and blue and white. It cracked, giving it a nice look of antiquity.

HIS enemies liken him to a little Napoleon. His friends admire his cool exposition of complex issues. To all, as an acquaintance observed yesterday, Gaston Francois Marie Eyskens is "very much the professor."

Despite his brutish appearance, the Neanderthal man seems to have been sensitive to some of the more tender aspects of life.

BERKELEY, Calif., june 12 -- Forget that Jim Ryun, Richmond Flowers and Frank Murphy are sidelined by injury and illness. Forget that there is little speculation about the team title because Southern California seems sure to repeat.
HARRISBURG, Pa., June 12 -- The State Senate passed a House-approved bill today to provide aid to private and parochial schools. The vote was 30 to 17, with 25 required for passage.

Heavy fog and rain failed to deter the contestants in the 31st metropolitan public links championships from starting out on their two appointed rounds yesterday. Thunder and lightening, however, did. This combination brought the one-day competition a halt.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 12 -- President Johnson told the General Assembly today that its approval of a treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons obligated the the United States and the Soviet Union to move rapidly on other disarmament negotiations.

BERLIN, June 12 -- Mayor Klaus Schutz blamed the Soviet Union today for the new East German curbs on travel to and from West Berlin and called on the Western allies to safeguard West Berlin's lifelines and freedom of access.

The nation's mutual savings banks had a net gain of $310-million in deposits during May, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday. This was down 29 per cent from the $439-million last year in May, but more than double the inflow of $115-million in May, 1966.

CAPETOWN, June 12 (UPI) -- Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard arrived here today from London and rushed to the bedside of Dr. Philip Blaiberg, the world's longest-surviving heart transplant patient, who was suddenly stricken earlier this week with a liver ailment.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said today that unless Vice President Humphrey altered his position on the Vietnam war he would find it very difficult to support him as the Democratic Presidential nominee.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Sentiment in the Senate, apparently swayed by an outpouring of public protests over the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, began shifting significantly today toward the adoption of stricter controls over the sale and possession of guns.
In the days since the death of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, former Kennedy campaign workers and other supporters have been volunteering their services to the McCarthy camp in a steady flow.

A group opposed to smoking filed a petition yesterday with the Federal Communications Commission seeking revocation of the broadcasting license of WNBC-TV (Channel 4) for its alleged failure to air a sufficient number of antismoking messages.
LONDON, June 12 (AP) -- Yachtsmen were reported making no headway in the single-handed trans-Atlantic race today amid 100-mile-an-hour gusts and mountainous seas.

SYRACUSE, June 12 (AP) -- Coaches agreed today that about the only thing standing between Pennsylvania crews and a sweep of the 66th annual Intercollegiate Rowing Association championships was the weather.
KEY WEST, Fla., June 12 (AP) -- William Henry Nelson, an American who defected to Cuba in 1963, was picked up on a raft by the United States Coast Guard today after having fled Cuba.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- A proposed resolution by the United States Conference of Mayors criticizing President Johnson on Vietnam and "months of inactivity" on the report of the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders deadlocked the conference's resolutions committee today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 12 (UPI) -- An error by Bill Mazeroski permitted Hal Lanier to score with the run that enabled Bob Bolin to win his first game as a starting pitcher in more than a year today and give the San Francisco Giants a 4-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
Restoration of stability in world financial markets largely depends on whether Congress votes to increase taxes and cut Government spending, Pierre-Paul Schweitzer said here yesterday.

The "Promenade" at Philharmonic Hall last night was "International," and at one point went as far afield as Japan. That nation was represented by an exotic ceremonial piece, "Etenraku," which means "Music Coming Through From Heaven."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 12 (Reuters) -- South Vietnam announced a series of restrictions today on reporting Vietcong rocket attacks -- aimed at Saigon for the ninth successive day today.
LONDON, June 12 (AP) -- Two small, privately owned airlines, British Eagle and Caledonian, were refused Government permission today to open trans-Atlantic routes.

It is an old axiom in the history of Federal regulation that an industry with a big enough financial stake can bring to bear much more political weight to weaken or evade regulation than the general consuming public can exercise in its own protection. The cynical action of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee on the natural gas pipeline safety bill is the latest depressing proof of that axiom.

NEWARK, June 12 -- An effort to unify this city's Negro community behind Negro candidates for two City Council openings will be made at a "Black Political Convention" to be held here from June 21 to June 23.
VERONA, N. J., June 12 -- The Board of Education of this virtually all-white suburban community voted, 41 to 1, last night to open its elementary schools to as many as 40 youngsters from Newark.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- Prospects that Governor Rockefeller will be able to win support from the Illinois delegation to the Republican National Convention appeared bleak today as the counting ended in yesterday's primary election.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- "What do we want?" shouted the Rev. Ralph David Abernathy.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI) -- President Johnson proposed today that the Government begin developing new electronically controlled vehicles for commuters.

The prosecution in the murder conspiracy trial of Herman B. Ferguson introduced as evidence yesterday a third pistol alleged to have been acquired by a three-man black "terrorist cell" to assassinate Roy Wilkins and Whitney M. Young Jr., the civil rights leaders.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 12 -- A hairline fracture of the left hind pastern, an area just above the hoof, forced Irving W. Berkemeyer's Dazzling Speed out of tomorrow night's seventh annual Realization Trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

MASTER J. CURDO of Chelmsford, Mass., a perennial titleholder in the Greater Boston chess area, captured first place in the recent Weaver Adams Memorial tourney in Boston, scoring 4-1. Four players in the 10-man, five-round Swiss scored 3-2 each to tie for second place.
BRUSSELS, June 12 -- King Baudouin today named Dr. Gaston Eyskens, a 63-year-old American-trained economist, to form a Cabinet and end the country's longest postwar Government crisis.
LEVITTOWN, L. I., June 12 -- A two-day strike by teachers in the Island Trees School District ended this morning when the teachers and the school board reached agreement on terms for a new contract.
THE ancient Ibizan breed of fast, agile hounds from the Balearic Islands will become eligible to compete in the miscellaneous class at dog shows on July 1.

The National General Corporation announced yesterday it had recently acquired 400,000 common shares, or about 7 per cent of the outstanding stock of the Great American Holding Corporation. Great American has approximately 6,229,000 shares outstanding.
SAN JOSE, Calif., June 12 (AP) -- Tracy Smith of the Army was an easy victor in the 5,000-meter run at the interservice track and field championships today. His time was 14 minutes 23.2 seconds.
LONDON, June 12 -- When Daniel Cohn-Bendit, the French student leader, was asked today whether he had come to Britain to galvanize the students of Britain into action he replied: "I am not Superman."
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Senate passed today a bill to give Congressional approval to the Great Lakes Basin Compact.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Senate Banking Committee moved today to strike down fixed sales charges on mutual fund shares and force these commissions to be set by competitive forces alone.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Hotels, restaurants and other local business in the Chicago and Miami areas will be able to take the normal tax deduction of the cost of advertisements placed in programs of the national political party conventions.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- A chemical that is thought to be important in the function of the nervous system has been detected in brain tissue for the first time, two scientists said today.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., June 12 -- Henry Carr, an enigmatic athlete whose earlier feats as an Olympic sprinter exceeded his football achievements, was traded by the New York Giants to the Baltimore Colts today in exchange for Barry Brown, a linebacker.

COLOGNE, West Germany, Thursday, June 13 (AP) -- Jupp Elze, West German middleweight champion, was in critical condition early today after he was stopped by Carlos Duran of Italy, who retained his European title last night on a technical knockout.

A group of parents on the Upper West Side announced yesterday that they would elect a governing board to plan a new decentralized school district despite the project's disavowal by the Board of Education.

BONN, June 12 -- After a day of internal debate and consultations with the Allies, the West German Government issued a declaration stating its agreement with Washington, Paris and London on "procedures" to be taken to ward off East Germany's latest restrictions.
LISBON, June 12 -- A 60-year-old convention between the United States and Portugal would have complicated the extradition of James Earl Ray had he been arrested when he was in Lisbon last month.
I don't know when commencement speakers will get around to denouncing baseball. Today's antic novel may happily postpone that day.

LONDON, June 12 -- The French franc came under renewed pressure today as European foreign-exchange markets were unsettled by the rioting in Paris and provincial centers. The London gold price climbed sharply, then relaxed. Sterling improved. Dealers were weighing the financial crosscurrents as central bankers and finance officials crisscrossed Europe for various meetings, making grave statements about the continued monetary problems.

PITTSBURGH, June 12 (UPI) -- The United Steelworkers Union opened preliminary contract talks today with the U.S. Steel Corporation and the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation here. The union initiated talks with nine other steel producers earlier this week.

SHRUB OAK, N. Y., June 12 -- The voters of the Lakeland School District, a fast-growing residential area that spreads across six towns of Westchester and Putnam Counties, approved a school budget last night that was larger than one they had rejected as extravagant on May 8.
President Johnson was taken to the United Nations yesterday in a most unusual way for Presidents -- in an unmarked police car.

A 65-year-old railroad car cleaner, employed for the last five years by the Long Island Rail Road in its Port Washington yards, was murdered at 4:10 A.M. yesterday by a mugger who took $10 from his wallet.

Francisco (Pancho) Rosales, the manager of Manuel Ramos, filed an emotional but unsuccessful appeal to the New York Athletic Commission yesterday, asking that a Mexican judge and a neutral referee be assigned to the world heavy-weight title fight between Joe Frazier and the Mexican challenger.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The United States Food and Drug Administration was charged today with "arbitrarily" blocking substantial development of the United States fishing industry.
LOS ANGELES, June 12 -- The Mets scored twice in the ninth inning tonight to beat Don Drysdale and the Dodgers, 2-1.

MONTREAL, June 12 -- Dave Balon, the Minnesota North Stars' top draft choice in last year's expansion hockey draft, is returning to the New York Rangers, where he began his National Hockey League career nine years ago.
PARIS, June 12 -- The sympathy felt by many Parisians for the student revolution here is changing to deep uneasiness and even fear.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Rumania is sending one of her highest leaders on an official visit to the United States next week.

SYRACUSE, June 13 -- The varsity crews of Pennsylvania, Northeastern and Washington qualified today on windy Lake Onondaga for Saturday's finals of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's annual championship regatta.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- An attempt to add $52-million for summer jobs to a $400-million highway funding bill failed in the Senate today.
EAST LANSING, Mich., June 13 -- The black flag of anarchy and the red flag of revolution fluttered down the aisle today amid the mild cheers of student radicals.

A butcher, a contractor who employed nonunion labor and restaurateur testified yesterday that they had joined a construction helpers' union at the urging of an ex-convict delegate who extolled the advantages of the union's health and pension programs.
TRACY, Minn., June 13 (AP) -- At least seven persons were reported killed when a tornado ripped into this southwestern Minnesota town tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The United States, Britain and France were reported today to be considering a coordinated diplomatic appeal to the Soviet Union to help ease the tension over Berlin.

PARIS, Friday, June 14 -- Col. Charles Lacheroy, who was condemned to death for his role in the military uprising against President de Gaulle in 1961, was permitted yesterday to return to France, a free man.

Three Manhattan accountants were charged in Federal Court yesterday with conspiring to to bribe an agent of the Internal Revenue Service to thwart collection of $513,794 in income taxes owed by their clients.

New River George found the swampy footing at Belmont so much to his liking yesterday that he sloshed to a convincing success in the $11,400 Annapolis hurdles race for 3-yearolds.

A teamster union official asserted yesterday that the city had sharply increased the rate at which it accepted applications for welfare in the last two years, compared with the preceding two years, and formally called for a City Council investigation.
LONDON, June 13 -- Student leaders from 10 countries, appearing on a British television program tonight, denounced elections as a means of bringing about change and expressing the will of the people.

ROCHESTER, June 13 -- Bert Yancey had just taken the first-round lead in the United States Open championship with a handsome 67 when he came face to face with Lee Trevino, who hadn't done badly himself with a 69. Automatically, Yancey began to laugh. Trevino breaks him up.

LONDON, June 13 -- For the first time in recent memory, a child was baptized this week in the River Thames near Tilbury, a grimy port area just east of London. It was another sign that I London's river is becoming cleaner every year through the increasing efforts of the Port of London Authority and the Greater London Council.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Mayor Lindsay said today that he had "not closed the door" on accepting appointment to the Senate. The Mayor talked about the Senate at a news conference, called 12 hours after he had received a late night telephone call from Governor Rockefeller suggesting they get together to discuss a successor to the late Robert F. Kennedy.

Rain may dampen the park grounds but not the enthusiasm or loyalty of Metropolitan Opera fans. DARIEN, Conn., June 13 -After a week of solid rest, Peggy Steinman's Not Always, the defending national highpoint champion, captured two classes and went into the lead for the regular working hunter championship of the Ox Ridge Horse Show today.

The Federal Reserve kept the nation's credit markets on a tight rein during the week ended Wednesday, banking figures published yesterday showed. But, as has been the case for the past two months, the money managers did nothing to increase the degree of monetary restraint.
Volume broke through to a record yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, but prices sagged in late trading.

PARIS -- Averell Harriman, head of the U.S. delegation seeking to arrange a Vietnam peace in Paris, is the most experienced negotiator in today's world and, incidentally, one of the most long-enduring public servants in American history.

LONDON, June 13 -- The riots in France led unexpectedly last night to a treat for British ballet-lovers, namely Margot Fonteyn's first appearance here in a role previously confined to her European guest performances.

Four men were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury here on a charge of making illegal short sales of 4,900 shares of Georgia-Pacific Corporation in April, 1966.
TRENTON, June 13 -- A 1-cent increase in New Jersey's gasoline tax and a 1 per cent increase in the state's corporate income tax cleared the Legislature today.

City Controller Mario A. Procaccino argued in State Supreme Court yesterday that the city was justified in withholding payment of money due on several jobs completed by S. T. Grand, Inc., because the contracts might prove to be "tainted."

LONDON, June 13 -- A Royal Commission reported today that British labor relations were tending toward indecision and anarchy. But it rejected, as a solution, suggested legal curbs on the local, wildcat strikes that hobble British industry.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -The Securities and Exchange Commission, for the first time considered today the suspension of a securities firm for allegedly inadequate recordkeeping in a case in which there was no accusation of fraud.

It's hard to say who's in the more enviable situation, one who is seeing the show for the first time or one who is having it intensively recalled after a 4 or 12 year lapse. Either way, it makes lovely, light summer fare.
