LONDON, June 13 -- Maj. Alistair Wicks, former recruiter of white mercenary soldiers for the Congo, explained in an interview today why he believed James Earl Ray, the accused slayer of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., was so desperately eager to see him.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 13 -Lloyd Lloyds of Kings Point, L. I., the owner of Flamboyant, is not a gambler. However, having gone along with the nothing ventured - nothing - gained gambler's credo by paying $10,000 to make his mare a supplementary starter in tonight's $99,561 Realization Trot, Lloyds wound up with a handsome profit as the daughter of Florican captured the seventh edition of the 11/16-mile event for 4-year-olds at Roosevelt Raceway.
The U.S. Supreme Court has extended the constitutional right to a trial by jury in state criminal proceedings in a case called Duncan v. Louisiana. [Times, May 21; editorial, May 23.]

Roy M. Goodman, former City Finance Administrator now seeking the Republican nomination for the State Senate, filed a complaint with the Fair Campaign Practices Committee yesterday accusing his opponent of conducting "a vicious smear campaign in which he is employing guilt-by-association tactics."

The mediation team representing Theodore W. Kheel in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville school district dispute over the dismissal of teachers declined its first assignment yesterday. It refused to decide which eteachers should be tentatively returned to their classrooms.

With the opening yesterday of the Board of Education's new computer center, any parent or passer-by can stroll through a doorway at 229 East 42d Street, sit at the keyboard of a small, shiny student terminal, and try his skill at mathematics as it is now studied by 6,000 elementary school students here.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -President Johnson addressed still another public appeal for cooperation to the Soviet Union today -- his third in 10 days -despite Moscow's insistence that the war in Vietnam be ended first.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, said today that new airline routes across the Pacific recommended by a Civil Aeronautics Board examiner were "completely inadequate" to meet the examiner's findings and comments.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -Cyrus Eaton, the Cleveland industrialist, who has just returned from conversations in Moscow and other capitals, said today: "We are on the threshold of peace in Vietnam."

The prosecution in the murder conspiracy trial of Herman B. Ferguson rested its case yesterday, after calling Roy Wilkins, one of the two civil rights leaders allegedly marked for death, and three detectives as witnesses.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 13 -- The National Collegiate Athletic Associations 47th annual outdoor track and field championships began today the same way the last two began -- with a victory by 120-pound Gerry Lindgren of Washington State.
A five-pound premature baby girl born with a bullet in her body was in critical condition yesterday at Kings County Hospital -- but not because of the bullet.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13 -- In its first commencement held indoors because of rain since 1922, Harvard University today conferred 4,113 academic degrees and 11 honorary doctorates, including a Doctor of Laws degree to Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran.

The Democratic state chairman said yesterday that one of the candidates for his party's nomination for Senator was "a disgrace to our delegation in Washington."

A 22-year-old draft resister, who failed to appear in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday morning after having refused induction on March 4, was arrested as he sat at the altar of the Washington Square United Methodist Church in Greenwich Village.

Prices rose slightly throughout the credit markets yesterday. Although trading activity remained light, there was a growing conviction, both in New York and in Washington, that the tax bill would pass next week.
The Keystone Shipping Company of Philadelphia has awarded a contract to the Bethlehem Steel Corporation for the construction of a 37,250-ton, multiparcel chemical tanker.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.
An 18-foot killer whale with a mouth the size of a small wheelbarrow got her teeth brushed at the Coney Island Aquarium yesterday.
Prices on the London stock market made a fairly broad advance yesterday led by industrial issues, reversing a recent easing trend.

BOSTON, June 13 (UPI) -- Bubba Morton's pinch single sparked a three-run rally in the eighth inning today as the California Angels defeated the Boston Red Sox, 4-2, in the first game of a double-header and handed Jim Lonborg his first loss of the season

BUDAPEST, June 13 -- Hungary's Communist leaders, headed by Janos Kadar, hailed a top-level Czechoslovak delegation led by Alexander Dubcek as it arrived here today. The warmth of the greeting was Mr. Kadar's way of demonstrating to the world, and especially to other East European countries, that he and Hungary fundamentally approve of the democratization process conducted by Mr. Dubcek in Czechoslovakia since January.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13 -- In a laboratory filled with glass and metal vats brimming with microscopic life, scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology here are brewing what may become the food proteins of the future.
Leonard H. Goldenson, president of the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., is considering steps the A.B.C. television network might take to curb violence in next fall's program schedule.

The Festival Orchestra Society, one of 61 symphonic groups picked to share in the Ford Foundation's $80.2-million matching grant program in 1966, suspended operation yesterday. A debt of $22,500 from the season just past must be met immediately, according to Stephen Benedict, president of the society, which has presented about 10 concerts a year in New York since its formaton in 1963.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 13 -- While a large majority voted in the General Assembly yesterday for the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons, many serious obstacles remain before the agreement can become effective.
TORONTO, June 13 -- The police cleared the mysterious "fat man" today of any conspiratorial effort to help James Earl Ray. accused as the killer of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
A dollar may be a dollar usually, but through June 24 a certain type of paper dollar, marked with the words "silver certificate," is more than that.
SCHEHERAZADE, Arabian nights and all that Eastern jazz to the contrary, there were still plenty of sober, sensible clothes shown for fall on Seventh Avenue this week.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- A family-to-family program to aid the underprivileged Negroes of the District of Columbia has been started by 350 Washington Negroes who refer to themselves as nonpoor or gainfully employed.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended June 8 were both above the volume in the corresponding week of 1967.

DEAUVILLE, France, June 13 -- The United States team maintained its position among the leaders during today's play here in the World Team Olympiad. A 10-10 draw with Chile in the 20th round was sandwiched between victories over Lebanon 20-0 and Brazil 19-1.

THE Rev. Dr. Ernest Thomas Campbell, who was named preaching minister of Riverside Church on Wednesday night, believes that his new church "has a singular reputation for ministering to the whole man -- body, mind and spirit."

WHAT more fitting day for it to happen? The same day the Big Board tore up the record book as volume pushed through the roof to 21.35 million shares, brokers put together the biggest deal in the history of the exchange.

The New York Urban Coalition announced yesterday that it had passed the halfway mark in its campaign to raise $4-million from private sources for its program to improve the quality of life in the city.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, June 14 -- A handful of rockets crashed into Tansonnhut Air Base shortly before dawn today as Saigon passed another restless night awaiting the explosion of shells amid its homes and shops.

LONDON, June 13 -- American and other foreign banks in Britain have indicated they are willing to deposit some of the sterling they hold with the Bank of England. The arrangement would give the central bank a sensitive instrument for controlling sterling loans.
Speculative fever on the New York Stock Exchange drove trading volume to its highest level in history yesterday.

PARIS, June 13 -- More than two years ago in the jungles northwest of Saigon, a North Vietnamese general is reported to have said at a meeting of Vietcong leaders: "In fighting while negotiating, the side that fights more strongly will compel the adversary to accept its conditions."
BERLIN, June 13 -- Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger flew to West Berlin today in a show of solidarity with the city in the face of renewed East German pressure.

The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange chalked up their heaviest trading on record yesterday as a speculative fever continued to grip the securities markets. Leading market averages showed modest declines.

LOS ANGELES, June 13 -- A woman in a polka-dot dress was huddled with Sirhan Bishara Sirhan in the Ambassador Hotel pantry just before Senator Robert F. Kennedy was shot, a principal witness has testified.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 -- Ernest C. Arbuckle, who by design has switched occupations about every 10 years, was elected chairman today of the Wells Fargo Bank, the country's 11th largest. Its resources approach $5-billion.
HONG KONG, June 12 -- A new form of anti-communism has come into being in China, expressed by young radicals disenchanted with 17 years of rule by Communist bureaucrats.
Yale University and the trustees of the National Gallery of Art disposed of a total of 693,411 common shares of the Gulf Oil Corporation yesterday in a secondary offering valued at $52.4-million.
ROCHESTER, June 13 -- The younger pros wore tapered cuffless slacks in pastel shades, but Sam Snead's pants were navy blue, wider and cuffed.
ROCHESTER, June 13 -- Bert Yancey, a former West Point cadet, marched into the first-round lead of the United States Open golf championship with a 67 today.

" We couldn't retail our campaign, like direct mailing, that sort of thing, in Indiana and California," Senator Eugene J. McCarthy recalled yesterday. "Ours was pretty much wholesale, in the public forum. We didn't have the money when we needed it.

Loew's Theaters, Inc., said yesterday that the registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for its tender offer to stockholders of the Commercial Credit Company became effective yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 13 -- The current wave of rocket attacks on Saigon has posed major political problems for the Government and has raised outcries against the United States for restricting the bombing in North Vietnam.

Litton Industries, Inc., the West Coast conglomerate, is expanding its interests in the publishing field through the $33-million proposed acquisition of Chapman-Reinhold, Inc., Oradell, N. J., magazine publishers.

The questioning of the last few days about who would be the heir of Robert Kennedy's delegate strength is ended. By an overwhelming majority Hubert Humphrey is heir apparent. (Times June 10.) But why Humphrey?

LONDON, June 13 -- For seven years in a row now the United States has won the Wightman Cup women's tennis competitions with Britain. They have proved formalities when played at home and cliffhangers over the odd years when the action has been here on the No. 1 court, the world's fastest grass surface.
For the next three months a new system of street loading will be tried in the traffic-choked garment district.

BOSTON, June 13 -- Assistant United States Attorney John Wall closed his summary arguments today in the case against five men accused of conspiring to violate the draft laws, saying, "The Government wins every case in which justice is done."

WASHINGTON, June 13 -While the nation's railroads complained here today of their dire need for a $461-million-ayear increase in freight rates, the Administration complained to the Interstate Commerce Commission that the carriers "have not made a case at all" for higher rates.
If you've been wondering why we've had so much rain for the last three days, it all stemmed from a low pressure area that lingered over New York until late yesterday afternoon.

BOULDER, Colo., June 13 -- Several hundred hippies in flower-painted Volkswagen buses have invaded areas just west of here with the explanation that the world is going to end this weekend and that the only safe places to make the scene are Boulder and Tibet.
DETROIT, June 13 -- The American Motors Corporation will sell its Kelvinator appliance division to White Consolidated Industries, Inc., the companies said today.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Diners Fugazy Sales Coop. said today that it would go ahead with plans to convert the 14,136-ton American Export Isbrandtsen Lines passenger ship Atlantic into the nation's first traveling trade fair ship.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 13 (UPI) -- The Government decreed limited martial law today to cope with a wave of strikes by civil servants and rapidly spreading student unrest.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) -- The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy stood outside the Agriculture Department today and told his followers that cutting the cost of food stamps did not help the man with an empty stomach and an empty wallet.
Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said yesterday that he believed the country would accept a "unilateral withdrawal" of United States forces from Vietnam to end the war.
BERLIN, June 14 -- The East Germans warned today of further harassments following their renewed pressure on land travel to and from West Berlin.

The reflecting pool in front of the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center still leaks. After almost three years of efforts to stanch the flow, nobody in authority quite knows what to make of the mystery.
THE National Broadcasting Company provided viewers last night with a front-row seat at "The Art Game," a popular pastime boasting features common to professional football and the stock market.

For the second time within sixty days an assassin's bullet has lowered the nation's flag. Hopefully, the echo of this blast will arouse Congress from its lethargic state to enact the gun-control legislation proposed by President Johnson.
ROCHESTER, June 14 -- Playing cautiously and putting brilliantly, Bert Yancey retained the lead today in the United States Open golf championship with a record-equaling total of 135.
Two of the city's social welfare administrators called yesterday for state permission to extend the experimental Employment Incentive Program for public-assistance recipients.

Congress has come to the aid of the parties in this election year by opening a crack in the door it supposedly closed two years ago against evasions of the Corrupt Practices Act. Both Senate and House have quietly passed a bill to repeal the present ban on tax deductions for advertising in the programs at national political conventions.

ALTHOUGH you would not normally think of these two novels together, they share certain attributes. Both are short, tightly composed, not overwritten. They say what they have to in the allotted space, without padding, without spilling over into unrelated topics. And the subjects are unusual in the sense that they are not frequently encountered in the world of fiction.
Three Reform Democrats who had supported the Presidential campaign of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy announced yesterday they would now support Senator Eugene McCarthy.
A bitter industry battle with undercurrents of inter-company spying and overtones of the comic-strip Superman appears to be shaping up among light-bulb manufacturers.

Last week, prompted by our latest act of burgeoning insanity, I turned my own hand-gun over to the police. It had been legally purchased and duly registered many years ago, but, from a cherished and well-cared-for possession (firearms have been part of our family life for generations), it had become an ugly thing; the symbol of an attitude of which I want no part, even by association.
PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- Dr. Gunnar Myrdal warned here today that the United States and the rest of the world were in danger of committing suicide unless the problems of war and poverty were solved.

Until the Rod Rodgers Company appeared there was something to yawn at, something to admire, but not much to enjoy in last night's festival series presentation of the Clark Center for the Performing Arts

Edgardo Sosa, a baritone whose career began with the State Opera of Uruguay, who has lived and performed in Los Angeles and San Francisco, and who has had an appearance here with the Little Orchestra Society, made his recital debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
Secretary of State Dean Rusk discussed yesterday with Soviet officials the West Berlin crisis and other Soviet-United States problems.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 14 (AP) -- An anonymous gift of $12.5-million to Harvard University, the fourth largest gift in its 332-year history, will enable the school to build a center for undergraduate teaching of science.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) -- The Washington Redskins obtained Gary Beban, last year's Heisman Trophy winner, from the Los Angeles Rams today and signed Pat Fischer, St. Louis Cardinal defensive back, as a free agent.
RECENTLY, an antiques dealer from Greenwich, Conn., received $1,400 at the Plaza Auction Galleries on East 79th Street for an oak chest. He was pleased because he had expected to get only about $600.
NEWCASTLE, Northern Ireland, June 14 (AP) -- Margaret Pickard beat Jean Ashley in the final match of the day to give Britain a 5-4 lead over the United States today in the Curtis Cup matches.

The Kennedy family will broadcast a message to the nation over three television networks today to express their appreciation for kindnesses during the period of mourning for Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

The social struggle of the past five weeks in France finally appears to be giving way to the political struggle of an election campaign. Strikes are ending, student barricades are coming down, demonstrations are fading.
The sophsticated New York racegoer, typed as determined to look down on steeplechase racing, had to undergo a change of attitude as he watched the Grand National at Belmont Park yesterday.

ROCHESTER, June 14 -- Ken Venturi, the 1964 United States Open golf champion, failed today to qualify for the final 36 holes of the current Open, perhaps his last. He has been bothered by a circulatory ailment in both hands since 1965.
GOLBASI, Turkey, June 14 -- The United States turned over to Turkey today Site 23, a huge communications center here, as it began a military withdrawal.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) -- Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, and Drew Pearson, the syndicated columnist, have renewed their feud.

Herman B. Ferguson and his co-defendant, 22-year-old Arthur Harris, were found guilty early this morning of conspiring to murder the civil rights leaders Whitney M. Young Jr. and Roy Wilkins. The all-white, all-male jury delivered its verdict shortly before 2 A.M. after more than eight hours of deliberation.

THE first of a series of 13 psychodramas adapted from the stories of Georges Simenon, creator of Inspector Maigret, was imported last night by National Educational Television from the television library of the British Broadcasting Corporation.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 14 -- Hours before the superb Nevele Pride, last season's harness horse of the year, won the $14,797 Elbridge T. Gerry Trot at Monticello Raceway tonight, a groom in Stanley Dancer's barn passed out the following few words of advice:
Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., extended yesterday until June 28 an exchange offer to stockholders. The original offer expired yesterday.
The London stock market closed the week yesterday on a firm tone, aided by sharp rises for shares of many secondary companies figuring in reported take-over bids.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 14 -- Earl Laird gained a spot in the $50,000 American Trotting Championship Race tonight with a victory in the $20,000 Dartmouth Trot. The 8-year-old black gelding, owned by Joan Cruise of Westbury, and driven by her husband, Jimmy, scored by a half-length over A.B.C. Stable's Perfect Freight.

They were standing and cheering for a new British pop group last night at the Fillmore East. The American debut of the Jeff Beck Group promises much heated enthusiasm for the quartet in its six-week American tour.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, June 15 -- The enemy fired about 20 mortar rounds into southwestern Saigon this morning, wounding eight persons.

I cannot help feeling that the current anti-gun propaganda is an emotional surge that is simply futile and fatuous. Somehow people turn in desperation to legislation as a nebulous panacea, despite experience and results such as were produced by the Sullivan Law in New York City, and the Volstead Act in the whole United States.

Dr. Grayson Kirk, the president of Columbia University, has declared that the institution's trustees "cannot be expected to share decision-making power on any subject with a group of students if that group has the avowed policy of destroying the integrity of the university."

HELMSTEDT, West Germany, June 14 -- With the new East German travel rules in force, the usual traffic lines at the start of a long weekend were conspicuously missing today at this chief crossing point into East Germany.

The extent to which an "entrenched'' administration in a labor union may legally limit the right of members to nominate, vote or stand for union office is an important question in the current court action involving the National Maritime Union, according to a brief of the United States Attorney's office.
AUSTIN, Tex., June 14 (AP) -- President Johnson announced today the appointment of 14 members to the National Highway Safety Advisory Committee.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 14 -- The United States team of Thunderbird, Inverness and Robin finished second, third and fourth in a 25-mile race fraught with the difficulties of light, variable airs today to become the leader for the Onion Patch Trophy.
PRAGUE, June 14 (AP) -Premier Imre Nagy, executed for his role in the Hungarian uprising of 1956, has received a eulogy here.
The electronics industry is pushing the sound of music in a variety of new equipment now on display at the 1968 Electronics Show in the New York Hilton Hotel.
Wheat futures registered new lifetime lows yesterday, by anywhere from 1/8 to 1/2 of a cent a bushel, continuing a long and deep decline.

TOKYO, June 14 -- The arrival of a Chrysler Corporation executive here this week, and reports that executives from General Motors and the Ford Motor Company will arrive soon, have created much speculation about the "imminent invasion'' of American manufacturers into Japan through knocked down assembling.
BALTIMORE, June 14 -- Heart rate and blood pressure together appear to be a primary factor in regulating mental attentiveness, a scientist said today.
ALBANY, June 14 (UPI) -- An American expedition has found what it believes to be the remains of Christopher Columbus's flagship, the Santa Maria, an amateur archaeologist reported today.
CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., June 14 -- The dark cloud hovering over Mal Anderson's tennis career for the last year disappeared today at the Long-wood Cricket Club.

DALLAS, June 14 (AP) -- William F. Alexander, an assistant district attorney who played a major role in the murder trial of Jack Ruby, is resigning because of "a lot of little things," District Attorney Henry Wade said today.

BENNINGTON, Vt., June 14 -- More than half the resident women students at Bennington College have signed a petition asking for their expulsion by the college because they refuse to observe the rules forbidding men in rooms at certain hours.

SYRACUSE, June 14 -- The Columbia varsity crew, which stuck together during the turmoil on the campus this spring and never missed a practice, will row tomorrow for the last time. This crew has what its captain, Tom Sanford, wryly calls "a perfect record."
SO far as New York is concerned the Stars of the Bolshoi dim tonight, but this small but stellar troupe of Bolshoi dancers is continuing on its coast-to-coast tour.
The Bulova Watch Company, Inc., registered the highest sales and earnings in its 95-year history in the fiscal year ended March 31, according to the report issued yesterday.

The D. H. Baldwin Company, the musical-instrument company, announced yesterday that its tender offer for all the outstanding shares of the Central Bank and Trust Company of Denver had been accepted by holders of a majority of the bank's shares.

The Wells Fargo Bank of San Francisco, the largest state-chartered bank in California, announced plans yesterday to convert from a state to a national charter. The conversion was designed, the bank said, to give it "more flexibility" in its operations, especially in doing business through subsidiary corporations. The Wells Fargo move was the second major conversion to national status in recent weeks.

DOUGLASVILLE, Ga., June 14 -- State troopers halted the mule train of the Poor People's Campaign today and arrested 67 persons for trying to take it onto a busy expressway. But the authorities later dropped the charges and opened the highway to the demonstrators.

BRISTOL, England, June 14 (AP) -- Cliff Richey blasted a ball out of the court again in another temper tantrum today and was disqualified in his semi-final match with his Davis Cup teammate, Arthur Ashe.

One of the leaders of the Youth International Party -- the Yippies -- charged yesterday that one of the three policemen who arrested him Thursday on charges of possessing marijuana had kicked him at the base of his spine.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The National Rifle Association sought today to counter the rising public pressure on Congress for stricter gun controls by suggesting that "the sportsmen of America" lay down a barrage of mail in opposition.

The three candidates for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate in New York agreed yesterday on two subjects: Republican Senator Jacob K. Javits can be defeated next fall and tighter gun control laws are necessary to curb violence.
NASHVILLE, June 14 (AP) -- The police surrounded a small group of demonstrators to protect them from angry crowd leaving a rally for the Presidential candidate George C. Wallace, tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- High - speed communications by radio and by telephone line have been plagued by smeared signals comparable to the "ghosts" that sometimes appear on television screens.

A retrospective of Greta Garbo's entire screen career will be shown July 9 to July 23 at the Museum of Modern Art, sponsored by the museum and the film department of Lincoln Center as part of Lincoln Center Festival '68.

An agreement in principle has been reached to merge the Jacobsen Manufacturing Company of Racine, Wis., into Kearney-National, Inc., of New York for stock valued at about $37.5-million, it was announced yesterday.

Is it the Izvestia commentator who bridles at any suggestion of a Moscow-Washington thaw and insists all is still frozen between the two capitals? Or is it Soviet Ambassador Dobrynin, who hailed the formal ratification of the Soviet-American consular agreement at the White House and used the occasion to voice a commercial for more American tourists to visit his country?
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., June 14 -- The total integration of Negro and white elementary school pupils here was ordered today by Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Commissioner of Education.
Prices continued to advance in the money and capital markets yesterday, ending the week with fairly substantial over-all gains.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) -- Local officials who administer Federal farm programs in the Black Belt of southern Alabama are helping to keep the Negro majority there in economic servitude, the head of the Civil Rights Commission charged today.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The national Kennedy for President headquarters, which opened in frenzied activity 12 weeks ago, closed today in forlorn sadness.

Mack Sennett's uniquely zany, inventive contributions to silent screen comedy were spotlighted two years ago by Mr. Lahue's all-inclusive "World of Laughter." Now, with the aid of Terry Brewer, an equally diligent researcher, Sennett and his entire Keystone troupe, who were kings of comedy from 1912 to 1917, are the whole show in "Kops and Custards."
The trading pace slowed yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and prices moved down with it.
BERKELEY, Calif., June 14 (AP) -- This year's graduating class at the University of California got a scolding today at its baccalaureate.

Carmine G. De Sapio, the former Tammany Hall leader, was ordered yesterday to appear as a witness in the Marcus kickback conspiracy trial. He is expected to be asked about testimony that he had paid a $12,500 kickback in relation to a Consolidated Edison contract.

LONDON, June 14 -- The correspondents who are "working -- and dying" in Vietnam are the real peacemakers," Hugh Cudlipp, chairman of the International Publishing corporation, said today at a memorial service for five reporters and photographers killed in Vietnam.

PARIS, June 14 -- Foreign Minister Michel Debre said today that the development of France's nuclear armed force would incur delays of one to two years as a consequence of financial difficulties because of the strike that has crippled the French economy for a month.
Mark Kellner gave up his gun yesterday and Robert Behravesh surrendered his knife in Queens.
Elsie Drake, Lloyd Gibson and Judy Whelan began moving last night from Manhattan to Englewood Cliffs, N. J.

MOSPORT, Ontario, June 14 (Canadian Press) -- Graham Hill of England, former world driving champion, wrecked his turbine-powered Lotus today in practice for tomorrow's 200-mile race for Indianapolis-type cars over the Mosport road circuit. Hill was not injured.

PARIS, June 14 (Reuters) -- Georges Bidault, the former French Premier who returned to France this month after six years of self-imposed exile, announced today the formation of a new political movement.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- West Germany has agreed to pay $785-million in a variety of ways during the next year to cover most of the United States balance-of-payments drain in keeping troops and their dependents in Germany.
A 47-year-old commercial artist, who allegedly shot and killed his wife and a boarder after an argument last night, surrendered to the police in the Fresh Meadows section of Queens.
California-grown grapes have almost disappeared from the New York market as a result of union pressures in support of striking grape pickers on the West Coast.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I. -- "We've had the Nehru, now it's time for the daishiki," Kirkland Oliver said as he laid a pattern over a piece of brightly colored cotton cloth imported from Kenya.

BOSTON, June 14 -- The mood of the trial of Dr. Benjamin Spock and four other defendants on charges of conspiring to counsel young men to evade the draft was set last January at the arraignment in Federal District Court before Judge Francis J. W. Ford.

Copies of 10 flags of colonial America, including the flag that flew over Fort McHenry during the bombardment witnessed by Francis Scott Key, who later wrote "The Star Spangled Banner," were displayed yesterday at Battery Park during Flag Day ceremonies.

IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, June 14 -- Setting forth again on his campaign, Senator Eugene J. McCarthy steadily needled Vice President Humphrey today for not campaigning and for not "dealing with the issues."

Mayor Lindsay has all the attributes required for a good Senator -- intelligence, courage, legislative experience, familiarity with the most pressing problems of the day. In addition, he has some special qualities that peculiarly fit him to succeed the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy. He shares the latter's appeal to youth and to minority groups everywhere. He also shares the great concern the Senator had for the problems of the downtrodden.

If you have followed the fortunes of the New York Mets since their rich but underprivileged birth six years ago, the unadorned facts about last night's 7-3 victory over the San Francisco Giants before 54,259 fans at Shea Stadium will depict in full the present Met glory.

A source close to City Council President Frank D. O'Connor said yesterday that there would be "no political blood-bath or head-rolling" if Mayor Lindsay, a Republican, were appointed to the Kennedy Senate seat and Mr. O'Connor, a Democrat, thereby became Acting Mayor.
Mayor Lindsay expressed hope yesterday that he could eliminate part or all of the new taxes that he has called for in the coming fiscal year.
Next Tuesday's primary election for State Assemblyman will be a wrenching one for the Staten Island Republican organization, no matter who wins.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman announced today a 13 per cent cut in Federal wheat-planting allotment for the 1969 crop in an effort to cut surpluses and increase farm prices.
OAKLAND, Calif., June 14 -The oldest of the old Yankee heroes, Mickey Mantle, put the blocks to the Oakland Athletics tonight as the Yankees coaxed out a 5-4 victory in 10 innings.
BOSTON, June 14 -- Dr. Benjamin Spock and three other men were found guilty in Federal District Court today of conspiring to counsel evasion of the draft. A fifth defendant was found not guilty.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 14 -- Despite some brave play by Nancy Richey, the United States trailed Britain, 2-1, today at the end of the first afternoon's play in the 40th Wightman Cup competition on the fast grass of the No. 1 court. Four more matches will settle the issue tomorrow.

Seven of 11 teachers who were "dismissed" last month by the governing board of the Ocean Hill-Brownsville Demonstration School district in Brooklyn were directed last night to return to their classes on Monday by Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, Superintendent of Schools.

PARIS, June 14 -- American officials took issue today with a forecast by Cyrus Eaton, the 85-year-old American industrialist, who recently talked with Soviet leaders, that "we are on the threshold of peace in Vietnam."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 14 -- Thailand responded today to a statement by Senator Eugene J. McCarthy that he thought the United States could afford to withdraw its troops from Thailand.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 14 -- Ed Call, whose production of Brecht's "The Caucasian Chalk Circle" in 1965 remains one of the peak achievements of the Minnesota Theater Company, was to have directed the "Twelfth Night" that opened the company's sixth season at the Tyrone Guthrie Theater last night.
DARIEN, Conn., June 14 -- White Lightning forged into the lead for the open jumper championship at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club Horse Show today by winning the bonus-point stake class.
The Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Association of New York led an assault on the men's bowling records yesterday in the 12th annual National Wheelchair Games.

BONN, June 14 -- Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger declared today he would get in touch with the heads of government of West Germany's three major Western allies to discuss a response to East Germany's latest pressures on the routes to West Berlin.
Hectic trading on the New York Stock Exchange calmed down substantially yesterday as volume dropped sharply from Thursday's record level.

MOSCOW, June 14 -- Polemical sniping between the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia over interpretations of Communism sharpened today with an attack on Cestmir Cisar, a secretary of the Czechoslovak Communist party and an important figure in Prague's program of democratic reforms.

MOSCOW, June 14 (AP) -- Rabbi Yehuda Leib Levin, recovering after major surgery, said today that he planned to fly to New York Monday "to tell the truth" about the policy of the Soviet Union toward its Jewish population.
ALBANY, June 14 -- The state sold 62.4 million lottery tickets in the sweepstake's first year of operation, or 300 million less than the original predictions.

LONDON, June 4 -- Following Muriel Spark and Iris Murdoch, Jennifer Dawson is the latest British woman novelist to go into the theater. Her play is "The Ha-Ha" (adapted by Richard Eyre and running at the Hampstead Theater Club), a study of a mentally sick girl that works extremely well as a small-audience piece without any loss of the book's delicate precision.

GENEVA, June 14 -- An international group of medical experts said today that heart transplants were "palliative" operations that should be resorted to only exceptionally at the present state of knowledge.

After two tragic assassinations in as many months it is time once and for all to reverse the tide in favor of law and order in this country. The first step in this direction is the passage of a stricter gun-control law.

The shooting of Senator Robert F. Kennedy and those with him again demonstrates that the responsibility for such mindless acts lies mainly with those legislators who permit the casual sale of guns in this country. Every other advanced industrial society has taken steps to curb the distribution of arms, yet in the United States an estimated 100 million guns are currently in the possession of citizens.
The family of Richard M. Nixon dominated the Finch College graduation here yesterday with one bachelor's degree, one doctorate and the major commencement address to its credit.
Thousands of New Yorkers who attend church or synagogue are expected to show their support for the Poor People's Campaign by participating in Wednesday's Solidarity Day march in Washington.

IDLE speculation over the guilt or innocence of murder suspects who are in custody but have not yet been brought to trial surely is not within the acceptable province of entertainment television shows.
The American Civil Liberties Union said yesterday that the freedom to bear arms must be sacrificed to the more important freedom of "free and fearless debate on which our free society rests."

TULSA, Okla., June 14 -- Richard M. Nixon has decided to counter Governor Rockefeller's new Presidential offensive by postponing indefinitely the resumption of his own campaign and thus avoiding any political controversy with the New York Governor.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The House Appropriations Committee clamped a lid on the so-called "Congressional pork barrel" today, halting virtually all new starts on public works projects and slashing funds for those already under way.

MOSCOW, June 14 -- President Johnson's appeal yesterday that the Soviet Union join with the United States in overcoming "animosities, suspicions and difficulties" and work for peace was reported today by Tass, the official Soviet press agency.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Plans for import quotas and marketing ceilings were opposed before Congress today by a committee of major business interests as "unwarranted and inconsistent with a free enterprise economic system."
Foundation work will begin this month at Kennedy International Airport for the $55-million program that will more than double the size of the International Arrivals and Airline Wing Buildings.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Leaders of the Poor People's Campaign and the Government apparently expect the encampment here to run beyond the present official termination date of June 23.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) -- The Internal Revenue Service reported today that the National Rifle Association had a tax-exempt status in good standing and was permitted to lobby in Congress under the law.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 14 -- Earl McCullouch and Lennox Miller of Southern California won titles in record-equaling times today in the 47th annual National Collegiate outdoor track and field championships. Neither was especially happy.
WHITE PLAINS, June 14 -- Thirty-two persons accused of being narcotics peddlers were arrested in several Westchester County communities today in a mass roundup. Seventeen more were being sought.

EAST LANSING, Mich., June 14 -- With a thumping, drum-like noise, a bearded man wearing a tall wastebasket over his head was led to a floor microphone to the laughter of the student radicals meeting at Michigan State University.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 14 -- The ouster of a Cabinet Minister today for advocating direct peace talks with the Vietcong has temporarily hampered the South Vietnamese Government's efforts to broaden its political base.

BUDAPEST, June 14 -- The leaders of Czechoslovakia and Hungary, Alexander Dubcek and Janos Kadar, declared their solidarity with the Soviet Union today while committing themselves to continuing the democratization of their Governments.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 14 -- Modern glass and aluminum buildings are nothing new in Belgrade, but the around-the-clock construction of a downtown underpass is symptomatic of the problems of affluence creeping up on the Yugoslav capital.
Advances in geriatrics and improved social benefits, especially in the United States, promise a bright future for trans-Atlantic passenger shipping, a leading European executive said yesterday.

Even the first faint step toward recivilizing our public life, a strong set of Federal and state gun-control laws, has been forestalled and threatened by the pernicious intrigues of the National Rifle Association and its affiliates and similar state groups.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 14 (AP) -- Six Harvard alumni have been named to the university's 30-member board of overseers.
ROME, June 14 -- A broadened liturgy for the central part of the Roman Catholic mass will be made available soon, the first such change in more than 13 centuries.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) -- Agriculture Secretary Orville L. Freeman told Congress today the food stamp program was the best way to feed the poor because the coupons could not be squandered in bingo games.

NEW HAVEN, June 14 -- Yale University has received a $600,000 gift from Mr. and Mrs. A. Varick Stout of Greenwich to endow a professorship in the social sciences, the first for the new Institute of Social Sciences.

LONDON, June 14 -- Louise Burgess usually goes to the Gateways Club only on Friday and Saturday nights. Last Wednesday morning was special. She put on a yellow clown's costume and walked down sunny King's Road in Chelsea to join 40 other women members for a fancy-dress dance.

Javits are battling one another with a ferocity that is bound to leave wounds even after Tuesday's primary. In our judgment, Nassau County Executive Eugene H. DEAUVILLE, France, June 14 -- The United States team held on to third place in the qualifying stage of the World Team Olympaid here today, but four other teams are close on the heels of the Americans, who will have to fight hard to stay in the first four in the standings and so qualify for the semifinal stage beginning Wednesday.

THERE'S' nothing like a cool drink on a hot day, especially after a strenuous game of tennis or a frustrating time at the office. Freshly squeezed lemon juice can add a refreshing, thirst-quenching touch to any number of summer beverages -- and supply Vitamin C as well.
Trading declined markedly yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and prices continued to lose ground.
EVER since ducks have been hunted with shotguns a certain number have been killed even though they were not hit with speeding pellets of lead.

PITTSBURGH, June 17 (AP) -- The United Steelworkers of America and Allegheny Ludlum announced an agreement today that will automatically settle all local issues when the industrywide contract expires on Aug. 1.
NORFOLK, Va., June 17 (AP) A submarine captain said today his search of the ocean near the Azores for the lost submarine Scorpion had convinced him she was not at a salvageable depth.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 16 -- President Tito is determined to hold another conference of nonaligned states undeterred by the failures of past meetings and the disappearance of many leaders who provided their drawing power.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The Supreme Court set aside today the death penalty of Duane Earl Pope in the 1965 killing of three Nebraska bank employes.

Proud mothers in their best spring hats gathered eagerly in a hot, muggy Harlem community center gymnasium with friends and relatives to attend the first commencement of Harlem Preparatory School yesterday.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., June 17 -- Vice President Humphrey has been urged by Norman Thomas to detail his present position on Vietnam.
PARIS, June 17 -- The best reading in Paris -- sour, joyous; stinging and farcical at times -was on the walls of the city's university and high school buildings during the May uprising.
HOUSTON, June 17 -- Jury selection was completed here today in the First Federal Court trial growing out of the 1966 collapse of the Westec Corporation.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 17 -- When all the yachts had reported their finish times and the time allowance calculations had been completed from them, the United States had made another stride on this raw, overcast and windy day toward the Onion Patch Trophy, an important international team-racing prize.

BETSEY JOHNSON, the bubbly 25-year-old who is the best known of Paraphernalia's young designers, has severed her connections with the company. (In turn, Paraphernalia, which manufactures ready-to-wear and franchises boutiques, has declared its independence from its parent company, Puritan Fashions, and will function as a separate concern.)

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 17 -- The leaders of the largest student organization in South Vietnam have denounced the war, urged a political settlement and said that the fighting "is being pushed on through foreign pressures."
LONDON, June 17 (Reuters) -- A Strike by pilots of the state-owned British Overseas Airways Corporation has halted all B.O.A.C. flights between London and New York, an airline spokesman said today.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The Supreme Court said today that it would not apply retroactively its recent ruling that state convictions could be reversed if trial by jury was denied.

The trial of Louis E. Wolfson, the industrialist, and four associates for the alleged manipulation of stock in the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation got under way yesterday in Federal District Court in New York with the selection of a jury.
QUIMPER, France, June 17 -On the opening day in the cam paign for Sunday's general election, the Government announced it would triple the amount spent for rural electrification in Brittany.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Gary Beban, all - America quarterback from the University of California, Los Angeles, today signed a contract with the Washington Redskins for an amount reported to be $200,000. The length of the pact was not disclosed, but officials indicated it would cover several seasons.

MORRIS, Ill., June 17 -- Six nuclear age "schoolboys" went into training in a little blue schoolhouse here today as the first class in the General Electric Company's ultra-modern B.W.R. (boiling water reactor) Training Center.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -Forty to 50 meat packing plants have closed throughout the country since Congress passed legislation to extend Federal standards to all meat packing and processing plants.

Today is Primary Day. The 6.5 million New Yorkers who are enrolled members of one of the four legal political parties -- 3,532,871 Democrats, 2,874,316 Republicans, 82,889 Liberals and 71,477 Conservatives -- will have an opportunity to help choose their party's nominees for the general election next November.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower was reported today to be responding favorably to treatment for a major and initially painful heart attack, suffered Saturday night. It was his fifth heart attack since 1955.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 17 On the training track at Roosevelt Raceway today Dale Wood, Dave Begin and Lou Mac Donald were working Johnny Chapman's horses. Chapman had taken the day off from training and was busy in Barn JJ, catching up on the condition of the 40 horses in his stable.

EL PASO, Tex., June 17 (UPI) -- Claudia Trevino, the comely blonde wife of the new United States Open champion, Lee Trevino, acknowledged that she had a "big head" today, but not of the self-esteem variety.

The same Senate which has been consistently niggardly (although not as outrageously so as the House) in providing housing programs for the poor is now being congratulated for its recent, iniquitous housing bill S-3497.
BRUSSELS, June 17 -- The Common Market's Executive Commission is moving with deliberate caution on France's requests for special trade protection because of her economic problems.
HACKENSACK, N. J., June 17 -- Five players, led by John De Zuew of South Africa, reached the round of 16 today with victories in the Eastern clay-court tennis championship at the Oritani Field Club.
ALBANY, June 17 (AP) -Governor Rockefeller has signed legislation to control the erection of billboards and other outdoor advertising along interstate and primary highways.

ROCHESTER, June 17 -- "It would mean a fortune to me if I won," said Lee Trevino before he began the fourth round of the United States Open golf championship. Today the new titleholder was beginning to realize what he had predicted.
The United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company won a strategic legal round yesterday in a battle for control of the Cleveland-based Clevite Corporation.

When their paths crossed in the practice area one day last week at Oak Hills in Rochester, Gary's inquisitive mind searched for some sort of explanation as to what methods the talkative Texan used to polish his game.
A $5,993,749,027 executive budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1 was adopted by the City Council and Board of Estimate last night only minutes before their midnight deadline.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a state could not deny welfare benefits to dependent children of mothers who engaged in extramarital sexual intercourse.

The promotion of Seymour S. Bitterman to senior vice president in charge of the Curtiss-Wright Aerospace group of the CurtissWright Corporation, was announced yesterday. He formerly was vice presidentoperations of the CurtissWright Corporation.

ST. LOUIS, June 17 - Samuel H. Liberman, lawyer for the Joneses, said today that he had known there had been a great deal of civil rights legislation in the Reconstruction period and that it had been fairly simple to find the 1866 statute.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 17 -- Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky, speaking to the nation tonight after a series of political setbacks, urged the people to rally to the support of the national Government and avoid any coup d'etat efforts.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that "certainly John Lindsay is the kind of man we're talking about" for the Senate seat made vacant by the assassination of Robert F. Kennedy. But he declined to say Mr. Lindsay was his first choice.

WINDSOR, England, June 17 -- Queen Elizabeth touched a sword to the shoulders of her son Prince Charles today, buckled a dark-blue satin garter below his left knee and pronounced him a knight of the realm as a member of the Order of the Garter.

MOSCOW, June 17 -- Scuffling broke out on Mayakovsky Square here today when three young Britons attempted to distribute leaflets criticizing Soviet imprisonment of writers, other dissidents and members of the Baptist Church.

Two of the three New Yorkers who seek the Democratic nomination for United States Senator ended their campaigns yesterday with trips upstate. The third stayed home, close to the Presidential candidate he supports.
ST. LOUIS, June 17 (AP) -- The New York Generals picked Ford Brunner, star goalie from Akron, University, as their first choice at the North American Soccer League draft meeting today.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 17 (UPI) --- Frank Quilici, substituting at second base while Rod Carew is serving with the Marines, hit a triple and double tonight to lead the Minnesota Twins to a 4-1 victory, their fourth straight, over the Washington Senators.
LONDON, June 17 -- New constitutional restrictions on the House of Lords may be ahead as a result of a struggle over the British Government's stand on Rhodesia.

NEW HAVEN, June 17 -- The defending Pacific Coast team of Argyle Campbell and Tim Hogan of the University of Southern California and Edward Butler and Tom McLaughlin of San Diego State College held the lead today at the end of the first day's racing for the Water C. Wood Trophy.

Texaco, Inc., in the largest public financing in the Eurobond market so far, announced plans yesterday to sell $75-million of guaranteed debentures overseas.

The Commercial Credit Company could divert as much as $1.5-billion in relatively unproductive assets into highly profitable computer leasing if its proposed merger with the Control Data Corporation were consummated, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

BONN, June 17 -- In an effort to ease some of the tensions created by the latest East German pressures on West Berlin, the Cabinet decided today at a special meeting against blocking travel to the West by East Germans.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, June 18 -- The United States military command said last night that North Vietnamese helicopters might have entered the war for the first time. Unidentified aircraft were sighted on radar in the vicinity of the eastern end of the demilitarized zone Saturday night and Sunday night, the command said in a statement.

Longshore employers from Norfolk, Va., to Miami have been told by the International Longshoremen's Association that containers shipped across piers staffed by union members must be loaded and unloaded by union labor.

A group of Columbia University students who were suspended after their arrest during the May 21 demonstration on the campus said yesterday that they would not accept expulsion and would return in September.
Polish-American and ItalianAmerican groups are planning a joint drive to fight alleged ethnic slurs.

Unquestionably the worst feature of today's primary is that voters will have to cast their ballots for delegates to the national political conventions without any indication of which Presidential aspirant a would-be delegate proposes to support. Nothing on the voting machine gives the voter a clue; unless he has informed himself before entering the booth, he will be voting blindly.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 17 -- Manuel Ramos is an enigma. Boxing experts, as well as casual onlookers, watching him train in the Ski Lodge at Grossinger's have come away from his sparring sessions shaking their heads in puzzlement.

A general 5 per cent rate increase, to become effective Oct. 1, has been announced by the American West African Freight Conference on eastbound cargoes. It affects shipments from United States and Canadian Atlantic and St. Lawrence River ports not west of Montreal and United States Gulf ports to West African ports, the Azores, Madeira and Canary Islands.

Rhubarb came up from the Jersey circuit yesterday to compete in the feature race of six furlongs at Belmont Park. The 4-year-old filly, who competes in the colors of Bwamazon Farm, was preceded by her fame and the 26,079 customers on hand made her the 1-2 favorite.

London June 17 (UPI) -- Britain's first heart transplant patient, Frederick West, 45 years old, died tonight of an "overwhelming" chest infection that put an unbearable strain on the heart he received May 3.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -The Supreme Court, citing a long string of previous decisions to the same effect, held today that states may not tax national banks, except to the extent that Congress has specifically authorized them to do so.

LONDON, June 17 -- It was like a gathering of the clan. Four Wimbledon champions of varying vintages, stragglers from the professional tournament at Boston and the cream of the amateur crop were on deck today at the London grass-court open ennis championship, the open tune-up for Wimbledon.

UNDER the glitter and the gold brocade, a sense of normalcy prevails on Seventh Avenue. Two intensive weeks of fall openings came to a close yesterday. Store buyers are placing their orders for the clothes that will begin coming into the shops by the end of next month.

Fifty-five Civil Court judges are preparing for service in Criminal Court in the event of riots or major disorders in New York this summer.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 -- Governor Rockefeller proposed today a new system for distributing Federal funds to states and localities. Its effect would be to give greater flexibility in utilizing the Federal grants.

BRUSSELS, June 17 -- After five days of bargaining between Flemish and Walloon politicians, Gaston Eyskens, the new Premier of Belgium, today named 28 men to his Government, making it the largest Cabinet in the nation's history.

PHOENIX, Ariz., June 16 -- At the Maricopa County gun range in the foothills 26 miles north of here, Frank Cannon, the range master, said there had been no significant increase in handgun firing since the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- In animate objects are classified scientifically into three major categories -- those that don't work, those that break down and those that get lost.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI) -- The Department of Commerce said today that personal income of Americans rose $4-billion in May to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $674-billion.

SOMER, N. Y., June 17 - The Metropolitan Transportation Authority confirmed reports today that it was planning an airport on residentially zoned acreage here. Prices of lumber and plywood have risen significantly in recent weeks, according to reports from the Pacific Northwest.

A reorganization of the Public Broadcast Laboratory was announced yesterday after Fred W. Friendly, former president of the Columbia Broadcasting System News Division, declined an offer to take charge of the experimental series of Sunday night telecasts.

Senator Jacob K. Javits announced yesterday that he would seek legislation to build a Federal office building and post office in Harlem.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The Supreme Court denied permission today to railroads to cut freight rates to meet truck and barge competition. Agreeing with the Interstate Commerce Commission, the Court ruled by 8-1 that rate-cut proposals may not be weighed by the standard of "out-of-pocket" costs.

PARIS, June 17 -- Some 60,000 workers in the five nationalized Renault automobile plants voted today to return to work. The Renault workers, the largest group of holdouts in France's month-long strike, said they would be back on the job tomorrow.

General Mills, Inc., the large producer of grocery products, flour and specialty chemicals, announced yesterday a 1,125,000share common-stock offering designed to raise more than $45-million.

The Mobil Oil Corporation announced yesterday that it had acquired the oil-exploration rights covering 450,000 acres on the northern part of the island of Sumatra, Indonesia. The rights were obtained from Refining Associates Canada, Ltd., with the approval of the Indonesian Government.

AGAINST the judgment of my betters, I was not able to find in the first part of Bernard Russell's autobiography, published last year, those excellences that others praised so highly. The picture of his Victorian, restricted boyhood, the great days at Cambridge, the sketches of friends and mentors were memorable.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -- Dr. Dwight Lyman Wilbur, who today not only became president of the American Medical Association, but also became the first son of a former association president to do so, says there was never any question of what he would do.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 18 -- Evidence accumulates as to the impressive strength of George C. Wallace in the Deep South, comprising the five states of Alabama, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi and South Carolina, according to the Gallup Poll.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The prospect of Senator Edward M. Kennedy as a possible running mate for Hubert H. Humphrey remains publicly unmentionable but privately in teresting to the Humphrey camp.

CHICAGO -- Unmowable fake grass can soon be replaced by tartans on the terrace, paisleys by the pool and textured Spanish tiles on the patio. Indoor-outdoor carpeting, considered the enfant terrible of the carpet industry five years ago, has become a style-conscious adult.

LONDON, June 18 -- Playing in their first open tournament, a couple of Americans treated the professional ranks with scant respect today at Queens Club. Ron Holmberg knocked out Pierre Barthes of France, 6-4, 6-3, without semblance of strain and then Clark Graebner thrashed Fred Stolle with the raw power of his service, 6-4, 11-9, at the London grass court tennis championships.

Loew's Theatres, Inc., announced yesterday a significant modification in its hotly contested bid to take over the Commercial Credit Company, a giant Baltimore finance company.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 18 -- George H. (Pete) Bostwick Jr., one of the most consistent amateur golfers in the area, got back into the winner's circle today only to be unable to celebrate at the 19th hole. After taking the 36-hole Hochster invitation by five strokes with a 143 at Quaker Ridge, Bostwick said, "Doggone, of all days to win. I can't even get a drink for it."

WIMBLEDON, England, June 18 (AP) -- Rod Laver of Australia and Mrs. Billie Jean King of Berkeley, Calif., were seeded at the top today for the singles at the Wimbledon tennis championships opening Monday -- the first time the courts have mixed both pros and amateurs.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Secretary of Defense Clark M. Clifford was reported today by Congressional sources to have expressed opposition to Congressional proposals to delay deployment of the Sentinel Ballistic Missile Defense System.

Mayor Lindsay has come off well in his perennial battle with the Democratic-controlled City Council and Board of Estimate over the cost of running the city. The two legislative bodies have actually effected cuts of $16 million in expenditures sought by the Mayor and added $9 million of their own. The difference of $6.7 million is about one-tenth of 1 per cent of the $6.1 billion budget Mr. Lindsay proposed.

CHARLESTON, S. C., June 18 -- George C. Wallace of Alabama, flanked by three participants in the Southern Governors Conference here, insisted today that he was interested in nothing but Presidential politics.
NAICAM, Saskatchewan -- The United States Air Force has parked a most unusual train on a siding between grain elevators and sprawling wheat fields that surround this prairie hamlet.

PARIS, June 18 -- There was no joy at the Folies-Bergere tonight.
NEWARK, June 18 -- The Federal District Court rejected today the appeal by F. Lee Bailey, the Boston criminal lawyer, for reinstatement as defense counsel in the Kavanaugh and DeFranco murder cases.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Senator Daniel K. Inouye of Haiwaii will deliver the keynote address at the Democratic National Convention.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -- United Air Lines announced a $160-million expansion program today for its San Francisco engineering and maintenance base, described as the largest facility of its kind in the world.

In a lease involving more than $8-million in rent, the Bali Company, Inc. has taken two entire floors in the Tishman Building at 666 Fifth Avenue.
