WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The backers of tougher gun controls organized a committee today to try to increase public pressure on Congress to pass such legislation.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 18 -- Nevele Pride, the 1967 horse of the year, heads a field of 11 trotters who were declared today into the $166,746.91 Dexter Cup Trot at Roosevelt Raceway. Each owner posted $2,500 to start his horse in the ninth edition of the Dexter, to be held June 27.

BOSTON, June 18 -- The Central Conference of American Rabbis called on 675 Reform synagogues today to make voluntary contributions to local governments in lieu of taxes for the use of various community services.

" See, those Jumps?" Jack Cooper said yesterday at Belmont Park, flipping through, a pictorial yearbook of French steeplechasing. "They're all tough. But our horses have been training for them. This is no last-minute decision."

WASHINGTON, June 18 -The Senate passed today legislation, already approved by the House, that would permit the Export-Import Bank to take slightly larger risks in its loans, guarantees and insurance for financing exports.

NEW HAVEN, June 18 -- The Pacific Coast Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association team made a successful defense of the Walter C. Wood Trophy for interdistrict team racing today in the opening event of three championships of the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association of North America.

Cirillo (Pepe) Fernandez will lead the San Diego Toros, the pace-setters in the Pacific Division of the North American Soccer League, against the battered New York Generals tonight at the Yankee Stadium. It's likely to be the final game of the season for the 24-year-old Uruguay booter, who has scored 18 goals in 16 games to pace the league.
Turnover declined again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. Prices edged down, too.
An all-out challenge to the Bronx Democratic organization by the Reform Democrats failed last night as the regulars swept all but two of the 24 district leaderships.

MEMPHIS -- From the moment of the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on April 4 evidence has accumulated to suggest that he was the victim of a conspiracy. Several bits of evidence incicate more than one person may have been involved in Dr. King's slaying.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- An economist who told a Senate subcommittee yesterday that defense contractors made higher than average profits on their Government contract work cited 100 concerns with the largest share of contract awards.
BRUSSELS, June 18 (AP) -- The European Economic Community, the Common Market, posted a January to March trade surplus with the United States for the first time since it was founded in 1958.

The thread that runs through the primary elections this year -- despite assassinations and unexpected initiatives and unknowable attitudes -- is a rejection of the Johnson Administration and its fundamental policies.

LONDON, June 18 -- James Earl Ray, accused of slaying the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., was told today that American demands for his extradition would take precedence over the relatively minor British charges against him.

MONROVIA, Liberia, June 15 -- The treason trial of Liberia's former Ambassador to Keya, is affording the 1.2 million citizens of this torpid West African country the rare opportunity of hearing their Government's policies attacked and the policymakers slandered.

The schooner America, a full-scale recreation of the famous racing vessel, departs today from City Island N.Y., on a two-month goodwill tour. The schooner will visit ports in Bermuda, England and Germany before returning to the United States in early August.
DETROIT, June 18 -- The General Motors Corporation recalled 22,683 medium and heavy duty trucks today for possible brake defects.
Housewives probably will pay pay more for their sugar by the five-pound bag and small boxes unless the Government makes a move before July 1.
Three construction helpers admitted yesterday that they had collected wages and State unemployment checks while they were drawing disability benefits from the welfare fund of their union.
" The alien actor issue? Oh, that. It's been going on for over a hundred years," the actress picketing the Shubert Theater remarked yesterday.

BUFFALO, June 18 -- Perched high up there like King George and Queen Mary out for an afternoon spin, it's easy to blow off a Thunderbird, outdrag a Corvette or put down a Cadillac in your 1911 Rolls-Royce touring car of teak painted a bright red.
PARIS, June 18 -- Employes of the Government-owned broadcasting monopoly have voted to continue their strike against political interference.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -The Securities and Exchange Commission warned all corporations today against making two specific types of financial statements that it said would be regarded as misleading.

Two defeats at the hands of the Houston Astros, 3-2 and 6-5, put a chill last night on the high enthusiasm attained by the New York Mets recently, but constituted a dazzling debut for Harry Walker, the new Houston manager.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -- One of the nation's strictest city gun control bills appeared assured of adoption here under the aegis of one of the leaders of Senator Robert F. Kennedy's Presidential campaign.
DEAUVILLE, France, June 18 -- The United States will meet the Netherlands and Italy will play Canada in the semi-finals of the World Olympiad beginning here tomorrow.
Widespread voting machine failures and a complicated ballot led to slow voting and long lines of impatient people at the polls in yesterday's state-wide primary election here.
Prices on the London stock market maintained a good part of new gains yesterday despite disappointment over British trade results for May.

PARIS, June 18 -- All through France, Gaullist parliamentary candidates are showing a film of turmoil in the Latin Quarter, students and police battling each other against a background of flaming cars and barricades of trees, paving stones and iron grilles.
Mayor Lindsay last night vetoed eight of the changes in his $6,082,455,491 executive budget for 1968-69 that were voted late Monday night by the City Council and the Board of Estimate.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Betty Furness suggested today that customers be given a choice of trading stamps or their equivalent in cash at the checkout counter.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -- Delegates to the annual convention of the American Medical Association took the first step today formally to prohibit racial discrimination within the 216,000-member organization.

PARIS, June 18 -- A North Vietnamese spokesman today indicated that Hanoi's negotiators would be willing in principle to receive Senator Eugene J. McCarthy when the Democratic Presidential candidate visits Paris late in July.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, June 19 -- Aircraft suspected of being North Vietnamese helicopters have been sighted over the demilitarized zone for the third day in a row, a United States military spokesman said last night.

At one end of a long corridor at the Commodore Hotel, last night, crepe paper streamers sagged over the heads of an ebullient young crowd of girls jumping into the air and young men stretching their necks out of button-down shirts to scream, "All the way with Gene and Paul."

Herbert Wechsler's June 16 letter in support of the so-called crime control bill -- the bill which now awaits Presidential veto or approval -- characterizes the bill as "an understandable reaction to the humiliation and frustration of the tragedy of California."

J. Lewis Fox, a former Democratic Assemblyman from Far Rockaway, Queens, admitted yesterday he lied when he said he did not accept $5,000 to bribe a public official. He pleaded guilty to perjury in the second degree.

Britain's Conservative peers no doubt derived heady satisfaction from engineering the House of Lords veto of a Government order tightening sanctions against Rhodesia. Now they may have time to reflect on what they have done to Britain's standing, to principles which Tory Governments stoutly defended in the recent past, and possibly to the House of Lords itself.

Adam Clayton Powell won another primary contest for nomination to Congress yesterday, but his margin over John H. Young, a 52-year-old advertising man, was only 3 to 2, far below his majority in earlier challenges.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 18 -- The United States has taken an incalculable amount of value from Jewish culture. This is a debt that can never be repaid, for it is part of the making of a nation. But today America also has an indigenous culture, and it was fascinating to observe in The Hague last night, and here the night before, Israel's new and magnificent troupe, the Batsheva Dance Company from Tel Aviv.

LONDON, June 18 (AP) -- A United States Navy ship reported tonight that it had found wreckage in the area where a search was under way for Jean DeKat, a French competitor in the trans-Atlantic yacht race that started from Plymouth, England June 1.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Twenty-two Mayors, including Mayor Lindsay of New York and all three of the nation's Negro Mayors of large cities, endorsed today the "Solidarity Day" march of the Poor People's Campaign.

BUDAPEST, June 18 -- Despite a fairly serious drought, continuing indebtedness to the Soviet Union and rising prices for some consumer goods, the Hungarian economy appears to be expanding in an atmosphere of stability.
EVANSTON, Ill., June 18 -Sixty airline executives are expected here Sept. 11-12 for the third annual Airline Management Development Conference at Northwestern University's Transportation Center.

As the tax bill, like a sputtering fuse, drew nearer to causing a potential explosion in the nation's credit markets tomorrow, investment bankers handled a huge volume of some $950-million of new fixedincome securities.

HANGING out with the mighty rich tends to narrow a young man's vision. Only after Halston Frowick bid an amiable farewell to Bergdorf Goodman's custom millinery salon last January did the hatter to Mesdames Kennedy, Paley, Ford, Mellon, Mesta and kind, adjust his perspective on fashion and the role he wants to play in it.

BUFFALO, June 18 -- George Schuster, 95 years old and still spry, received tonight a $1,000 prize overdue by 60 years. Schuster drove the Thomas Flyer that won the Great Race of 1908 from New York to Paris via San Francisco, Pacific steamer to Japan and then overland from Siberia across the European continent.

LONDON, June 18 -- Uninhibited by the success of "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead," Tom Stoppard has modestly been turning out a series of lightweight fantastic comedies. The latest, "The Real Inspector Hound, is at the Criterion Theater here.
LONDON, June 18 -- British overseas trade failed to show any improvement during May over the deep deficit recorded in April, the Government announced today

The front-runner for the Republican Presidential nomination, Richard M. Nixon, appears to be standing four-square for silence. Confident that he has a majority of the convention delegates under seal, Mr. Nixon has let it be known that his political strategy is to speak only in generalities and ignore Governor Rockefeller.
AT A TIME when Wall Street is especially jittery about speculation, a mutual fund that is buying securities for long-term appreciation may be as refreshing as an ocean breeze.
The United States should face the following facts:
New York State Democrats gave Senator Eugene J. McCarthy's Presidential campaign a much-needed psychological boost yesterday in balloting for 123 delegates to the Chicago nominating convention.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday attacked the "massive indifference" of the Federal Government toward legislation providing extra funds for summer youth programs here and in other cities.
Whitney North Seymour Jr. won the Republican nomination for the House of Representatives in the Silk Stocking 17th District in Manhattan yesterday, defeating his insurgent opponent, S. William Green.
The Civil Aeronautics Board reported yesterday a continued decline in operating profits of scheduled all-cargo services for certificated route air carriers for the year ended Dec. 31, 1967.

There is an uneasy feeling in the country about the election these days because the people feel helpless to influence the choice of the Presidential nominees. They see and hear the candidates, they watch the polls and listen to the commentators, but the decision lies with a majority of the convention delegates, who are answerable mainly to themselves and their political leaders.

When Melvin W. Alldredge, chairman and newly named chief executive officer of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, Inc., opened the company's annual meeting here yesterday, he said, "I think we have an interesting day ahead."

Anyone who has ever watched the Anguished Masses Struggling Upward across 100 feet of a post office lobby knows that the art of the mural is a special art. A display that opened on Fifth Avenue yesterday shows that a new generation of muralists is on the way, with ideas of its own.
PRAGUE, June 18 (AP) -- The Soviet commander of Warsaw Pact forces has said that maneuvers this month in Czechoslovakia would involve only command staffs of the various services.

Three policemen and a demonstrator were injured in a fight outside Public School 175 in Harlem yesterday morning when an ousted Negro teacher tried for the second day in a row to prevent the school's white principal from entering the building.
Television-commercial production costs, which have zoomed 72 per cent in the last five years, have agency brass in a stew and probably a client or two in a snit.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Senator Edward W. Brooke warned today that pressure was mounting for a renewed expansion of the war in Vietnam if North Vietnam's negotiators did not show more flexibility in the Paris talks with the United States.

UNDER the explicit title "The Business of Religion," the program entitled "C.B.S. Reports" delved last night into the sensitive subject of the dimensions, advisability and abuses of tax exemption for the nation's churches and synagogues.

The Armco Steel Corporation announced yesterday a realignment of executives with the formation of the company's fifth major group -- for steel -- and an executive committee. The change will be effective July 1.

The vice president of the militant African - American Teachers Association was the main speaker at the graduation ceremony of an overwhelmingly white Brooklyn school yesterday, and he offered advice that he said would "sound old-fashioned."
PRINCETON, N. J., June 18 -- Princeton University today named Dr. Carl A. Fields as Assistant Dean of the College, making him the first Negro in the university a 221-year history to hold the post.
ALBANY, June 18 -- Governor Rockefeller has signed a bill giving local officials emergency powers to deal with threats of rioting.

British Eagle International Airlines has announced through its New York office that it will appeal the refusal of the Air Transport Licensing Board to grant British Eagle licenses to operate scheduled services between London and New York at a route servicing London, Bermuda, Nassau and Chicago.

Hugh D. Auchincloss Jr.'s June 10 letter tries to exonerate the Arabs from any responsibility or connection with the assassination of Senator Kennedy. He ignores the malicious falsehoods of Arab leaders, the Arab press and radio, which have been planting implacable hatred for Israel and her friends in the hearts of the Arab people.

A move to unseat the governing board of the controversial Ocean Hill-Brownsville Demonstration School District in Brooklyn was started yesterday with an appeal to the Board of Education for a new election.
The Broadway strike by actors entered its second day yesterday with no sign that the dispute was near an end.
For the last year Harry Walker has been confined to talking about hitting in the Houston Astros' organization. Yesterday his conversational horizons were expanded.

The former confidential law assistant to former Judge Melvin H. Osterman was suspended from the practice of law for three years yesterday for participating in the bribery of State Liquor Authority officials.
Senator Jacob K. Javits won the Liberal party nomination for United States Senator in yesterday's primary with ease over Murray Baron, the Liberals' former New York County chairman.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has done it again -- inaugurated successfully another concert series. Last night an overflow audience, which filled three U-shaped rows of temporary seats on stage and had enough people left over to make a row of standees at the rear of Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium, was attracted by a chamber music concert presented upder the direction of Alexander Schneider.
A two-year-old venture here has trained 250 men to become "preventive maintenance mechanics," upgrading their skills and incomes.

The dinner dance in the enormous pink tent at Gracie Mansion last night was not once referred to as a debutante party. Such' gatherings rarely are. But a debut it was, with three young-girls in long dresses and all the usual' trappings.

Allard K. Lowenstein, a severe critic of the Johnson Administration, scored an upset victory in yesterday's primary when he defeated Albert Vorspan, candidate of the powerful Nassau County Democratic organization, for the party's nomination for Representative in the Fifth Congressional District.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 18 -- Governor Rockefeller came to New Jersey today in the hope of solidifying his wobbly support among its 40 delegates to the Republican National Convention -- the eighth largest state bloc.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The Senate Labor Committee approved today a bill authorizing $250-million in Federal funds over four years to fight juvenile delinquency.

HOUSTON, June 18 -- James W. Williams, former Westec Corporation board chairman, was unaware until the company collapsed that an alleged conspiracy existed to falsify financial reports, his attorney told a Federal Court jury here today.

The tax increase won't reverse inflation. It may not save the dollar. Combined with the $6-billion cut in spending, it may prove heady medicine indeed for an economy that has yet to experience the first withdrawal pains from its current inflationary binge.
The District Attorney of Queens County was directed yesterday to appear in Supreme Court July 1 to explain why the first-degree manslaughter conviction of Mrs. Alice Crimmins should not be set aside.

The base payroll for 7,600 employes is estimated at $72million this year. Mr. Keck said that, excluding the $44-million maintenance base, his airlines capital investment in the San Francisco Bay area was about 23-million.
Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., had record sales and increased earnings in the three months ended April 30, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, June 18 -- The only American star appearing in a regular West End London production now is Joan Diener. Her husband, Albert Marre, who directs her show, explained tonight the problems he faced in importing American talent.

Paul O'Dwyer, the maverick who campaigned on the "peace" issue and linked his candidacy to the Presidential drive of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota, won an upset victory for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New York yesterday.
ANAHEIM, Calif., June 18 -- Al Downing made a brief and inconclusive "comeback" tonight while the New York Yankees were being buffaloed by a 22-year-old rookie named Tom Murphy.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Administration's gun control bill picked up decisive support in the Senate today as a Judiciary subcommittee unanimously approved a proposal to ban mail order sales of rifles and shotguns.

CLEVELAND, June 18 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy declined to say today that he would support Vice President Humphrey as the Democratic Presidential nominee even if Mr. Humphrey altered his position on Vietnam policy.

ASCOT, England, June 18 -- The grass was lush green, the blue hydrangeas were in full bloom, the champagne cost $9 a bottle, women looked smart, starlets maneuvered for publicity, and somewhere at this prime social event of the sporting season horses were running and people were betting.
The Chief Rabbi of Moscow said in an interview here yesterday that he could not understand charges that anti-Semitism existed in the Soviet Union.

The hysterical, demagogic statement of June 12 issued by Harold W. Glassen, president of the National Rifle Association, indicates that perhaps the vast majority of civilized Americans at last have this little band of murder-weapon lovers on the run.
The appointment of David K. Darcy as a senior vice president of the Irving Trust Company, where he will head the bank's national division, beginning July 1, was announced yesterday.
BERLIN, Wednesday, June 19 -- Foreign Minister Willy Brandt of West Germany went to East Berlin yesterday to establish direct contact with Soviet authorities on the issue of access to West Berlin.
Defense lawyers in the Marcus bribery conspiracy trial summed up their cases yesterday before an all-male jury in Federal Court.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Republicans accused the Democratic party today of letting United States arms superiority slip away while succumbing to "wishful thinking" in trying to improve relations with the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Administration's long-stalled tax increase proposal, coupled with a cutback in Federal spending, cleared the House Rules Committee today with surprising ease. The bill provides for a 10 per cent surcharge on both personal and corporation income taxes.

VENICE, June 18 -- The awarding of prizes at the Venice Biennale, scheduled for Saturday, has been postponed indefintely, officials of the art exhibition announced today. Although they cited "technical difficulties," it was understood that the panel of jurors had resigned out of sympathy with students who have urged a boycott of the Biennale.
NEW ORLEANS, June 18 (AP) -- The New Orleans Buccaneers traded their scoring leader, Doug Moe, and playmaker, Larry Brown, to the Oakland Oaks today in exchange for three young players.

DENVER, Colo., June 18 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit held today that persons could not be confined in state mental institutions against their will without having been represented by a lawyer at commitment proceedings.

PARIS -- The most significant lesson of this year's international student revolt is how fragile modern society has become. With surprisingly little difficulty a handful of young scholars managed to catalyze discontent in Paris and tie up most of France.

PEKING, June, 18 (Agence France-Presse) -- Soviet and other Communist diplomats walked out of a dinner given here tonight by Premier Chou En-lai when he said the United States and the Soviet Union had invented "nuclear colonialism."

A young jazz oboist who attends the New York College of Music may be on the verge of startling the jazz world. His name is Jim Hahn. He played last night with a quintet of fellow students at Caravan House, 132 East 65th Street.
TEL AVIV, June 18 -- All five members of an Egyptian patrol -- a lieutenant and four soldiers -- were killed early today in an encounter with Israeli forces in the Sinai desert.

Secrecy has been cast upon the role to be played by Alexander Rittmaster, for 16 years the chief financial adviser to Louis E. Wolfson, at Wolfson's trial on Government charges that he defrauded stockholders of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation.

EL PASO, Tex., June 18 (AP) -- Not at all the brash young man he was after rising to golf stardom Sunday, Lee Trevino, the United States open golf champion, received a royal welcome today as he returned to his El Paso home.
The stock market struggled through an irregular pattern yesterday and finished lower in moderate trading.
The Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism will open next month an intensive eight-week program to train 20 minority group members for news careers in radio and television.
BRUSSELS, June 18 -- A growing number of observers believe the gold price on the free market may have already reached its highest level this year.

Letters, telegrams and telephone calls to Mayor Lindsay are urging him to remain in City Hall if Governor Rockefeller offers to appoint him to the Senate seat vacated by the death of Robert F. Kennedy.

In girding itself for tomorrow's vote on the long-delayed tax surcharge and spending reduction package, the House of Representatives has only one really important issue before it. It is whether or not Congress will permit the use of flexible fiscal policy as a positive economic weapon.

The chief executive officer of the World Council of Churches said yesterday that its forthcoming assembly hoped to launch a movement among Christians to overcome the gap between the rich and the poor.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A 10-member commission appointed by President Johnson to study violence set out today on a course that will probably lead to public hearings this summer.

BONN, June 18 -- Bonn is asking its allies and friends to close down East German trade representative offices in their countries in reprisal for East Germany's latest pressure on the access routes to West Berlin, informed sources said today.

CARUPANO, Venezuela, June 16 -- The old fisherman pulled his hat down close over his ears and fell into a slow dance of astonishment. Overhead, green skyrockets and pinwheels fractured the Caribbean night.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -- Two spokesmen for the American Medical Association today voiced disagreement with the Supreme Court ruling that the jailing of chronic alcoholics for public drunkenness does not violate their constitutional rights.

Civil rights leaders and government officials yesterday hailed the Supreme Court's decision against housing discrimination as one of its most significant acts since the Court banned segregation in the nation's public schools in 1954.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 18 -- Secretary General Thant predicted today that the Vietnam peace talks in Paris would remain deadlocked for a long time.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 18 -- The strong United States team of Thunderbird, Inverness and Robin gained its third straight victory in the international sailing for the Onion Patch Trophy today and was comfortably, but not securely ahead in the standing with the last and most important event of the series remaining.

IN the introduction to his survey, Arthur M. Eastman, professor of English at the University of Michigan, reminds us that the "Annotated World Bibliography" for 1964 lists 3,193 items for Shakespeare, exclusive of films, radio broadcasts, television shows and recordings. True, that was the year of the 400th anniversary of the poet's birth.

The Allied Stores Corporation, one of the largest department store chains in the country, has decided to curtail sharply its sales of firearms, Theodore Schlesinger, president, said after the annual meeting here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The Senate approved today a bill that would give the states first Choice of surplus Federal property now available first to the Agency for International Development.

Presenting a New York Philharmonic "Promenades" concert on an election night guarantees that it will be a pop concert in every sense of the term. The champagne that customarily flows at tables and in lobbies at these hopefully effervescent events was replaced last night at Philharmonic Hall by soda pop in two colors, while the musical list was filled with determinedly light, if not always popular, pieces.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- There were differences in mood and substance between today's solidarity march and the march on Washington five years ago. And there was no better illustration of these differences than a sad-eyed little Negro girl in a red T-shirt.
Cushman Wakefield, Inc., has named two financial executives to new posts.
Railroad freight rates will be increased another 3 per cent, probably starting Monday morning, under an Interstate Commerce Commission order issued yesterday afternoon.
MOSCOW, June 19 -- A Soviet literary critic appealed today for an end to venomous and sarcastic reviews that strive to discredit young poets.

ANAHEIM, Calif., June 19 -Steve Barber pitched a most peculiar game for the New York Yankees against the California Angels tonight. He allowed only four hits but gave 10 walks, and the fourth hit and 10th walk proved his undoing.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Legislation aimed at reducing the cost of buying and owning mutual-fund shares was approved in compromise form today by the Senate Banking Commitee.

American scientists are eagerly charting the course for a grand tour by one unmanned spacecraft to Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune -- a journey that could begin in 10 years, but could not be repeated for 179 years.
Five years ago more than 200,000 Americans of all races, colors and creeds and from all walks of life joined the first great March on Washington to support Negro demands for equal rights.
LONDON, June 19 -- Two members of a Soviet trade delegation were requested to leave Britain last month for activities "totally inconsistent" with their status here, the Foreign Office said tonight.
LONDON, June 19 (UPI) -- Britain announced today vast new resources to defend sterling while the benefits of the devaluation of the pound from $2.80 to $2.40 last November work through the economy.

TORONTO, June 19 -- Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau attracted the biggest turnout of Canada's election campaign today amid the tightest security precautions this city and probably any Canadian politician has known.
OTTAWA, June 19 (UPI) -- A dispute that is threatening to turn into a general strike on the St. Lawrence Seaway system may be settled before Friday by a compromise, a union spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- More than 50,000 orderly Americans marched here today to emphasize their demand for a just share of affluence and dignity for Negroes, Spanish-speaking minorities, American Indians and poor whites.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said today that the outcome of the New York primary was additional evidence of voter dissatisfaction with policies of the Johnson Administration and should cause Democratic leaders to have second thoughts about Vice President Humphrey as the party's Presidential nominee.
Both Paul O'Dwyer and Democratic State Chairman John J. Burns have told their political associates that they will try to unify the party, despite the potentially divisive forces at work within it.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 19 -- Perfect Freight's chances to repeat last season's victory in the $50,000 American Trotting Championship were not hurt a bit by today's draw for post positions for Saturday night's 23d edition of the mile-and-a-quarter race at Roosevelt Raceway.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- A fresh, bipartisan approach to the Congressional formulation of new American shipping policies was urged today by Representative Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, the House Republican leader.

BOSTON, June 19 (AP) -King Ranch's Out of the Way picked up ground on the rail turning into the stretch and charged to a narrow victory today in the 34th running of the $61,050 Massachusetts Handicap at Suffolk Downs.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -The International Monetary Fund disclosed today that it had borrowed $265-million worth of five European currencies to replenish part of the currency holdings that were depleted in France's drawing of $745-million earlier this month.
HONG KONG, June 19 -Fighting between rival revolutionary factions that has been going on intermittently for some weeks in Kwangtung and Kwangsi is reported to have reached a new stage of intensity.

The election of Walter E. Hoadley, the economist, as executive vice president of the Bank of America was announced yesterday. He will continue to head the economics department of the bank and as a member of the bank's managing committee and of the advisory council of the bank's board of directors.

BUDAPEST, June 19 -- Intellectuals here say that Janos Kadar, the Hungarian Communist party leader, has emerged during the last two weeks as a strong backer of expanded freedoms in the arts and sciences.

Silver prices rose quite sharply yesterday morning on the basis of much higher London quotations for the metal. Later in the day, enough selling entered to force prices down more sharply than they had risen in the case of some deliveries.
The New York and the American Stock Exchange reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 19 -- Joe Frazier's manager, Yancey Durham, didn't hesitate today when asked for a prediction.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 19 -- With five members abstaining, the Security Council approved today the guarantee offered by the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union to provide immediate assistance to nonnuclear-weapons countries facing nuclear attack.

The stunning McCarthy-O'Dwyer antiwar victory in Tuesday's Democratic primary did not spill over to all of the state's Congressional contests. In some House races, antiwar candidates lost, while national convention delegate slates pledged to Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, the antiwar Presidential candidate, were running up big victories.

Two physicians whose names appeared on fraudulent disability certifications that enabled members of Mason Tenders Local 46 to bleed their union's welfare fund refused yesterday to answer most of the State Investigation Commission's questions.

LOS ANGELES, June 19 -- Russell E. Parsons, a 73-year-old Los Angeles attorney, will serve as defense counsel for Sirhan B. Sirhan, the 24-year-old Jordanian accused of murdering Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

Paul O'Dwyer, assessing New York's surprising primary, said yesterday his own upset Democratic Senate victory sprang "from a combination of ingredients that included the tragic death of Senator Robert F. Kennedy."

LONDON, June 19 (Reuters) -- Ships and planes from three nations combed 200 square miles of the Atlantic today for a lone yachtsman while United States para-medics waited in Iceland to drop into the ocean if his position is pinpointed.

The American Telephone Telegraph Company attained the highest revenues and earnings in its 83-year history in the three and twelve months ended May 31, despite an 18-day nationwide telephone strike that began April 18, H. I. Romnes, board chairman, reported yesterday.

LIVE television coverage of the "Solidarity Day" ceremonies of the Poor People's campaign in Washington was extremely limited and perhaps not without reasonable journalistic justification. In comparison with the memorable 1963 Washington march, in which the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. gave voice to his dreams, the crowd was small and the element of inspiration not present in like degree.
A Federal jury convicted four out of five defendants in the Marcus bribery conspiracy case yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -Senator Eugene J. McCarthy's victory in the New York Democratic primary made influential members of California's big delegation determined today to keep it uncommitted as long as possible.

DEAUVILLE, France, June 19 -- The United States led the Netherlands by 16 international match points here tonight with 20 deals remaining to be played in the World Olympiad semi-final. The Americans survived early shocks and built up a lead of 32 points at the half-way stage, but the Dutch grabbed back 16 points in the night session.

HUE, South Vietnam, June 19 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu signed the nation's first general mobilization law today and said that it would eliminate the need for additional United States troops in South Vietnam.
PARIS, June 19 -- American and North Vietnamese negotiators stepped up their mutual public recriminations today, but at the same time prospects improved for moving to secret bargaining.

Wasp-Americans are as angry as wet hornets, according to John Doe. "We are sick and tired of ethnic slurs that make Wasps the object of ridicule and contempt, and we intend to fight back," Doe said the other day at the first meeting of Sting, a new organization formed to boycott or sue anybody who speaks comically or disparagingly of a Wasp.

The Wind Quintet of the Argentine Mozarteum, on its way to take part in the InterAmerican Music Festival in Washington next Tuesday, decided to make a couple of extra stops first. Last night it made its American debut in Town Hall here, and on Monday it will play the first preview concert of the new Temple University Music Festival at Ambler, Pa.
The board of governors of the American Stock Exchange announced yesterday new margin requirements on several issues. They will go into effect with the opening on Thursday.
Two 17year-old youths who allegedly tried to rob a cab driver last night were critically wounded by the cabbie, who was a moonlighting policeman.

LONDON, June 19 -- John Lennon, in his second capacity as an author, has now reached the stage of the National Theater with "In His Own Write," which forms the last part of a triple comedy bill containing forgotten plays by Henry Fielding and John Maddison Morton, the Victorian farceur.

ROME, June 19 -- Senator Giovanni Leone, the 59-yearold Christian Democratic former Premier, agreed today to explore the possibilities for finding a way out of Italy's difficult and potentially dangerous Government crisis.

A total of 41 rookies and experienced players were asked yesterday to report to the early camp of the New York Jets, July 10 at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I. The rest of the squad is due July 20.

The money and capital markets wound up their last day before the tax bill vote in the House of Representatives convinced more than ever that the legislation would be passed and that less upward pressure would be exerted on interest rates over the months ahead.

Three companies announced yesterday that they had filed registration statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission for future offerings of common stock.

CARVERSVILLE, Pa. -- They say that Carversville is so small you'd never know it was a village until 5 in the afternoon when everyone goes to the little post office to pick up the mail. Kennedy, said yesterday that he still believed that supporters of thhe asssassinated Senator had the power to determine who would be the next President.

LAGOS, Nigeria, June 19 -A big relief operation has begun here to channel food and drugs to civilians in the areas worst hit by Nigeria's civil war.
