It will mark the first time in the history of downstate trotting and pacing that before and after dark competition will be offered.
A teacher at Public School 175 in Harlem said yesterday that a majority of the school's teachers had voted to ask the principal, Harvey S. Nagler, to stay away from the school.

The June 18 letter of M. T. Mehdi, secretary general of the Action Committee on American-Arab Relations, appears to be the beginning of a campaign to convert the discussion of the assassination of Senator Kennedy into an anti-Israel diatribe.

BOSTON, June 20 (UPI) -- Tony Conigliaro, the Boston Red Sox outfielder whose big league career was apparently cut short when he was hit by a baseball, said today doctors had given him permission to resume practice whenever he wanted.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- A financial emergency is difficult to feel, see or even understand, especially when it is as much potential as actual. But a sense of impending financial emergency, to go with the rest of the nation's troubles, was the reason why a majority in the House voted today to raise the people's taxes.

THERE are three reasons for reading this biography-for-the-defense of Senator Joseph Raymond McCarthy (1908-1957) by Roy Cohn, the former chief counsel of the McCarthy-chaired Senate Subcommittee on Investigations of the Committee on Government Operations -- (1) for first-hand, behind-the-scenes material we do not already know; (2) for Mr. Cohn's appraisal of McCarthy in perspective; and (3) for whatever light the book may shed, by design or inadvertently, on the character and career of its author.

TRENTON, June 20 -- A bipartisan plan to develop the marshy and largely uninhabited Hackensack River meadowlands into a vast urban complex was killed early this evening in the Assembly's Republican caucus.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- President Johnson expressed pride in his foreign policies tonight -- including his course in Vietnam -- and combined his statement of self-defense with a jest at the expense of educators who have often condemned his course.
All six Republican members of the City Council turned against Mayor Lindsay yesterday as the Council joined the Board of Estimate in overriding all his vetoes of the 1968-69 executive budget.
Wheat, corn and soybean futures had something in common yesterday, all registered lifetime lows in every contract.
Rudolf Bing will continue as the Metropolitan Opera's general manager through the 19711972 season. Mr. Bing, who is 66 years old, has headed the company since 1950.
Edson Arantes Do Naciemento, known as the Black Pearl and Black Tulip in international soccer circles, but listed as just plain Pele on scoreboards, returns to the Yankee Stadium tonight.

The last of the season's "Promenades" offered by the New York Philharmonic at Philharmonic Hall was homegrown, yet anything but homespun. The program, presented last night and to be repeated tonight and tomorrow, attested to the sophistication and variety of styles that American composers can achieve, even in the field of light opera.

An artistic ride by Manuel Ycaza enabled the Cragwood Stable's Jig Time to score a smashing victory yesterday in the feature race at Belmont Park. The accomplishment enabled the aggressive Panamanian jockey to round out a triple for the day, most commendable in view of the fact that he had only three mounts.

The United States Government was held liable yesterday for unspecified damages to a floating Brooklyn drydock five years ago. The damage resulted when a sailor returning from shore leave opened valves that flooded the drydock and capsized the Coast Guard cutter Tamaroa.

BUENOS AIRES, June 20 -- For the second time this year, Argentina's conservative military government is facing a challenge from the judiciary branch, and police under military command are involved in a bitter struggle with judges.

Count Don Luchino Visconti di Modrone, whose family can trace its line back to Charlemagne's father-in-law, frowned. "I don't like to be called by that name. It's useless. Oldfashioned. I prefer Luchino Visconti."
The Vietnamese war is a tempest that may yet be tamed in a teapot.
Besides his secret role as an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Herbert Itkin, a star witness in the Marcus case, was also a code-named agent for the Central Intelligence Agency.

Dr. Benjamin Spock's challenge of the draft comes from an authority on human behavior who is deeply concerned about right and wrong in present United States attitudes toward international law, justice and elementary concepts of humaneness.
MONTREAL, June 20 (AP) -- Interlake shipping in the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Seaway system came to a standstill today in advance of a strike of 1,200 seaway workers scheduled for tomorrow.

A Boston financier testified in Federal court here yesterday that he received written agreements under which three companies controlled by Louis E. Wolfson were to purchase their own stock in private transactions.
COLOGNE, Germany, June 20 (UPI) -- Jupp Elze, West German middleweight boxing champion, died today from injuries received eight days ago in a bout with the European champion, Carlos Duran of Italy.

NORFOLK, Va. June 20 (AP) -- The search for the lost submarine Scorpion has not disclosed undersea mountain peaks high enough for a submarine to collide with, the admiral who directed the search testified today.
CHICAGO, June 20 -- Governor Rockefeller denounced Richard M. Nixon's views on the Vietnam War today, berating the former Vice President for a "dismal display" of "belligerent prophesies."

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -Secretary of Defense Clark M. Clifford said today he was extending to all parts of the nation the Pentagon's rule that servicemen may not rent lodgings from owners who practice racial discrimination.

QUEBEC, June 20 -- Robert L. Stanfield, the Conservative leader campaigning to be the next head of Government in Canada, today accused Pierre Elliott Trudeau, the Liberal Prime Minister, of "exploiting anti-Quebec sentiment" to win the general election next Tuesday.

About 50 demonstrators occupied the sunny, high-ceilinged office of a Bronx school district superintendent yesterday to press their demands that Daniel F. Zeccola be removed as principal of Public School 51.
DEAUVILLE, France June 20 -- Italy led the United States by 23 international match points at the half-way stage in the final of the World Olympiad here tonight.
SAN SALVADOR, June 18 -- Salvador's cautious middle-of-the-road Government has received two severe warnings of possible trouble on its left in recent months.
Prices were mixed at the close of moderately active trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 20 -- The religious antagonisms that still mar the life of Northern Ireland are reflected in the recent expulsion of a Protestant politician from the Orange Order, a militantly Protestant group, because he attended Roman Catholic services as part of a civic celebration.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, June 21 -- Allied soldiers, trying to block North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops from the jungled approaches to Saigon, fought new vicious battles yesterday.

Senator Eugene J. McCarthy told publishers of Negro publications yesterday that the nation could not solve its urban, poverty and racial problems "until power and responsibility are democratically shared."
The Johnson Wax Company is seeking outstanding works in all the crafts for a collection it plans to assemble.

VENICE, Italy, June 20 -"Bravo," cried a jaded art dealer from Rome the other evening, applauding a word brawl in the Piazza San Marco between a young Italian artist and a group of local students from the Fine Arts Academy. "At last we have an interesting Biennale again."
The Security First National Bank of Los Angeles and the Pacific National Bank of San Francisco plan to merge on July 1, they announced jointly yesterday.

Theater lights beamed brightly along Broadway last night as actors ended their three-day strike after overnight negotiations supervised by Mayor Lindsay. At 6 A.M. a tired and wan Mayor announced at Gracie Mansion: "Performances in the Broadway theaters will be resumed tonight."
ATLANTA, June 20 -- The Rev. Dr. Robert J. Marshall of Chicago was elected tonight president of the 3.3-million-member Lutheran Church in America.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -Today was the fifth anniversary of the United StatesSoviet Union agreement to establish an emergency communications link, but State Department officials said there was no acknowledgment of the fact on the Hot Line itself.

Along a treeless street on the industrial outskirts of Cambridge, two miles from Harvard Yard, a new, red brick building stands virtually deserted between a thriving steel plant and a rubber goods factory.
DETROIT, June 20 -- Detroit newspapers are preparing today to break a strike that has kept them closed for more than seven months.

The New York State Trial Lawyers Association, together with District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens, called upon Governor Rockefeller yesterday to convene a special session of the Legislature to enact a strong gun control law.
Opposition among architects, builders and city planners to the prospect of a skyscraper atop Grand Central Terminal appears not to have been softened by the building design produced by Marcel Breuer.
CHICAGO, June 20 -- The printing equipment industry opened its international exposition, PRINT 68, here today with an optimistic eye to the future.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Secretary of Defense Clark M. Clifford said today that he detected "bits and straws" of forward movement in the talks between the American and North Vietnamese negotiating teams in Paris.

LONDON, June 20 -- A year ago the Opposition leader in the House of Lords, Lord Carrington, stood up and told his colleagues: "It has always been my view that the House of Lords will only be able to use its delaying powers once."

The United States stopped bombing Hanoi over two months ago. Now the North Vietnamese bomb Saigon. They use rockets instead of planes. There is not even the pretense of a military target; innocent people are being killed daily.
LONDON, June 20 (Reuters) -- Sir Eric Roll, a director of The Times of London, was named a director of the Bank of England today, succeeding the press magnate Cecil King.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Richard M. Nixon, reportedly eager to return to the campaign trail, will embark shortly on an effort to strengthen his appeal in seven or eight industrial states, most of which he lost to John F. Kennedy in 1960.
BONN, June 20 -- Today was the 20th birthday of one of West Germany's healthiest offspring -- the Deutsche mark.

LONDON, June 20 -- The trouble in France -- that minirevolution -- provided one strange fringe benefit for Britain when London's Festival Ballet was prevented from appearing at Paris's Marais Festival and offered, at very short notice, an unexpected London season at the New Theater.

LOS ANGELES, June 20 (AP) -- A professional gambler who is an ex-convict told a Federal Court jury today that members of the exclusive Friars Club were cheated out of more than $400,000 in crooked card games.

The 350 teachers who have been boycotting eight schools in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville experimental district in Brooklyn have been notified that their services will be terminated in the district when the present term ends on June 28.

The State Investigation Commission said yesterday that evidence of kickbacks, milking of welfare funds and deals between some construction employers and crooked union officials that it had developed was indicative "of what is probably happening in other unions and in other industries operating under similar conditions of racketeer control."
Tenneco, Inc., announced yesterday it had acquired a patent on a cigarette filter using polyurethane, either alone or in combination with various other materials.

BOSTON, June 20 (AP) -Former Deputy Banking Commissioner Martin J. Hanley and five loan company officials convicted in a 221-day small-loans trial received jail terms today ranging from one to six years.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 20 -- Chumbo took the lead for the open jumper championship at the opening session of the Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show today, but win, lose or draw he won't seek the national high point title.

A $13-million valuation that the Interstate Commerce Commission placed last year on the New Haven Railroad's claim to a share in the earnings of Grand Central Terminal was sharply criticized yesterday by a court-appointed special master in the line's reorganization.

PARIS, June 20 (AP) -- The European women's golf team, led by Catherine Lacoste, clinched a 10 1/2-7 1/2 victory over the United States today by winning three of the second-day singles matches and tying another.

LIKE most revolutions, the one in men's fashion is impaling some of its leaders on the horns of a dilemma. What, for instance, is a haberdasher whose fame rests in whole or in part on his neckties supposed to do about assorted movements (from Mao-Nehru to bead-and-bell-wearing hippie) that threaten to do away with that traditional expression of male personality.

CRANFORD, N. J., June 20 -- Some 9,000 persons here and in nearby Kenilworth and Westfield received gamma globulin inoculations last night and today to prevent a possible outbreak of hepatitis from contaminated water.

NEW DELHI, June 20 -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi called upon 52 national leaders attending the two-day meeting of the National Integration Council in Srinagar, Kashmir, today to cooperate on a "manypronged attack on forces of disintegration."

William Manchester, the author who feuded bitterly with the Kennedy family over certain passages of "The Death of a President," and the book's publisher, Harper Row, have contributed $750,000 from the book's profits to the John F. Kennedy Memorial Library at Harvard University.
Winners of monthly grand prizes of up to $100,000 in the New York State Lottery were selected yesterday at a drawing in Liberty Square, Port Chester.

President Johnson's signature of the omnibus crime-control bill is more a surrender to public hysteria over crime in the streets than it is an expression of conviction that the bill represents a sound contribution to the defense of law and order.
PRAGUE, June 20 (Reuters) -- Military exercises involving the armies of five Communist countries began today, the Czechoslovak Defense Ministry announced.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- After more than 10 months of controversy and delay, the House approved a tax increase bill today by 268 to 150. Three members voted "present."

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 20 -- The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, the largest state-chartered bank in the nation, is giving serious consideration to converting to the status of a national or Federally chartered bank, one of the institution's senior officers said here today.

DENVER, June 20 (AP) -- Radioactive fallout dumped on the Albany-Troy, N. Y., area during a rainstorm in 1953 caused a doubling of childhood leukemia over an eight-year period, a radiation health expert said today.
Thousands of workers at 30 voluntary (nonprofit) hospitals here staged noonhour demonstrations yesterday to demand a minimum wage of $100 a week.
The Federal Reserve maintained its tight credit posture during the statement week ended Wednesday, but once again did not move to make it appreciably more restrictive.

PHILIP O. EISENBERG is no speculator. He buys stock for the long pull -- even the cheapies. In early October, 1967, he bought 500 shares of Jamaica Telephone in an over-the-counter purchase for $1,009.50 and waited for the certificate.
FORT WORTH -- They called it "Carter's Folly." Now it is the setting for something of a rural renaissance. By 1971, the city hopes to have one of the country's important visual arts centers.

BERLIN, June 20 -- The three Western allies and their partners in the North Atlantic alliance moved today to curb travel by East Germans to the West in retaliation for new East German visa regulations imposed on West Germans and West Berliners.

Following are excerpts from a question-and-answer session following an address by Vice President Humphrey at the National Press Club in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:

LONDON, June 20 -- Clark Graebner made the Wimbledon seedings look silly for the second time this week and Charles Pasarell gave Rod Laver the fight of his life as the London grass-court championships at the Queen's Club came to boil with a marvelous feast of tennis today.
The eight-year-old court battle between Adam Clayton Powell and Mrs. Esther James resumed in Supreme Court yesterday before Justice Gerald T. Culkin.
ST. LOUIS, June 20 (AP) -Bob Gibson kept three shutout strings alive today by blanking the Chicago Cubs with five hits in leading the St. Louis Cardinals to a 1-0 victory.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., June 20 -- The Board of Education here said today it was "extremely dissatisfied" with the state order to integrate its 11 elementary schools, which are predominantly Negro on the south side of the railroad tracks and white on the north side.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The House Administration Committee approved today a bill that would make it a crime for political candidates to divert campaign contributions to personal use and would tighten contribution and campaign regulations generally.

The Pan Am Building, balanced on the back of Grand Central Terminal north of the great room is, I believe, one of the few structures which New Yorkers really do resent, overbearing as it is to Park Avenue.
Prices on the London stock market renewed an upward trend yesterday after the preceding day's setback.

EMERSON, N. J., June 20 -- Paul McGowan of Plainfield West, a 37-year-old Internal Revenue Service employe, survived the challenge of youth and the elements today to lead the way into the semi-finals of the 67th annual amateur championship of the New Jersey State Golf Association.
An 11-year-old boy fired 20 shots from his apartment window with his father's rifle and wounded a roof repairman in both legs yesterday, according to the police.

Michael Butler, producer of "Hair," said yesterday that he was planning to bring back the Living Theater, an avant-garde repertory group, from a self-imposed European exile to an Off Broadway house in the fall or winter.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 -Three Federal scientists reported today that research performed recently in the United States and Latin America had raised hopes for the development of a vaccine against syphilis.

SUTTON, Mass., June 20 (AP) -- Mrs. Gerda Whalen of Germany and Sandra Post of Canada surprised America's top women golf pros with par-shattering efforts and a share of the first-round lead today in the $20,000 Ladies Professional Golfers' Association championship.
The less than one-year-old marriage between the two major West German trans-Atlantic and cruise steamship lines -- North German Lloyd and German Atlantic Line -- is about to come to an end.
GRENOBLE, France, June 20 -- "If we could vote," said a student at a pinball machine, "a majority would vote for Mendes."
Paramount Pictures's "Rosemary's Baby," the film adaptation of Ira Levin's novel, has been given a "C" (condemned) rating by the National Catholic Office for Motion Pictures.

The top ad man at Time magazine is moving up to a corporate vice presidency. Robert C. Gordon, 53-yearold world advertising director of the weekly news magazine, was elected yesterday a vice president of Time, Inc. He will be replaced at the magazine by John A. Meyers, 39, the former United States ad sales manager.
The police raided an alleged house of prostitution on the East Side at 2 A.M. yesterday that they said contained a swimming pool, sauna bath and several circular "room-sized beds.'

BONN, June 20 -- The West German Government today proposed a subsidized air shuttle between Hanover and West Berlin to compensate for a reduction of Autobahn travel expected as a result of East Germany's new visa rules.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Supporters of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy are planning a nationwide campaign this summer to convince delegates to the Democratic National Convention that their man is more popular than Vice President Humphrey and would make the party's strongest candidate in November.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 -- The St. Francis Hotel on Union Square will add a new 32-story tower with 440 rooms, it was announced today.
ESSEN, Germany -- The first head of the House of Krupp whose name is not Krupp is named Vogelsang, which means bird song.
A WOMAN and a man who occupy opposite ends of the design and price spectrum have won the top honors in the 1968 Coty American Fashion Critics Awards.
The directors of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company have elected Joseph A. McFadden as executive vice president and Harold F. Selesky as senior vice president.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 20 -- Jim Hines and Charlie Greene bettered the world record for the 100-meter dash tonight in the Amateur Athletic Union's national outdoor track and field championships. Each won his semi-final in 9.9 secinds, and many track people suspected that the track was short.

Another summer season of "Jazz in the Garden" concerts opened last night at the Museum of Modern Art. The series, which has been running since 1960 with the exception of two summers, is broadening its perspectives this year to include such tangential areas of jazz as folk-rock, gospel, rhythm and blues and hard rock 'n' roll.
The Board of Estimate gave its approval yesterday of the building of a large apartment development, a high school and a small park on the site of the old Ruppert Brewery in Yorkville.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Marine Corps reprimanded today and cleared for retirement a veteran officer it had charged with offering for publication a book sharply critical of United States policy on Vietnam without submitting it first for official clearance.

CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- Dave Newmark of Columbia University turned his back on American history and grease paint today and signed a three-year contract with the Chicago Bulls of the National Basketball Association.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, June 20 (AP) -- The military police arrested two men today and charged them with having financed an unsuccessful attempt to invade Haiti and overthrow President Francois Duvalier.
The minuscule band of family and friends who ran Paul O'Dwyer's unexpectedly successful campaign for the Democratic nomination for Senator laid plans yesterday to expand into a statewide operation.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

PITTSBURGH, June 20 (UPI) -- Pinch-hitter Jim Fairey's first major league homer in the 10th inning tonight enabled the Los Angeles Dodgers to score a 3-2 victory which snapped Pittsburgh's nine-game winning streak after the Pirates had won the opener of a twilightnight doubleheader, 7-3.

NEW HAVEN, June 20 -- Reveling in brisk, gusty northwest winds, San Diego State College sailors overtook Yale and established a commanding lead today in the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association of North America's dinghy championship off Short Beach.
BOSTON, June 20 -- Reform Jewish spiritual leaders were given the right today to seek deferments as military chaplains on the ground of conscientious objection to a particular war.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Federal and local policemen faced angry, bottle-throwing youths outside Resurrection City early today in the latest of a series of disorders in and around the camp.

Directors of the General Artists Corporation, the Trans-Beacon Corporation and Creative Management Associates, Ltd., have approved a merger involving about $50-million in stock, it was announced yesterday.
The big shooting scene is coming up in Congress. It is taking on the look of the familiar walkdown between the good guys and the gunslingers at high noon in the Old West.

DETROIT, June 20 (AP) -- The nation's auto industry stepped up its production to a scheduled 205,018 cars this week, an increase of nearly two per cent over last week's 201,012 despite a reduction in Saturday operations.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., June 20 -- Speakers at a hearing here tonight ran 4 to 1 in opposition to the state's plan for a Hudson River Expressway, and the 300 persons pressent indicated by their booing that they too were overwhelmingly opposed.
HOUSTON, June 20 -- Some publicized Westec Corporation profits were based on sales that never took place, the former president of the company testified today.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Vice President Humphrey resumed his Presidential campaign today with a pledge that he would be his own man if elected.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 20 -- In the pattern of the ghost of Hamlet's father, the spectral figure of Cassius Clay hovers somewhere in the background whenever Joe Frazier provides drama with his fists. It may come as a surprise to the unfrocked heavyweight champion of the world to learn that his disembodied spirit is currently haunting the Borscht Belt as Joe's private spook.
YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, June 20 -- "I am a lot healthier today than when I was 20."
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Administration's gun control bill was approved today by the House Judiciary Committee but ran into a potentially troublesome delay in the Senate Judiciary Committee.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Privately owned housing starts in May fell 16 per cent below those in April to an adjusted annual rate of 1,331,000 units, the Commerce Department reported today.

PARIS -- The new Berlin crisis -- or noncrisis -- can obviously not be separated from other crises, real or potential, in our complicated world. Although the fact is rarely mentioned nowadays, Berlin remains an ultimate touchstone.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 20 (AP) -- Amid clouds of tear gas, policemen and students fought today for the second day in a row in a dispute over education policies. More than 100 people were re ported arrested.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Demonstrators of the Poor People's Campaign staged their first acts of mass civil disobedience today, and 87 marchers were arrested in a series of confrontations with policemen hurling teargas.

PARIS, June 20 -- With more than nine million Frenchmen back on their jobs after nearly five weeks of strikes, the tenuousness of the labor peace was illustrated today by the workers' reoccupation of a factory at Vichy.

As the House of Representatives began consideration of the tax bill and defeated an early move to block it, prices rose strongly throughout the money and capital markets yesterday. Later in the day, the House approved the tax measure.

With yesterday's affirmative vote in the House, the bill combining the 10 per cent tax surcharge and the $6-billion reduction in Federal spending has surmounted the most serious hurdle in the long and tortuous obstacle course that has bedeviled and delayed it. At long last, flexible fiscal policy will have a chance to work.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -A high Pentagon official told Congress today that "the United States can no more afford to refuse to sell arms to its friends abroad than it could undertake a unilateral disarmament."

BONN, June 21 -- The chief Government spokesman, Gunter Diehl, said today, in reply to a question, that West Germany was weighing the possibility of flying freight into West Berlin to bypass East Germany's increase in truck and barge tolls to West Berlin, which will go into effect July 1.
Mayor Lindsay held a reconciliation meeting in his office yesterday with five of the six Republican Councilmen who voted, on Thursday, with Democrats to override his vetoes of the 1968-69 budget.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 21 -- Pam Carmichael made equestrian history today at the Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show when she rode the winners of both the large and small junior working hunter divisions for the second straight week.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 21 -- Since so many Minnesotans are of Scandinavian descent, one would have thought an Ibsen play would be among the first orders of business when the Minnesota Theater Company got started in 1963.

DEAUVILLE, France, June 21 -- The incomparable Italian Blue Team won its 11th world championship title here this afternoon, beating the United States team in the Olympiad final by 49 international match points, 172-123.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 21 -- United States sources said today that misinterpreted radar blips and the sighting of "flying lights" might have caused the reports that enemy helicopters were operating around the demilitarized zone.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk tried today to check any sense of optimism that the Paris talks with North Vietnam were on the verge of significant progress.

Civil commitment of narcotics addicts at their own request or the request of relatives will be suspended Monday because of inadequate funds and lack of space in state treatment centers, judges throughout the state have been informed.
TORONTO, June 21 -- Bruce Devlin of Australia and Arnold Palmer of Latrobe, Pa., found the second round of the Canadian Open golf championship to be a turning point today.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- President Johnson approved today the award of a Moscowto-New York route to the Soviet airline, Aeroflot.

PARIS, June 21 -- To many of the 15 million women who are registered voters in France, President de Gaulle is a stern but soothing grandfather figure who always knows best. As women voters outnumber men by nearly two million, the outcome of the legislative election Sunday and the future of President de Gaulle may depend on how they feel.

David R. Segal in a letter published June 14 mistakenly assumes that the designation of Doak Barnett as head of the "After Vietnam Task Fore" indicated the order of national priority of the Vice President.
Sales and earnings of the H. J. Heinz Company in the three and twelve months ended May 1 set records, R. Burt Gookin, president, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk jokingly suggested today that the allergies now suspected of giving him a slight fever might be related to his political critics.

The New York State Banking Board set the interest ceiling on home mortgage loans at 7 1/4 per cent yesterday. This new rate, which is effective July 1, replaces a 6 per cent ceiling that had been in force since 1880.
Negro leaders disagreed sharply yesterday on whether the peace issue or civil rights played the major role in capturing the Negro vote for Paul O'Dwyer in Tuesday's Democratic primary.

Of all the inequities in welfare programs, the cruelest are those that penalize children for the behavior of their parents. Such inhuman denial of Federal funds will no longer be allowed, as the result of a unanimous decision by the Supreme Court on the so-called "substitute father" regulation.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., June 21 -- Hugo Vihlen, unable to buck the surging Gulf Stream in his six-foot sailboat April Fool, ended his 4,100-mile solo trans-Atlantic voyage 25 miles from shore today and came home aboard a fishing yacht to a hero's reception.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 21 -- Students stoned the United States Embassy and fought the police here today. At least three persons, including a policeman, were killed. Dozens were injured and scores were arrested.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Saturday, June 22 -- Thailand promulgated her long-awaited Constitution yesterday and began her latest attempt at building a working democracy after almost 10 years of military rule.

MONTREAL, June 21 -- Carrying his election campaign to this city today, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau had to stop on the way in from the airport because the engine of the open-air bus he was riding in became overheated.

Kenneth Clark of the State Board of Regents tried to submarine the proposed decentralization plan passed by the State Legislature by urging the community to take over the schools should the Governor sign the bill. The bill, however, was signed.
The Municipal Art Society has expressed its "determined opposition" to the proposed second skyscraper over Grand Central Terminal.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren has quietly submitted his resignation to President Johnson after 15 years as the nation's highest-ranking judicial officer.

The newly elected head of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee emerges as a quiet, scholarly and effective organizer of the poor through the eyes of those who know him. He is maintaining a policy of strict silence about himself.
The sensation among the current fillies, Lloyd Miller's Dark Mirage, will be the big attraction for the bettors in the Coaching Club American Oaks at Belmont Park today.
VENICE, Italy, June 21 -- To catch the Biennale, you'd better look fast. That's the word passed along by Venetian students, and as of this moment it seems to ring true.
WHO would have thought that a rumor of a possible take-over of the Franklin National Bank could possibly get started?

Mayor Lindsay, who in the past has discouraged members of his administration from becoming involved in political campaigns, said yesterday that many of his key people were working in the Presidential campaign of Democratic Senator Eugene J. McCarthy.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower's doctors decided today that he was getting along so well they would stop issuing daily medical bulletins on his progress after a fifth heart attack.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The president of the American Stock Exchange suggested today that the trading activities of large institutional investors, such as mutual funds, may have to be placed under the same kinds of restrictions as the activities of brokerage firms.

BOSTON, June 21 (AP) -- The Christian Science Monitor will report in its editions tomorrow that a survey by its political writers shows that Governor Rockefeller would have almost enough electoral votes to defeat Vice President Humphrey if a Presidential election were held between them today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 21 -- The South Vietnamese police broke through a crowd in the heart of Saigon today and seized an American who had just burned a draft card.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 21 -- The leader of the Venezuelan Communist party sat smiling and comfortable in his tastefully furnished living room, surrounded by gold-framed pictures of his five grandchildren.
DETROIT, June 21 -- A former New York City police officer, Johannes F. Spreen, was named Police Commissioner here today.
LONDON, June 21 -- The British Actors Equity Association said today that "if anything we are too liberal" in allowing American actors into Britain.

At 2:30 P.M. yesterday the Uniformed Firemen's Association signed the first written labor contract in its history. At 3 P.M., it filed notice with the city's Office of Collective Bargaining that it was ready to negotiate a new contract.
I believe the city should cover the uninsured losses resulting from the ruptured water main in Bedford-Stuyvesant so movingly described in a news story in The Times of June 12.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 21 -- A fife-and-drum corps welcomed Governor Rockefeller to this restored Colonial capital today with an 18th-century air called "A Successful Campaign."

LOS ANGELES, June 21 -- The Los Angeles Police Department canceled today a nationwide wanted - for - questioning bulletin for an unidentified "woman in a polka-dot dress" reported at the scene of Senator Robert F. Kennedy's fatal shooting June 5.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 21 -- Walter Nirenberg, who takes over tomorrow as president of the American Apparel Manufacturers Association, is a production-oriented executive in an industry that has traditionally been marketing-centered.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 21 -- Seventeen persons, including the 17-year-old daughter of Dutchess County Executive David Schoentag, were arrested in this area last night and early today in a series of narcotics raids.
PEMBROKE, Ontario, June 21 -- After putting in 8,000 miles of driving in a month of campaigning, Delbert O'Brien, candidate for Parliament, said he felt as if he had only started.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- The strong showing registered by Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota in the New York Democratic primary may contribute to keeping the important 118-vote Illinois delegation to the party's national convention uncommitted throughout the pre-convention period.
ATHENS, June 21 -- The leaders of Greece's Orthodox Church have formally condemned abortion as a "sinful and criminal act."
THIS is a good time to buy Belter furniture: The prices are about what they were 20 years ago. However, finding such pieces of furniture may be a problem.
Ground was broken yesterday for Westbeth, the world's largest housing project for artists.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- South Africa found a way today to get rid of some of its mounting hoard of gold without breaking prices on the free market. But the method is not likely to recur often, or in large amounts.

A militant neighborhood leader and the head of a research concern preparing a report on slums for the National Association of Manufacturers stood on a decayed Brownsville street yesterday and debated the causes of the deterioration around them.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Johnson Administration's new program to find jobs for the disadvantaged through the private sector has exceeded expectations for the hard-core unemployed, but has fallen far short in youth employment for the summer, the White House reported today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 21 -- They rise at dawn. Each morning they learn to set up mortars and plant booby traps and charge with bayonets.

A principal and one of his teachers were reassigned yesterday as part of a temporary settlement ending a 28-hour sit-in at a Bronx school district superintendent's office by demonstrators demanding the principal's suspension.

SEATTLE, June 21 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy's heartened supporters are flexing their political muscles in Washington in the aftermath of the Minnesotan's victory in the New York primary last Tuesday.

If some benevolent dream merchant decided to compose a script for the satisfaction of New York Met fans among the 46,868 at Shea Stadium last night, he could hardly improve on the real-life details that went into a 5-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
ATLANTA, June 21 -- The Rev. Dr. George F. Harkins was elected secretary of the 3.3-million-member Lutheran Church in America today.

The end of the spring season in New York is bringing some unexpected visitors into the concert halls. Two nights ago the Argentine Mozarteum Wind Quintet made what was almost an impromptu appearance at Town Hall, playing a program with beautiful precision and style.

A Slovak writer has reported that many East European Jews, including Communists, have emigrated to Israel convinced that "the possibility of socialism for Jews could exist only in their own Jewish state."

MIAMI, June 21 (UPI) -- The tropical storm called Brenda sprang to life with winds of 60 to 70 miles per hour in the Atlantic Ocean today and began intensifying while heading away from the United States mainland.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 21 -- The greatest sprinting orgy in track and field history was held last night in the Amateur Athletic Union's national outdoor championships. The times were so fast they were difficult to believe. Many highly placed track officials and coaches still refuse to believe them.

The Columbia Broadcasting System took issue yesterday with the Supreme Court's decision last Monday that community antenna television systems do not infringe a copyright when they pick up programs from the air and distribute them to homes of subscribers.

ROME, June 21 (AP) -- Pope Paul VI has agreed to allow Roman Catholic theologians to become members of the Faith and Constitution Committee sponsored by the World Council of Churches, the Vatican announced today.
Eugene R. Black, former president of the World Bank and now a business consultant, announced yesterday his resignation as a director of Comsat, the Communications Satellite corporation.

The New York City Hospital-affiliation program has been the center of considerable controversy. Privately controlled voluntary hospitals have been engaged to staff the city hospitals with hospital-employed salaried physicians -- at a 10 per cent profit. The program has been the subject of two investigations, one by the City Controller concerning its cost, and the other by state legislators concerned with quality of care rendered patients in city institutions.

WOMEN who live on the Upper West Side don't have to travel to the East Village to buy dresses with bells on them. There are clothes for hippies as well as for students, career girls and housewives in the fashion shops that are burgeoning along the two-and-a-half-mile strip bounded roughly by Columbia University on the north and Lincoln Center on the south.

Great as was the impact of Tuesday's primary, it would unquestionably have been even greater if New York State had a true Presidential preference primary, with slates of delegates legally bound to support the winner at least on the first convention ballot. The Legislature should act to convert the New York primary into such a contest so that this state's voters and the state itself can exercise their proper share in selecting Presidential candidates.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 21 -- Major commercial banks in Newark have agreed to provide low-cost personal loans to individuals in the largely Negro Central Ward who would not otherwise qualify for credit.
BALTIMORE, June 21 (AP) -- An aide to George C. Wal lace said today a rally scheduled for Baltimore next Thursday night had been switched to Columbia, Md.
LANSING, Mich., June 21 (UPI) -- Gov. George Romney urged the Republican party today to include his proposal for "guaranteed neutralization" of Vietnam in its 1968 platform.
"As a businessman, I'm hardly in favor of tax increases. But we have to do something to get our house in order. The tax increase may be the way of bringing home to people what has to be done."

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Senator Mark O. Hatfield, who surprised many observers yesterday by endorsing Richard M. Nixon for the Presidency, explained today that one reason he had done so was to be "in a better position" to influence Vietnam war policy should the Republicans win in November.
NEWARK, June 21 -- An all-black political convention opened a three-day meeting here tonight hoping to gain a consensus on Negro candidates for the coming citywide election.

LONDON, June 21 -- It hardly bears believing. In a field was loaded with top professionals, two amateurs will clash for the London grass-court tennis title tomorrow when Clark Graebner of the United States meets Tom Okker of the Netherlands.

Communist China, the United Nations' odd man out, once more was conspicuous by its absence last week when the General Assembly endorsed a nuclear nonproliferation treaty that was properly hailed by most of the rest of the world as a major step toward ending the peril of nuclear war. Obviously, that peril remains critical as long as one of the five atomic powers remains outside international arms control and security arrangements.
France's renowned and immensely popular Theatre de la Cite, a true theater of the proletariat that sells a working man a good seat for $1 at home,, has come to New York for a three-week run.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- For an official who is not allowed a dime for professional image-making and whose every public thought is written on the public record, the Chief Justice of the United States is the wonder if not the envy of image seekers in this capital.
A Christian prelate from the Middle East warned at an interfaith gathering yesterday that "atheistic ideologies" were making inroads among the Arabs. He was apparently referring to Communism.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- A tiny loom that weaves a square inch of textile material is saving money for the carpet industry. The device, which is about two by three inches overall, displays carpet designs for buyers, avoiding the considerable cost of larger samples. John M. Snyder, director of research and development for Viking Carpets, Inc., New York, received Patent 3,388,441 for it this week.

Mayor Lindsay revised experimental traffic regulations in the garment district yesterday after leaders of the industry protested that loading regulations put into effect on Monday were causing "complete chaos."
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Consider the problem of Senator Philip A. Hart.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The final Congressional passage of the tax bill today will significantly slow the booming American economy, in the view of experts in and out of the Government.
Prices rose in the money and capital markets yesterday in celebration of enactment of the tax bill, but the advance was not wild.
ALBANY, June 21 -- Governor Rockefeller signed a bill today limiting cancellation or reduction of automobile insurance during the life of the policy.
Jake had been selling ice cream at a street corner on Second Avenue in East Harlem.

SUTTON, Mass., June 21 (AP) -- Sandra Post, a 20-year-old pro rookie from Oakville, Ontario, took a one-stroke lead today in the second round of the $20,000 Ladies Professional Golfers' Association championship.

BORDEAUX, June 21 -- The prices of a number of French wines exported to dealers in the United States are expected here to rise by between 5 and 15 per cent in the next several months as a result of the present round of wage Increases in France.
JACKSON, Miss., June 21 -- George C. Wallace of Alabama campaigned before both houses of the Mississippi Legislature today and later directed some verbal fire toward one of his favorite targets.
A plea for the rebuilding of the American merchant marine was made here yesterday by a former Congressman and diplomat.
Mayor Lindsay leaned forward toward the short, blinking man standing by a cot in an infirmary for derelicts yesterday.

The very first ensemble to be heard in Lincoln Center Festival '68, which will present several major performing groups from all over the world, turned out to be the Police Department's Emerald Society Piper Band.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- When Earl Warren was waging his campaigns for Governor of California, the word in the West was that nobody was for him except the voters.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 21 -- While last-minute preparations were being made today along the waterfront for a Bermuda race start tomorrow that was jeopardized by the tropical storm Brenda, a protest committee met at the Ida Lewis Yacht Club and nullified a shorter, related event.
STORNOWAY, Island of Lewis with Harris, Scotland -- A bus carring a dozen tourists pulled out of a village in the southern part of this island in the Outer Hebrides on June 16 and made history.
One of the nation's bestpublicized experiments in resident repertory theater appears to have ended in failure.
HARTFORD, June 21 -- Connecticut Democrats convened here this evening, still sharply divided over the choice of a Presidential candidate.
Eli Zaret, former director of the Bureau of Receivership, a part of the city's Department of Real Estate, was indicted yeserday on charges of accepting a $500 bribe from reputed underworld figures.
The London stock market moved up on a broad front yesterday under the stimulus of encouraging economic and corporate reports.

PARIS, June 21 -- Premier Georges Pompidou charged tonight that the Opposition had started to prepare a campaign of post-election violence and that some men and organizations had begun to go underground for this purpose.

The establishment of a philanthropic, educational and literary organization to create a better understanding of Latin American and Spanish culture among American audiences was announced here yesterday.

OMAGH, Northern Ireland, June 21 -- The Mellons of Pittsburgh certainly are not one of your average American families, so it wasn't very surprising, really, when they decided to have a reunion not in Pennsylvania, where they keep a lot of their $3-billion fortune, but here in Northern Ireland where they all began.

The historic decision by the United States Supreme Court in the case of Jones v. Mayer Company represents for the Negro as much of a milestone in the field of housing as Brown v. Board of Education did in the field of education. This judicial landmark, citing both constitutional and Congressional mandates that are a century old, tears down the last legal walls of discrimination surrounding private and public housing.

The end of this school year indicated clearly that the American campus is as confused as the state of America. The radical activists who make the headlines represent a very small minority. Most students remain complacent, as American students have always tended to be.

PATERSON, N. J., June 21 (AP) -- Superior Court Judge Gordon H. Brown revoked today the $50,000 bail for Harold Matzner, a defendant in the tangled Kavanaugh - DeFrance murder cases, and ordered him sent to jail.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 18 -- A historic dream of building a bridge across the Bosporus to link the European and Asian halves of Istanbul is nearing reality.

SAIGON, Saturday, June 22 -- Skimming across the glittering paddy fields at 100 miles an hour in the Mekong Delta yesterday, the armed helicopters were upon the little band of Vietcong soldiers almost before they were heard.

TORONTO, June 21 -- The St. Lawrence Seaway, a vital route to the Atlantic for Mid-western farmers and business men in the United States and Canada, was closed today by a strike of 1,250 operating and maintenance workers.

Dr. Linus C. Pauling, the Nobel Prize winning chemist, told an "emergency meeting" of scientists yesterday that if Federal support for science research and education was cut back heavily, "the United States will suffer seriously for many years."

Truett Laboratories, a division of the Southwestern Drug Corporation in Dallas, Tex., said yesterday it had developed a process for producing L-as-paraginase, a drug that has shown promise in treating leukemia, on a large-scale basis.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday sharply criticized university administrations at schools disrupted by students.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Senate overwhelmingly passed the tax increase and expenditure control bill today and sent it to President Johnson. The vote was 64 to 16.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 21 -- Like Mighty Mouse, the New York Yankees rose up tonight, shook off their .210 team batting average, rattled 15 hits off four pitchers and subdued the powerful Minnesota Twins, 11-6.

NEWARK, June 21 -- Supporters of state legislation to develop the Hackensack River meadowlands deplored today the defeat of the measure in the Republican Assembly caucus but said that they would press ahead with their plans until they succeeded.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 21 (AP) -- A long-standing position that bars divorcees from the Church of the Nazarene unless the divorces were the result of adultery by a spouse was left untouched today after strong debate on the floor of the General Assembly.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., June 21 -- Nevele Pride set a world record for a 3-year-old trotting colt in competition over a half-mile oval tonight as he romped to victory in the $15,100 Battle of Saratoga at Saratoga Raceway.
The stock market advanced slightly yesterday in comparatively sluggish trading. Late profit taking shaved some of the earlier gains.

GROWN-UP Girl Scouts, some 600,000 volunteers and professional staff in all, are scheduled to adopt a new uniform in late summer or as soon as the old ones wear out. The familiar two-piece, forest-green dress will be replaced by a simple, one-piece A-line style with walking pleats and patch pockets designed by Stella Sloat.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Patrick Lyndon Nugent, grandson of President Lyndon Baines Johnson, gave one of his many news conferences as he celebrated his first birthday at the White House today.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The Blackstone Rangers, a street gang in Chicago, were armed by self-styled revolutionists and prepared to join a national Negro uprising, investigating Senators were told today.

EMERSON, N. J., June 21 -- George Haines Jr. of Somerset Hills and Frank O'Brien Jr. of Plainfield, a pair of precision-playing youngsters, shot their way into the final round of the 67th annual amateur championship of the New Jersey State Golf Association today.
CESKE BUDEJOVICE, Czechoslovakia, June 18 -- The Roman Catholic bishop of this diocese in South Bohemia was nervous when he picked up his telephone and heard a police officer identify himself.
ASCOT, England, June 21 (AP) -- The Royal Ascot meeting today ended with a victory for Queen Elizabeth II.
There were fireworks at Yankee Stadium last night even before Santos of Brazil, led by the great Pele, started play against Napoli of Italy.

TOKYO, June 21 -- Ken Yasui, a candidate in the Tokyo constituency for the House of Councilors, Japan's Senate, climbed the ladder to the top of his campaign car as if he had not already done so half a dozen times during the morning. The spring in his step belied his 57 years.

THE labor pains the Roman Catholic Church has been visibly undergoing in its efforts to give birth to a new life-style in the spirit of the Ecumenical Council Vatican II were the subject of an interesting but rather superficial and unbalanced documentary last night on the National Broadcasting Company.

SCHENECTADY, June 21 -- John J. Burns, the Democratic state chairman was optimistic today that a floor fight could be avoided next Friday when the state committee picks at-large delegates who will command 65 votes at the Democratic national convention.

The Ingalls Shipbuilding Division of Litton Industries, New Orleans, yesterday submitted the lowest of three bids for the construction of eight large, combination container - conventional cargo ships for Farrell Lines and for American President Lines.

BRUSSELS, June 21 -- Many European money managers and investors have shrugged off their fears about the dollar and dollar shares and are plunging into Wall Street.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -The leader of the Poor People's Campaign demanded today that President Johnson explain to the nation the reason why poverty exists in America.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Less than two months ago, President Johnson protested that a $6-billion cut in Federal spending would bring chaos to Government operations.

Rabbi Yehuda Leib Levin Moscow's Chief Rabbi, held "court" yesterday to a stream of Orthodox rabbis who called to pay their respects and endorse his efforts to establish contact between Russian and American Jews after a lapse of more than 50 years.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -If your ideas about LatinAmerican music are still limited to catchy rhythms, bewitching tunes and simple but colorful instrumentations, you had better start updating them.
Two partners and an employe of one of the nation's major accounting concerns were found guilty by a Federal Court jury here yesterday of conspiring to issue false financial statements.

ST. LOUIS, June 21 (UPI) -The last of the great river paddle boats -- the Delta Queen -churned toward St. Louis today and a meeting with a Representative who is fighting to keep the big sternwheeler plying the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) -- A panel including Stokely Carmichael, the militant Negro leader; Mrs. Martin Luther King Jr. and Sidney Poitier, the actor, announced today plans to evaluate the Presidential candidates and make recommendations to Negro voters.
GENEVA, June 21 -- Canada was authorized today to delay for six months the first tariff cuts on chemicals and plastics that she was to introduce under last years Kennedy round trade agreement.

John L. Edmonds, 41 years old, a Harlem-born lawyer and former Deputy Commissioner of the Community Development Agency, was appointed yesterday director of the Model Cities Neighborhood in the Harlem -East Harlem area.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 21 -- A conference of non-Communist Asian states on a prospective settlement in Vietnam and a plan for regional development after peace returns to the area is being pushed quietly by Premier Thanom Kittikachorn of Thailand and his Foreign Minister, Thanat Khoman.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 21 (UPI) -- Vice President Humphrey swept up the lion's share of Indiana's 63 delegate votes today at a state Democratic convention picketed by supporters of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy.

By the usual rules, world sugar futures should have closed higher yesterday and silver futures should have declined. Instead, sugar moved down and silver rose.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Army has sharply reduced its support of civilian marksmanship programs, limiting it to those clubs whose members generally still have their military obligations ahead of them.

BORDEAUX, France, June 21 -- A longtime Gaullist campaigner, whose intimates call him "mon general," Jacques Chaban-Delmas mixed grandeur and glibness this week in his drive for re-election to the French National Assembly.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 21 -- George Young and Wade Bell turned in the brightest performances tonight as the Amateur Athletic Union's 80th annual national track and field championships ended in a blaze of records.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Shortly after Earl Warren became Chief Justice of the United States in 1953, the term "Warren Court" began to be used to describe the bold, liberal look that the Supreme Court acquired.

PARIS, June 21 -- North Vietnamese negotiators appeared today to go along with the American assessment that the atmosphere of the negotiations on Vietnam is improving slightly, but they insisted there had been "no progress" on issues of substance.

Larry Newbold of the Bronx, top scorer on the 1967-68 Long Island University basketball team, has been named assistant varsity basketball coach of the Blackbirds by Roy Rubin, director of athletics and head varsity basketball coach.

ANDROS ISLAND, the Bahamas -- This thinly populated island, the largest in the Bahamas chain, has only one hotel, no supermarkets, no drugstores and almost no paved roads. POLSON, Mont. -- Conservationists term Montana and its resources one of America's best- kept secrets. Some of the state's recreational resources are so-out of the way that the average Montanan, let alone the visitor, is unaware of them.

WHATEVER else is happening in the realm of railroad passenger service, the annual revival of summertime excursions renews hope among some rail enthusiasts that at least a few carriers will continue to provide room on their tracks for something other than freight.

THE one thing Mose (Chief) Yellowhorse liked about being a relief pitcher was it gave him a chance to catch up on his sleep. Since he was in the habit of short-changing himself on slumber because of a weakness for bar-hopping the night before, the Pawnee Indian snoozed blissfully away in the bull pen under each warming afternoon sun.
PARIS, June 22 -- Three Americans face the unknown tomorrow in the $140,000 Grand Steeplechase of Paris.

DURHAM, N. C., June 22 (UPI) -- Gail Sykes, a junior from Odessa (Tex.) College, defeated Carol Semple of Hollins College in Virginia, 10 and 9, to win the 24th annual women's collegiate golf tournament today.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) -- Richard M. Nixon called the crime rate in Washington "a national disgrace" today. He promised that, if elected President, he would restore "freedom from fear" to the city.

BERGEN, Norway -- When June arrives here in western Norway, Bergen seems to stretch and yawn after a long, dark winter. This is fruit country, and, until the middle of this month, the apple, cherry, plum and pear trees were in full bloom.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -Some of the richest and most prominent businessmen in Haiti are reported to have been summoned before a military tribunal this weekend in connection with an abortive invasion attempt by Haitian exiles last month.
WESTPORT, Conn, June 23 -Gustavus won the open jumper championship at the Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show today after a race that was not decided until the first jumpoff of the final class.
In the presence of the largest baseball crowd of 1968, the New York Mets completed a highly satisfactory home stand by beating the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5-4, at Shea Stadium yesterday.

Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, says the United States must set up a nongovernment commission to keep watch on Federal spending and cut expenditures down to the highest priorities.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 23 -- Britain has presented a letter to Secretary General Thant rejecting the explanations given by Spain for having imposed new restrictions on movement to and from Gibraltar.

A 21-year-old man was shot and killed in the Orchard Beach picnic grounds in the Bronx shortly before 11 A.M. yesterday in what the police described as the climax to a night of drinking by the victim, his alleged assailant and two other friends.

Last week's huge Solidarity Day demonstration in Washington provided impressive notice to the nation of the magnitude of its unfulfilled commitment to 30 million poor citizens. It was an important message, delivered with dignity and order; it is entitled to prompt response from Congress and the Administration in ways that will be meaningful in broadening access to America's abundance.
A 36-year-old specialist in hospital administration has been appointed chief executive of the Bellevue Hospital Center.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Some observers here believe that one of the hopeful "bits and straws" in the current Vietnam diplomacy is, paradoxically, Communist China's continued nervousness about the talks between North Vietnam and the United States.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 23 (AP) -- The authorities today suspended classes indefinitely at the university here and ordered public school vacations to begin a week early after student activists said they would continue demonstrations that led to one death, scores of injuries and 1,500 arrests in three days of violence last week.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 23 -- President Abdel Rahman Arif of Iraq issued a decree today accepting the resignation of two Kurdish Ministers, Ihsan Shirzade, Minister of Municipalities, and Abdel Fettah Shali, Minister of Development in the North (Kurdistan).

The annual cost for a moderate living standard for a retired couple in the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area in the fall of 1966 was estimated at $4,323, the Middle Atlantic Office of the Bureau of Labor statistics said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -Gov. Ronald Reagan of California said today that Chief Justice Earl Warren would show "lack of faith in this system of ours" if he resigned now so that President Johnson could choose a successor before leaving the White House.
STRATFORD, Conn., June 23 -- Watching "Richard II" at the opening of the 14th American Shakespeare Festival last night, I was struck by the number of really awful lines in this play.

ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, June 23 (AP) -- Jackie Stewart of Scotland, driving with his right wrist in a cast, won the Dutch Grand Prix in a French Matra-Ford today, giving France its first world championship auto race victory since 1952.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., June 23 -- In all of Long Island this sunny Sunday afternoon the only driver who had no trouble with the traffic was Mark Donohue. The brush-top mechanical engineer from Media, Pa., serenely tooled his Chevrolet Camaro past everything in his way to win a TransAmerican race for small sedans over the 2.85-mile Bridgehampton Race Circuit.
NORTON, Conn., June 23 -Andrew T. Kostanecki won the Eastern championship regatta of the International Tempest Class for the second straight year today on Long Island Sound.

TEL AVIV, June 23 -- Israel began excavation today for the route of a new oil pipeline.

BABYLON, L. I., June 23 -- An infant girl and her older sister were drowned this afternoon when an outboard motor boat capsized in the heavy swells of Fire Island Inlet. Their uncle was missing and presumed drowned.

SUMMER replacements on television traditionally fall into the categories of network throwaways made up of pilot films of rejected series or tryouts for new talent. Two of this summer's better replacements fall into the latter category.

TORONTO, June 23 -- Bob Charles of New Zealand reiterated today a simple golfing premise as he won the Canadian open championship by two strokes with a 72-hole total of 274. The premise: It doesn't make any difference whether you hit the ball right-handed or left-handed as long as you do so in fewer strokes than your opponent.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 23 -- Ted Uhlaender, a statistics graduate of Baylor University, produced some unusual statistics today as the Minnesota Twins finally overpowered the New York Yankees, 6-3.

Parochialism has long been the curse of New Jersey's government. The defeat of the proposal to create a state agency to reclaim and develop the Hackensack meadows for the benefit of the entire state is a depressing new example of the grip held by this kind of selfish short-sightedness. The plan was killed by the Republican caucus mainly because of the outcries of thirteen local communities, whose rights would in fact have been fully protected.

WOODBOURNE, N. Y, June 23 -- Correction officers at the state's narcotics addiction rehabilitation center here will be allowed to carry riot sticks as a result of a rampage last week in which two-thirds of the 600 addicts attacked guards and smashed windows.

BRADLEY BEACH, N. J., June 23 -- Chief Rabbi Yehuda Leib Levin of Moscow emphasized repeatedly in speeches today that the Torah was the religious document that united Jews the world over.

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, June 23 (Reuters) -- The Government will shortly apply "serious charges" against the director of the Bahamas Government Information Service, David Knox, who was arrested here June 1, the First Secretary of the British High Commission in Kingston, Jamaica, Charles Sanderson said here tonight.

Seventeenth rather than 18th, for Visconti has set the action a century earlier than Mozart envisaged it.

Capt. Harry F. Guggenheim's Too Bald will head an expected field of 12 fillies and mares today in the $29,250 Vagrancy Handicap at Belmont Park. The 18th running of the sevenfurlong dash will mark the opening of the final week of the new Belmont's spring meeting.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 23 -A Swedish champion, Kentucky Fibber, is the second entry in the $100,000 Roosevelt International on July 13 at Roosevelt Raceway. The three owners of Kentucky Fibber cabled acceptance of an invitation to the 1 1/4-mile trot today.

District Director in San Francisco ruled against the club.

Parcel Tankers, Inc., of Oslo, Norway, a pioneer in the recent development of liquid-carrying tankers, has placed an order for four new 17,000-ton vessels with J. Boel Fils, S. A., Tamise, Belgium.

A youngster who said he wanted "to go to South America and be a revolutionary" and a silver-haired candidate for the United States Senate who scored an upset victory in the Democratic primary shared the stage yesterday at the Benjamin Franklin High School commencement.
CLEVELAND, June 24 (AP) -- Jim Northrup of the Detroit Tigers tied a major league record with two bases-loaded homers tonight as he paced the Tigers to a 14-3 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI) -- A minister denied today sworn testimony that his church had been used as an arsenal for South Side Chicago's biggest youth gang.

A strong leasing market and firm rental rates have been found in a study of office space in downtown Newark.
Governor Rockefeller has vetoed a bill that would have increased to life imprisonment the penalty for selling or offering marijuana to minors. The present maximum in New York State is 25 years.

The Glen Alden Corporation's tender offer for shares of Schenley Industries, Inc., has been delayed by a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of the Glen Alden registration statement. The statement, filed three months ago, has not yet received S.E.C. approval.
The Transit Authority said yesterday that it expected to lose more than $6-million a month operating the subways in the fiscal year starting next Monday and that this would endanger the 20-cent fare.
MOSCOW, June 24 (AP) -A North Vietnamese delegation arrived Moscow today to open talks on next year's Soviet military and economic aid, now estimated at more than $1-billion a year.
Despite a rise in sales, Corning Glass Works and subsidiaries showed a decline in earnings for the 24 weeks ended June 16, according to the report issued yesterday.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 24 -An overnight "prom train" excursion for 185 high school seniors ended at 5 A.M. today when the police ordered the train cleared.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The leadership of Communist China has undergone the most extensive purge in the 19year history of the regime, but the power struggle in Peking remains unresolved and a warning of a possible "new civil war" has appeared in the official press. The warning appeared in the Shanghai newspaper Wen Hui Pao.

Archbishop Terence J. Cooke announced yesterday a major reorganization of the training of candidates for priesthood in the Roman Catholic archdiocese here in a move to strengthen their education and to "conform to the current accepted American educational format."
ROME, June 24 -- Giovanni Leone, a Christian Democratic senator and former Premier, announced today that he had formed a Government, bringing an end to 18 days of political crisis.

Five leading poets from abroad read their works last night in a program arranged by the Lincoln Center Festival '68 in cooperation with the Poetry Center of the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -President Johnson asked Congress today to require the national registration of every firearm and a license for every gun owner whose state does not enforce Federal license standards.
BOSTON, June 24 -- Governor Rockefeller indicated today that he had all but abandoned the idea of a campaign alliance with Gov. Ronald Reagan of California.

Five cars of a northbound Penn Central passenger train jumped track in the Bronx last night. All incoming and outgoing train service at Grand Central was stopped for two hours on both the Penn Central and New Haven lines.
A building contractor who holds $2.9-million in city contracts was arrested yesterday on charges of giving an Internal Revenue Service agent a $5,000 bribe.

MEXICO CITY, June 24 -Mexico's only important opposition party announced today that it had decided to continue competing in elections, despite its anger over alleged irregularities in recent municipal voting in Baja California.

BRUSSELS, June 24 -- The sweep of Gaullists in yesterday's first round of French elections gave the franc support in foreign exchange markets today, sending it above its "floor" level for the first time since the early days of the wave of strikes and violence.

EGGPLANT -- or aubergine, as the French and English call the deep polishedpurple vegetable -- does not have to be soaked with oil to be palatable in spite of its affinity for the golden liquid. One of the most delectable ways to enjoy eggplant is stuffed with a piquant meat filling, baked and served as a main course.
Some of the first indications of a possible improvement in the United States' trade balance, mainly through faster-rising exports, are beginning to appear.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI) -- The House voted today for a three-year study of whether the United States should convert to the metric system.

In a report on the amount of cigarette smoking shown on television, the American Cancer Society said yesterday that smoking appeared on two out of five network shows checked during prime time between April 15 and May 15.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 24, (AP) -- A former Westec Corporation President Ernest M. Hall Jr. 42, of Houston, testified today that he and former board chairman James W. Williams, 36, also of Houston placed an $8-million dollar order for 160,000 shares of Westec stock that triggered the company's collapse.

LONDON, June 24 -- Commuter and long-distance passenger service was thrown into confusion today as railway workers defied Government calls for wage restraint and staged a slow-down to force a big pay increase.

OF all the great American musicals, where would you rank "West Side Story"? Surely very close to the top. For besides being a stunning show in itself, its kinetic interplay of story, music and dance suggested possibilities that resulted in other stunning shows.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -The Johnson Administration expects a final deficit of about $25-billion in the fiscal year 1968, which ends on Sunday.

WHEN the managerial guillotine was finally put to use this season, the blade fell twice in swift succession as two heads tumbled into the basket. A few days after Gene Mauch was chopped down by the Phils, Grady Hatton got it in the neck from the Astros.

The general election Canada is holding today -- its sixth in eleven years -- seems to have set both good and bad precedents. It has aroused greater public response than any campaign since John G. Diefenbaker's Conservative landslide in 1958, bringing predictions of a record turnout at the polls.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -The outflow of private United States capital to foreign countries fell by $926-million in the first quarter of 1968 from the level in the fourth quarter of last year, new balance-of-payments figures disclosed today.
A Congress that is bent on cutting the fat out of this year's Federal budget is down to the bones of the foreign-aid program and still hacking.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -The Arena Stage announced today that it would add a number of Negro actors next season as part of an expansion financed by a $250,000 Ford Foundation grant.

DETROIT, June 24 -- The public high schools of Detroit today were called "appallingly inadequate -- a disgrace to the community" in a 360-page report issued after two years of study by a group of citizens.
MILLBROOK, N. Y., June 24 -- Boy Scouts will be camping out this summer in woods on a 2,500-acre estate where followers of Dr. Timothy Leary set up tepees last year.
The Atomic Industrial Forum has recommended that the Federal Government sell its three gaseous diffusion plants to three separate private owneroperators.

FALLSBURG, N. Y., June 24 -- The head of the largest Orthodox rabbinical body in the Western Hemisphere called on religious leaders today to exercise all of their influence to stop mixed marriages between Jews and non-Jews and to restrain Jewish groups from "deviating from the fundamental principles of Jewish religious laws" that govern marriages.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., June 24 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits cautioned city officials here today against setting out on redevelopment plans "grandoise beyond any likelihood of getting anywhere."

In E. W. Kenworthy's June 14 news article on Senator Eugene J. McCarthy's comment about unilateral withdrawal of American troops from Vietnam, he wrote that "the Senator also said he thought it would be possible to withdraw United States troops from Thailand."

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee today approved legislation -- opposed by the Administration -- that would direct the Federal Reserve Board to back up the home mortgage market in tight money periods.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 24 (AP) -- Premier Tran Van Huong was booed and hooted today for 10 minutes in the lower house of parliament. A source close to the Premier said the demonstration had been part of an organized right-wing effort to unseat the Government.
Most grains and soybeans utures were lower yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

PRAGUE, June 24 -- A Czechoslovak parliamentary delegation that returned last week from a tour of the Soviet Union told the National Assembly today that fears and doubts about Czechoslovakia's liberal reform persisted in Moscow.

NEW HAVEN, June 24 -- Ens. Fred V. (Butch) Minson of Old Lyme, Conn., a June graduate of the Coast Guard Academy, won the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association of North America single-handed championship today.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Racial discrimination remains a major barrier to Negroes hunting jobs, and labor unions have not done all they can to eliminate prejudice within their own ranks, the labor federation said today.

CINCINNATI, June 24 -- The New York Mets gave it a mighty effort tonight, tying the score with three runs in the ninth, but failed again to reach the .500 mark as they lost to the Cincinnati Reds in 11 innings, 6-5.
After a firm opening, stock prices headed downward yesterday in the slowest trading in five weeks.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -The Senate, responding to Administration pleas on the need to develop a defense against Chinese and Soviet nuclear threats, defeated today a move to postpone deployment of the Sentinel missile defense system.

ROME, June 24 -- Pope Paul VI appealed today to the negotiators in Paris to agree on a truce in Vietnam that would make the possibility of a satisfactory solution of the war "relatively near and easy."
LONDON, June 24 -- Rod Laver, nervous and lackadaisical, took four sets to beat an American, Gene Scott, today as all the favorites advanced in a raw, rainy opening day at Wimbledon.

The first indictment for labor racketeering at Kennedy Airport following the State Investigation Commission's exposure of allegedly widespread crime there came to light yesterday with the arrest of a teamster union shop steward.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Senate confirmed today the nominations of four New Yorkers for Federal judgeships and the nomination of former New York Mayor Robert F. Wagner as Ambassador to Spain.
PARIS, June 24 -- At 61 years of age, Maurice Jacques Couve de Murville has excelled in almost everything he has ever undertaken, although he has a handicap of about 22 in golf.

Just a week before hearings are scheduled to begin in Washington, the head of the Investment Bankers Association stoutly defended yesterday two bulwarks of the securities industry -- minimum commissions and commission sharing.

Vandals broke into Public School 26 in Brooklyn over the weekend, bringing to 15 the number of break-ins there since April 14 and raising to 700 the number of window panes that have been smashed since then.

The use of bank checking accounts rose sharply during May, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday, continuing the strong uptrend that has been evident for much of the past year.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System introduced last night at 10 P.M. the first of three documentaries on "The Cities." The series, produced by John Sharnik, will deal with urban problems and, based on the first program, should be well worth any viewer's time.

Production of steel in the week ended last Saturday gained slightly from output in the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
