WHEN Manuel Ramos reported for his prefight physical examination in the Catskills last week, the Mexican heavyweight was wearing a blue windbreaker. In bold lettering on the front were those magical words, "Assistant Activities Director -- Grossinger's."

TRENTON, June 25 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes signed into law today a one-cent increase in New Jersey's gasoline tax and a 1 per centage point increase in the state's corporate income tax. He acted a few hours after the Legislature adjourned at dawn this morning for the summer.

CAIRO, June 25 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic, a Moslem; Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, a Christian, and clergymen of almost every branch of Christianity joined today in attending the consecration of the Coptic Orthodox Cathedral of St. Mark in Cairo.
PRAGUE, June 25 -- Two laws unusual in any Communist-ruled country were put before the Czechoslovak National Assembly today. One was passed, the other is certain of speedy passage.

Six policemen swam out to the rescue of the pilot and five passengers of a sightseeing helicopter that crashed into the Hudson River yesterday soon after taking off from its pier at West 30th Street.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Senator Charles H. Percy is regarded by most Republican leaders as the party's likeliest Vice-Presidential candidate, which may be the reason he does not like to risk talking about the possibility.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The executive directors of the International Monetary Fund have deferred, perhaps indefinitely, a decision on whether the fund should buy gold offered by South Africa.
ROME, June 25 (UPI) -- Pope Paul VI announced a series of reforms today eliminating much of the traditional pomp in church ceremonials, including the throne for bishops.

Queens loves the Metropolitan Opera and the company returns the borough's affection. Each time the Met has gone to Crocheron Park in Bayside it has drawn large crowds and, as it discovered last night, loyal ones.
ALBANY, June 25 -- Governor Rockefeller's office announced today the last of the Governor's actions on bills left behind by the 1968 Legislature, including approval of two truth-in-lending measures.

BUFFALO, June 25 (AP) -- A museum official was arrested today for allegedly having stolen documents signed by famous historical figures and selling a letter signed by Abraham Lincoln to a leading New York autograph dealer.

Arthur J. Goldberg became a partner in the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton Garrison yesterday, a day after ending his service as United States Permanent Representative to the United Nations.

Twenty-five young Negro men left Kennedy International Airport yesterday on a two-and-a-half-month trip to Africa to "seek to discover the source of our heritage."

Joseph (Joe Bananas) Bonanno, reputed head of a New York Mafia family, was most recently in the news when an Associated Press report from Tucson, Ariz., June 5 said he had been taken to a hospital there for treatment of a possible heart attack. The dispatch said that Bonanno lives in Tucson. He is about 63 years old.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 25 -- At 9 o'clock this morning, Jim Dunnigan Jr., the racing secretary at Roosevelt Raceway, opened the entry box for Friday night's card and found the names of only a dozen horses.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 25 -- A 61-year-old man who had spent 29 years in state mental institutions after his conviction in 1938 on a charge of third-degree arson, started a proceeding in Nassau County Court here today to clear his name.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 25 (AP) -- Robert G. Fichenberg, managing editor of the Albany Knickerbocker News, was elected president of the New York State Society of Newspaper Editors today, succeeding Maurice D. Herbert of The Newburgh Evening News.
The City Council raised the basic real-estate tax rate by 14.5 cents yesterday, to a record $5.218 for each $100 of assessed valuation, and it voted to collect the taxes four times a year.
The North Shore Women's Committee of the Arthritis Foundation will hold an art exhibition and sale Saturday from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. on the Plaza in Locust Valley, L.I. Admission is free.
The world's largest postal facility will be built here to replace the General Post Office, Postmaster General W. Marvin Watson announced yesterday.

SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., June 25 -- South Lake Tahoe, the hub of a magnificent resort area, is spending a quarter-million dollars to stage one track meet. Almost everyone here thinks the price is cheap.

Herbert Itkin, the Government informant and witness in the case of James L. Marcus, was mentioned yesterday in a Federal kickback indictment of a union official. The indictment said the union official, Frank A. Zulferino, took a $3,000 kickback from recipients of a $375,000 mortgage loan made from union funds.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 25 (AP) -- Prison authorities prepared today to move about 100 convicts out of the riot-scarred and fire-crippled Ohio State Penitentiary.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- People seem to dislike the sonic boom enough to make the outlook dim for designs of the supersonic transport as they are now, a panel of scientists said today.

The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra played its first concert under its new musical director, Henry Lewis, on Monday night at the Garden State Arts Center at Telegraph Hill in Holmdel. That made it an event in New Jersey artistic history.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The Senate turned back repeated efforts today to slash the $1.8-billion military construction authorization bill and passed it, 78 to 3.

Full of Fun handled top weight of 124 pounds and the opposition with equal competence in the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday. RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 25 -- Soon after Isaac Beamon first went on the migrant farming cycle 15 years ago, his wife began asking, "When are we going to make our last move?"

Prospects for a settlement of labor disputes spurred a widespread advance on the London stock market yesterday. Although trading continued quiet, the market moved ahead steadily and late buying put some leading industrial shares sharply higher.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., June 26 -- Thirty-two persons were arrested in an early-morning roundup of alleged heroin dealers today in the southwestern section of Suffolk County.

THOSE enthusiasts who like to read about interesting bridge hands have a feast available in a new book entitled "Bridge Writer's Choice 1968." Seventy-eight members of the International Bridge Press Association have contributed favorite deals.
Paul O'Dwyer told a group of Negro ministers in Queens yesterday that he supported their request for adequate Negro representation among judgeships to be filled this year.

Despite the assertion by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan yesterday that no ill will existed between his office and that of United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau, an increasingly bitter conflict has been developing between them for months.

Frank Howard of the Washington Senators, the American League's home run and runs-batted-in leader, has been named to the league's All-Star team for the first time and Brooks Robinson of the Baltimore Orioles made it for the ninth consecutive year.
A program for improving reading this summer through the use of television was announced yesterday.

POCANTICO HILLS, N. Y., June 26 -- Mrs. Steven C. Rockefeller, a 29-year-old blonde, fresh-faced and comely, went to Brooklyn last month to attend the celebration of Norway's Independence Day. She hasn't been th same since, and the 4,000-acre Rockefeller family estate here may never be the same again.

STRATFORD, Conn., June 26 -- Although George Bernard Shaw's "Androcles and the Lion" is a short play full of wit and exuberance, it seemed to run on for hours in its first performance here last night at the American Shakespeare Festival.
NEWPORT, R. I., June 26 -- Fog and acrimony are forecast for tomorrow when the two leading sailboats in the single-handed trans-Atlantic race are expected to cross the finish line here.

Speculative buying pushed prices of silver futures higher yesterday on the Commodity Exchange, following rising prices for gold in the London market. The silver rise occurred despite a lower spot price for silver in New York, where Handy Harman quoted the price at $2.45 an ounce, off 3 cents.

PARIS, June 26 -- The United States, seeking a breakthrough in the deadlocked talks on Vietnam, appealed to the North Vietnamese delegates today for some indirect sign or unpublicized move of military restraint to help scale down the war.

OTTAWA, June 26 -- Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau went to his office this morning to begin carrying out the mandate he won in the national election yesterday to create a "just society" and give Canada a new place in the world.

TRAVELERS who extol the food of Peru talk of home cooking and restaurants, of native specialties such as roast kid with mint and roast pig with fresh coriander. One of the most vocal advocates of la cocina peruana is a tall, dark-haired, former New Yorker, Mrs. John S. Pearson, currently in Manhattan, who ranks the Peruvian kitchen as one of the great cuisines of the world, along with the French and Chinese.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy has asked close friends and aides to suggest a memorial to his brother that would embody the ideals for which Robert F. Kennedy lived.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A determined bloc of Republicans threatened a filibuster today as they stepped up their fight against confirmation of President Johnson's appointments to the Supreme Court.

DENVER, June 26 -- Vice President Humphrey proposed tonight that every American child be guaranteed an education from the time he is 4 years old through a college degree, with the Government providing the money where necessary.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 26 -- Unless the impasse in contract negotiations between the Standardbred Owners Association and the managements of Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceways is cleared by 10 A.M. Friday, tomorrow night's harness-racing program, featuring the $166,746.91 Dexter Cup Trot, may be the last one to be staged here for some time.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The United States reacted swiftly today to new French moves to subsidize exports by announcing that special duties would be imposed on goods from France.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, June 26 -- North Korea displayed a 12-foot speedboat during a meeting of the Korean Armstice Commission here today, and said it was the "U.S. imperialist spy boat" that it had reported having sunk Saturday off its west coast.
Nursery school tots, 4 years old and not quite 4, who have not yet learned to lisp "Picasso," have put together a multicolored creation in painted wood that will be a gift to the Spanish master.

STRATFORD, Conn., June 27 -- Although scholars are uncertain about the year in which Shakespeare wrote "Love's Labour's Lost," I think it's highly unlikely that it was done sometime during the 1967-68 New York theatrical season, which saw the production of "Your Own Thing" and "Hair."
A pledge to refuse military service as long as the Vietnam war continues has been signed by 100 present former presidents of college student bodies and campus editors.
LONDON, June 27 -- The revolution at Hornsey College of Art and Design is weary but, its instigators believe, triumphant.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -The day of the Buck Rogers flying belt seemed a large hop closer today as engineers described a jet belt designed to propel a man for miles over rooftops, treetops or any other kind of terrain.
A $3-million public school will be built on the East Side without cost to the city under a plan disclosed yesterday by the New York City Educational Construction Fund.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -Following is the text of President Johnson's message to Congress requesting a constitutional amendment to lower the voting age to 18 years:

Bernhard M. Auer, a daytime resident of the 34th floor executive suite of the Time-Life Building, is just back from a year's sabbatical traveling in southern Europe, boating along the East Coast of North America and just plain reading.
AREA A -- In keeping with the curtailment of angling activities along the New Jersey and Long Island coasts because of unfavorable weather, pickings have been lean in the Barnegat Light area.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., June 27 (AP) -- Policemen halted a protest march four blocks from City Hall today, arresting about 40 of the marchers and ordering 150 others off the street.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 27 -A reversal of roles has taken place between Greek and Turkish Cypriotes in the last few months. This change is forming an ominous backdrop to the communal peace talks just beginning on the island.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -President Johnson proposed today a constitutional amendment that would lower the voting age to 18.
Twice Cited of the Taylor's Purchase Farm made her task appear relatively simple in the six-furlong race that featured the card at Belmont Park yesterday.
Civil Court Judge Maurice Wahl ruled yesterday that the New York City Housing Authority had no responsibility to protect its tenants against the criminals who prey on them.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 27 -- Charles Stephens, who gave a deposition that was read in the extradition hearing of James Earl Ray in London today, has moved, as have two other important witnesses in the case, from the Memphis rooming house where the rifle shot was fired that killed the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

One of the Fresh Air Fund's unusual vacation facilities is Camp Hidden Valley at the Sharpe Reservation camping center near Fishkill, N. Y. There, an equal number of able-bodied and physically handicapped needy New York City boys and girls receive free three-week vacations.

DETROIT, June 27 -- An owner of Negro slum property in Detroit has turned over management control of 17 buildings to a Negro-led tenants' union that had been pushing a rent strike at some of the buildings.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 -- The little professional, Ken Rosewall, defeated the top-ranked American, Charles Pasarell, today in a classic that will long distinguish this first open Wimbledon tennis tournament.

BRUSSELS, June 27 -- The chief prosecutor of Brussels announced today that the former Belgian mercenary leader, Col. Jean Schramme, had confessed to the murder of a fellow Belgian in the Congolese district of Maniema last year and that he was now under arrest.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 27 -- Ted Hood, anything but a novice in ocean sailing, but a first-time starter in the Newport - to - Bermuda race, sailed his 52-foot steel yawl Robin rapidly and precisely over a 635-mile course and early this evening was the apparent main winner on corrected time.
LONDON, June 27 -- James Earl Ray, accused of killing the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., spoke out about the case for the first time today and denied committing the crime.

Stephen Borsuk, who graduated yesterday from Stuyvesant High School with a 97.53 average, special awards in physics, biology, advanced calculus and Hebrew, and a scholarship to Columbia University, is a quiet, reserved young man.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 27 -A call for greater cooperation among architects and other business and professional groups whose work affects the country's physical environment was issued here today as the American Institute of Architects recessed its 100th annual convention.

SPOLETO, Italy, June 27 -- A gala audience welcomed the Festival of Two Worlds back to this old, beautiful Umbrian hill town for the 11th time tonight and gave Gian Carlo Menotti's new, unorthodox production of Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" an enthusiastic reception.

Mayor Lindsay, angered at the sight of thousands of "vandalized, stripped and abandoned" cars on the city's streets and parkways, instituted a new plan yesterday to have them hauled away. It will go into effect on Monday.

" TIME for Americans," the American Broadcasting Company's six-part series on various aspects of race prejudice, led off last night with the first of a two-part program on "Bias and the Media." The guests were Lena Horne, Harry Belafonte, Dr. Alvin Poussaint, psychiatrist and author, and Lawrence Neal, poet and critic.
ROME, June 27 (AP) -- The Vatican announced a program today to modernize teaching of student priests in seminaries and to foster contacts between the seminaries and secular universities.

LONDON, July 27 -- Two Polish editors made an appearance in London today to deny that anti-Semitism played any part in the actions of their Government. They said that Jews had been removed from high posts, along with others, because they were too old or out of sympathy with policy.
ONCE known as "the great stone face" behind 25 Soviet vetoes in the United Nations Security Council, Andrei Andreyevich Gromyko has mellowed in his last 11 years as Soviet Foreign Minister.

After ten years of near-absolute power, France's Gaullist Government has been repudiated in the streets, then -- within a period of six weeks -- upheld at the polls. Whatever the size of the enlarged Parliamentary majority it wins in Sunday's run-off election, the traumatic events just experienced are unlikely to leave Gaullism unchanged. The question is whether it will, or can, change enough to avoid a repetition of last month's chaos.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 27 -Vice President Humphrey and his political advisers are considering a wide range of potential Vice-Presidential candidates, by no means excepting Senator Eugene J. McCarthy.

The Democratic chairmen of 24 upstate counties have called on Paul O'Dwyer, the party's nominee for Senator, to give a "final and definitive statement" on his opposition to Vice President Humphrey as a Presidential candidate.
A work stoppage beginning Sunday midnight at any or all of 40 of the 99 hospitals here was authorized last night by members of a hospital union.
LEE, Mass., June 27 -- The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival opened its 36th season in the drizzly Massachusetts countryside here this afternoon with spirits, if not its theater, undampened.
RICHMOND, Calif., June 27 -- Fires and looting have disrupted this San Francisco Bay city for two nights since a Negro boy was seriously wounded in a car theft investigation.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -The United States prepared today to move quickly to open long-sought discussions with the Soviet Union seeking a mutual limitation of strategic missile systems.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) -- Interlocking directorates involving 16 major companies are being dissolved to avoid Justice Department antitrust action, Attorney General Ramsey Clark announced today.

A depressingly familiar litany of complaints and recommendations on what's wrong with New York City hospitals has emerged from the State Investigation Commission's study. The crippling shortages of personnel and equipment bedeviling the municipal hospitals, the fantastic fetters of red tape that paralyze daily administration and prevent basic reform, the looseness of the original affiliation program that permitted abuses to creep in -- these are all well documented.
IT is almost 300 years to the day since Moliere's "George Dandin" had its premiere in Versailles, something of a Lincoln Center of its time.

The credit markets continued to probe yesterday, testing whether interest rates could be moved decisively lower after passage of a bill to increase taxes. So far, the results of this effort have been inconclusive.

BUENOS AIRES, June 27 -- A public opinion poll marking the second anniversary of the military regime in Argentina indicates that a majority of the country's citizens feel the Government has accomplished "nothing good."
THE ALGIERS MOTEL INCIDENT. By John Hersey. Hardcover: 397 pages; Knopf; $5.95. Paperback: 334 pages; Bantam; $1.25.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 27 -- When an enemy force estimated at two divisions began closing in on the Marine combat base at Khesanh 5 1/2 months ago, the United States military command decided that the little-known outpost was far too important to lose.

JERUSALEM, June 27 -- Premier Levi Eshkol said today that Israel must not advance public peace proposals in her dispute with the Arabs because each concession she made at this point would become a minimum Arab demand.

Money was tight during the week ended Wednesday, banking figures published yesterday indicated. There were signs, however, that the Federal Reserve money managers may have decided to be somewhat less aggressive in pursuing their policy of monetary restraint.

THE most entertaining deal in the recent Olympiad in Deauville, France, occurred in a match between Switzerland and Spain. East and West can make ten tricks in a red suit if they are inspired to drop North's singleton king, but nevertheless one would expect NorthSouth to play in four spades.

Edward A. Orlando, a contractor who had been scheduled to testify yesterday before a Federal grand jury about his dealings with James L. Marcus and Herbert Itkin, was indicted instead by a New York County grand jury on charges of bribing public officers.

IT used to be that a barber was a barber. He ran his clippers over a man's head like a lawn mower or cut off a half inch here and there. When his customer emerged, he looked as if he'd just had his hair cut. But times have changed.
A new, independent city Department of Consumer Affairs is to come into existence soon under a bill approved yesterday by the City Council's Codification Committee.

CLEVELAND June 27 -- Tony Jacklin of England, using a borrowed driver in place of one that came apart yesterday, scored a 66 as the $110,000 Cleveland open golf tourney began today. The five-under-par score gave the 23-year-old professional from Scunthorpe a three-stroke lead.

The State Investigation Commission said yesterday that the pairing of voluntary "prestige" hospitals with municipal institutions -- a program on which the city has spent $225-million in the last seven years -- was full of "shocking" evils.

DETROIT, June 27 -- John Hersey's new book, "The Algiers Motel Incident," was called today "highly prejudicial" to the trial of the Detroit police officer who is charged with murdering a Negro during last July's riots.

Leonard Bernstein will end his tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic with performances of Mahler's Third Symphony, which he will conduct at Philharmonic Hall on May 15, 16 and 17 of next year in the last three concerts of the orchestra's 1968-69 subscription season.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board has proposed cuts totaling millions of dollars in the rates paid to United States airlines for carrying ordinary mail for the military services on foreign flights.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee dealt a setback today to the Administration's gun control legislation by deciding to postpone any action until next month.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, vigorously opposed moves in Congress today aimed at forcing or inducing the Federal Reserve to help housing by buying obligations of the home loan banks or the Federal National Mortgage Association.
Aerospace engineers reported yesterday on new research suggesting that, contrary to earlier pessimism, the sonic boom created by aircraft could be reduced to tolerable levels.

Yehuda Leib Levin, Chief Rabbi of Moscow, broke out of the mold of purely Jewish affairs yesterday to discuss with leading members of the Roman Catholic, Protestant and Greek Orthodox clergy what he considers to be the imperative mission of religion in the contemporary world.
At Kennedy Airport, where people and taxi drivers often have trouble getting together, airport officials are taking steps to make everyone happier.

HOUSTON, June 27 -- Cleon Jones, who had experienced defensive problems on the soggy slopes in Cincinnati last night, was an offensive star in the synthetic 72-degree sterility of the Astrodome tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 27 -- Roy Wilkins, the executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, accused Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of "intruding in our convention" and wondered out loud today if "meddling has become a technique" in the Senator's Presidential campaign.
Bache Co., Inc., is planning an ambitious expansion of its back-office facilities, which should enable it to streamline the processing of securities transactions of its more than 1 million customers.

HURON, S. D., June 27 -- This dusty plains community, the center of a bountiful livestock and wheat area, has seen more big-time politics this year than any other American town of 16,000, and more than most cities of 160,000.

PRAGUE, June 27 -- Rude Pravo, the newspaper of the Czechoslovak Communist party, reported today that 90 per cent of its non-Communist readers questioned in a poll favored the creation of opposition parties.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 27 -Alone aboard a 57-foot ketch, pounding into a stiff nor'easter, an English geography teacher, Geoffrey Williams, streaked through the murk past Brenton Reef light tower at 2:33 o'clock this morning, setting a record for a solo trans-Atlantic crossing.

Democratic State Chairman John J. Burns encountered new problems yesterday as he strove to work out an agreement on the 97 at-large delegates to the Democratic national convention. The delegates will be elected by the state committee today.
Prices of some platinum futures rose the daily limit of $10 an ounce yesterday, after having dropped sharply the day before. Generally, these futures have been rising for many months.

BRUSSELS, June 27 -- Despite some grumbling in Common Market circles, France's five partners in the European Economic Community were expected tonight to accept new French import controls without retaliation.

" New York and Who to Blame It On," a one-hour revue tracing the city's history, will begin a tour of lower-middleincome areas July 9 at 3 P.M. in Conference HousePark, Hylan Boulevard and Phillip Street, on Staten Island. The performance will be repeated at 6 P.M. in Wolfes Pond Park, Holton and Cornelia Avenues, S. I.

Despite a damp, chilling mist that hung over Central Park like a soggy blanket, 4,200 people huddled in the Wollman Memorial Rink last night to hear Count Basie's orchestra and singer Joe Williams give the first concert in this season's summerlong Schaefer Music Festival.
Mayor Lindsay made a special plea yesterday to the leaders of the United Jewish Appeal to help New York City by offering jobs to "our own Negro immigrants from the South."
Stocks declined slightly yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as trading resumed after the third one-day hiatus this month.

PARIS, June 27 -- Foreign Minister Michel Debre said today that France would continue her policy of independence from all blocs. He declared that American retaliation against her emergency trade measures would be discriminatory, implying that it was interpreted as punishment for this independence.
MOSCOW, June 27 -- The Soviet Union affirmed today that it was ready to open discussions toward a mutual limitation on the deployment of costly antimissile defense systems.
With strong civic and political backing, a petition drive has been started to restore proportional representation in the election of City Councilmen.

WALTON HEATH, England, June 27, (AP) -- Three United States players moved into the the quarter-final round of the British women's amateur golf championship today but four others were eliminated.
WASHINGTON, June 27--Senate Republicans accused President Johnson today of practicing "cronyism" in nominating two old friends to the Supreme Court.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 27 -- While representatives of Roosevelt Raceway and Yonkers Raceway, along with a horsemen's committee, were negotiating the future of downstate harness racing, Nevele Pride was out on the track, outclassing 10 other 3-year-old sophomores in the ninth annual Dexter Cup Trot. The gross purse of $166,746.91 was the season's highest so far.
HONG KONG, June 27 -- An increasingly edgy, xenophobic regime in Peking has cut down Communist China's contacts with the outside world to its lowest level to date.

POMONA, Calif., June 27 -- Charlie Greene, a light-hearted and sometimes irreverent individual, was never one to downgrade his abilities. Even as a 19-year-old Nebraska freshman he was totally unawed by the great Bob Hayes, then deemed the world's fastest human and soon to become an Olympic sprint champion.

UPPER DUBLIN TOWNSHIP, Pa., June 27 -- The amphitheater erected by Temple University here for its first summer music festival has acquired only a third of its roof so far, but the festival will have its formal opening tomorrow night anyway.
The class of '68 of Washington Irving High School -659 girls, most of them from poor families -- got their diplomas yesterday in a stronghold of the upper-middleclass, the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Mario J. Cariello, Borough President of Queens, has criticized the Federal Aviation Administration for not giving Queens residents advance notice of the testing of a new take-off pattern at La Guardia Airport.

Tim Foli, the No. 1 pick in the recent free-agent baseball draft, spurned college football recruiters yesterday and signed a contract with the New York Mets for a bonus reported to be about $75,000.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 27 -- Christ Episcopal Church will hold its 27th annual fair in the Parish Hall and on the grounds of the church at East Main Street here on July 13.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, June 28 -- Enough rockets to mount the war's heaviest shelling of Saigon were found yesterday in rice paddies 13 miles northwest of the capital, a spokesman said.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- A bill to create a Redwoods National Park in California was approved today by the House Interior Committee.

Brokerage houses will have to report their annual income and expenses to the Securities and Exchange Commission starting in 1970 as a result of a new S.E.C. rule adopted in Washington yesterday.

DENVER, June 28 (AP) -- Two members of a pacifist organization had their heads shorn and beards shaved off in a Carbon County, Wyo., jail after they were picked up on a hitchhiking charge, an Ohio clergyman said yesterday.

ROME, June 28 -- The bones that Pope Paul VI said on Wednesday have been identified as those of St. Peter were returned last night to the niche under the papal altar of St. Peter's Basilica where they were first discovered.

Stock prices closed the week yesterday by drifting downward in relatively slow trading. Early firmness in the list began to dissipate after the first hour of trading and an irregular decline continued until the close.

Prices held steady in moderate trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

PARIS, June 28 -- The franc hit its legal minimum in money markets as devaluation fears persisted today, forcing the Bank of France to intervene again.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The outlines of a possible compromise in the battle over gun control legislation emerged today as segments of the gun lobby started retreating from their adamant opposition to stricter controls.

New and shorter hours for visitors to the Brooklyn Museum, announced yesterday, will go into effect July 1 and will be tried out at least through the summer.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- South Africa, rebuffed for the time being in its efforts to sell gold to the International Monetary Fund, used its automatic drawing rights today to acquire $62.02-million worth of four foreign currencies.

Perennials, of course, flower year after year, but some are less winter-hardy and must be replaced. THE passing of Sir Herbert Read, who died on June 12 at the age of 74, brought to a close one of the most remarkable careers in modern times.
