HARTFORD, June 29 -- Just one year after the United States Senate censured him for "conduct contrary to accepted morals," Senator Thomas J. Dodd appears to be stronger politically than many observers here had thought he would ever be again.

Summer doldrums have quieted the ripple of retail volume in some parts of the nation. Business is good by most standards but lacks the powerful upward thrust that would quicken the pulse of merchants and manufacturers.
LOVE AND WORK. By Reynolds Price. 143 pp. New York: Atheneum. $4.50.
WESTBURY, L. I., June 29 -- Roosevelt Raceway was shut down tonight for the second straight time as horsemen defied a Court's restraining order by refusing to enter their horses to fill the races.
TO THE EDITOR: Michael Halberstam, in "Are You Guilty of Murdering Martin Luther King?", June 9, raised some interesting points, but on some of them I would like to take issue with him.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 29--Scuffles erupted today on the floor of the N.A.A.C.P.'s 59th annual convention half an hour before the frequently turbulent six -day meeting was hurriedly adjourned and left much convention business unfinished.
CAIRO, June 29 -- Egypt's bumper cotton crop prospects for this year are threatened by what may become worst infestation of boll weevil in 50 years, according to the Ministry of Agriculture.

THERE is a new force at work in the Negro ghetto of Newark -- the force of the "responsible militant." It saved Newark from another wholesale holocaust, 1967-style, in the days after Martin Luther King's assassination. It may just have a chance of damping this tinderbox of a city in the months ahead.

The Liberal party's state committee voted overwhelmingly yesterday to call for "an immediate cease-fire" in Vietnam while negotiations to end the war proceeded in Paris. The resolution, adopted by voice vote, also announced the party's opposition to any policy that would continue the war in Vietnam or require the country to engage in similar wars elsewhere.
THE AGES OF LIFE. By Lorus J. and Margery Milne. 331 pp. Harcourt, Brace World. $6.95.

NINETEEN HUNDRED AND SIXTY-EIGHT seems a year of educational adventures -- of all kinds -- and perhaps none has been greeted with the palpable joy of one that took place in the Old Tarrytown Road School in Greenburgh, New York, the other day.
In connection with "Growing Up Straight -- the Father's Role," May 26, by Peter and Barbara Wyden, we feel that the following points ought to be made:

City Council President Frank D. O'Connor said yesterday that he hoped unity could be re-established in the state Democratic party despite the walk-out of 300 supporters of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy from the state committee meeting here Friday.

A long, leisurely weekend looms ahead -one that all good gardeners deserve to enjoy, if they have done all their deeds. Here are a few chores to check on to be sure the vegetable, flower and rose patches are in readiness for the summer.

The nation's oldest foreign trade zone, which has survived -- but not exactly flourished -- on Staten Island since 1938, has acquired new management and is seeking a new home in the city where there can be more employment as well as more foreign commerce.
The maker of a drug designed to lower the cholesterol in the blood has sent a "corrective letter" to doctors saying that the company may have issued misleading advertising about the product.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -The capital is full of chatter these days about personalities. It is talking about the President, who is angry because the Time-Life organization says he has lost some of his power since he decided to retire from politics; it is gossiping about Humphrey who overstates everything and McCarthy who understates everything, and about de Gaulle's election, and whatever happened to Dean Rusk?
ANYONE who wants to compare the original piano version of Mussorgsky's Pictures at an Exhibition with the orchestral transcription by Ravel can do so by purchasing recordings of each.

LOS ANGELES, June 29 -Four years can make quite a difference, Tom Farrell, the tiny Olympian from St. John's University, conceded today. The 24-year-old Farrell was a close, but not happy, qualifier as a fourthplace finisher in his 800-meter heat.

WASHINGTON -- After a brief July Fourth recess this week, a slow-moving, weary 90th Congress will head into the homestretch for adjournment, struggling in the final weeks to find a way to pay the nation's bills and still economize.
IT IS now apparently obligatory for all "adult" films to show a naked man and woman in bed, pre-, during, and post-coitus. They are usually handsome and naturally wrapped up in each other.
DUBLIN, June 29 (UPI) -- Ribero, a 100-6 long shot, overtook favored Sir Ivor in the stretch today and won the Irish Sweepstakes Derby at The Curragh in a major upset.

Elaine Powell, a 16-year-old Bronx girl, went job hunting yesterday at Central Commercial High School. After being interviewed by more organizations than she could recall, she went home to 416 Paulden Avenue to consider at least seven possibilities.
At first glance, the Ponce de Leon looks like a flattop, with containers instead of aircraft lined up on her deck.
HOMESTEAD, Fla. June 27 -- Hugo Vihlen, the adventurer who sailed 4,100 miles across the Atlantic in a six-foot boat called the April Fool, says that he could not have made it in a larger craft.

OTTAWA -- A few days before last Tuesday's federal elections, an interviewer asked Pierre Elliott Trudeau if he was worried about the publicity over his kissing so many pretty girls along his campaign trail.
STANFORD, Calif., June 29 (UPI) -- Twenty-five professional journalism fellowships at Stanford University were announced today for reporters and editors to study in nonjournalism subjects.

WOOD-BEAM celings in various forms have become quite popular in recent years with homeowners and apartment dwellers. For those who may prefer actual wood instead of the various imitation plastic forms, one company has introduced real hand-hewn wooden beams of western red cedar that are specifically designed for do-it-yourself installers.

DURING the past few months, many have expressed surprise, alarm, shock, astonishment bordering on disbelief, over acts of violence perpetrated against Americans of international renown. It is true that Martin Luther King Jr. and Senator Robert F. Kennedy were both humanitarians who successfully sought to make significant contributions to mankind.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 29 -- With the active part of the Newport - to - Bermuda yacht race completed at sea last night with the arrival of the German sloop Tjoo Hoo, the only order of business left today was the distribution of prizes to those who earned them in the Western Hemisphere's leading offshore event.
RYE, N. Y., June 29 -- Stuart B. Rowe Jr., sailing Ann, was the International Class winner on Long Island Sound today after a close three-way battle in which two of the 33-foot sloops collided.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 29 -- Premier Tran Van Huong said today that he would dismiss 50 to 100 district chiefs within the next month as his first major step against corruption and inefficiency in the South Vietnamese Government.
PARIS, June 30 -- Senator Claiborne Pell said today that the time had come for a third party, preferably France or the Soviet Union, to try to help break the deadlock in the Vietnam talks here.

RUMFORD, R. I., June 30 (AP) -- Pete Bostwick Jr. of Meadow Brook, L. I., playing with steady precision while the leaders faltered, shot a one-over-par 70 on the final round today to win the seventh annual Northeast amateur invitation golf tournament by one stroke.

SOME families eat in the kitchen, but the Herbert Passins cook in the dining room. There is a modern, well-equipped kitchen in their seven-room penthouse atop a Broadway office building, but one of the first pieces of furniture the couple installed was an imported Japanese teppanyaki table.

Mrs. Renee del Vecchio, dressed as if she had just come from church, waded knee deep in Central Park's Conservatory Pond yesterday as her 3-year-old daughter, in a bathing suit, spashed about happily.
BOSTON, June 30 (UPI)--A three-run homer by Duke Sims marked a four-run rally in the 10th inning today and lifted the Cleveland Indians to a 7-5 triumph over the slumping Boston Red Sox.
ONEONTA, N. Y., June 30-- For the second year in succession Ch. Stargazer of Dartvale was selected as best in show at the Del - Otse - Nango Kennel Club event.

CHRISTIANSTED, St. Croix, June 30 (UPI)--Virgin Islands Democrats elected last night an 11-man state to the Democratic National Convention in Chicago. The group, although uncommitted, leans toward Vice President Humphrey. The Virgin Islands has five convention votes.
The city's new truth-in-advertising law goes into effect today.
Kennedy International Airport is 20 years old today.
ROME, June 30 (Reuters) --Following, in an official Vatican translation into English, is the text of the Pope's message and credo today to mark the end of the Roman Catholic Church's Year of Faith.
HOUSTON, June 30--Back when Jerry Grote was a member of the Houston Astros, there used to be a special emphasis paid to the art of being elusive on the basepaths.

PORT JERVIS, N. Y., June 30 --Frank Chapot, who leaves for a tour of Europe with the United States Equestrian Team Tuesday, rode Swinger to both the open jumper and regular working hunter championships at the Tri-States horse show today.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 30 --Thomas Hume's Shields Class sloop, Pantomime, and William S. Jayson's Lightning, Outlaw, were winners on Long Island Sound today for the second successive afternoon when Riverside Yacht Club held the season's 14th championship regatta for Yacht Racing Association fleets based east of Rye.
PARIS, June 30 (AP) -Dhaudevi, owned by Mrs. Georges Courtois of France, scored a decisive victory today in the $282,650 Grand Prix de Paris for 3-year-olds at Longchamps.
The State Commission for Human Rights announced yesterday that nine major New York companies had submitted plans for improving employment opportunities for minorities.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company yesterday announced a price increase, averaging 2.75 per cent, effective today on most passenger, truck, farm tires and tubes.

LOS ALTOS HILLS, Calif., June 30 (UPI)--Men's 200-meter free-style relay teams from the Santa Swim Club and the Foothill Aquatic Club finished in a dead heat while recording the second fastest time ever, 1 minute 39 seconds, for the event today.
The election of Lee S. Bickmore as a director of Hart Schaffner Marx was announced over the weekend. He is chairman of the board of the National Biscuit Company.

COLORADO SPRINGS, June 30 (AP)--Bob Unser, winner of the Indianapolis 500, drove his Chevrolet-powered car up a 12 1/2-mile winding course in the record time of 11 minutes 54.9 seconds and won the Pikes Peak Hill Climb today.
"Cautious" is the word for the economic mood of American families. So reports the National Industrial Conference Board in a survey released for publication today.

WASHINGTON, June 30--Direct investment abroad by United States corporations this year will be at least as large as last year's record despite the new program of mandatory controls, according to estimates of top officials administering the program.
SAIGON, South Vietnam. June 30--The Saigon radio announced today that Thich Tri Quang, the Buddhist leader, had been released from prison after more than four months in "protective custody."

LOS ANGELES, June 30-- Dave Patrick is Villanova's track captain, and Erv Hall is Villanova's captain-elect. Both won finals today--Patrick as expected and Hall in a major upset--as the United States Olympic track and field trials ended.
CLEVELAND, June 30--Despite a fear of sunstroke, Dave Stockton closed with a 72 today and won the Cleveland open golf tournament with a four-round total of 276.

A representative of the Soviet Embassy in Washington, speaking at a farewell dinner here for the Chief Rabbi of Moscow, Yehuda Leib Levin, expressed the hope last night that the rabbi's visit, which will end today, would help to establish better understanding between the Soviet and the American peoples.

Demonstrators who had occupied the offices of city Social Services Commissioner Jack R. Goldberg since Friday evening in a demand for improved welfare benefits were taken into custody last night by the police.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 (AP)--The Philadelphia Phillies today signed Willie Jones, 19 years old, of Southern High School, Philadelphia. Jones, an outfielder-pitcher, will report to the Phils' farm team at Huron, S. D., in the Northern League.
The Interpublic Group of Companies has sold the Thomas J. Deegan Company back to Thomas J. Deegan Jr. It was first sold for cash and bought back for cash, according to Mr. Deegan.
THE DO-GOODERS. By Alfred Grossman. 229 pages. Doubleday. $4.95.
The election of Frederic H. Brandi, chairman of Dillon, Read Co., Inc., to the board of directors of Farbwerke Hoechst A.G. of West Germany was announced over the weekend.
A group of 150 angry Puerto Ricans tried to storm the gates of Gracie Mansion yesterday, demanding to talk with Mayor Lindsay about housing conditions in the East Harlem.
MERIDIAN, Miss., June 30-Policemen guarding the home of a prominent Jewish businessman against nightriders wounded a young Alabama man and killed his woman companion early today.

Intervention by Robert A. Glasser, chairman of the New York State Harness Racing Commission, failed yesterday to break the impasse that closed Roosevelt Raceway Friday and Saturday nights. Track officials and the horsemen are scheduled for a court battle today in Special Term, Part I Supreme Court at Mineola, L. I., with the outlook dim that anything can be accomplished to re-open the Westbury, L. I., harness track in time for racing tonight.

KASSEL, Germany, June 30 --Kinetic sculpture is whirring in Auepark, and light-up environmental works have invaded the Alte Galerie. Bearded artists lounge in the staid Friedrichsplatz, and a psychedelic discotheque has even branched out from Dusseldorf to catch the patronage of with-it art lovers.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP)--The Poor People's Campaign staged a silent ministers' march around the nation's Capitol today. More than 500 clergymen, nuns and denim-clad one-time residents of Resurrection City moved slowly, in 94-degree heat, on streets opposite the Capitol grounds.
One of every six births in New York City last year was illegitimate, a rise from one of every 15 in 1957, a labor union analysis reported yesterday.

About 6,00O people attended the Saturday night program of the Forest Hills Music Festival in Queens. Ario Guthrie and Judy Collins gave highly professional and pleasing performances that ranged from monologue to folk and pop song.
When airplanes emerged as instruments of warfare in World War I, nations became grimly aware of the importance of territorial air space.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sunday, June 30 (AP)--Teo Cruz wrested the world lightweight boxing championship from Carlos Ortiz early this morning by gaining a split decision in a 15-round bout.
WASHINGTON, June 30-The man who was in charge of the Consumer Price Index the last three years believes that the ascent rate of the index will slow down.
GRANDMASTER Larry Evans of New York blanked the opposition 9-0 and captured first prize in the recent 1968 "Strawberry Chess Open" in Marysville, Wash.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 30 (UPI)--Ron Rector, an Atlanta Falcon back, was listed in serious condition today in Riverside Hospital, suffering from injuries received in a motorcycle accident.

STANHOPE, N. J., June 30-Summer outdoor music festivals seem to be springing up like goldenrod all over the landscape, and as they multiply, differences among them become increasingly difficult to detect.

CHICAGO, June 30 (AP)-John Kawalik scored two goals and assisted on a third today as the Chicago Mustangs played a 3-3 tie with the New York Generals. The tie extended the Mustangs' unbeaten streak to 12 games in the North American Soccer League.
BALTIMORE, June 30 (AP)-Kathy Whitworth blasted out of the trees on the 18th hole and finished with a par 5 to win the $20,000 Lady Carling open today beating Carol Mann by one stroke.
WASHINGTON, June 30--The Castro regime has arrested a Cuban-born United States citizen who was piloting a commercial aircraft that was hijacked yesterday by a passenger and diverted to Havana.

Alberto-Culver, a threeagency company, has moved about $9-million in advertising out of one agency and split it up with the other two. This seems to be following the recent apparent trend of agency consolidation, as well as the tendency for big agencies to get bigger.

The total value of building contracts signed in one month above the $6-billion mark for the first time in May, the F. W. Dodge Division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company reported over the weekend.

LONDON, June 30 (AP)--Ray Gunter, one of the Labor Government's closest links with its trade union supporters, quit the Cabinet today and told Prime Minister Wilson: "I no longer desire to be a member of your Government."
MARIETTA, Ga., June 30-The Lockheed C-5 Galaxy, 10 of which could have done the job of all 300 planes in the Berlin airlift of 1948, flew for the first time today.
An American jet airliner carrying 231 persons, including 214 United States servicemen, was forced down by Soviet fighter planes in the Kurile Islands north of Japan.

The index of help-wanted advertising fell again in May, but only slightly, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday. At 187, based on the 1957-59 average taken as 100, the index is a single point below the April figure. However, it is 13 points above the corresponding 1967 level. The index measures the volume of classified advertising in 52 major newspapers throughout the country.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 30--Leaders of Jewish community relations agencies were told today that their organizations must not become "disengaged" from the Negro struggle for full equality "because some Negroes are violent, or ungrateful, or anti-Semitic."

STAMFORD, Conn., June 30 --Two thousand friends and guests of Jackie Robinson sought patches of shade on the lawn sloping to a pond behind his house in North Stamford yesterday to hear an afternoon of jazz.
PRAGUE, June 30--The military staff exercises of Warsaw Pact forces that created anxiety in Czechoslovakia for about a month ended today.

Reading a prospectus, as every potential investor in a new stock offering should do, is not half so difficult as reading through the typical insurance policy. In effect, just the reading of a prospectus is an insurance policy of sorts.

HOUSTON, June 30 (UPI) --Everett C. Thomas and Louis John Fierro today became the second and third patients ever to leave a hospital after heart transplant surgery. They attended a Houston-New York baseball game, where Mr. Thomas of Phoenix, Ariz., yelled for the Astros and Mr. Fierro, of Elmont, L. I., cheered for the Mets.
Governor Rockefeller of New York suggested here yesterday that the states set up antipoverty programs with Federal aid.

The issues in the strike by 45,000 deep-sea going members of the National Maritime Union against the Maritime Service Committee and the Maritime Tankers Committee, management groups that negotiate for six major freighter operators and the major oil companies:

It was upward of 93 degrees yesterday in Harlem's Mount Morris Park, at Fifth Avenue and 124th Street. The upward came from the music of Count Basie and his orchestra, one of several attraction on the opening bill of the second annual Harlem Cultural Festival.
NURNBERG, West Germany, June 30 (Reuters)--David Piper of Britain, driving a Ferrari, won the 200-mile Nurnberg auto race for sports cars and prototypes today. Frank Gardner of Australia, was second.

Three executives will join the headquarters staff of Goodbody Co. in July, according to an announcement yesterday by Harold P. Goodbody, managing partner of the investment banking and brokerage firm, which operates a nationwide chain of 98 offices.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., June 30 (AP)--Charlie Glotzbach, driving a Dodge, trimmed nearly six miles an hour from the Firecracker 400 qualifying record today as he won the pole position for the Fourth of July race with a two-lap speed of 185.156 miles an hour.

MOSCOW, June 30 (UPI) -Vladimir Dudintsev, whose novel "Not by Bread Alone"-which attacked Soviet bureaucracy -- drove former Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev to vow "he will never write like that again," re-emerged yesterday with the publication of a new edition of his book.
CHICAGO. June 30--Whatever happened to the menace of international Communism? Or the worldwide crusade against tyranny? Or the notion that wars are fought to be won?

The issues in the contract dispute involving 12,700 non-medical workers employed by 17 private nonprofit hospitals in the League of Voluntary Hospitals and Homes of New York and represented by Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Union:
Anaconda Australia, Inc., a unit of the Anaconda Company, has announced the discovery of narrow widths of high-grade nickel sulphides at two sites in Western Australia.

WASHINGTON, June 30--Early one afternoon just before the Government flattened Resurrection City last week, the young Negroes who had taken up residence there streamed noisily aboard a battered old bus.
BERLIN, June 30--Walter Ulbricht, strong man of East Germany, marked his 75th birthday today in ostentatiously robust health, at the apparent pinnacle of his power.
An investigation of gambling payoffs to policemen has taken six years to produce indictments because of uncertainty about the legality of wiretap evidence, high police sources said yesterday.

Marty Decatur of the 92d Street Young Men's Hebrew Association won the national Amateur Athletic Union one-wall handball championship yesterday at the Municipal Courts, Brooklyn. Decatur defeated his teammate, Steve Sandler, the defending champion, 21-18, 21-5.

Butch Seewagen of Bayside, seeded first, won the New York State men's tennis championship yesterday by defeating Robert Cowin of Mountain Lakes, N. J., 6-2, 6-1, 6-1, at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens.
CHICAGO, June 30 (UPI) -- Jim Hickman hit his first homer of the season today and drove in three runs as the Chicago Cubs defeated the National League-leading St. Louis Cardinals, 6-2.
The election of Francis C. Rooney Jr. as a director of the Bankers Trust Company and Bankers Trust New York Corporation was announced over the weekend by William H. Moore, chairman.

As part of its program honoring the work of the Koussevitzky Music Foundation in behalf of American composers, Lincoln Center Festival '68 presented a quartet of commissioned pieces last night at Philharmonic Hall.
PARIS, Monday, July 1--The regime of President de Gaulle crushed its opposition at the polls yesterday and won an overwhelming majority in the National Assembly.

LOS ANGELES, June 30 (UPI)--The Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Atlanta Braves, 3-2, today as Paul Popovich, Len Gabrielson and Wes Parker provided the key hits to back up a five-hit pitching performance by Jim (Mudcat) Grant.
BONN, June 30--The West German Government has blocked an East German inland barge from traveling through its territory to the Netherlands, a Government official confirmed today.

The strike pressure through which New York City hospital employes already have won assurance of a minimum wage of $100 a week is part of a much broader drive--formless but insistent--to push up scales for unskilled workers performing grubby, unpleasant jobs essential to community safety or comfort.
ROME, June 30--Pope Paul VI gave the Roman Catholic Church a new credo tonight, a restatement of the essence of belief that must be accepted by all members of the church.

LONG BRANCH, N. J. June 10 (UPI)--Judy Garland, looking pale and weary, tonight checked out of Monmouth Medical Center, where she was being treated since she collapsed during a performance last night at the Garden State Arts Center. The singer left by car for Newark Airport for a flight to Boston. Physicians said she had collapsed from exhaustion.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 30 (AP)--Pete Rose's two-run homer and Lee May's four singles paced Cincinnati to a 5-3 victory over the San Francisco Giants today.
The Yankees will renew their old rivalry with the Giants next spring, when the San Francisco club will play two exhibition games in Yankee Stadium on the weekend before opening day.
PLOTS AGAINST PRESIDENTS. By John Mason Potter. 310 pages. Astor-Honor. $5.95.

A Critics Institute has been formed by the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Foundation "to raise the level of theatrical criticism in this country and bridge the gap between play-wrights and critics," George C. White, president of the foundation, announced yesterday.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 30--After finishing as runner-up two weeks in a row, Chumbo finally won an open jumper championship today with an assist from his rider.

President Johnson, according to Time magazine, proposed Cyrus R. Vance and Henry H. Fowler to Congressional leaders as possible successors to Chief Justice Earl Warren before designating Abe Fortas for the post.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Owen B. Kiernan, Massachusetts Commissioner of Education, has been appointed executive secretary of the National Association of Secondary School Principals, effective Jan. 1. He will succeed Ellsworth Tompkins, who will retire.

WASHINGTON, June 30--Major responsibility for administration of the mass transit program will shift tomorrow from the Department of Housing and Urban Development to a 38-year-old lawyer in the Department of Transportation.

Tonight's performance of "Golden Rainbow" has been cancelled to permit its stars, Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme, to participate in a United Cerebral Palsy fund-raising program at the Concord Hotel, Kiamesha Lake, N. Y. Tickets for the performance will be exchange or refunded. Instead of taking a week's vacation, the stars will cancel other performances during the summer.

The National Maritime Union, which has been denouncing government officials in recent weeks for failing to appreciate the importance of a strong merchant marine, is currently making its own contribution to driving the American flag off the seas by calling an indefensible strike.
One hundred million dollars is the magic number for New York construction now. It will buy a Pan Am Building, a Grand Central Tower or a new General Post Office.

Siemens America, Inc., and the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company of Milwaukee announced over the weekend the signing of an agreement for Allis-Chalmers to install, maintain and service steam turbines and associated equipment made by Siemens AG of Germany and sold in the United States by Siemens America, Inc.
WALTON HEATH, England, June 30 (AP)--Brigette Varangot rallied to defeat Mrs. Claudine Cos Rubin on the 20th hole today in an all-French final of the British women's amateur golf championship.

Pan American World Airways announced the election of Thomas J. Flanagan as vice president and assistant to the senior vice president-operations. Mr. Flanagan was formerly vice president--Far East operations. He organized and directed the airline's "rest and recuperation airlift," which carries servicemen from the Vietnam battle zone to rest areas in Asia, Hawaii and Australia.

The volume of outstanding commercial paper rose by $561-million, or 3 per cent, during May to a seasonally adjusted level of $17,769,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported over the weekend. Directly placed paper rose by $711-million, or 6 per cent, while dealer paper declined by $150-million, or 3 per cent.

It was so hot at Yankee Stadium yesterday that even the Yankees caught fire. They scored two runs in the sixth inning to go ahead of the Oakland Athletics and two in the seventh to defeat them for Steve Barber's first victory since the cool of last September.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30 (Reuters)--A militant South Vietnamese anti-Communist announced today he had formed a new political party to end the war peacefully, unify the South with the North, and build a socialist economy.

LONDON, June 30--It's been a long time coming, this first open Wimbledon. At the halfway stage, it still prompts a question that has the tennis world agog in anticipation. Who is to win it? Will it be professional or amateur?
The price milk dealers must pay to dairy farmers for whole milk will go up today in the New York-New Jersey area, according to an announcement yesterday by the Metropolitan Dairy Institute.

MOSCOW, June 30 (AP) -Communist sources said today that Communist China had developed its first Intercontinental Ballistics Missile, broadening a nuclear capability that Peking says includes a hydrogen bomb.

ORANGE, N. J., June 30--A 16-year-old girl returning with a friend from a trip to a New York City discotheque was fatally beaten early today as they took a short cut through Orange Park to their homes.
A new rush-hour, skip-stop subway service, the KK line, will begin linking Queens, Brooklyn and midtown Manhattan this morning.

If all goes well at Pan American World Airways, Harold E. Gray, chairman and chief executive officer, hopes to steal away from the executive suite this summer for a four-day golfing weekend in Eleuthera Island, in the Bahamas.

DETROIT, June 30 (AP)--Unbeaten Tommy John pitched a five-hit shutout for his seventh victory and Bill Voss belted a grand slam home run today as the Chicago White Sox snapped the Detroit Tigers' five-game winning streak, 12-0.

"Back to Aqueduct" is the cry of the thoroughbred horse player on the New York scene. The horses will return to "Big A on the Subway" today for a session of 24 racing days that will conclude on July 27.
BATH, England, June 30--In the elegant cream-and-gold assembly rooms of Bath last night, couples in evening dress danced to waltzes and polkas conducted by Yehudi Menuhin.
Nathaniel Gibbon Jr., who has been first vice president of the United Mutual Insurance Company since 1960, has been elected president, the board of directors announced yesterday.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 30 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan signed a state budget of slightly less than $5.7-billion last night after vetoing expenditures of more than $16-million, most of which were for the University of California and the state colleges. Despite the cuts, the budget is the highest ever approved for any state, and is more than $500-million higher than the first state budget signed by Mr. Reagan a year ago.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- Chuck Hinton's two-run triple capped a four-run rally in the first inning that helped the California Angels gain an 8-4 triumph over the Washington Senators today.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 30 --A shift in the wind at the start of the second race of the five-race series for the 5.5meter United States sailing championship resulted in a shift in the lead today on Long Island Sound. F. Gardner Cox of Villanova, Pa., took full advantage of the unpredictable Sound weather to win the race aboard Cadenza and the victory moved Cox into the lead in the series by a quarter-ofa-point.

LONDON, June 30 -- Despite the invasion of Europe by United States corporations, the British tobacco industry has stayed relatively free from American influence. All this could change as the result of the surprise $110-million bid by Philip Morris, Inc., for a half interest in Britain's second biggest tobacco company, the Gallaher Company, Ltd.
MOSCOW, June 30 (AP)-The Soviet Government announced today that it had awarded the Order of the October Revolution, one of its highest orders to Walter Ulbricht on the occasion of his 75th birthday.

For the first time in French parliamentary history, a single party has captured an absolute majority in the National Assembly. President de Gaulle has accomplished one of the most dramatic political reversals of modern times.
WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., June 30--A 20-year-old youth drowned here yesterday while swimming in the Atlantic Ocean off Dune Road.
MOZAMBIQUE, Africa, June 30 (AP)--Brazil scored twice in the second half today to defeat Portugal, 2-0, in an international soccer match.

CHICAGO, June 30--Some dissident Democrats at the meeting of the Coalition for an Open Convention agreed today to start a third-party effort in case neither major party nominated a candidate who offers "the people of the United States an alternative to present policies."

HONG KONG, June 30 (AP) --Hong Kong moved armed motor launches into waters adjacent to Communist China today shortly after Communist gunboats seized and towed away at least 14 fishing vessels that had been working inside British boundaries.

The New York All-Star Gaelic football team defeated University College of Dublin, 16-9, yesterday at Gaelic Park, Bronx, in a benefit exhibition contest sponsored by Mayor Lindsay's play-street program before 4,121 spectators.

THE six young matrons who had gathered in the living room of a Lower East Side co-op apartment looked like middle-class, urban housewives married to professionals or businessmen, each with a few young children. Which is just what they were.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 30 (AP) --Leslie Williams, a lieutenant in the British Royal Navy, became the fourth finisher today in the one-man trans-Atlantic yacht race, which started June 1 at Plymouth, England.
BALTIMORE, June 30 (AP)--Dave Johnson's pinch-single drove in the tie-breaking run during a seventh-inning rally that moved the Baltimore Orioles to a 6-4 victory over the Minnesota Twins today.
GRENOBLE, France, June 30--Pierre Mendes France, France's most respected leftist leader, was narrowly defeated by a Gaullist candidate in today's National Assembly elections.

WOODMERE, L. I., June 30 --Hartley Grim of the Hewlett Point Yacht Club, sailing an M-16 Scow, won the Queen of Bay handicap race today as 22 boats from the Woodmere Bay, Hewlett Point and Hempstead Bay fleets completed in a six-mile race in a 15-25-knot westerly in Woodmere Bay.

BETHPAGE, L.I., June 30-John Greenleaf scored three goals and Dave Rizzo added two as Bethpage defeated Brookville, 7-5, today in the Northeastern Circuit 12-goal polo tournament at Bethpage State Park.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30 -- Another sizable arms cache was discovered west of Saigon yesterday and military officials said today they were convinced that the enemy had been dealt a severe blow.

DETROIT, June 30 -- "We want a real Gold Cup race, not a half-speed one," said Bill Muncey, a four-time winner of this prestige event for unlimited hydroplanes. Thus, with his and other drivers' recommendations, Referee Bill Newton postponed today the $63,000 regatta until tomorrow at 2 P. M. because of rough water.
WASHINGTON, June 30--The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

WEST BABYLON, L. I., June 30--Salvatore Regina, 77 years old, of 99 East Neck Road, was struck down and killed shortly after 9 o'clock last night as he crossed the road near his home. The alleged driver of the car, Nick Conti, 46, of 10 Seward Street, North Babylon, was arrested and charged with drunken driving. He was released to await a hearing.
WASHINGTON, June 30--The Export-Import Bank reported over the weekend a large increase in the use of its discount facility for export credit paper in the second quarter of this year.

WASHINGTON, June 30-New York City, with all its skyscrapers, continues to be one of the hardest places in the United States or Canada for a company looking for new office space to find a varied selection, and the market appears to be getting tighter, a report issued today shows.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I.-Dr. Robert Schwartz of Millburn, N. J., and Ted Cohn of West Orange, N. J., defeated Victor Elmaleh of New York and Harold Meltzer of Englewood, N. J., 6-1, 7-5, in the final today to win the Long Island senior doubles tennis tournament at the Shore Tennis Club.

Arthur J. Goldberg, former United States Permanent Representative to the United Nations and former Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, today takes the posiition of impartial chairman of the New York coat and suit industry.

Richard C. Egbert has joined the brokerage firm of Spencer Trask Co., Inc., as vice president and director. Before joining the company, he was with the Case National Bank. Before that, he had been with Estabrook Co., where he became a partner in 1963 and had the responsibility of being syndicate partner.

RYE, N. Y., June 30--Stuart B. Rowe Jr., with his International Class sloop, Ann; Richard and James Sykes's Dixie in the Shields Class, and Howard McMichael Jr., sailing his Tempest, Cottontail, won their second straight races on Long Island Sound today as the season's largest Yacht Racing Association fleet, 169, sailed in a 10-to-20-knot west-northwest breeze.

MOSCOW, June 30 (UPI)-Soviet surgeons used parts taken from the heart of a calf to repair two heart valves for a woman patient, the trade newspaper Trud reported today. The operation was seen as another step toward Russia's first full human heart transplant.

The Security National Bank of Long Island, Huntington, reported over the weekend that net operating earnings in the six months ended June 30 reached $2,585,400. up 32.6 per cent from the year-earlier $1,949,300. Deposits on June 30 were $608,115,000, up 21 per cent from $502,378,000.
PHILADELPHIA, June 30 (UPI)--Willie Stargell drove in three runs with his 13th home run and a double today to lead the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 5-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.
Direct obligations of the United States Government that will mature within 12 months amount to $108,776,894,184. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:

BRUSSELS, Monday, July 1 --Tariffs dropped today in at least 18 countries, including the six in the Common Market, improving prospects for further expansion of world trade and a pickup in American exports.

FORT SUMNER, N. M., June 30--In a dusty cornfield surrounded by low shrubs and an occasional sunflower five miles from here, 200 Navajo Indians in native costume re-enacted today the signing of the treaty that 100 years ago freed them from captivity by the cavalry and ended their wars with the United States.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 30 --Senator John Tower, a favoriteson candidate, released the 56 Texas delegates to the Republican National Convention today and told them he supported Richard Nixon.

DETROIT, June 30--The automobile industry intends to keep grinding out cars in the third quarter at well above last year's levels, automobile industry sources reported today. The four manufacturers have set up a program of 1.5 million automobile assemblies in July, August and September, up 20 per cent from 1,250,000 units rolled off the lines in those months last year.

"New York and Who to Blame It On," the revue that will be giving outdoor performances under the auspices of the APA-Phoenix, was written by Joseph Hurley. A previous announcement by the management said that Donald Moffat had collaborated. Mr. Moffat is the director.

A special committee of city educational leaders has proposed an intensive experiment in poverty area elementary schools in the fall that would include the beginning of formal education at the age of 3, a 10-hour school day and reduced class sizes and more individual attention.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30, (AP)--James Cecconi of Hillside, N. J., lifted a total of 900 pounds today and won the heavyweight title in the National Amateur Athletic Union Teen-Age Weightlifting championships.
A BASIC change in the award of master points at club level is projected by the American Contact Bridge League and will affect many thousands of duplicate players in the metropolitan area.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 30 -Vice President Humphrey predicted today that Senator Edward M. Kennedy "will do what is right" about supporting him for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

The historic achievement in Europe today of a six-nation customs union of 185,000,000 consumers-almost as many as in the United States--is blemished by France's new restrictive measures to protect its strike-weakened economy against foreign competition. But the blemish is slight.

EAST LANSING, Mich., June 30--Senator Eugene J. McCarthy today left the impression with Michigan delegates to the Democratic National Convention that he would favor Governor Rockefeller of New York over Vice President Humphrey, provided Mr. Rockefeller's views on foreign and domestic policies were acceptable.
Thaddeus F. Lemanski and A. Richard McCann have been admitted to general partnership in the New York Stock Exchange firm of H. N. Whitney, Goadby Co.
BERKELEY, Calif., June 30-A state of emergency was extended over the whole city of Berkeley tonight following a renewal of window breaking and reported looting in several areas.
Countries that account for more than a third of American exports are putting into effect today their first cuts in import duties under the Kennedy round tariff agreement.
WASHINGTON, June 30--A recommendation that all cigarette advertising be banned from television and radio is about to be made to Congress by the Federal Trade Commission.
Mediation efforts got under way at City Hall last night in an effort to avert work stoppages planned for 6 A.M. today by nonmedical workers at some private, nonprofit hospitals.
LOS ANGELES, June 30-- "No," said Dave Patrick, with a soft smile, "I'm really not sorry Jim Ryun wasn't in the race, as long as he recovers in time to make the team."

Youthful East Bronx residents, angered when a teenaged girl was injured by a light truck, swarmed into the streets early yesterday, assaulted the driver, overturned his truck and set it ablaze, and then hurled bricks and bottles at firemen trying to douse the fire.

"So this beach isn't classy, but what do you expect for a subway token," Ruben Torres, a telegraph operator, said yesterday as he dipped a toe into the copper-colored Long Island Sound off Orchard Beach, the Bronx.

Few new issues of securities are scheduled for sale this week. The market will be closed Thursday for Independence Day and Friday to give stock exchange firms their fourth day to clear up backoffice paperwork.

A spokesman for the barge industry was openly lobbying for the railroads in Albany last week. It was part of a courtship going on nationally to persuade the railroads--the bargemen's ancient rivals--that both categories of carrier would profit from improvements in the inland waterway system.
BOSTON, June 30--Commercials and movies were major subjects of discussion here today at the 17th annual convention of the National Cable Television Association.

The Long Island Rail Road was struck at 12:01 A.M. today by its track maintenance men. It continued normal service early this morning and said it was "hopeful" that service would be near normal in the rush hours today.
CHICAGO, June 30--Senator Eugene J. McCarthy challenged Vice President Humphrey today to meet him in public debate "on the crucial issues facing America."

OTTAWA, June 30--The controversial national plan for free medical service goes into effect tomorrow with only two provinces, British Columbia and Saskatchewan, ready to participate. Less than 10 per cent of Canada's 20 million people will immediately benefit.
The long battle to control the deficit in the United States balance of payments has taken a turn for the better, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company said yesterday.

The nation's largest shipper, the Military Sea Transportation Service, reported yesterday that 24 vessels carrying military supplies exclusively have been tied up by the two-day strike of the National Maritime Union.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he had "no intention" of asking Governor Rockefeller to appoint him Senator, "now or ever."

DETROIT, June 30 (AP) -- Eleven-year-old twin sisters were stabbed to death early today. The police said that one of the girls had been killed in her bedroom and the other as she attempted to flee down a nearby alley.

The secret papers found in the knapsack of Ernesto Che Guevara when he was captured by tile Bolivian Army on Oct. 8 reveal clearly that the guerrilla movement and Mr. Guevara's role in it were under the close and personal supervision of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba.
PITTSBURGH, June 30--New orders for steel continued to drop last week.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 30 (AP) -- The touring United States Olympic basketball team beat Finland's national team, 91-87, tonight. Mike Barrett led the Americans with 25 points, Glynn Saulters had 16 and John Clawson and Spencer Haywood 14 each.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 30 --Charles C. Tillinghast Jr., president of Trans World Airlines, will become the 15th chancellor of Brown University tomorrow.

MONTREAL, June 30 (Canadian Press)--Dick Carmody of Palm Springs, Calif., posted a four-under-par 68 today for an aggregate of 208 and won the Quebec open golf tournament by two strokes at the Islesmere Golf Club.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 30 (AP) -- Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the 15-year-old son of the late Senator, arrived today for a visit to East Africa. He was taken to the home of the United States Ambassador, Glenn W. Ferguson, after a flight from Paris. He is expected to stay three weeks as the guest of the director of national parks in Tanzania, John Owen.
Ramparts magazine has obtained from the Cuban Government for publication tomorrow what is purported to be an authentic copy of the original manuscript of Ernesto Che Guevara's Bolivian diary.

Jimmy Ellis, recognized as heavyweight champion by the World Boxing Association, agreed yesterday to defend his title against Floyd Patterson in Stockholm on Sept. 14, according to United Press International.

THE Rome Opera found a congenial vehicle in Verdi's "I Due Foscari," which it presented at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. There was some historical appropriateness in having the company give this work, since it was the first of Verdi's operas to have its premiere in Rome.
A Rockefeller-for-President advertisement about the Governor's handling of the 1964 Rochester riots was called inaccurate yesterday by Rochester's former City Manager.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Attorney General Ramsey Clark gave the Subversive Activities Control Board a new lease on life today by asking it to declare seven persons to be members of the Communist party.
BOSTON, July 1 -- An enormous expansion of cable television facilities in New York City became a likelihood today.

LONDON, July 1 -- What a day for Americans! Four men in the last eight at Wimbledon. Start with Arthur Ashe, who slammed over 19 aces to dethrone the defending champion, John Newcombe, in a five-set slugfest, 6-4, 6-4, 4-6, 1-6, 6-3.

The Greentree Stable picked up at Aqueduct yesterday where it left off at Belmont Park on Saturday. Buck Run, ridden by Heliodoro Gustines, won the feature race at the Big A, the $33,925 Tremont, thereby matching the stable's stakes success of Saturday, when Stage Door Johnny won the Saranac.
T-Bone Walker got famous for playing what?
The last ritual was delicious and then everybody could forget about the public schools until September; it used to be that way.

DETROIT, July 1 -- Arjay R. Miller, vice chairman of the Ford Motor Company and one of the nation's best-known and highly paid businessmen, is leaving Ford to become dean of the Graduate School of Business at Stanford University.

THE little old gray frame house on East 92d Street, with a one-story-high privet bush in its front yard and an old-fashioned railing on its front porch, could pass for the house of a recluse. It has a silent, withdrawn look and could stand a coat of paint.

GENEVA, July 1 -- Major trading nations agreed today on a procedure for examining protectionist measures taken by France to shield her strike - weakened economy, amid indications of a common desire to avoid a trade war.
MIAMI, July 1 -- A passenger used a pistol to hijack a Northwest Airlines plane carrying 92 persons tonight and forced the pilot to land in Cuba.
A Federal judge in Wilmington, Del., has granted a motion to appoint a receiver for the B.S.F. Company, an important link in the chain of companies controlled by Victor Muscat, the financier.
The stock market continued its low-keyed retreat yesterday as prices went through another modest setback.
A strike by 850 trackmen forced tens of thousands of Long Island Rail Road commuters to sizzle, swelter and struggle to get to work yesterday morning on the year's hottest day.
OTTAWA, July 1 (Canadian Press) -- The St. Lawrence Seaway Authority announced a new wage offer to its 1,250 striking workers today and asked their union to resume bargaining this week.
The first Yiddish-English dictionary in 40 years will be published here next week and will include words that never were when the last one came out.

BRUSSELS, July 1 - The Common Market's Executive Commission sought today to infuse a new spirit of dynamism into the six-nation community. It acted as the last tariff barriers between the member states were eliminated, effective today.

ALBANY, July 1 -- In a 4-to-3 decision that drew a stinging dissent, the Court of Appeals today held that the state must pay a property owner damages for the noise of passing traffic when the state takes part of his land to build a highway.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, July 2 -- United States marines, supported by artillery and fighter planes, were said to have killed 157 North Vietnamese soldiers early yesterday in a fight near the Khesanh combat base.

Dr. Carol Master, a tanned, 25-year-old blonde, began her interneship at Metropolitan Hospital yesterday with an attentive expression, an enthusiastic attitude and an occasional impish glance at another young interne -- her husband.

The amendment to the Social Security Act curtailing pension payments to nonresident aliens is a monstrous injustice and a crime against little people. The inability of the Department of State to extract reciprocal measures from other governments is no excuse for such flagrant breach of contract.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A vice president of the New York Stock Exchange said today that he could not "rationalize or defend" the system of sales commissions on stock transactions that the exchange has had in effect for decades. He noted that the exchange recently proposed that the system be altered.

Three new legitimate theaters, each with a minimum seating capacity of 1,100, will be erected in enclosed-mall shopping centers in Cherry Hill, five miles east of Camden, N. J.; Plymouth Meeting, 14 miles northwest of Philadelphia, and Willowbrook, four miles west of Paterson, N. J.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Urban Coalition is alive and well at 1815 H Street in Washington, D. C.
NAUSHON ISLAND, Mass., July 1 -- Just east of Tarpaulin Cove on this, the largest and perhaps loveliest of the Elizabeth Islands, there is a smaller cove and it was there the terns were diving.

WASHINGTON July 1 (AP) -- Consumer credit, swollen by the largest increase in outstanding installment credit in more than a year, reached a record $100.3-billion by the end of May, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday.

WHEN Governor Rockefeller visited Cleveland last month, the wire services sent out a photograph showing him playing a drum with a crowd of musicians at the airport. Behind Governor Rockefeller in the picture stood Gov. James Allen Rhodes of Ohio, vigorously clapping in time to the music.

The city's acute financial squeeze has forced the basic real estate tax up to a record level of 5.21 per cent. The size of that impost is bound to increase pressure for a reconsideration of the rules that allow one large group of New York property owners -- the institutions enjoying tax exemption -- to bear no part of the burden borne by all other owners.
PART TWO of the New York Shakespeare Festival's "Henry IV" joined Part One in repertory Sunday night in Ceneral Park, and turned out to be that rare thing, a sequel that does not disappoint.
More ships were scrapped last year but less shipping tonnage was lost in accidents throughout the world in 1967 than in 1966, according to a Maritime Administration report.
MINEOLA, L. I., Tuesday, July 2 -- There will be harness racing at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

LOS ANGELES, July 1 (AP) -- A first-inning wild pitch cost Bob Gibson a chance for a record-tying sixth straight shutout tonight, but the St. Louis Cardinals, right-hander went on to quell Los Angeles, 5-1, for his seventh straight victory.

BONN, July 1 -- Franz Cardinal Konig, Archbishop of Vienna, announced today that the Roman Catholic Church might revise its censure of Galileo Galilei, the 17th-century Italian scientist who was declared a heretic for asserting that the earth moves around the sun.

BOSTON, July 1 (AP) -- Mickey Mantle of the New York Yankees was named to the American League All-Star team for the 16th year today. The injured Al Kaline of the Detroit Tigers was passed by for the first time since 1955.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday dedicated a $1.3-million police communications center that cuts in half the average time it takes the police to dispatch emergency help to the citizen.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Yankees lost more than usual tonight. They not only dropped a 3-1 decision to the Senators -- which has been known to happen -- but they also lost one manager and two pitchers before five innings had been played.
Hogan yesterday characterized as "utterly without foundation and absolutely ridiculous" a charge that a "leak" to the Mafia existed in his office.

Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba, in an introduction to what he described as an authentic copy of Ernesto Che Guevara's Bolivian diary, has written a scathing denunciation of Latin-American Communists who refuse to embrace guerrilla warfare to promote revolution.
An increase of 16.6 per cent in scheduled domestic airline passenger traffic for May has been reported by the Air Transport Association of America.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 1 (AP) -- The meeting of the five Central American Presidents in San Salvador will deal with the crisis facing their regional common market.

Montgomery Ward Co., the nation's third largest mail order and retail merchandising concern, is planning to further diversify its operations through a consolidation with the Container Corporation of America.

WASHINGTON, July 1 - Budget Director Charles J. Zwick laid down new procedures today for Federal agencies to achieve the $6-billion spending cut mandated by the tax bill signed last week by President Johnson.
Following are excerpts from a manuscript, purported to be the diary that Ernesto Che Guevara kept in Bolivia, which appear in English translation in Ramparts magazine today:
WASHINGTON, July 1 (Reuters) -- President Johnson will visit the five Central American republics during a three-day trip beginning Saturday, the White House announced tonight.

In a June 20 letter Prof. Robert McCloskey denies that there is strong historical precedent for the claim that Vice Presidents should be loyal to political goals of Presidents of the United States. I was surprised that he neglected to offer the example of Aaron Burr, which would have made his point so excellently.

BARCELONA, June 30 -- Watched by an audience estimated at 3,500 young workers and 40 plainclothes members of the political police, a pantomime was acted out here today showing how the needs of Spain's working class are being ignored.

THOSE whose native language is English are notoriously poor linguists, so it is fortunate for the bridge players among them that their own tongue is the international language of the game. The Anglo-Saxon countries frequently import bridge talent but rarely export it, perhaps because of the language problem.
At about 9:45 P.M Eastern Standard Time on March 3 a woman in Indiana looked out a window and saw a procession of fiery objects fly past in the sky.
Neglect and abuse of children is increasing, according to a special committee of the New York County Medical Society, and changes are needed in state procedures to reduce the problem.
With trading mixed in all commodities, wheat futures rose yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade but weakened under liquidation and closed lower.

WASHINGTON, July 1 - The United States asked the Soviet Union today for the immediate return of a DC-8 commercial aircraft, its crew and 214 United States servicemen forced to land yesterday in the Kurile Islands of the Soviet Union.
TOKYO, July 1 -- Japanese reports of radar contact with the American plane indicated that it had been intercepted and forced to change course while over international waters south of Iturup Island.

The Railway Express Agency, Inc., has decided not to sell its business after all, but it is going to sell all or a portion of a subsidiary, the R.E.A. Leasing Corporation, in order to raise working capital.

At 12:01 A.M. yesterday in Roanoke, Va., Herman Pevler, president of the Norfolk Western Railway, acquired for that carrier the Delaware Hudson Railroad in exchange for 412,627 shares of N. W. common stock and a $1-million five-year N. W. note.

Representatives of several Puerto Rican community organizations invaded the offices of the city Human Resources Administration yesterday, holding a deputy administrator captive in a conference room for two hours while they discussed their grievances concerning the administration's hiring policies.
Governor Rockefeller proposed yesterday a new "good neighbor policy" for the Western Hemisphere as he prepared to go to Montana to resume his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination.
Mediators tried again yesterday to settle a strike against The Amsterdam News, but without success.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 -- Two authorities on constitutional law dealing with church-state relations clashed today on the significance of the recent Supreme Court decision that upheld the New York law on the loan of textbooks to parochial school pupils.

Chief Rabbi Yehuda Leib Levin of Moscow and Cantor David Stisken of Leningrad departed yesterday for Montreal and Moscow after re-establishing contact with many segments of the American rabbinate and Christian Church leaders.
Fire insurance premiums on properties in New York State rose by an average of 9.6 per cent under rate adjustments that went into effect yesterday.

WAVERLY, Minn., July 1 - Ten days ago, before the storm that also flattened the soy bean that also flattened the soybean banner strung over U. S. Route 12 that read;"Welcome to Waverly, home of Vice President Humphrey."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 1 -- This morning, as they do every morning, representatives of the United States command placed a hefty stack of mimeographed press statements on a table in a Government building in downtown Saigon.

LOEW'S THEATRES, Inc., conceded yesterday that it failed to gain a majority of Commercial Credit Company stock in its tender offer and that the offer would not be extended beyond last Friday's expiration date.
LONDON, July 1 -- Sand and dust from the Sahara and southern Spain fell on parts of England today, the hottest day here in seven years.
A FOURTH OF JULY feast should be festive, fun and fixed out of doors, and there should be typically American dishes to please young and old.
Thirty-eight welfare clients and their supporters were arrested yesterday morning as they blockaded the main office of the city's Department of Social Services.

WASHINGTON, July 1 - President Johnson announced today that the United States and the Soviet Union had agreed to open talks "in the nearest future" that would be aimed at limiting and reducing both offensive nuclear weapons and defensive antimissile systems.
Three of the jurors who convicted Mrs. Alice Crimmins of the strangling of her 4-year-old daughter returned to court yesterday to testify at a hearing on her motion to set aside the conviction.

Two groups that drove out their music with a ruggedly percussive attack -- Mongo Santamaria's eight-man ensemble and Hugh Masakela's quintet -- battered their way through two concerts last night at the Schafer Music Festival in Central Park.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) -- The House voted today to spend $100-million more yearly on school lunches for needy children, a major goal of the Poor People's Campaign. More than 4 million poor youngsters would benefit.
Two weeks ago 14 municipal hospitals eliminated their $11 fee for family-planning advice. Since then there has been only a 10 per cent increase in the number of women asking for the service.
Travel was described as "a little light" as the new rushhour KK line subway service began operations yesterday linking Queens, Brooklyn and Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, July 1 - The Congress should establish a guideline for the Federal Reserve Board to expand the money supply by 2 to 6 per cent a year, the Joint Economic Committee recommended today.

The American flag was lowered on Iwo Jima the other day as the United States returned the Volcano and Bonin Islands to Japan just 23 years after the historic flag-raising on Mount Suribachi. But this gesture of American-Japanese friendship took place against a background of rising anti-Americanism in Japan that points up the need for continuing dispassionate appraisal of the mutual security arrangements to which both countries have been committed for nearly two decades.
The much-acclaimed plans for transit improvement bid fair to perpetuate the "billions for construction but not one cent for operations" syndrome that has for so long plagued city transit.

MOSCOW, July 1 -- The treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons was signed by 36 countries in Moscow today and the Soviet Union took occasion to issue a new appealto the world for urgent measures to stop the arms race and achieve disarmament.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- President Johnson accepted today the resignations of two members of Federal agencies -Gen. William F. McKee, head of the Federal Aviation Administration, and Lee Loevinger, member of the Federal Communications Commission.

Flowers, green leaves and, with luck, a clear, star-filled sky will provide the backdrop on July 12 for the eighth annual Evening of Elegance, which will be held at the Boat Basin Rotunda, 79th Street at the Hudson River.
NOW that stubby-toed shoes, rope necklaces, waist cinchers, and moire taffeta dresses are back in fashion, can veils, another favorite of the nineteen-forties, be far behind?

Earnings reports for the second quarter started to roll in yesterday from the nation's major banks. Without exception, they made good reading for bank shareholders -- so good in fact, that it is not hard to understand why bank shares have been outstanding performers in the market in recent months.

The Billy Rose Foundation has made a grant of $110,000 to the Metropolitan Museum of Art that will enable the museum to continue its program of remaining open on Tuesday nights for the next two years.

The chief ingredient in the dawn settlement of the New York City hospital strike threat was the realization by everyone involved that a walkout would be calamitous for tens of thousands of sick people. The situation was aggravated by the probability of clashes between strikers and police that might have touched off explosions in Negro and Puerto Rican slums.

The original autograph score of Mozart's "Haffner" Symphony, which in its 185-year history has never been out of private hands and thus available for scholarly study, was given yesterday to the Music Division of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center. Mrs. L. Lee Stanton, president of the board of the National Orchestral Association, which owned the document, presented it to Edward G. Freehafer, director of the library.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Treasury bill rate rose at today's auction from last week's levels, the Treasury disclosed today.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 1 -- Nothing, it seems, changes here at the "Cradle of the Trotter." Year in and year out, with the start of Grand Circuit week (actually five afternoon programs), local farmers mingle with big-city slickers -- you can tell the difference without a score card -- and the swirls of dust make breathing a chore while the heat is usually on the unbearable side.
Agreement was reached here yesterday on a two-year contract that will give 17,000 nurse's aides, kitchen workers, porters and other hospital employes a minimum weekly wage of $100.
Prices declined slightly in light trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.
MIAMI, July 1 (UPI) -- A $100,000 doubloon, stolen in a $1.5-million theft of rare coins from Willis du Pont, the multimillionaire, was recovered tonight in a motel room here.

ALFRED, N.Y., July 1 -Alfred University announced today that an eight-member faculty review board had upheld the dismissal of a 40-yearold teacher accused of violating the institution's policy on demonstrations.

BERKELEY, Calif., July 1 (UPI) -- The Berkeley police force was on alert tonight and the entire city under a 10-hour curfew as rebellious political activist planned new tactics following three nights of violence in the streets.
The Sanitation Department attempted yesterday to remove confusion that has developed over a new plan for the removal of abandoned vehicles.

The tobacco industry, which spent about $235-million to broadcast cigarette advertising last year, had no official comment yesterday on the news that the Federal Trade Commission was recommending that Congress ban all such commercials from television and radio.
Following are remarks by Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin and excerpts from a Soviet memorandum on steps to reduce the arms race, as made public in English by Tass, Soviet press agency:
A 68-game preseason exhibition schedule that includes 23 interleague games was an-announced yesterday by the American and National Foot-ball Leagues.

LONDON, July 1 -- With the first European tariff cuts under the Kennedy round negotiations just going into effect today, about 100 trade experts opened a two-day, unofficial conference in London to discuss what more could be done to expand world trade.
MILWAUKEE, July 1 -- Gov. James A. Rhodes of Ohio said today his state's delegation to the Republican convention would remain uncommitted until convention time.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Some easing in the interest rates on mortgage loans to finance construction projects was predicted today as a result of the income tax surcharge and the accompanying Federal spending cut signed last week by President Johnson.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 1 -- F. Gardner Cox Jr. increased his lead in the United States 5.5-Meter sailing championship series on Long Island Sound today while a Toronto real estate man, Stanley Liebel, moved in to second place.

Government bond prices rose slightly yesterday, not because of any particular news development, but because of the longer range economic implications of the tax surcharge bill that President Johnson signed into law last Friday.

Howard R. Hughes, the elusive Texan and former Hollywood producer, is bidding for control of American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., the radio and television network operator and theater owner, with a tender offer of almost $150-million.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The first Federal safety standards for used motor vehicles have tentatively been scheduled for issuance this fall, the Department of Transportation said in a report sent to Congress today.
RICHARD WAGNER. The Man, His Mind and His Music. By Robert W. Gutman. 490 pages. Harcourt, Brace and World. $12.50

HONG KONG, July 1 -- Observances in Peking today of the 47th anniversary of the Chinese Communist party were viewed by China analysts here as emphasizing the present muddled and uncertain state of the Cultural Revolution.

DALLAS, July 1 -- A special panel of the National Education Association has recommended that the million-member organization impose sanctions on individual schools, educational administrators and companies "found to be inrringing human rights."
BONN, July 1 -- The West German Government indicated today that it had no immediate intention of signing the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.
A former assistant chaplain at Columbia University refused to submit to induction into the Army yesterday in a challenge to what he called the use of the draft "as a punitive measure."
WASHINGTON, July 1 - The average young man who is a heavy cigarette smoker can expect to have his life shortened by eight years if he continues the habit, the Public Health Service reported today.
BRENTWOOD, L.I., July 1 - The Suffolk County police reported today that one gun was used in three homicides committed in the last three days in this suburban community.

The temperature rose to 97 degrees here yesterday, and residents in large sections of the city were without water because youngsters turned on thousands of fire hydrants to cool themselves on the hottest day so far this year.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 1 - Vice President Humphrey won today the support of 136 Democratic Mayors, who said he was the "man of exceptional talent and experience" their cities and the nation needed as President.
NORWALK, Conn., July 1 -Richard Maney, the theatrical press agent, died of pneumonia last night at Norwalk Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 213 Wolfpit Avenue.

OTTAWA, July 1 (Canadian Press) -- The Bank of Canada, the nation's central bank, today announced a reduction to 7 per cent from 7 1/2 per cent in its lending rate -- the equivalent of the Fderal Reserve's discount rate in the United States.

PARIS, July 1 -- Premier Georges Pompidou today called for a broadly based Government coalition comprising not only Gaullists of all shades but also the members of the middle -of-the-road group that had opposed him in the election.

You remember Mel Powell. Played piano for Benny Goodman and Glenn Miller in the forties, when swing and boogie-woogie were the words to know. In a more recent reincarnation the protean Mr. Powell has been chairman of the composition faculty at Yale and director of the university's electronic-music studio.

THE CHAIN LETTER CRAZE, which breaks out at least once a decade, has erupted again. The current epidemic is distinguished by its reliance on the Xerox or other multi - copying machines and its strength in the interlocking circles of fashion and society.
Following, as recorded by The New York Times, is the text of a statement in Washington yesterday by President Johnson on the signing of the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons:

Richard M. Nixon has gained support among Republican voters in his bid for the Presidential nomination, but in several selected categories of voters he trails the Democrats he might face in the November election, according to a poll taken by Louis Harris.

WASHINGTON, July 1 - A broad-based fourth political party, springing up after the August nominating conventions in time for the November election, is regarded by many politicians as a legal possibility but one with enormous practical problems.

JERUSALEM, July 1 -- Defense Minister Moshe Dayan was pointedly absent today from a meeting in which the Israeli Cabinet approved the appointment of Yigal Allon as Deputy Premier and minister in charge of absorption of immigrants.

AS Max Frisch originally wrote it in 1953, "The Firebugs" is not so much a conventional play as an eight-scene climax, a dramatized convulsion that cannot be stopped any more easily than can a sneeze once started.
The National Maritime Union agreed yesterday afternoon to an "immediate end" to a three- day strike that had delayed the sailings of 130 ships in Atlantic and Gulf ports.

LOS ANGELES, July 1 -- There was an awesome finality to the final Olympic track and field tryouts in the old days. No matter how glossy a man's occupation, no matter what records or championships he held, he was given only one all-or-nothing shot at winning a berth on the United States Olympic team. If he failed, he was out.
Mayor Lindsay learned yesterday that the city had almost 20,000 fewer summer jobs to offer slum youths than it had last year. He responded with an emotional attack on President Johnson and Congress.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (Reuters) -- The Defense Department announced tonight that it was abandoning plans to create a full new infantry division because of stringent economies in Federal spending.

Back from a three-day visit to Rome and an audience with Pope Paul VI on Monday, the Most Rev. Terence J. Cooke, Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, said yesterday that the Pontiff "still encourages theological discussions."
WESTBURY, L. I., July 2 -- The racing secretary's office at Roosevelt Raceway resembled Grand Central Station today.
In key organizational moves, Richard M. Nixon set up yesterday a top level economic advisory committee and named coordinators for research in domestic and foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Administration asked Congress today to abolish the death penalty for all Federal crimes, including Presidential assassinations, and to reduce to life imprisonment the sentences of Federal prisoners on Death Row.

TOKYO, July 2 -- Lionel Rose, the battling aborigine from the Australian Bush, came up from a second-round knockdown tonight to retain his world bantamweight championship by gaining a decision over Takao Sakurai of Japan in 15 lively rounds.
An elaborate system of "protection'' payoffs to the police by gamblers and nightclub operators led to the indictment yesterday of 37 men, including 19 present and former policemen.

The City Planning Commission moved yesterday to acquire greater control over construction in the immediate area of three major transportation centers -- Grand Central Terminal, Pennsylvania Station and the Long Island Rail Road's complex in Jamaica, Queens.
The Players Association of the National Football League yesterday turned down an offer made by the negotiating committee of team owners, and some form of a strike appears imminent.
Archbishop Terence J. Cooke announced yesterday that he had named the Archdiocese of New York's first Negro pastor, at the same time appointing him as Vicariate Delegate for Harlem.

The essence of the recommendations by the latest committee on the improvement of the city schools is that all the best available elementary school strategies be translated into four models and tested for several years. All but one of the models would cost substantially more than any of the present programs.
When Liggett Myers recently introduced their pretty little Designer Packs, it apparently was only the beginning of a new marketing approach for the cigarette end of the business.

" OF BLACK AMERICA," the Columbia Broadcasting System's series of seven programs on various aspects of Negro history and culture, was winningly introduced last night with "Black History: Lost, Stolen or Strayed.

Major Negro and Puerto Rican leaders charged yesterday that minority groups were under - represented in New York's delegation to the Democratic National Convention and called for a new meeting of the party's state committee to correct the situation.
A SINISTER TWILIGHT. The Fall of Singapore, 1942. By Noel Barber. 364 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $6.95.
The president of the board of Haryou announced yesterday that he would ask for city and Federal investigations of the multimillion-dollar anti-poverty agency and police protection for himself.
The New York Knickerbocker, the tabloid-type Sunday magazine that made its first appearance here and on suburban newsstands last February, has been acquired by The New York Daily Column.

A telephone call from New York to Chicago, Louisville or Omaha will cost 10 cents less beginning Aug. 1 as part of a $20-million reduction in long distance rates announced yesterday by the American Telephone Telegraph Company.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The House tonight passed a bill to establish Federal safety standards for interstate gas pipelines and local gas distribution systems. The vote was 350 to 14.

JERUSALEM, July 2 -- The settlement of Jews in the former Jordanian sector of this city, in defiance of a United Nations Security Council resolution deploring any change in the city's status and against the advice of Israel's friends, including the United States, is being pressed at full speed.
A mother who lost a son in Vietnam gave new expression yesterday to the war protest.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 2 -- A majority of the American people reject the notion that the United States is a "sick society," but as many as one-third do hold such a view, the Gallup Poll indicated today.

Seventeen Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish groups here said yesterday that they would try to channel their millions of dollars in purchasing and building funds only to companies and unions that give equal employment opportunities to minority groups.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 2 -- The most probable outcome of the trans-Atlantic race to Germany that will begin from St. David's Head tomorrow was that one of the four 73-footers would cross the finish line at Travemunde first.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 2 -- The late King George VI engaged in some dashing doubles in a Wimbledon championship back in 1926 and the crowned heads of Europe have been frequent spectators in the royal box.

The Maritime Administration said yesterday that an application had been filed for mortgage insurance on 425 lighters to be operated by Prudential Lines in connection with five LASH (Lighter Aboard Ship) vessels now under construction.
