Few of us like to see disharmony formalized. Hence our aversion to strikes, divorce, third parties and declarations of war.

The barrels are cooling in Congress on gun-control legislation as the long Independence Day recess begins. Nothing will happen unless the public makes it happen between now and July 9, when the committees resume debate on how strong or weak a law the American people want -- and will get.
" What do you do about the worker who turns off the television set when a play by Shakespeare is on?"

If well begun is half done, as the copybook maxim used to insist, Jorge Mester is at least halfway toward becoming a first-rate conductor. Now just 33 years old, the Mexican-born musician already has his own orchestra, the Louisville Symphony, and has been guest conductor of many others, including the Boston Symphony.

The interest of magazine and book publishers in the story of Ernesto Che Guevara as a revolutionary martyr has gained new momentum with the publication of his purported Bolivian notebooks by the Cuban Government.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- An executive speaking out for the tenants of America's office buildings registered a protest today with owners and operators against methods of listing rental rates that he termed confusing and sometimes misleading.
MIAMI, July 2 (UPI) -- Jack (Murf the Surf) Murphy was found legally insane tonight by Criminal Court Judge Carling Stedman and will escape immediate trial for armed robbery and murder.
WHITE PLAINS, July 2 -- Last August three masked men wearing tan Army fatigues robbed the Greenville branch of the Scarsdale National Bank and Trust Company of $71,000.
MIAMI, July 2 (AP) -- A plane chartered by the State Department today returned 86 travelers from Cuba, where they were stranded when a hijacked American jetliner was ordered to leave them behind.

Mayor Lindsay named 17 elected and appointed public officials yesterday to make up a third of the members of the city's Council Against Poverty. The move was required by new Congressional legislation that took effect Monday.
MADRID, July 2 -- His Honor arrived here today to become His Excellency.
CLEVELAND, July 2 -- Vice President Humphrey rejected today Senator Eugene J. McCarthy's challenge to meet him in television debate prior to the Democratic National Convention next month.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) -- The House Armed Services Committee almost certainly killed the Navy's controversial F-111B fighter-bomber today by agreeing with a Senate decision to withhold any more money for it.
All but two of the 19 children on Rongelap Island who were less than 10 years old when a hydrogen bomb was exploded on nearby Bikini Atoll in 1954 have developed abnormal thyroid glands.

MOSCOW, July 2 (UPI) -- The reprimands and dismissals recommended today by the presidium of the Central Committee of Sports Societies will be taken up by the national federations of the sports concerned, but this is considered mere formality.
As expected, the management of American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., said "no" yesterday to the bid for control made by Howard R. Hughes the privacy-loving multimillionaire.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., July 2 -- Booing, catcalling parents shouted down supporters of a state order to integrate the city's schools at a meeting of the Board of Education tonight.

FOR the general public and even for a sizable portion of the Museum of Modern Art's most faithful fans, the title of the museum's new show may be confusing. "The Art of the Real," which opens today, has nothing to do with realism in art, unless its emphatic contradiction of realism's validity is a connection of sorts.

MRS. RICHARD M. NIXON still has what in the 1952, 1956 and 1960 Presidential campaigns were known as respectable Republican cloth coats. But there's been a mink coat in and out of her closet since Christmas of 1964, and mink, as virtually everybody knows, is one of the marks of achievement in American society.
BRUSSELS, July 2 -- A traveler crossing the German-Belgian frontier noticed that there seemed to be as many trucks as usual waiting to clear customs.

DALLAS, July 2 -- The president of the National Education Association, declaring that "the time of need is here," tonight called for a multimillion-dollar association "defense fund to back striking teachers and to "prevent reprisals" against them.

The long simmering price conflict between American steel producers and importers came to the surface again yesterday as the Crucible Steel Company announced it was offering discounts on large purchases of stainless steel sheet by major distributors.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 -- The concept of black separatism for American Negroes was debated by two Negro leaders last night before 250 specialists in the field of intergroup relations.

A Health Department official yesterday criticized a $1 fine against a company that had prepared 12,000 pounds of veal that was later confiscated as dirty. The meat was to have been shipped to the United States Military Academy at West Point.

The Sperry Hutchinson Company is planning to enter the banking business through an exchange offer for the common stock of the State National Bank of Connecticut, the nation's second oldest national bank whose assets exceed $322-million.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The National Transportation Safety Board urged the Federal Government today to outlaw the practice by some airline pilots of using radar to try to steer their way through storm areas.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 2 -- This is the place where they seem to manufacture speed, where you need to run laps of better than three miles a minute to qualify for a good position in the starting line-up.

The present fight in the Senate over the confirmation of Abe Fortas as Chief Justice of the United States and Homer Thornberry as Associate Justice has plenty of precedents, but it revives the old and discredited practice of opposition on partisan political grounds.
HARTFORD, July 2 -- Connecticut supporters of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy accepted today John M. Bailey's offer of nine seats in the state's 44-member delegation to the Democratic National Convention.

WHILE some stockbrokers were dealing yesterday with small investors and others were occupied with big institutions, the firm of Scheinman, Hochstin Trot, Inc., went briskly about its way as "the businessman's broker."
TOKYO, Wednesday, July 3 -- North Vietnam announced today that it was releasing three United States pilots for humanitarian reasons.
LONDON, July 2 -- Britain's gold and foreign exchange reserves dropped by 26-million, or $62.4-million, last month to 1.11 billion, or about $2.68-billion, the Treasury announced today.

Tommy Trotter, racing secretary for the New York Racing Association, received an important phone call from Delaware yesterday morning. It was from Frank Whiteley Jr., trainer for Mrs. Edith W. Bancroft's string of thoroughbreds.
Prices advanced slightly in light trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

MOSCOW, July 2 -- Events rarely live up to expectation. Artistic events, that is. With earthquakes, I understand, you can be luckier. As a consequence I heard stories of the new version of "Spartacus" by the Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow with a degree of healthy skepticism all but amounting to disbelief.
Platinum futures prices resumed their upward trend yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, after dipping on Monday.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Top aides of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy have told him that they are convinced Vice President Humphrey's delegate claims are "greatly exaggerated."
ALBANY, July 2 -- The Court of Appeals held for the first time today that a wife may recover damages for the loss of her husband's "consortium" from any party responsible for injuries to him.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 2 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan acknowledged today that a current recall campaign directed against him could be "embarrassing" in connection with his prospective role as a favorite-son candidate at the Republican National Convention.
The stock market broke its latest losing streak yesterday, posting the first advance in six sessions.

An advertising agency executive who recently produced two anti-smoking TV spots for the American Cancer Society said yesterday that many actors had declined to appear in the one-minute films, because they feared that cigarette sponsors would not consider them for commercials.

PAMELA LYONS has a pretty smart mommy. Yesterday, when a lot of people were sweltering in the 90-degree heat, Pamela was celebrating her second birthday at what was probably the coolest birthday party in town.
BRENTWOOD, L. I., July 2 -- The Suffolk County police arrested three Brentwood men tonight as suspects in the three slayings committed in this suburban community since Saturday.

UMUAHIA, Nigeria, July 2 -- Transportation problems and the delicate issue of sovereignty are preventing a relief effort by international agencies that are trying to arrest widespread starvation in Biafra, the secessionist former Eastern Region of Nigeria.
LONDON, July 2 -- A London court today ordered James Earl Ray returned to the United States to stand trial as the accused assassin of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 3 -- The Soviet Union continued this morning a news blackout on -the United States airliner forced down in the Kuriles. The official press agency, Tass, clearly reflecting a decision of the Soviet Government to play down the incident, has not recorded the release of the airliner.

BOSTON, July 2 -- The newly elected president of the National Cable Television Association said today that the future of the cable television industry would be marked by amalgamations of smaller companies and eventual merger into giant corporations.
GOSHEN, N. Y., July 2 -- Giving a touch of class to the harness racing meeting here, two groups of fans were transported to Historic Track in Rolls-Royce cars today.
PARIS -- The strategy of fear played a significant role in President de Gaulle's smashing electoral victory which disintegrated the badly led Center and whittled the Left to bite-size.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 2 -- United States B-52 bombers rained tons of explosives on targets in North Vietnam just north of the demilitarized zone today for the second consecutive day.
YOKOTA AIR BASE, Japan, Wednesday, July 3 -- Looking tired but cheerful, the Americans arrived at this United States Air Force base near Tokyo this afternoon en route to Vietnam.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 2 -- Arthur Ashe and Clark Graebner, a couple of amateurs, have reached the semi-finals of this first Wimbledon open tennis tournament, and the United States has two players there for the first time since Alex Olmedo, a transplanted Peruvian, and Barry MacKay reached the last four in 1959.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Gen. Harold K. Johnson, Army Chief of Staff, retired from the service today with words of praise and gratitude from President Johnson.

Bud Harrelson's error on a routine grounder to shortstop allowed the winning run to score with two out in the ninth inning last night as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the New York Mets, 2-1, at Shea Stadium.

A student committee and two other groups studying the reorganization of Columbia University in the wake of turbulent student demonstrations last spring will receive Ford Foundation grants totalling $100,500.
LONDON, July 2 -- At the age of 80, Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery of Alamein is still a man of strong opinions and pungent language.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Soviet Government today released an American airliner that was forced down Sunday while en route to Vietnam with 214 United States servicemen and 17 crewmen aboard.

ROME, July 2 -- For Pope Paul Paul VI and millions of Roman Catholics, the human bones unearthed almost three decades ago under St. Peter's Basilica are the true remains of St. Peter, prince of the Apostles and first Bishop of Rome.

Federal Judge Caleb R. Layton asked lawyers in a stockholder suit against the former management of the B.S.F. Company yesterday in Wilmington, i DeL, to work out an agreement on the duties of a receiver and report back on 3uly 12.
The tide of favorable earnings reports from the nation's major banks continued to flow in yesterday.

Thirty of the National Basketball Association's top players are going to put their talents to work in behalf of the late Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s Southern Christian Leadership Conference and Mayor Lindsay's Urban Action Task Force.

HONG KONG, July 2 -- A revolution -- piano accompaniment -- came to the Peking Opera last night.

The eight and one-half week driver strike at the United Parcel Service is having a severe, adverse effect on summer business of New York's big retail establishments. Despite a variety of efforts to cope with the stoppage of their regular delivery service, eight of the city's largest department stores realized a loss in their sales last month, averaging 5 per cent below that of June, 1967.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Senators heard testimony today that most union leaders had abdicated as protectors of their members' job safety and health.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Administration officials are anxious to start arms limitations talks with the Soviet Union as soon as possible because they hope to influence important military decisions pending before the Soviet leadership.

Scandinavian Airlines (S.A.S.) is ordering seven more McDonnell Douglas jet aircraft for delivery early in 1970. Six are Super-DC-9 medium range twin jets, and the seventh is a DC-8-62 convertible freighter.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Senator Robert P. Griffin said today that executives of companies that do business with the Government were putting pressure on Senators to confirm two Supreme Court appointees.

One of the largest mergers in the home furnishings industry was announced yesterday, involving an agreement between the Armstrong Cork Company and Thomasville Furniture Industries, Inc., a leading producer of quality furniture.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- A broker who buys and sells stock on the American Stock Exchange for mutual-fund portfolios testified today that he was "very happy" to do this business for 10 per cent of the commission that he was nominally required to charge under the exchange's rules.

The Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday three moves designed to broaden and diversify its activities in oceanography.

ALBANY, July 2 -- The Court of Appeals upheld today the right of the state to compel treatment for narcotic addicts who have not been charged with criminal activity. But it declared unconstitutional the procedures under which most addicts have been placed in so-called rehabilitation centers.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- A scaled down version of Congressional proposals to improve the American merchant marine was cleared today by the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries.

The Treasury announced the sale yesterday of $4-billion of bills to raise roughly a third of the new cash the Government will need to borrow during the first half of the fiscal year that began Monday.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 2 -- A typical midsummer Long Island Sound calm that makes a yacht race dull and tiring hit the fourth race of the United States 5.5-Meter championship series today.

The First National City Bank, the largest bank in New York and the second largest in the nation, yesterday announced a plan to form a one-bank holding company. Its first investment would be shares of the bank itself.

With fair skies and warm weather predicted for the start of the long Independence Day weekend today, New Yorkers were expected to head in near-record numbers for beaches and other holiday areas.
MOSCOW, July 3 (Reuters) -- The United States, Britain and France lodged protests with the Soviet Union today over restrictions recently imposed by East Germany on travel to and from West Berlin.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 -- In a time of changes so swift they are frightening, the thoughts of at least one member of the international social set are turning toward home.

JACKSON, Miss., July 3 -- Gov. John Bell Williams of Mississippi objected today to a proposal by Vice President Humphrey for an investigation of reported discrimination in the state's Democratic party.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 3 -- Kialoa II and Stella Polare, two big yawls in the first division of four, led the procession today as 33 yachts dropped St. David's Head light astern at the start of a trans-Atlantic race to Germany.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Hubert Humphrey's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination is long on delegates but woefully short on excitement. No one who spent the last week touring with the Vice President through the central part of the country came away with any evidence that Senator Eugene J. McCarthy would present a serious threat to Mr. Humphrey at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago next month.

CAIRO, July 3 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser and McGeorge Bundy, president of the Ford Foundation conferred here for an hour today. Mr. Bundy then flew to Beirut on a tour of foundation projects in the Middleeast.

" Are you for or against Breezy Point?" asked Mrs. Ann McMahon as she hospitably offered a visitor a chair on the porch of her trim white bungalow on Beach 219th Street. The question, in one form or another, is the standard greeting to a stranger in this mixed community of 2,700 summer cottages and year-round households at the western end of the Rockaway Peninsula.

JOSEPH PAPP'S latest variation on "Hamlet" is an interracial political comedy set in what seems to be Emperor Jones territory. As long as it is faithful to this conception, the Mobile Theater production is quite interesting.

MIAMI, July 3 -- Premier Fidel Castro asserted tonight the authenticity of the Bolivian diary of Ernesto Che Guevera published this week in Cuba and reproduced in the United States and other countries.

An organization of welfare clients leading a series of demonstrations against the welfare system warned Mayor Lindsay yesterday that the clients and the city's Department of Social Services were on "a collision course."
ATLANTA, July 3 (AP) -- A scientist reported today that he had successfully changed subordinate monkeys into bosses by electrical stimulation of the monkeys' brains.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Standing at attention under the gaze of his commander in chief, Gen. William C. Westmoreland became Army Chief of Staff today amid Pentagon pomp and ceremony.
OTTAWA, July 3 -- The Canadian Government announced today it had reduced tariffs on an extended list of chemicals and plastics imported largely from the United States.

CINCINNATI, July 3 (AP) -- Willie Mays was named to the All-Star team for the 15th consecutive year today as the National League manager, Red Schoendienst, completed his squad for Tuesday's game in Houston.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- President Johnson, expressing "horror" over the killing committed by a man with a gun in New York City's Central Park this morning, called upon Congress to pass stronger control measures "to protect the American people against insane and reckless murder by gunfire."

MOSCOW, July 3 -- The Soviet Communist party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, denounced the United States today as a land of violence and terror and of "political gangsterism that causes contempt and disgust throughout the world."

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Representative Gerald R. Ford predicted today that the Republicans would gain at least 40 seats in the House elections this fall and take control for the first time since 1954.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy may challenge the seating of some state delegations at the Democratic National Convention on the ground that he was not given a fair share of the delegates.
LONDON, July 3 -- James Earl Ray, the alleged killer of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., was reported today to have robbed a London bank of the equivalent of $240 late in May.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Mel Stottlemyre once won 20 games for a losing ball club and he could do it again this year. The slender pitcher won his 10th game of the season last night, pitching a four-hitter as the Yankees defeated the Senators, 4-1.

CHICAGO, July 3 (UPI) -- Northwest Industries, Inc., the holding company that is the parent of the Chicago North Western Railway, announced today revised terms for the proposed merger of the Chicago, Milwaukee St. Paul Railroad with the North Western system.
PARIS, July 3 -- North Vietnamese diplomats held a reception today to celebrate, as the invitations said, "the destruction of the 3,000th American plane in North Vietnam."

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 3 -- Only three of the 18 eligibles answered the call for the 55th Historic-Dickerson Cup contest for 3-year-old trotting colts today at Historic Track. Since one was the incomparable Nevele Pride, the outcome was almost a forgone conclusion.

AREA A -Electrical storms on Tuesday night slowed what was previously good blue fishing. Black, ling and whiting schools are reported moving into the Brielle, N. J., area and fluke, blackfish and striped bass are being taken in fair quantities in the Long Branch region.

Last weekend, about 1,000 people met in Chicago as the Coalition for an Open Convention to find ways of preventing the nomination of Hubert H. Humphrey. At a time when the life of the nation is pictured by many as violence and disorder, these people kept repeating one simple theme: Democracy can, and should, be made to work.
TORONTO, July 4 -- Potash, a key fertilizer ingredient, which Canada hopes will be one of her big export commodities of tomorrow, is making news again.

CORNING, Iowa, July 4 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy toured this southwest Iowa town today telling farmers that they deserved a fair price for the food they produced. He is seeking support for his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination among the state's delegates to the national convention.
After two years of the dominance of electric pop groups, the singer-songwriter with the pre-Edison guitar is making a comeback.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 4 -- Prime Minister Ian D. Smith tonight removed from his Cabinet one of its principal right-wingers, William Harper, the Minister of Internal Affairs.
DORTSMOUTH, England, July 4 -- Twelve days less than a year ago when Alec Richard Rose put out from Portsmouth on his second attempt to sail around the world, he said:
One of the first certified public accountants to practice in New York is retiring after 57 years in the business.

Restaurant Associates Industries, Inc., is expanding its operations into the airline and industrial catering and vending business through the acquisition of Al Green Enterprises, Inc., of Detroit, it was announced yesterday.

The Navy has announced selection of three final competitors -- shipyards and cooperating industrial and design concerns -- for the procurement of a fleet of modern destroyers in the largest Defense Department contract ever awarded.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- A plan was announced today aimed at streamlining the work of the United States Catholic Conference to give priests, the religious and the laity greater voice and direct contact with bishops of the Roman Catholic Church.
A comparison of murders in Manhattan and London has disclosed that guns were the lethal weapons seven times more often here than in the British capital.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 4 -- With the naming today of Le Chant of South Canterbury, N.Z., the field for the 10th annual Roosevelt International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway on July 13 was increased to seven. One more entrant, to complete the starting list, will emerge from the Canadian trotting championship race at Richelieu Park in Montreal tomorrow night.

THE Von Zedwitz Trophy for the New York Double Knockout Team Championship was won last month by a team headed by Peter Weichsel of New York and including Murray Schnee, Dr. Kalman Apfel and Martin Ginsberg, all of New York, and Lou Levy of Newark.

SARATOGA, N. Y., July 4 -- Snow fell in this leisurely paced spa tonight, not, let me hasten to add, on the Saratoga greensward but on the stage of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center. The New York City Ballet, crowning a national holiday with a theatrical one, opened the center's third summer season with the Christmas ballet fantasy "The "Nutcracker."

PARIS -- May was Europe's revolutionary month and for a time it seemed it might reverse conservative currents already visible on the political scene. But the spring tide proved to be a neap tide. Summer has set in far more stodgily than promised.

ALBANY, July 4 -- The Public Service Commission announced today that it would start hearings July 17 to examine Mayor Lindsay's charge that the Consolidated Edison Company has been overcharging its gas customers for five years.

PITTSBURGH, July 4 -- Several thousand Boy Scouts, hundreds of volunteers and representatives of the Federal, state and city governments dedicated today the new Scout Center and Flag Plaza on the perimeter of Pittsburgh's Golden Triangle.

The New York Mets and the Pittsburgh Pirates had a safe and sane Fourth at Shea Stadium yesterday. They played two games close to the vest, scored the same number of runs and wound up with one victory apiece.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 4 (UPI) -- George C. Wallace blamed "anarchists" led by college professors today for setting off a wild protest demonstration at a rally here last night.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 4 -- It will be Billie Jean King against Judy Tegart for the Wimbledon tennis crown tomorrow, but it is a miracle that Mrs. King, the two-time champion, is there at all.
Judging from the deserted streets yesterday, thousands of New Yorkers celebrated the Fourth of July by going out of town.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 4 -- Despite a day-long threat of rain and a hovering, damp chill, the Newport Jazz Festival opened its annual four-day series of concerts tonight before an audience of more than 7,500, the largest first-night attendance in the festival's history.
A 27-year-old mother of four and a male companion were found shot dead yesterday in a Queens house when the woman's 4-year-old son came upon the bodies lying on the kitchen floor.

The Maritime Administration said this week it had granted technical approval to an application by American Mail Line to install at its own expense a flume stabilization system aboard five 21,500-ton dry cargo ships now under construction at Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

CODY, Wyo., July 4 -- The Buffalo Bill Museum, a $2-million repository for the belongings of Col. William F. Cody, was dedicated here today. As part of the festivities, a 1,900-pound stuffed red bull buffalo was flown in by helicopter to be placed in the museum.
" WE all know minis are dead," asserted June Weir, the fashion editor, and Paul Hanenberg, the managing editor, of Women's Wear Daily.
VIENNA, July 4 -- The first agreement signed by the Soviet Union to deliver natural gas to a western nation has been announced here.
CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- Out The Window and Fort Marcy each won a division of the $40,000 added Stars and Stripes Handicap before a crowd of 30,388 at Arlington Park today.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission issued a warning today against fraudulent real estate financing schemes through which, it said, prominent companies and experienced real estate developers had been bilked, as well as ordinary property owners.

The British have agreed to enter a proposed series of eliminations to determine a challenger for the America's Cup race off Newport, R. I., in 1970, it was announced today by Percy B. Chubb 2d, the commodore of the defending New York Yacht Club.

Theodore Mann, watching his Circle in the Square Theater fill up these nights for his recently opened revival of Eugene O'Neill's "A Moon for the Misbegotten," which he also directed, cannot help reflecting on the tides of fame, not his own, but O'Neill's.

DALLAS, July 4 -- The refusal of a tavern to serve an African diplomat yesterday because he was black has stirred wide indignation among the 7,000 delegates to the National Education Association's convention here and has led the organization to demand an apology from city officials.

PARIS, July 5 -- A rally here tonight of about 400 non-Communist Vietnamese students living in Europe charged tonight that both the Communist bloc and the Western world were violating Vietnamese sovereignty by intervening in the war.

PATERSON, N. J., July 5 -Mayor Lawrence F. Kramer ordered taverns in a Puerto Rican section here closed tonight, and the police partially barricaded the area before turning out to combat a fifth straight night of disorders.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- A deep-submergence module, or chamber, patented this week for the General Electric Company, is a glass sphere held together by a frame of titanium alloy. One or a chain of the spheres could be used for laboratory or living quarters on the ocean floor and could be anchored or made mobile.

The theft of $750,000 in Treasury Department bills from the brokerage firm of Merrill, Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith was disclosed yesterday with the indictment of two ex-convicts described by the Government as members of the Mafia.
Angel Angelof, the Central Park killer, slept with a knife under his pillow.

Democratic State Chairman John J. Burns said yesterday that he was looking into the possibility of reconvening the State Committee to elect a new slate of delegates-at-large to the party's national convention.

A teamster union local on strike here since May 3 against the United Parcel Service was ordered yesterday by its inernational union to let the local members vote on the company's latest contract offer. The vote is to take place Tuesday.

After imposing import quotas and special export subsidies to defend the franc, the French Government is attacking domestic inflation by ordering a steep rise in the central bank's discount rate and by levying higher taxes. Resolute action was surely required after the damage done by the paralyzing wave of strikes and by the expensive concessions needed in order to resume production.
JACKSON, Miss., July 5 -- A shrewd engaging man quietly left the state government this week after eight tempestuous years in which he helped put velvet gloves on Mississippi's two-fisted racism.

ECONOMY may drive people to decorate their apartments with furnishings they beg, borrow or salvage, but, in the cases of four tenants with disparate tastes, eccentricity has prolonged the practice after the need for thrift has passed.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (AP) -- Wilt Chamberlain, the Philadelphia 76ers' record-cracking giant, has been traded to the Los Angeles Lakers for three players -- Darrall Imhoff, Archie Clark and Jerry Chambers -- and an undisclosed amount of cash, The Associated Press learned today.
The nomination of Vice President Humphrey for President would spell disaster for the Democratic party and the democratic process, Paul O'Dwyer said yesterday.
The New York Yankees defeated the Baltimore Orioles for the first time in 11 months last night, on the pitching, hitting and even sprinting of Prof. Fritz Peterson.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- Several of the nation's biggest cities have gun control laws, and more cities and towns are considering them, but advocates of local laws point out that they cannot be fully effective without interstate sales restrictions.

The players of the National Football League have been instructed not to report to their training camps until labor negotiations between the owners and the Players Association have been concluded. This instruction was telegraphed to the players by John Gordy, a Detroit Lions guard who is president of the association.

GREENWOOD, Miss., July 5 (AP) -- A Chancery Court judge has issued a sweeping injunction virtually forbidding the Greenwood Movement to continue its efforts to induce citizens to join a boycott of white merchants.
MOST women keep their jewelry in dresser drawers, on closet shelves, in little chests or in wall safes. Mrs. Adam Auerbach of Jackson Heights is different. She pins hers to the bedroom wall.

DALLAS, July 5 -- City leaders, including a representative of Mayor Erik Johnsson, apologized at the National Education Association convention today for the refusal of a tavern to serve an African diplomat and several other Negroes attending the five-day session.

The Sheepshead Bay Handicap on the turf will be the star attraction at Aqueduct today. With the surge of interest in thoroughbred activity generated by the dramatic performance of Dr. Fager in winning the Suburban on Independence Day, a crowd of 55,000 is expected to attend the program.

Long before the Surgeon General's advisory committee in 1964 said that there was a definite cause-and-effect link between heavy smoking and lung diseases, people would jokingly refer to cigarettes as "coffin nails." The latest report by the Public Health Service in Washington makes that horrible little phrase all too real -- and emphasizes once again the official Government position on the indisputable hazard to health of cigarette smoking.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Federal insurance for a $500,000 mortgage to restore and bring back to the United States the last American-built square-rigged sailing ship has been requested by the National Maritime Historical Society, it was made known yesterday by the Maritime Administration.
Sarah Vaughan and Herbie Mann sold out the first of twin concerts last night at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park. They gave the 5,500 listeners a worthwhile evening.

READING, Pa., Juy 5 -- Mrs. Susie Maxwell Berning increased her lead to four strokes in the women's United States Open golf championship today as par rounds became conspicuous by their absence. With a 73, two over regulation figures, Mrs. Berning brought her 36-hole aggregate to 142 over the Moselem Springs Golf Club course.

The Shipbuilders Council of America is fighting the plan of a New Orleans builder to have his yard declared a foreign-trade subzone so that he can use duty-free foreign steel at some saving over domestic production.

I would like to second Dr. Richard Wunder's recent plea in your columns for support in saving the Hudson County Courthouse in Jersey City. As a former curator of the Newark Museum, I have been familiar with the courthouse, and its valuable and beautiful series of murals by some of America's leading artists.
LONDON, July 5 -- "We're getting used to living with the bomb."
PENZANCE, England, July 5 (AP) -- The British National Union of Railwaymen voted today to call off a 12-day slowdown.

SANTA CLARA, Calif., July 5 (AP) -- Sue Pederson tied a world record, but lost the race, then 25 minutes later set another world record tonight in her leg of a relay race in the Santa Clara invitation international swim meet.
UPPSALA, Sweden, July 5 -- Several years ago at an ecumenical meeting, a woman delegate reported to a fellow church leader that water lilies had appeared in a nearby swimming pool.

NIAGARA - ON-THE-LAKE, Ontario, July 5 -- The atmosphere is that of an amateur production of "The Pirates of Penzance" at the old town hall some 40 years ago. The cast dresses behind curtains strung on a clothesline; the audience sits on bridge chairs fitted out with blue pillows; you can't enter the auditorium once the curtain is up, because the floor squeaks.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Officials confirmed today that the United States and West German Governments have been discussing for some time Bonn's request for an American defense guarantee in the event of nuclear war.

BONN, July 5 -- Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger of West Germany indicated today that his Government would seek a United States guarantee against nuclear aggression by the Soviet Union before accepting the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 5 -- Vice President Humphrey urged today that every Democrat be given a chance to shape the party's 1968 platform.

MOSCOW, July 5 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser held intensive, all-day discussions today with the Soviet leaders on Cairo's demands for prompt action to bring about an Israeli withdrawal from Arab territories.

A large metal sign being removed from Harry and Ben's Delicatessen on West 47th Street slipped and shattered a window yesterday, sending a shower of glass to the sidewalk outside the Gaiety West, its archcompetitor across the street.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 5 -- A rent strike by Negro tenants in public housing against the Municipal Housing Authority here has entered its third month amid growing impatience and anger on both sides.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 5 (AP) -- Fifteen persons were injured and five youths held by the police when three firebombings, window-breaking and other vandalism broke out on the city's South Side following a fireworks display last night.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 5 -- President Johnson met at his Texas ranch today with the President of Bolivia and prepared for a conference tomorrow in Salvador with the Presidents of five Central American republics.

KATONAH, N. Y., July 5 -- At the Caramoor Festival tonight two of the great male ballet dancers of our time, Anton Dolin and Edward Villella, decided to emerge from the dancer's traditional mask of silence. Mr. Villella made his acting debut as the soldier Joseph in Stravinsky's "L'Histoire du Soldat" and Mr. Dolin as the fastidious and pernicious devil.

GRAND BLANC, Mich., July 5 (AP) -- Taking advantage of an overnight rain, the United States Open champion, Lee Trevino, went for the pins today to post a four-under-par 68 and take the second-round lead in the $125,000 Buick open over the 7,001-yard, par-72 Warwick Hills course.
PORTSMOUTH, England, July 5 -- It was announced at midday today that Alec Rose, who came home yesterday from a solo voyage around the world in a yawl, had been knighted.

ATLANTA, July 5 (AP) -- A biography of Gov. Lester G. Maddox, just published, says he ordered State Troopers during the funeral march for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to "shoot them down and stack them up" if marchers attempted to enter Georgia's Capitol.
The cancellation of six trains was announced by the Long Island Rail Road yesterday after an unusually large number of locomotive engineers reported sick as the evening shift approached.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The Federal Communications Commission warned television and radio station owners today that they faced possible loss of their licenses if they discriminated against Negroes in their employment policies.
The Federal Reserve took a first, tentative step yesterday toward easing the pressure that it has been applying on the nation's credit markets for the last six months or so.

TORONTO, July 5 (AP) -- A $10-million damage suit initiated four years ago on behalf of eight babies whose mothers took thalidomide before their birth has been settled out of court, it was reported today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 27 -- Ten years ago fewer than 1,000 American servicemen were stationed in Vietnam, and their presence was scarcely noticed.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 5 -- Dewan and Poleax, both stakes winners this season, head a field of nine 3-year-old colts in the 28th and richest running of the Hollywood Derby tomorrow at Hollywood Park. The race will have a purse of $127,000.

SYDNEY, Australia, Saturday, July 6 (Reuters) -- Wally Mellish, a psychopothic gunman, today walked around inside a besieged suburban cottage here with the infant son of his teen-aged bride of four days in his arms and a revolver in his belt.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 5 -- Allied ground forces found three major caches of enemy munitions today as they swept the provinces around Saigon to minimize the possibility of another attack on the city.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 5 -- Until today, the third race on tomorrow night's harness racing program at Roosevelt Raceway shaped up as a run-of-the-mill, overnight handicap one-mile trot for a gross purse of $7,000.
A State Supreme Court Justice rejected yesterday the main legal arguments of the General Motors Corporation in defense of a $26-million invasion of privacy suit filed against it by Ralph Nader.

The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, New York's third largest bank, yesterday reported record net operating earnings and an increase in its rate of return on stockholders' equity but lower profit margins.

CHICKEN, tuna and shrimp salads are good honest fare for family meals and lunch boxes, but there are times when something a little more imaginative is called for. The main dish salads given here are suggested for just such occasions.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., July 5 -- "The fringe benefits for the star performers are getting more and more phenomenal," Phil Greenwald, the Concord Hotel's entertainment director, said. "If you consider what they charge and what extras I give them, it can wind up costing us over $10,000 for one performance."
LAGOS, Nigeria, July 5 -- The Government warned today against outside efforts to airlift relief supplies directly to Biafrans.

The June 18 news article concerning the jet airport to be built in northern Westchester County failed to list several important factors that have a bearing on the desirability of such a facility in this location.

The Hope Presbyterian Church in Creve Coeur, Mo., has no fixed furnishings or decorations. Instead, brightly colored movable banners hang from hooks in the ceiling, and the sanctuary can easily be converted into a gymnasium or dance hall.
A 22-year-old Bronx school-teacher went into Criminal Court yesterday to fight a summons she received last month for taking a picture of a friend on a subway platform. She won her case.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 -- Tom Seaver set a club record for consecutive scoreless innings pitched tonight, but that was the extent of his success as he and his New York Mets lost to the Philadelphia Phillies, 3-1, at Connie Mack Stadium.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 -- George Breen barked a brief, but futile, command through the giggles of a group of girls at Gimbel Pool. Small wonder. It was 7 A.M., and only maintenance men and swimmers were stirring in the city.

PEWTER is so strongly connected with the country look that the demand for it increases every summer when collectors take to the road to uncover treasures in simplified design characteristic of rural taste.

LINCOLN CENTER'S Festival '68 introduced a welcome group of musical visitors to New York last night: The English Chamber Orchestra played the first of four concerts in Philharmonic Hall. The 20 - year - old ensemble, which is based in London, is being led here by 25-year-old Daniel Barenboim, who made his New York conducting debut recently with the London Symphony Orchestra.
A 26-year-old chemist who allegedly fled to Canada to avoid the draft attempted to slash his wrist yesterday while pleading to charges in Federal Court.
THE Italian world champions bid more optimistic game contracts than any of their opponents, and make the majority of them for a net profit.
LOS ANGELES, July 5 -- A national "Draft Lindsay for President" campaign was announced here today, assertedly without the knowledge of Mayor Lindsay himself.
Prices on the London stock market closed out the week yesterday not far below peak levels reached in the previous day's trading.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 5 -- Rod Laver has taken the first open Wimbledon tennis championship. The 29-year-old Australian redhead dazzled Tony Roche of Australia with his wristy volleys and topspin backhands to win by 6-3, 6-4, 6-2 in exactly an hour before Princess Marina and a sunspattered, sellout center-court crowd, some of whom had queued for 24 hours.

LONDON, July 5 -- The British have a way with classic revivals, which is just as well because traditionally the British theater is full of them. The British have learned that a good old play is better than a bad new play, and on the whole the London theater is the better for it.
The City University plans to establish a four-year liberal arts college at Fifth Avenue and 110th Street in Harlem.

Two official representatives of the Nigerian Government purchased yesterday a two-page advertisement in The New York Times to counter recent articles appearing in The Times that they said had depicted their Government in a bad light.

With the invention of the atom bomb, the demand was made more urgent than ever that scientists and inventors examine the social effects of their innovations before loosing them on the world. Actually scientists and inventors always had very clear ideas of what their creations were intended to achieve.
CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- A guard was dismissed today for alleged laxity after five inmates of the Cook County Jail made an unsuccessful effort to break out.
BARCELONA, Spain, July 2 -As his little car groaned up the steep hill to Montjuich Castle, Mr. Fals, a master mechanic, insisted resolutely:
ROME, July 5 -- Premier Giovanni Leone asked the Italian Parliament today to give his "summer Government" a vote of confidence.

UPPSALA, Sweden, July 5 -- Pope Paul VI sent greetings to 720 Protestant and Orthodox church leaders today indicating his desire to "continue and extend the collaboration that already exists between the World Council of Churches and the Catholic Church."
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren rejected today the assertion that President Johnson was a "lame duck" President who should not appoint new members to the Supreme Court.

GENEVA, July 5 -- The international trading community completed today its tactical maneuvering to prevent a tariff war over France's protectionist trade measures by establishing a 22-member watchdog committee.

JERUSALEM, July 5 -- Israeli officials indicated today that they would never again accept the presence of United Nations observers in the Sinai Peninsula as a substitute for a peace treaty negotiated with the United Arab Republic.
OTTAWA, July 5 -- Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau announced tonight the make-up of his new Liberal Government. The Cabinet of 29 members will be the largest in Canadian history.
Activity in commodities futures remained almost at a standstill yesterday as most of the major exchanges remained closed.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI) -- A Pentagon official charged today that Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover had been "badly misinformed" in contending that the Defense Department was blocking development of a new nuclear attack submarine because it wanted "cheaper, not better, military weapons."
Four of the fastest hands in jazz are at the Village Gate this week providing an unusually succinct summary of more than 40 years in the development of the jazz piano.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 5 -- Roy Wilkins, a moderate among civil rights leaders, joined with leaders of the militant Congress of Racial Equality today in urging cooperative efforts to benefit Negroes. Mr. Wilkins called such unity "a necessity if black people are going to successfully attack the problems that beset them."
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Tourists still go daily to Suite 3327 of the New Senate Office Building ("Mr. Kennedy, New York, Walk In") to seek passes for admission to the Senate Visitors Gallery.
Captain Marvel -- tall, dark-haired, a flash of lightning emblazoned on his chest -- leaps over a parapet in the moonlight, hs cape billowing behind him.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 4 -- Two truckloads of soldiers and a troop of mounted policemen swiftly surrounded a Government bank building in the center of town one day recently and hauled out several dozen employes.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 5 -- Sonny Liston, the former world heavyweight champion, scaled 219 pounds, compared with 215 for Henry Clark, at the weigh-in today prior to their 10-round bout tomorrow at the Cow Palace.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Diplomatic analysts are detecting signs that Burma and Communist China are groping toward restoration of their once cordial relations, shattered a year ago by a wave of anti-Chinese violence in Rangoon.
The generally strong tempo of retail business here yesterday, spurred by annual Fourth of July clearances, helped to soften the frowns that merchants have been wearing because of a summer sales lull.
PASSAIC, N. J., July 5 -- Cerise, a six-year-old Negro child, clung to her counselor, a 20-year-old white girl who is a senior at the University of Michigan.

The Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, Inc., the nation's leading food chain with 4730 stores, reported yesterday a 30.6 per cent decline in earnings on a one per cent sales dip in the first fiscal quarter ended May 25.

In his June 25 letter Mounir R. Sa'Adah decries the sale of sophisticated armaments to Saudi Arabia, Libya and Iran, stating that these countries need a greater priority of national spending to alleviate the misery of their populations.

On June 22, 1967, the City Council repealed the Multiple Dwelling Code, the municipal ordinance establishing minimum standards for housing maintenance, and enacted the first part of the Housing Maintenance Code drafted by the Department of Buildings in conjunction with the Legislative Research Drafting Fund of Columbia University.

Eleven Brooklyn College students among a group who were dismissed last May for seizing the college registrar's office demanded reinstatement yesterday on the ground that their constitutional rights had been violated.

NEWBERRY, Mass., July 5 -- Arriba, who has performed for three different owners so far this year, took the lead for the open jumper championship today at the opening session of the Ould Newberry Horse Show.

KONA, Hawaii -- The candidate did not act much like a 60-year-old. For 10 days, in the dehydrating midsummer heat of a dozen states, he talked, shook hands, signed autographs and somehow brought himself to tolerate the absurdities of Presidential politics in the United States.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The wings of an F-111-A broke off during a ground test for structural strength two months before the controversial warplane was sent to Vietnam, it was disclosed today.

TOKYO, July 6 -- The detention of an American-chartered airliner and its military passengers on a Soviet-held island north of Japan this week has focused the attention of the Japanese on their claim to the same island and several others under Soviet occupation.
JERSEY CITY, July 6 -- The car stolen from Deputy Attorney-General John Lombardi after a savage beating by eight assailants Wednesday was recovered by the police today.

ROBERT TRENT JONES has built golf courses on every continent except Australia and Antarctica and likes to say that the sun never sets on Robert Trent Jones courses. ("Are you sure," he asks querulously, "that Antarctica is a continent?") But the important thing about Robert Trent Jones is that he is, at bottom, more golfer than golf architect, and if there is one place his enormous success is rooted it's right there.
PATERSON, N. J., July 6 -- Relative quiet prevailed tonight in the predominantly Puerto Rican communities here following five nights of disorders.

GRAND BLANC, Mich., July 6 (UPI) -- Rookie Rod Horn mastered the Warwick Hills golf course with a five-under-par 67 today to move into a tie with Lee Trevino, the United States Open champion, after the third round of the $125,000 Buick open.

This will be especially urgent if the Vietnam war has been ended by negotiation in the interim.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- A gun-control bill providing for states to register and license guns under Federal guidelines will be introduced Monday by Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat-Liberal of Queens.

WILMINGTON, Ohio, July 6 -- The training camp of the Cincinnati Bengals, pro football's newest team, opened here today and Paul Brown swung back into action. "I feel I've never been away." said the 59-year-old coach, general manager and absolute monarch of this enterprise.

CAPETOWN, July 6 -- The condition of Dr. Philip Blaiberg, the world's longest surviving heart transplant patient, deteriorated today, and Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard's surgical team at Groote Schuur Hospital was reported considering giving him a third heart.

SAN FRANCISCO. IN the long parade of fish and flatworms, rats, cats and mice that have given their all for science, it is just possible that Rat No. 895 -- with the help of a bearded psychologist named David Krech -- will hold a special significance for the education of our children's children.

PITTSBURGH, July 6 -- The chairman of the Pittsburgh branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has dismissed as "superficial" a city-sponsored report on racial disorders that swept Negro districts here from April 5 to April 12.
Holland-America Line's no-tipping policy, in effect for less than three months, was described last week as providing ship passengers with a more pleasant experience aboard ship.

THE new General Post Office announced for New York last week will be just about as big as the Pan Am Building laid on end -- if anyone would want to do it. Most New Yorkers have a hard enough time accepting it standing up.

The revolver used by Angel Angelof in Wednesday's gun battle in Central Park has been traced to two New Jersey policemen who reportedly sold it illegally, sources close to the investigation said yesterday.

WASHINGTON -- The American capital approached the historic missile talks with the Soviet Union in a mixed mood last week. On the one hand there was political pressure in an election year to put the most optimistic interpretation on Moscow's willingness to discuss a mutual limitation of strategic capabilities. On the other hand there was ingrained skepticism that any talks with the Russians could lead to a genuine detente.

GLORIOSAS, or glory-lilies, are tender African members of the lily family, entirely distinct from the recently introduced gloriosa daisies that are large forms of our native rudbeckia or coneflower. The species usually grown in gardens are Gloriosa superba and G. rothschildiana, natives of Central Africa, northern Rhodesia and the Transvaal. Except in the Deep South, where they are hardy, gloriosas are grown as summer bulbs in the garden, or indoors.

NEW HAVEN, July 7 -- Thomas G. Bergin, a renowned Dante scholar and a wry poet in his own right, has resigned as master of Yale University's Timothy Dwight College after 15 years in the post. He will continue teaching at Yale as Steriing Professor of Romance Languages.

GENEVA, July 7 -- Central bankers of the major Western countries made further progress today on a plan to bolster the international monetary system by providing massive long-term aid for Britain's pound.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Chronically unemployed people in northeastern New Jersey will be trained for clerical jobs in Wall Street under a joint industry-government program announced today.
Government officials yesterday criticized and sought to counteract sudden cancellations of insurance on property in cities that have suffered riots.

LONDON -- What is it that London authors have against London critics? John Osborne has always been uptight and scurrilous about them and is running true to form in his latest play. In the directing field, Tony Richardson has recently led a charge of an extremely light brigade against them, and Bill Gaskell, director of the Royal Court, has declared that they are not his friends.
A moonlight cruise up the Hudson, with passengers dancing to Latin rhythms, was transformed abruptly into an ugly riot soon after midnight yesterday.

But some cautious players make a safety play by taking their vacations at bridge tournaments or at resorts where bridge activities are available.
Four Senators and five Representatives constitute a "key issues committee" set up yesterday by Richard M. Nixon.

The Communist party, U. S. A,. yesterday nominated a 38-year-old Negro woman, Mrs. Charlene Mitchell, as its first candidate for President since 1940.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Congress is quietly laying the basis for tightened restrictions on profiteering from defense contracts.
WARSAW, July 7 -- The Central Committee of the Polish Communist party will meet tomorrow for the first time since the still-unresolved party crisis began four months ago.

Paul O'Dwyer, the Democratic Senate candidate, and City Council President Frank D. O'Connor yesterday in effect joined in a call for greater minority representation on the state delegation to the Democratic National Convention.

Preaching in a Harlem church that once barred black people, the first Negro pastor in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York called on a nearly all-black congregation yesterday to "seek reconciliation with your brother."
The second containership in a six-vessel fleet that will place United States Lines ahead of the field will be delivered at Chester, Pa., today and will sail immediately to load cargo for Europe.
With slow but deliberate speed, Geyer, Oswald, Inc., and Rumrill-Hoyt are moving toward a merger that would push the new shop into the top 25 American agencies. That's nice company -- for a company.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Interior Department said today it would cost about $48-billion to separate storm and sanitary sewers now combined that serve some 36 million -- people and even that would not solve the pollution problem.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 7 -- Allied patrols on the Saigon River and its tributaries have been intensified as part of the continuing effort to prevent enemy infiltration into the South Vietnamese capital, a United States Navy spokesman disclosed tonight.
TABLERIE is an inspired new shop at 1033 Third Avenue (near 61st Street) devoted to enlivening the table. Few hostesses will be able to walk out without succumbing to at least a small temptation.

The Lindsay administration will meet with the leadership of the City Council on Wednesday to present its plans for the use of $8-million in job-training and employment funds.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The registration provisions of the National Firearms Act were applied today to a 45-caliber carbine that can be fired like a machine gun.

GRAND BLANC, Mich., July 7 (AP) -- Tom Weiskopf, the second leading money-winner on the professional tour, shot a three-under-par 69 for a total of 280 to win the $125,000 Buick open golf tournament today by one stroke.
HOUSTON, July 8 -- The American League All-Star team, most of whose players have never been exposed to the Astrodome, worked out there today. The National League didn't bother.

DETROIT, July 8 -- A Detroit judge granted today a six-month postponement in the murder trial of a Detroit policeman charged with the slaying of a young Negro during the riots of last July. The judge cited what he termed prejudicial publicity surrounding the publication of John Hersey's new book, "The Algiers Motel Incident," as the reason for the postponement.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 8 -- Dr. Robert J. Glaser, vice president for medical affairs of Stanford University, was named acting president of the institution today. He is also dean of the university's School of Medicine.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Federal Trade Commission reported today that low-income buyers in the District of Columbia were "frequently confused and deceived" by merchants through deceptive practices that it thought were typical of other big cities.

CINCINNATUS, N. Y. -- Two little boys from Brooklyn stood in the straw, manure and mud of the barnyard and looked at a gray, four-legged animal with a long head and pointed ears and up at a high brown building with a wide entrance.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Five Democratic House members from New York prodded Governor Rockefeller today to act quickly in appointing a successor to the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

The General Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday in Akron, Ohio, that it had raised the prices of its passenger, truck and off-the-road tires and tubes by 2 1/2 to 5 per cent, effective immediately.

The State Commissioner of Education yesterday called for the establishment of a "new balance of power in the classroom -- one in which the arts are fundamental in the program of every fully educated student."
PARIS, July 8 -- A paramilitary police operation at dawn today captured the red flag flying over the University of Paris Medical School and took 17 hand-clapping prisoners.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 8 -- United States marines fought two sharp battles on the edge of the demilitarized zone yesterday while armed helicopters poured rockets and machine-gun fire into a fleet of sampans farther south.

Miles Laboratories, Inc., makers of consumer and professional medical products and chemicals at Elkhart, Ind., reached an agreement in principle yesterday to purchase the S.O.S. business of the General Foods Corporation for $56-million in cash.
An inquiry into what is believed to be a multi-million-dollar-a-year business, executive consulting services, was opened yesterday by Acting Licenses Commissioner Joseph L. Forstadt.
Prices rose markedly to a record in active trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.
At least 13 licensed taxicabs were halted yesterday by bands of men who ordered the drivers from their cabs, overturned the vehicles and in some cases burned them.
Congress was asked by the Department of Transportation yesterday to enact laws that would simplify hiring procedures for United States seamen.

Rosalyn Tureck thinks it's all right to play the subject of the B-flat fugue from Book One of Bach's "The Well-Tempered Clavier" this way: dah, dah, dah, dit, dah, daah. But she rather prefers it this way: dah, dah, dah, dit, dit, daaaah.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 8 -- Artifacts unearthed in a Utah cave challenge a long-held "climatic theory" favored by many archeologists who believe human life disappeared from much of the American West during an extended post-glacial drought.

CAPETOWN, July 8 (AP) -- Dr. Philip Blaiberg, 59 years old, who has lived longer than any other man with a transplanted heart, showed continued improvement today after a bad setback and his surgeon said he was satisfied with his condition.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 9 -- Japanese voters have endorsed the conservative, pro-American Liberal-Democratic party, headed by Premier Eisaku Sato, in the election Sunday to the House of Councilors, or Senate.

If the Statue of Liberty somehow came to life, turned her head and looked down on the bizarre goings-on yesterday morning on Liberty Island, she probably would have dropped the torch and the tablet and rubbed her eyes in disbelief.

A 250-copy edition of a book of Andrew Wyeth's paintings with a text by Richard Meryman is being prepared for sale at $1,500 to $2,000 apiece. The color work for this edition has served as a guide for printing of 50,000 copies of the book to be sold to the public at $55 each.

LONDON -- Probably the most encouraging single aspect of the London theater is the evidence it offers that an Establishment theater does not have to be stuffy to be established. Britain's two most distinguished theatrical institutions, the National Theater and the Royal Shakespeare Company, are both, on occasion, surprisingly irreverent, and always open to adventure and experiment.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 8 -- Californians viewed with increasing seriousness today a recall movement against Gov. Ronald Reagan.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Bache Co., Inc., conceded today that the bulk of the mutual fund shares it sells are those of companies that give it the most commissions to buy and sell stocks for their investment portfolios.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The Justice Department asked Federal judges today to order two of the nation's largest paper producers to divest themselves of wholesale distributors they have acquired since the mid-1950s.

A commuter boat service between the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn and the foot of Wall Street was begun yesterday, with all 150 passengers riding free.

The American Heritage Publishing Company, which started 14 years ago with a quality hard-cover magazine and developed a $64,000 investment into a $64-million corporation, announced plans yesterday to produce and distribute its own books.

ALBERTA, Ala. -- Eugene Witherspoon sat on the sagging porch of the house where he was born 61 years ago -- the grandson of a slave. WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Fear that he might not live through another term in office influenced President Johnson in his decision not to seek re-election, says Drew Pearson, syndicated columnist.

Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, was voted a salary increase to $70,000 a year from $45,000 by the agency's board at a May 27 meeting, it was learned yesterday.

HOUSTON, July 8 -- In a sort of glorification of artificiality, baseball's 39th midsummer All-Star Game will take place tomorrow night in the Astrodome, the world's largest television studio and only indoor ballpark.
Rank and file Democrats and the followers of Robert F. Kennedy prefer Vice President Humphrey to Senator Eugene J. McCarthy as the party's Presidential nominee, according to the Louis Harris poll.
BONN, July 8 -- Representatives of the six Governments of the Western European Union concluded today that prospects for a detente with the Soviet Union were slim.

Pedestrians in the Times Square area dove for cover last night as four detectives fired at a mugging suspect who dodged in and out of traffic on 42d Street. Ten shots were fired before the suspect was caught, uninjured, in a parking lot on Eighth Avenue and 42d Street about 9:30 P.M.
George Archinal, Republican county leader of Queens since January, 1965, gave up his leadership last night in an attempt to achieve party harmony for the fall election.

HOUSTON, July 8 -- No one will have to concern himself with the weather during the All-Star Game at the Astrodome tomorrow night. The lighting system will be bright and even; the temperature will be 72 degrees and the wind velocity will be a gentle one mile an hour. Those All-Stars who survived last year's horror will welcome the change.
JERUSALEM, July 8 -- An Israeli official said tonight that Isareli withdrawal from the east bank of the Suez Canal could be effected only as part of a peace treaty with the United Arab Republic.
MOSCOW, July 8 (AP) -- A decade after a Moscow-New York airline service was first envisaged in Soviet-American talks, Pan American World Airways and Aeroflot agreed today to begin flying next week.
BOSTON, July 8 (UPI) -- Scattered incidents of stone-throwing and window-breaking broke out in the South End tonight after a city-sponsored concert of rock music.

A workman at Boston's Logan International Airport injured his hand recently and, within minutes and without leaving the airport, was thoroughly examined by a distant doctor over a new two-way closed-circuit television system called "tele-diagnosis."

NOANK, Conn., July 8 -- Before long, some mature lobsters off Connecticut's shores will be carrying tiny radio transmitters on their horny backs.

CHICAGO, July 8 (UPI) -- Contract negotiations between the National Football League players and owners broke down again tonight when the players rejected an offer to increase pension contributions 25 per cent in 1968 and 50 per cent in 1969.

The spot rate on the British pound bounced up sharply on foreign exchange markets here yesterday in what dealers said was an "over-reaction" to the $2-billion Basel loan agreement for support of sterling.

The Roof at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel, sole survivor of all those gay dancing places where New Yorkers reveled in sky breezes before air conditioning came in, opened last night for its 41st season. It seemed very new because it deliberately went back to the past.

Without any threats of strike throughout several weeks of quiet negotiations, the American Football League Players Association and the league's club owners agreed yesterday on a two-year plan involving pensions, preseason payments and medical coverage.
