In a string of events that typically lead to the birth of a conglomerate, nine directors of a holding company with major interests in the shipbuilding field unseated yesterday most of the board members of a leading floor-coverings company.
BONN, July 10 -A high-ranking West German official said today that Bonn was seeking no additional guarantee of nuclear protection from the United States.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 10 (UPI) -- J.E.B. Stuart High School, from Falls Church, Va., stayed in contention while other United States entries faltered today in the opening competition of the Henley Royal Regatta.

Your July 7 editorial on the impact of the tax increase and spending cut almost rates an A-plus. Especially commendable is your description of inflation as a process set in motion by past events, in this instance the demand-pull inflation and overheating of 1965-66.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The House voted tonight to make a $5.3-billion down payment on a 10-year goal of six million new housing units for the nation's poor and moderate income families.

In politics as in television, this seems to be the season for reruns. The argument between Mayor Lindsay and Secretary of Labor Wirtz over the amount of Federal funds available to New York City this summer echoes the disagreement earlier in the year between Human Resources Administrator Ginsberg and Presidential Assistant Califano. It's still a case of the "Feds" fudging the figures.

In the confusion that followed a "goal" scored a split second after the final whistle, the New York Generals danced off the field at Yankee Stadium last night with a 1-0 victory over the Boston Beacons.

BALDWIN PLACE, N. Y., July 10 -- Construction workers watched a yellow and white helicopter swoop in at a work site in a heavily wooded area here yesterday, pick up a 950-pound slab of concrete and move it 3,000 yards in a fraction of the time it would have taken the workmen.
The Justice Department has assured the three major networks that members of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have been instructed not to impersonate newsmen during investigations.
The Taylor Instrument Companies "will vigorously resist the attempt by Ebasco Industries, Inc, to take over Taylor Instrument."

Longshoremen opened negotiations yesterday for a new contract with broad demands including a 65 per cent increase in hourly wage rates -- $6, instead of the current $3.62. In addition, they asked employers for a six-hour work day, two hours less than now.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Government has asked processors of whole pooled human blood plasma to stop shipping it in interstate commerce because of the risk of hepatitis.
The labor impasse in the National Football League began to involve players as well as pensions yesterday.
LONDON, July 10 (AP) -- The British Aircraft Corporation is studying a project for a new airliner with a seating capacity of around 200. A spokesman said the aircraft would be designated the BAC-311.
PRAGUE, July 10 -- Uncertainty rose tonight over a delay in the departure of two regiments of Soviet troops after Warsaw Pact maneuvers in Czechoslovakia last month.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The pre-convention plans of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy include his supporters' sponsorship of local public hearings to be attended by delegates to the Democratic National Convention.
Willie J. Smith, director of the city's Neighborhood Youth Corps and a leader of yesterday's massive youth demonstration for summer jobs at City Hall, was asked recently by a friend:
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Navy version of the F-111 swing-wing airplane sank today in the sea of controversy it was born upon six years ago.
WATER MILL, L. I., -- "For 28 years," Audre Fiber said, "I've designed kitchens for everybody else, and this is the first for my own pleasure."

Although magazine advertising revenue for the first six months was up 1 per cent over the first six months of 1967, the number of advertising pages was down 4 per cent, the Magazine Publishers Association reported yesterday.
TRENTON, July 10 (AP) -- The New Jersey Commuter Operating Agency announced today "a sweeping investigation" of the Penn Central commuter service to determine the causes of alleged inadequacies.

CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, July 10 -- The British amateur champion, Michael Bonallack, stole the spotlight from the vaunted American invaders today in the first round of the British Open golf championship.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 10 -- American infantrymen clashed with enemy troops 19 miles southwest of Saigon today and B-52's pounded the surrounding jungles in a continuing effort to find and break up concentrations near the capital.
A rookie patrolman shot in the head by another policeman Tuesday night in an argument over a stalled car in a Bronx traffic jam died yesterday.

Demanding a "denunciation" of a column written by Jimmy Breslin, 15 young members of the Communist party staged a three-hour "confrontation" yesterday at the editorial offices of The New York Post, 75 West Street.

MOSCOW, July 10 -- The Soviet leaders and President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic agreed during their talks here on "further joint steps" in the Arab conflict with Israel, a communique reported tonight after the President had departed for Yugoslavia.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- President Johnson indicated today that he might ask Congress to resume its deliberations after the national political conventions to complete action on unfinished legislation.

HOUSTON, July 10 -- Despite a strong objection from Arthur Allyn, owner of the Chicago White Sox, the American and National Leagues agreed today on a 162-game schedule with a two-division format in each league for 1969 only.

If Dr. David B. Truman expects "more violence on the campus this fall," as The Times quotes him as saying on July 3, is it not possible that he and his associates must be going about the business of restoring peace to the campus by the wrong methods?
Arrangements were announced yesterday for the Bank of France to receive $1.3-billion in short-term credits from five central banks and the Bank for International Settlements to support the franc.
Simply observing a fight can affect the chemistry of the brain, a husband-wife research team has determined from experiments on mice.

MOSCOW, July 10 -- The Soviet weekly Literaturnaya Gazeta denounced today as "counterrevolutionary" a recent manifesto of Czechoslovak liberal intellectuals demanding a mass purge of conservative Communist followers of the ousted regime of Antonin Novotny.
American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., lost a second attempt yesterday to stop the $148.5-million tender offer for 43 per cent of its stock being made by Howard R. Hughes.
Comment in the steel industry yesterday on the proposed Japanese restraints on exports of steel to the United States generally indicated dissatisfaction with the offer.

Combustion Engineering, Inc. said yesterday the antitrust allegations by the United Nuclear Corporation contained in a suit it filed last week against Combustion Engineering in the Federal District Court in Philadelphia are "totally without merit."

Fifty detectives sweeping through Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens early yesterday said they had smashed an organized crime ring preying on legitimate businessmen, both big and little. Fourteen persons were arrested and a large quantity of merchandise was seized.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Opponents of gun control legislation stalled the measures in the Senate Judiciary Committee today after riddling the gun registration provisions with exceptions.
An angry crowd of 1,500 youngsters protesting cutbacks in summer job programs erupted into violence outside City Hall yesterday.
PARIS, July 10 -- North Vietnam accused the United States Government today of "spreading rumors" of forward movement in the Vietnam talks here "to appease American public opinion."
A grand jury investigation of the attacks on licensed cabbies by the drivers of gypsy (unlicensed) cabs was demanded yesterday by the New York City Taxi Drivers Union Local 3036.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 10 -- It was only 9:30 in the morning and already the sun's rays were strong enough to force some railbirds to seek cover near the main track at Roosevelt Raceway. Those who sought and found shelter, though, made certain to pick points of vantage from which they could watch the trotters going through their training chores for Saturday night's $100,000 Roosevelt International.
Ninety airliners were crisscrossing the skies over the New York area at one time yesterday, but a new $7-million radar system at Kennedy Airport is set up to track and label them automatically.

Edward Jay Epstein, one of the first best-selling critics of the Warren commission's investigation of President Kennedy's assassination, has written a 25,000-word attack on District Attorney Jim Garrison's inquiry and charges of conspiracy in the President's death.
Tax-exempt securities prices advanced yesterday, but Government issues hesitated after their rise earlier in the week. The corporate bond market, like the New York Stock Exchange, was closed.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 10 -- Richard M. Nixon trails Vice President Humphrey by five percentage points in the latest trial heats run by the Gallup Poll, but Governor Rockefeller is even with Mr. Humphrey.

OF all the great ballet classics, "Giselle" seems to be both the frailest and, paradoxically, the most endurable. It has now survived for comfortably more than 120 years and yet still nearly every major, and many not so major, ballet company throughout the world includes it in its repertory.

" WHY be a square? Write a letter in-the-round," says Ron Chereskin, a young artist-designer whose new stationery is guaranteed to keep writers and readers going around in circles. The round papers come in bold colors and are decorated with splashy art nouveau or pop art designs.
THE SASSOONS. By Stanley Jackson. 304 pages. Illustrated. Dutton. $7.95.
CLEVELAND, July 10 -- Richard M. Nixon disclosed today that Gov. James A. Rhodes had urged him to seek Mayor Lindsay of New York as his running mate.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy proposed today that the United States delay deployment of the Sentinel missile defense system and also of the Poseidon and Minuteman 3 offensive missiles.

UNITED STATES players in world team championships suffer from one permanent handicap: Most team events in which they compete here are on a board-a-match basis, which is singularly poor practice for the international match point scoring that is standard in high-level competition.
TALENTED Curt Brasket of Minneapolis is one of many American chess masters who hardly ever win an important tournament but who are constant threats to the top runners.
LONDON, July 10 -- A bitter dispute divided the Conservative party today after a back-bench revolt on the issue of race.

Oliver J. Troster, partner in Troster, Singer Co., brought "five dusty bottles of rare Scotch" to his office yesterday. But by late afternoon, he not only lacked the time to mark his 49th year in Wall Street but also had passed up his usual lunch.
George Nicolau, former head of the city's Community Development Agency, has been appointed executive director of the newly formed Fund for the City of New York, it was announced yesterday.
Prices on the London stock market climbed to records yesterday, despite hesitation among investors awaiting a cue from the British trade figures for June, to be disclosed today.

Despite the unquestionable competence of his successor, Maurice Couve de Murville, the abrupt departure from office of Premier Georges Pompidou suggests some disturbing implications for the future of France.

At the end of a turbulent academic year, decentralization of the city's school system remains in the talking stage. Growing local controversy, aggravated by the Legislature's reluctance to authorize an effective action program, has obscured the basic issues. Unless those issues are understood, the continuing debate threatens to create deep, permanent divisions which would undermine the process of education and endanger the peace of the community.
During the current furor over gun control, both legislators and the public should differentiate between lethal modern weapons and their clumsy antique counterparts.

Show Off had a lot to be the extrovert about at Aqueduct yesterday. Competing in the $27,800 Astoria Stakes, for 2-year-old fillies, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's color-bearer contributed a decisive victory. She had four rivals in the 5 1/2-furlong sprint, and she beat her nearest pursuer, the Cragwood Stable's Tatallah, by a length and a-quarter.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Department of Defense reported today that the Army's re-enlistment rates dropped sharply last year, with a somewhat larger drop occuring among Negroes than among whites.

BALTIMORE, July 10 (AP) -- Hank Bauer was dismissed as manager of the Baltimore Orioles today, less than two years after he had directed them to the American League pennant and victory in the World Series.
HONG KONG, July 10 -- "Detection," Sherlock Holmes once declared, in The Sign of Four, "is or ought to be an exact science, and should be treated in the same cold and unemotional manner."
DETROIT, July 10 -- The automobile industry will "show substantial strength for the balance of the year," James M. Roche, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, predicted today.

BRUSSELS, July 10 -- A high rate of economic expansion in Europe that will reduce European exports to the United States and help the American balance of payments was forecast today by the executive authority of the Common Market.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The United States and the Soviet Union have warily worked their way toward the first real effort to limit the manufacture of weapons in the nuclear age. The key word of that age, therefore, has now become "parity."

MOSCOW, July 10 -- A leading Soviet physicist has issued a plea for full intellectual freedom, Soviet-United States cooperation and a worldwide rejection of "demagogic myths" in an urgent program to avert nuclear war and famine.
The city has been exploring the sale or lease of four municipal hospitals, with a total of 1,223 beds, to medical schools and voluntary, nonprofit hospitals.
Prices advanced sharply to another record on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

The Rev. Andrew J. Young, executive vice president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, accepted yesterday a check for $25,000 donated by members of District 65 of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union.

THOUSAND OAKS, Calif., July 11 -- Coach Tom Landry, speaking in his flat Texas drawl, said, "Let's go," and 66 cookies and free agents of the Dallas Cowboys lined up today to run 40-yard wind sprints against a timer's clock.
BALTIMORE, July 11 (AP) Earl Weaver, a minor league player and manager throughout his baseball career, was named today to replace Hank Bauer as manager of the Baltimore Orioles.
The Times's July 9 editorial "To Right a Wrong" is a study in selective indignation misapplied in part.

OTTAWA, July 11 -- Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has rebuffed pleas from striking unionists and Great Lakes shippers that the Government intervene to end the three-week-old St. Lawrence Seaway strike.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -Clark M. Clifford confirmed today that he would fly to South Vietnam Saturday to talk about preparations to meet an expected Vietcong offensive. It will be his first trip to Saigon as Secretary of Defense.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 11 -- Mrs. William H. Foulk Jr., representing the host Indian Harbor Yacht Club, won the last two races in the Syce Cup regatta today and retained the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound.
A new cargo jet service between New York and Australia is scheduled to begin today by Quantas, the Australian airline.

Angel Angelof, who arrived in the United States two years ago to seek, in the words of his visa application, "to build up my life in the free world," was buried yesterday in the city's potter's field.

THE American Broadcasting Company presented last night the second half of its program on "Bias and the Media." It was an all-white discussion with distinguished executives from broadcasting, print journalism and advertising conceding the sins of the past in denying the Negro his rightful place in the communications industries.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -Secretary of Defense Clark M. Clifford announced today that the Navy would proceed to build one of the two advanced types of nuclear submarine long urged by Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover to combat a growing Soviet submarine threat.
THEY were saying nice things on Wall Street yesterday about the Dow-Jones industrial average.
The drive to get a fourth party on the ballot in as many states as possible in November is slowly gaining momentum.

IN their nine years together, the Paper Bag Players have staged their elegantly homestitched children's shows in all kinds of places -- theaters, schools, settlement houses, concert halls. This year for the first time they go outdoors.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -Postmaster General W. Marvin Watson indicated today that he was prepared to issue orders for prompt cutbacks in postal services.
ROME, July 11 -- Premier Giovanni Leone won tonight by a narrow margin a vote of confidence in the Chamber of Deputies, giving a precarious lease on life to his minority Government.

A group of psychiatrists and psychologists, reporting to President Johnson's Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence, has reached the conclusion that things might settle down around here if the American people will only put less emphasis on "winning" and learn that it is "at least as important to be a good loser."

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- President Johnson issued an urgent appeal today to "all those bearing responsibility" to allow relief food supplies to reach people facing starvation in Biafra, the breakaway former Eastern Region of Nigeria.

Let no smokescreen of niceties hide the names of the Senators who are contemptuous of the American public that demands a gun-control law. Let the people who have written their legislators, have watched funerals of slain national leaders, have read of the parliamentary maneuvering in Congress to block an effective law, know what occurred behind the closed doors of the Senate Judiciary Committee this week.
IN the fierce competition among stores for fashion status, almost any ploy is likely to be used.
THE Brooklyn Championships, one of the oldest of all sectional tournaments, begins today at the New York Hilton for most of the contestants.

MOSCOW, July 11 -- Pravda, the Soviet Communist party newspaper, expressed alarm today over what it called "counterrevolutionary forces" in Czechoslovakia. It declared that their tactics were more "treacherous" than those of anti-Communist rebels in the 1956 Hungarian uprising.

The news article "An Outlet for Some Quilting Artisans" in your June 11 Women's Page has created much misunderstanding among your readers, as evidenced by Mrs. Irving Ostrow's June 20 letter, and also evidenced by direct response to us. The facts are as follows:

The Radio Corporation of America increased its second-quarter earnings by 13 per cent, despite the impact of the recently enacted 10 per cent income-tax surcharge, Robert W. Sarnoff, president and chief executive officer, reported yesterday.

BERLIN, July 11 -- Heinrich Albertz, the former Mayor of West Berlin, today advocated recognition of East Germany by West Germany and its Western allies to stabilize conditions in Central Europe and to strengthen the security of this city.
The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) sold yesterday $250-million of debentures that were priced to yield 6.50 per cent, the lowest rate for a top-quality industrial-bond issue since last winter.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the holiday week ended July 6 were both above the comparable 1967 week.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Senate hearings on the nomination of Associate Justice Abe Fortas as Chief Justice of the United States made little progress today as opponents pressed their efforts to block confirmation by trying to delay action until after President Johnson leaves office.

Daniel Barenboim, conducting the English Chamber Orchestra again at Philharmonic Hall last night, continued to show the qualities that stamp him as a strong-minded, thoroughly individual musician. He led with his feelings, but he was anything but irresponsible about them.

MILWAUKEE, July 11 -- One could have convinced oneself, easily enough, that some time machine had transported one 10 years or more into the past. Here was County Stadium in Milwaukee, with 40,575 spectators on hand, and there were the New York Yankees, down on the field, winning a ball game, 5-4.

Crafty Look finally made his way to the winner's circle yesterday, after more than a dozen failures this year. The 4-year-old campaigner owned by the Chance Hill Farm, won the feature event on the card at Aqueduct, the Queens County Chamber of Commerce purse, at 1 1-16 miles on the turf.
HOUSTON, July 11 -- The former board chairman of the Westec Corporation was found guilty tonight of falsifying financial statements of the concern and of committing mail fraud.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 11 -- Don Mortell and Bob Zender of Chicago led the first qualifying round with a 66 today in the 80-team John G. Anderson Memorial amateur golf tournament.

Jacob K. Javits and Paul O'Dwyer sat side by side at a disorganized news conference yesterday -- their first joint appearance since they were nominated to run against each other for Senator -- and spent their time agreeing with each other.

MADRID, July 11 -- One hundred and sixty-eight Spanish journalists -- more than one-third of the active press corps in Madrid -- have signed a letter to the Government protesting a growing series of penalties and restrictions on the press.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -Major elements of President Johnson's consumer protection program gained ground in Congress today as the Senate passed two bills and a Senate committee approved another.
" JIMMY RICO -- leave your socks on," Joel Grey said with mock sternness.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 11 -- Joseph Holmes Is going to ask some tough questions when he meets with four school superintendents in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn this summer.

James L. Buckley, the Conservative candidate for the United States Senate from New York, feels that President Johnson's "unilateral decision" to negotiate peace in Vietnam has produced "tremendous unease" among America's allies in Southeast Asia.

LONDON, July 11 (AP) -- Savage gales whipped the eastern coast today as southwestern and central England, deluged by the worst rainstorms in memory, were hit by swirling floods. Six persons were feared dead.

Willie J. Smith, the $18,000-a-year city employe who led Wednesday's angry job protest outside City Hall, was suspended from his post as director of the Neighborhood Youth Corps yesterday for engaging in "inappropriate and insubordinate activities."

" The Teacher Corps should be expanded into a major national program." So said the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders in its far-reaching report. But unless Congress moves quickly, the Teacher Corps will be neither national nor major nor a program worthy of the name.

LAGOS, Nigeria, July 11 -Organizational uncertainties are seriously disrupting the belated efforts to feed the victims of Nigeria's year-old civil war, but federal authorities have relaxed their opposition to proposed daylight airlift of relief supplies into Biafra.

PARIS -- One consistent, underlying strain of Gaullist leadership under the Fifth Republic is the effort to move France leftward and into the future out of a stodgy and old-fashioned tradition. This goal has been approached in three separate phases.
LONDON, July 11 -- Britain's trade figures at last took a turn for the better last month, reducing the persistent deficit.

When the American Ballet Theatre revives Leonide Massine's "Aleko" tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House for the first time in 13 years, it will be harking back to a ballet philosophy rarely expounded in the United States today.
PRAGUE, July 11 -- The Czechoslovak Government announced today that some of the Soviet troops that took part in Warsaw Pact maneuvers last month would begin a gradual departure Saturday.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) -- House and Senate negotiators reached agreement today on a three-year, $150-million program of grants to state and local agencies for control of juvenile delinquency.

A Cornell University medical scientist reported yesterday that he had found an apparently permanent stunting of brain growth in babies who had suffered from malnutrition before and shortly after birth.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 11 -- An Alibi Breakfast is meant to serve as a forum for pre-race excuses. Sometimes these sessions develop into eating and oratorical contests, with the emphasis heavy on eating but light on oratory.

Aside from Gunther Schuller, David Amram must be the most ubiquitous of contemporary musicians. He is a versatile "serious" composer who also writes for the theater outdoors (Shakespeare) and indoors (Arthur Miller, among other others) and for films.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) -- The House voted today to start producing a new style helicopter despite a key member's complaint that the contract for the multimillion dollar program was awarded under "very peculiar circumstances."

Two New Jersey men yesterday were charged with arson in connection with a threealarm fire that apparently began in a burlesque house in the basement of a four-story commercial building in the Times Square area.

ATHENS, July 11 -- Greece's army-backed regime today made public its proposed new constitution, a document that strips the King of virtually all his powers, increases the authority of the executive, and gives the army the task of "protection of the prevailing regime."
Thirty-two per cent more major crimes were reported to the New York Police Department in May', 1968, than in the same month of 1967, the de- :partment said yesterday.

LONDON, July 11 (AP) -- Joseph Conrad, the Polish-born seafaring author who was dismissed as second mate of a cargo ship in 1884, apparently used the episode as a basis for some of his scathing literary descriptions of sea captains, according to records released today.
PRINCETON, N. J., July 11 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy holds a slim lead over both Richard M. Nixon and Governor Rockefeller in the latest test election races by the Gallup Poll.

Operations of Owens-Illinois, Inc., in the second quarter this year resulted in a 35 per cent increase in earnings, to $14,013,000, or 91 cents a share, from $10,452,000, or 67 cents a share, in the 1967 period. Earnings for the half, however, declined from last year, the glass company reported yesterday.
DETROIT, July 11 -- The General Motors Corporation has given a not-too-subtle slap to a safety device of its rival, the Ford Motor Company.
CARNOUSTIS, Scotland, July 11 -- With the early leaders stumbling and falling today, Billy Casper added a course-record 68 to his first-round 72 for 140 and a four-stroke lead in the British Open.

In a ruling said to be the first of its kind in New York, a State Supreme Court Justice held yesterday that a woman who had been deceived into "marrying" a man already married might sue him for damages although she had lived with him before the fraudulent marriage ceremony.

PARIS, July 11 -- France's new National Assembly held its first session today with Premier-designate Maurice Couve de Murville sitting alone on the red - plush Government bank and outgoing Premier Georges Pompidou among the rank-and-file deputies.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 11 (AP) -- Army Capt. Margaret Thompson, a sharpshooter from Topeka, Kan, outgunned the Olympic gold medalist Lones Wigger of the Army today to become the first woman to win the small-bore rifle prone title in the United States international championships.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- Television networks will not get all the circuits they requested at the Democratic National Convention, a spokesman for the Illinois Bell Telephone Company said today, because a strike by electrical workers has made full installation impossible.
JERUSALEM, July 11 -- Diplomatic history probably will not record many grandmothers who served as Foreign Ministers, but then Golda Meir is no ordinary grandmother.
A gunman armed with a .30-caliber carbine stood outside a South Bronx tenement last night and sprayed the street with bullets, killing three men and wounding another.

AREA A -- Striped bass continue to provide good fishing in Barnegat Inlet for those who seek them with grass shrimp during the daylight hours. At night, somewhat larger stripers are being taken from the inlet by anglers working off the jetties with live eels.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 11 (AP) -- Cornell University, the defending champion, overpowered the Harvard lightweight crew at the Henley Royal Regatta today in the Thames Cup event.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 11 -- For the second straight year, Ron Howell, the big 29-year-old Floridian, found himself in prominent contention for the New Jersey open crown as the first half of the 72-hole competition was completed today.
CAIRO, July 8 -- The 2,000year-old temple of Dendur has begun its journey from the banks of the Nile to Fifth Avenue and will leave its motherland, presumably forever, in about two weeks.
HONG KONG, July 11 -- High officials of North Vietnam and Communist China have reaffirmed continued solidarity between their two countries.

Dr. James B. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner, yesterday urged "thorough study" of a proposal that localities' share of school financing be transferred to states, and that local authority to levy taxes for schools be eliminated.
The Federal Reserve System maintained its moderately tight money policy during the week ended Wednesday, banking figures published yesterday showed.
The Spirit of Communication, that winged fellow wrapped in yards of cable, was bounced some time ago from the cover of New York Telephone Company directories.
DETROIT, July 11 -- A paradox is the only way to describe the present condition of the Ford Motor Company.
With a shrug of the shoulder and a straight face, Geoffrey Sidebottom looked off into space yesterday and said, "Pele? He's got two legs. Just like everybody else."

TONY KUBEK has moved gracefully from the role of an active ballplayer to a commentator on the baseball scene. The threat of a permanent back disability abruptly terminated his career as Yankee shortstop much too soon. Now he follows the sport from a broadcast booth where his observations have assumed a singular pertinence.
PARIS, July 11 -- French monetary reserves were dropping at a record rate when foreign central bankers decided on massive mutual support measures last weekend.

HANOI, North Vietnam, July 11 (Agence France-Presse) -A "Vietnamese committee of solidarity with the American people" has been set up here "to strengthen the alreadyexisting friendly relations between the two peoples," it was announced today.
UPPSALA, Sweden, July 11 -- The World Council of Churches today admitted nine Roman Catholic theologians to membership in its principal theological body, the Commission on Faith and Order.

COLLEGEVILLE, Minn., July 11 (UPI) -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy charged today that what he called the Johnson Administration's "failure to make full use of Federal funds or Federal power" had left millions of Americans starving.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Vice President Humphrey, house-bound with the grippe, urged today continued American military assistance to Israel until peace is achieved in the Middle East.
A 30-day jail sentence imposed on Adam Clayton Powell in November, 1966, for criminal contempt of court was affirmed yesterday by a 3-2 vote of the Appellate Division.
Stock prices climbed in heavy trading yesterday morning, but the advance faltered in lighter turnover during the afternoon, leaving prices mixed at the close.

The industry organization that represents companies controlling about 65 per cent of the money spent on national advertising, has suggested that members not associate themselves with television entertainment programs that emphasize "excessive or unnecessary violence.''

District Attorney Jim Garrison asserted yesterday that his office had been exchanging information with a foreign intelligence agency that he said had "penetrated the forces involved in the assassination" of President Kennedy.

The goal of school decentralization is to bring the administration of educational policies so close to the community and so to improve the quality of education that parents will regain confidence in those who teach their children. This goal can be accomplished only if the professionals -- the district superintendents, principals and teachers -- have the power to respond to community needs, without waiting for directives and funds from a distant authority.

The Taylor Instrument Companies yesterday linked hands with another Rochester concern, the Ritter Pfaudler Corporation, in an attempt to block a bid by Ebasco Industries, Inc., to gain control of Taylor.

Hundreds of people walked through a flower-decked funeral chapel in Harlem yesterday to view the body of Ellsworth (Bumpy) Johnson, a controversial underworld figure whose death, a police official said, "marked the end of an era."
The city will appropriate up to $5-million this summer to increase the number of slum teenagers in the Neighborhood Youth Corps from 26,900 to 43,000.

STOCKHOLM, July 11 -Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union criticized Israel tonight as contributing increasingly to unrest in the Middle East by her continued occupation of captured Arab lands.

For the first time since 1956, the Larchmont Yacht Club's Race Week, Long Island Sound's leading and oldest sailboat fixture, will be held entirely during the afternoons starting tomorrow. In the intervening years the eight-day event had starts in the morning, mostly for juniors, and in the afternoon, mainly for their elders. The competition will be held for the 70th time.

Nine Reform Democratic clubs announced yesterday that they would challenge the "validity" of the New York delegation to the Democratic National Convention if minorities and supporters of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy did not get greater representation.
A crowd of 100 to 150 youths throwing rocks and bottles was dispersed by the police last night at Prospect Avenue and 161st Street in the Bronx after several store windows were broken.

Well, the three-day All-Star game break did not affect the batting eye of the Mets and Cubs who managed 20 base hits in a twilight-night doubleheader last night and scored three runs, one more than the minimum.

Standing near the spot where George Washington was inaugurated as the first President of the United States, Governor Rockefeller told a big and boisterous lunch-hour rally yesterday why he would like to be the 37th President.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 11 -- Recent reports that North Vietnam might consider a coalition government in Saigon built around a three-month-old political alliance have failed to stir any noticeable public interest in South Vietnam.

Earnings of the General Electric Company in the three and six months ended June 30 declined from the year-ago periods, according to the semi-annual report issued by Fred J. Borch, president.
A State Supreme Court suit to restrain the Board of Estimate from exercising any powers over the city's expense and capital budgets was initiated terday by the Citizens Union.
LONDON, July 11 -- Britain hopes to cut a bigger swath in Europe militarily and politically as she liquidates her role east of Suez, a supplementary defense white paper said today.

BRUSSELS, July 11 -- Central bankers of the major Western nations have taken the offensive in the war against currency speculators and have given the world dramatically improved prospects for monetary stability.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) -- The new treaty to stop the spread of nuclear weapons won unqualified support today from uniformed and civilian chiefs of the Defense Department. They declared it would not jeopardize United States security.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Labor Department officials contended today that New York City would receive a total of $1.5-million in extra Federal funds to create more jobs this summer, and not just the $1-million allocated to the neighborhood Youth Corps to hire slum teen-agers.
George London, the Metropolitan Opera bass baritone, has been named music administrator of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.

CENTURIES ago -- in the nineteen-twenties to be more specific -- the Russian impresario Serge Diaghilev had the bright idea of asking Igor Stravinsky to orchestrate some pieces by Pergolesi, and give them a contemporary accent.
Like a new father holding a baby for the first time, Van Sloan picked up a reel of computer tape yesterday and placed it on a magnetic tape drive.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) -- Capt. Howard B. Levy's attorney asked an Army review board today to reverse his three-year court-martial sentence because his antiwar statements were protected by the Constitution's guarantee of free speech.

The city has deliberately forfeited $700,000 in Federal funds to expand the Head Start program because of concern over the quality of the program, according to Mitchell I. Ginsberg, the city's Human Resources Administrator. The program seeks to prepare 21,500 preschool children in the slums for elementary school.

BOSTON, July 11 -- Early reports from a task force of college students from the deep South indicated today that they were picking up better than 100 signatures a day in support of the Presidential candidacy of George C. Wallace, former Governor of Alabama.

Futures contracts in precious and semiprecious metals, which had been especially attractive since the devaluation of the pound last November, lost some of their luster yesterday. Futures prices slipped in sympathy with a drop in the spot prices of gold and silver on world free markets.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI) -- Senators were told today that the United States planned to be a leading supplier of nuclear explosion devices for peaceful purposes to nations that sign the new treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.

I think it would be the gravest mistake if the supporters of Senator McCarthy were to veer off now toward a third party as suggested in the July 5 letter of Prof. Monroe H. Freedman, and abandon the effort to secure the Senator's nomination as candidate of the Democratic party.
Six Cubans invaded the studios of a Spanish-language radio station here at gunpoint last night and broadcast an anti-Castro statement urging revolution in Cuba.

With sheer power and doggedness they never displayed before, the New York Generals upset the top soccer attraction, Santos of Brazil, last night for one of the most significant victories ever achieved by a United States club.

The present concerted Moscow press campaign against Prague's liberals arouses grave concern particularly since Pravda has chosen to compare Czechoslovakia in 1968 with Hungary in 1956. This latest campaign is following on the heels of an even cruder effort to exert pressure on Prague by keeping Soviet troops in Czechoslovakia well after the end of the "maneuvers" that were the pretext for allowing them in.

Extensive delays, affecting thousands of passengers on incoming and outbound domestic and international flights and underscoring recent criticisms expressed by airline pilots, were reported last night at Kennedy and La Guardia Airports.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Post Office Department announced today an immediate ban on the extension of mail carrier services to new residential developments as part of a broad plan to conserve postal manpower.

While the tender offer by Howard R. Hughes, the industrialist, for control of American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., was not made until July 1, the initial contacts concerning the bid were made as early as six months ago.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today challenged under the antitrust laws 40 acquisitions made since 1953 by the Maremont Corporation of Chicago, a producer of shock absorbers, exhaust systems and other automotive parts.

CAPETOWN, July 12 -- A small but elite group of heart surgeons and pathologists began to gather in Capetown today for an international symposium that will bring together for the first time most of the world's pioneers in heart transplant surgery.

LAGOS, Nigeria, July 12 -- The Government is ready to open a land corridor from Enugu for relief supplies into secessionist-held areas of Biafra, where mass starvation threatens, the Commissioner of External Affairs, Dr. Okoi Arikpo, announced today.

PARIS, July 12 -- Maurice Couve de Murville, who will assume the functions of Premier tomorrow, announced tonight the formation of a Government strikingly similar in composition to that of Georges Pompidou, his predecessor.

Second-quarter sales and earnings of the St. Regis Paper Company exceeded those of the preceeding year's period, but half-year profits dipped despite increased sales, the semiannual report disclosed yesterday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 12 -- A United States soldier was shot in a crowded alley in Saigon today, and fresh rumors of impending attacks swept the city. He died several hours later.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 12 -- New faces and old waistlines provided the topics of conversation today as the New York Jets opened their training camp at Hofstra University with 39 players, mostly rookies. The other experienced players will report July 20.

Members of Governor Rockefeller's staff have released the information that the Governor does not plan to announce his choice of a successor as Senator from New York until after the Republican convention.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 12 -- The $100,000 Roosevelt International Trot, far from being the oldest, hardly the richest clearly not the most prestigious but certainly the most glamorous event in harness racing, will be tomorrow night's piece de resistance at Roosevelt Raceway.
ROME, July 12 -- The Vatican expressed astonishment today over a pledge by Premier Giovanni Leone to resume taxation of the Holy See's dividends from its Italian investments.

MADRID, July 12 -- The prospect that Prince Juan Carlos de Borbon will be chosen to occupy the Spanish throne after Generalissimo Francisco Franco dies or steps down was advanced a step by a Cabinet decree today.
SEATTLE, July 12 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said today that a foreign policy statement by Vice President Humphrey seemed not to square with the policy followed by the Johnson Administration.

MOSCOW, July 12 -- The Soviet armed forces newspaper, Krasnaya Zvezda, scoffed today at apprehensions that recent Warsaw Pact maneuvers in Czechoslovakia, in which Scviet troops took part, had been a strategem by Moscow to put pressure on the reform leadership in Prague.

TACOMA, Wash., July 12 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy dropped his plan today to meet with Dick Gregory after the entertainer was returned to jail from the hospital where he had been treated for a severe cold.
The Fire Department said yesterday that it would eventually replace half of its 134 hook-and-ladder trucks with new tower ladders, aerial platforms that ride on 75-foot telescopic booms.

BONN, July 12 -- The West German Government offered a glimpse of its abrasive diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union today by publishing the texts of its confidential negotiations with Moscow on a mutual renunciation of the use of force.
Work on a new longshore-industry contract began in earnest yesterday as negotiators for management and labor explored each other's positions.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- A Soviet writer and literary critic has apparently defected with his wife to the United States, State Department sources said today.
What looks like a piece of Pennsylvania has been found buried under the Bronx.

The spot rate on the British pound moved up well above the $2.39 level in moderately active trading on foreign exchange markets here. The gain reflected the absence of currency uncertainties that has tended to depress rates ahead of the week-end.
PLYMOUTH, Mass., July 12 (UPI) -- George C. Wallace called today for a "nose-to-nose, eyeball-to-eyeball meeting with people like Charles de Gaulle."

HARPSUND, Sweden, July 12 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union, in a spontaneous lakeside news conference in the Swedish countryside, tried today to play down Czechoslovak fears over the protracted presence of Soviet troops.
The nation's balance of payments -- as measured by transactions in official reserves -- moved into "heavy surplus" in the second quarter, informed Government officials said yesterday.
BOGOTA, Colombia -- The jackhammers start at 7 in the morning and are not stilled until dusk.
Prices rose again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange to another record in trading that was slightly less active than that of Thursday.

Tenants of a housing project in Harlem are about to get their request granted by the city: the project named 14 years ago for Stephen Foster is to be renamed in honor of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

In a telegram sent last night to Democratic party leaders and Mayor Richard Daley of Chicago, three network broadcasting executives said that unless the telephone strike in Chicago was ended, radio and television coverage of the party's convention would be impaired.

More than 100 California grape growers and shippers charged the United Farm Workers Organizing Committee and five New York labor unions yeaterday with setting up an illegal boycott of California grapes.
HONG KONG, July 12 (AP) -- North Vietnam is carrying out an intensive propaganda campaign to exploit the American decision to abandon the Marine combat base at Khesanh.
STONEWARE no longer only means the oversized early 19th-century jugs and jars to the country dealers who know the pottery field.
HELMET-SHAPED lamps are rapidly becoming the lighting designers' major ammunition in the battle to replace outsize lamps with smaller ones in the home.

Stage Door Johnny, barely known in the early part of the season but now a full-blown star, will head the field today in the $75,000 added Dwyer Handicap at Aqueduct. Only five rivals willl oppose the Greentree Stable's hero, who is certain to go off the shortpriced favorite in the 1 1/4-mile test for 3-year-olds.
The presidents of Plume Atwood and the National Acme Company met yesterday in Cleveland, where Acme has headquarters, to discuss "matters of mutual interest."
WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI) -- Four members of the Federal Communications Commission traded charges with two other members today in a public display of internal disagreement within the agency.

The long and great tradition of New York City as host to foreign visitors and residents predates the honor of having the United Nations here. Manhattan has long been an unofficial diplomatic capital, a tourist capital and a capital of international commerce. Foreigners form part of the way of life in New York.
Joseph Bach, the 80-year-old man who was shot twice in the back by Angel Angelof in Central Park on July 3 after Angelof had killed a young woman, died early yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital.

JOHN WEITZ, the first Seventh Avenue designer to streak successfully into men's fashions, will give a speech at the Cologne Men's Fair on Aug. 23. He is the first American designer to be asked to address the gathering, which has been called the Cannes Film Festival of men's fashions.

Corporate bond prices continued to climb yesterday, ending the week with one of the sharpest gains this year. The new Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) 61/2 per cent debentures, marketed so swiftly on Thursday, rose 3/8 of a point yesterday, reducing their yield to 6.37 per cent.

Two drama students serving as counselors at the Fresh Air Fund's three girls' camps at Sharpe Reservation, near Fishkill, N. Y., have undertaken a program to encourage impoverished New York City children to take an active interest in dramatics.
Mayor Lindsay moved yesterday to step up his controversial Little City Halls program and strengthen his legislative liaison with the Democratic City Council.
A 19-year-old Harlem woman was stabbed in Brooklyn Criminal Court yesterday by a man who was charged with stabbing her last May.

LONDON, July 12 -- A "Save the Argylls" petition circulated in Scotland today following the announcement in yesterday's defense white paper that the famous unit would be disbanded as part of general British military retrenchment.
MADISON, Wis., July 12 -- More than 7,000 University of Wisconsin students sitting on a small beach here cheered Mayor Lindsay today as he said Americans "have had enough of Vietnam."
PRAGUE, July 12 -- Czechoslovakia will propose to her allies a program of bilateral conversations as an alternative to the conference of Communist leaders that Prague rejected earlier this week.
Roman Catholics have joined Protestants and Jews in making information about church occupations and religious careers available to high-school students through guidance counselors.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- Eddie Stanky resigned as manager of the Chicago White Sox today. He will be replaced by Al Lopez, the man whom Stanky succeeded more than two years ago.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Vice President Humphrey advocated today a shift in American foreign policy from confrontation and containment of Communism to "reconciliation and peaceful engagement."

The Community Art Gallery, a showcase for local talent, will be opened at the Brooklyn Museum in late September. It will feature work by unknown artists and is expected to attract museum visitors for the first time.

CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, July 12 -- Billy Casper still leads the British Open, but just barely. His four-stroke lead was shaved to a single shot today by the New Zealand southpaw, Bob Charles, with Gary Player a little terrier yapping at their heels, another stroke away, Four strokes back of Casper was Jack Nicklaus.

LONDON, July 12 -- Cheap, disposable "paper" under-wear that can be washed four or five times before wearing out is a fast-selling line in the British stores that can stock it. The manufacture's problem is to keep up with demand.

LONG BEACH, Calif., July 12 -- The crews of Harvard and Pennsylvania advanced into the finals of the Olympic rowing trials today by winning opening heats as expected. Penn had the best time over the 2,000-meter course, an impressive 5 minutes 56.1 seconds.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 12 -- A tight security guard was put around the home of Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson today after the police safely removed a hand grenade from under the dashboard of one of his two personal automobiles.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Walter P. Reuther has accused George Meany of foreclosing cooperation between the United Auto Workers and the labor federation in this year's elections by his "unprecedented" suspension of the U.A.W.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- A Presidential advisory council recommended today repealing laws making abortion a crime and recognizing full legal rights of illegitimate children.

The 10-week-old United Parcel Service strike, which was supposed to have ended Monday, may continue because another union that repairs the company's trucks has refused to accept the same offer that was approved by the teamsters union drivers Thursday.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The House passed today a two-year $211-million health program that includes a new pattern of aid to communities for treating alcoholism and narcotics addiction.
DETROIT, July 12 -- New car sales continued at record levels in early July with dealers delivering 211,942 American-made cars, the auto makers reported today.

MIAMI, July 12 -- A gunman attempted to hijack a Delta Air Lines passenger jet on a flight from Philadelphia to Houston tonight and ordered the plane flown to Cuba. The plane's second officer talked him into surrendering his weapon and the plane made an emergency landing in Miami.
COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., July 12 -- Congress was urged today to defeat pending legislation that would permit the use of giant-sized trucks on the Interstate Highway System.

A visit by three jurors to a location described by a key witness in the trial of Mrs. Alice Crimmins should not be sufficient reason for setting aside her murder conviction, the prosecution argued in Queens Supreme Court yesterday.

WOODSTOCK, Vt., July 12 -- Ch. Kyi-Chu Friar Tuck, a gray-and-white Lhasa Apso, owned by Robert D. Sharp of Norwalk, Conn., was named best in show in a field of 747 dogs at the Woodstock Dog Club fixture today.

City budget officials said yesterday that they would have trouble finding $5-million to finance summer jobs for teenagers in a budget made increasingly tight by an "escalation of demand" for services by the poor.
Six Democratic county leaders in the city and suburbs have offered to give up their full votes on the state's delegation to the party's national convention to make room for Negroes and Puerto Ricans.
TRENTON, July 12 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes signed into law today a bill providing $2-million to help New Jersey's slum youths, mainly Negroes and Puerto Ricans, go to college.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The United States announced today that it would donate an additional 5,000 tons of food worth $1.3-million to victims of the Nigerian civil war.

AUSTIN, Trex., July 12 (UPI) -- Wilbur J. Cohen, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, proposed today that "the Federal Government should take over the entire running of the welfare program." He said "this would take the burden off of the states and cities and make the entire system more uniform."
TALLEYRAND'S judgment of the Royal House of Bourbon, voiced in 1796, was that "They have learned nothing and forgotten nothing.''
The theft last January of $140,000 in negotiable New York City bearer bonds from the offices of a Wall Street law firm was made known yesterday with the arrest of a man in Harrisburg, Pa.

Robert Rogers, suspected of shooting three persons to death on a South Bronx street on Thursday night, surrendered to a deputy sheriff yesterday afternoon on the courthouse steps in the small North Carolina city of Graham.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- President Johnson presented today a third Distinguished Service Medal to Gen. William C. Westmoreland, praising him for his leadership in "the most complex war in American History."

THE prim, sober dresses had an air of impoverished gentility. Their hems modestly covered the knees. They suggested office girls writing in their ledgers in cheerless cubicles -- or the rich women of 40 years ago dressed by Chanel in jersey to look like their maids.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 12 (AP) -- The Cornell lightweights and the J. E. B. Stuart High School eight of Falls Church, Va., gained semi-final berths in the Royal Henley Regatta today, despite some of the worst conditions in the 129-year history of the event.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 12 -- Regents of the University of California urged the Legislature today to override Gov. Ronald Reagan's veto of several millions of dollars of university budget items.

Futures prices of new-crop soybeans shot up yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade following a report that this year's production might have been endangered by improper use of herbicides.
Stock prices drifted to a mixed finish on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday as trading activity dropped sharply from Thursday's high level.

There is little likelihood in the near future that Congress will endorse the recommendations of the Joint Economic Committee by directing the Federal Reserve authorities to maintain the annual growth rate of the money stock within a 2 to 6 per cent range. But the question of whether the monetary authorities should be guided by a quantitative rule for economic stability is an important one.

Ernest Gallashaw, who was acquitted in the 1966 fatal shooting of 10-year-old Eric Dean during racial unrest in Brooklyn, was found guilty last night of supplying a machine gun to bank robbers last August.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Senate minority leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen, used strong language today to chide a fellow Republican Senator, Robert P. Griffin, for attempting to block President Johnson's nominations of two old friends to Supreme Court posts.
LONDON, July 12 -- For Harold Wilson and his Labor Government -- men who had almost forgotten the taste of good news -- this has been a happy political week.
The International Business Machines Corporation had record earnings in the three and six months ended June 30.

Insurance agents who have been on strike at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company since May 20 are seeking the support of organized labor throughout the city for a demonstration next week at the company's headquarters.
THE Open Pairs and Limited Pairs of the Brooklyn championships will be played at 1:30 P.M. and 7:30 P.M. today at the New York Hilton.
Two Manhattan caviar concerns have been convicted in Criminal Court of selling ordinary caviar as kosher caviar and fined $250 each.
PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 12 -- Ron Howell, a former United States Marine sergeant, finished like a true champion today to win the $10,000 New Jersey open golf crown going away.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- Senator Stephen M. Young predicted today that North Korea would release the Pueblo and her crew next month in return for an American apology and a large indemnity payment.

Two Argentine women -- described by a Customs official as couriers for "one of the largest heroin smuggling rings in the world" -- were arrested at Kennedy International Airport Thursday morning when about $4-million worth of heroin was found taped to their bodies.
The 10,000-member Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association won the right yesterday to argue its case attacking the constitutionality of the state's 10-month-old Taylor Law before the Court of Appeals.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 12 -- The seizure last month by the Lebanese Government of two private banks, Banque al Ahli and its subsidiary, Credit Hypothecaire Libanais, has focused attention here on severe economic ills that beset this mercantile country.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- France has sold the United States about $100-million worth of gold to get badly needed dollars -- dollars that President de Gaulle once scorned. Be tween 1962 and 1966, France turned in almost $2.9-billion of her dollars for gold at the United States Treasury.
CAIRO, July 12 -- The Soviet Union has been showing increasing interest lately in the early reopening of the Suez Canal, authoritative sources close to the Egyptian Foreign Ministry reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- President Johnson became the center of a controversy today when it was disclosed that he was seeking to assemble perhaps the most comprehensive historical record of any Administration.

In a June 29 letter, Gustave L. Levy, president of the Mount Sinai Hospital, chides Controller Procaccino for his allegations of fiscal wrongdoing in the Mount Sinai affiliation pact with the City Hospital Center at Elmhurst.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- It will soon be possible for a New York businessman to interrupt a telephone conversation with a client in Chicago. send him over the telephone a copy of the document they have been talking about, and resume the conversation.
MIAMI, July 12 -- Claude R. Kirk Jr., the flamboyant young Governor of Florida, endorsed Governor Rockefeller of New York for President today.

LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- John Gordy, president of the National Football League Players Association, charged today that the league's clubowners were trying to "break" the association. At the same time, he said he had sent a telegram to Art Modell, the N.F.L. president and head of the owners' negotiating committee, requesting a resumption of the stalemated labor negotiations.

THE National Broadcasting Company televised last night the first of four one-hour programs devoted to the topic "What's Happening to America?" Edwin Newman had as his guests Dr. C. Vann Woodward, Yale historian, and Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, Negro psychologist and civil rights leader.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Successive home runs by Tom Tresh and Frank Fernandez with two out in the seventh inning brought Steve Barber and the New York Yankees a 2-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight and handed Tommy John his first defeat of the season.
