WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Emergency provisions of the Medicare law may be helping some hospitals in the South to side-step civil rights requirements.

CENTRAL ISLIP, L. I., July 14 -- A suspect in a slaying and two other inmates at the state hospital here overpowered an attendant last night and forced him to aid in their escape. They were armed with a pistol, and the police said they were considered dangerous.

Vibrant, pulsating rhythms -- Afro-Cuban, Brazilian and just plain Latin rock -- swelled out of the Wollman Skating Rink in Central Park Saturday night when the Montego Joe Septet and Sergio Mendes and Brasil '66 gave two concerts as part of the Schaefer Music Festival. Both shows drew full houses of 5,500 people.

NEWARK, July 15 -- The clearing of the new site for the New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry was started here today while state officials and Negro community leaders met to discuss problems that threaten to halt construction.

GARY, Ind., July 15 -- On May 7, Richard M. Nixon won an uncontested victory in Indiana's primary election, rolling up more than 475,000 votes and assuring himself of the state's 26 votes at the Republican National Convention, at least for one ballot.

Two 10-story office buildings connected by an arcade with a restaurant and service facilities have been scheduled for construction on an 8.3 acre tract on the northwest corner of Route 4 and Hackensack Avenue in Hackensack, N. J., by the James D'Agostino Construction Corporation.

There is a new isolationist tide running in America which makes it obligatory for all the serious Presidential candidates to define with precision the world role each envisions for this country in the nineteen-seventies, as Vice President Humphrey has begun to do with the foreign policy statement issued by his campaign headquarters late last week.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 15 -- Frank O'Brien, a 20-year-old Florida collegian from the Plainfield Country Club, shot a record-tying 66 today to take the lead in the 16th annual Ike golf championship at Wykagyl.
Prices on the London stock market continued to advance to new high ground yesterday.
GARY, Ind., July 15 -- Governor Rockefeller said today he would resign from the Knickerbocker Club and others to which he belonged if they did not eliminate discriminatory policies.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has postponed the telecast of a public opinion survey on racial attitudes scheduled for next Tuesday at 10 P.M. Instead, it will rebroadcast the first program in its "Of Black America" series on prejudice entitled, "Black History: Lost, Stolen or Strayed."

MOSCOW, July 15 -The Soviet Union and the United States signed a new cultural exchange agreement today after six weeks of arduous negotiations hampered by Moscow's growing sensitivity to Western ideological influences.
Nine firemen were overcome by smoke and the day's heat yesterday while fighting a stubborn, smoky blaze in a supermarket in Harlem.

ATLANTA, July 15 (AP) -- The Atlanta Braves combined two singles, two walks, a passed ball, wild pitch and an error for three runs in the first inning, which were enough to beat the San Francisco Giants tonight, 4-2.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Association of American Colleges, a national organization representing 900 colleges of liberal arts and sciences, recommended today that students share in formulating college institutional policy as one of six steps designed to curb campus disruptions stemming from student unrest.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 15 -- The Jets and the Mets got company today -- the Nets.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Anna Filippi took a long stroll through a woods and a meadow today, and when it was over she said:
ROME, July 15 (Reuters) -Sources in Caritas, the Roman Catholic relief agency, said today that it had smuggled 30 planeloads of food and medicine to starving Biafran refugees.
ATHENS, July 15 -- Seventy American students, defying a ban on demonstrations, staged a four-hour sit-in at the headquarters of the Greek Tourist Organization here today.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen claimed 103 first-ballot votes for the Republican Presidential nomination today and predicted that his total would rise on later ballots at the Miami Beach convention starting Aug. 5.

UPPSALA, Sweden, July 15 -- The 720 delegates to the conference of the World Council of Churches began plenary debate today on the six position papers that are expected to be the major work of the Fourth Assembly. After initial discussions, it became apparent that most would be referred back for further committee work during the next few days.

LONDON, July 15 (AP) -- Alan Winnington, 58 years old, a journalist who covered the Korean war from the Communist side for The Daily Worker in London, has returned home after 20 years in exile. He left London in 1949 for Asia. Now an East Berlin correspondent for the Worker. he said he was here for a three-week stay.

The president of the teachers' union called yesterday on Mayor Lindsay's five new appointees to the Board of Education to demonstrate that they were "independent thinkers" on school matters and not "robots" of the Mayor.
Andy Warhol, currently recuperating at Columbus Hospital from near-fatal gunshot wounds, has had a theater named after him.
PARIS, July 15 -- A 22-year-old member of the Katangese group of self-styled instructors in street fighting for Sorbonne students was charged today with the murder of their leader.

LONDON, July 15 (AP) -- United States, British and French authorities are nearing an agreement to annul a 15-year-old Allied order for dismantling the multibillion-dollar Krupp industrial empire in Germany, British sources reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -Mayor Lindsay urged Senate and House conferees today to correct what he called "serious weaknesses" in the pending Federal housing bill, which he said could hamstring the bill's benefits in New York City and other large cities.

To the Editor: I am rather tired of the constant sniping at Richard Nixon which appears in your editorial and letter columns. That he is not the darling of the liberal "progressive" wing of the Republican party, which is championed regularly in your paper, is evident.

BACK in the nineteen-twenties and thirties, the late Joe Cook used to do a comedy nightclub routine that began with his announcement that he would imitate four Hawaiians. He never actually did -- the gag was an introduction to a rambling discourse on other subjects.
LISBON, July 15 -- Portugal's vast program to harness the Zambezi River in Mozambique will cost upwards of $315-million. It was announced here today.

HACKENSACK, N. J., July 15 -- Guy W. Calissi, the Bergen County Prosecutor, said today that a so-called vigilante group known as PRE-ARM (People's Rights Enforced Against Riots and Murder) was a one-man organization consisting of its chairman, Ernest T. Bradow.

DETROIT, July 15 -- Automobile production at the Chrysler Corporation's Dodge plant in Hamtramck was back to normal this evening after picketing led by Negroes crippled output Friday and earlier today.

After resorting to virtually everything but a slide rule and a seance session to come to his conclusions, Tommy Trotter, the racing secretary for New York's big thoroughbred racing tracks, announced yesterday the much awaited weights for next Saturday's $100,000-added Brooklyn Handicap.
The price of lead was reduced yesterday by one-half cent a pound, to 12 1/2 cents, by the American Smelting and Refining Company.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (UPI) -- A lifetime job security agreement covering 13,000 Penn Central shop workers in 13 states was announced today by the Railway Employes' Department of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Reed M. Chambers, a World War I ace and founder of the United States' first commercial airline and aviation underwriting organization has retired as chairman of the United States Aviation Underwriters, managers of the United States Aircraft Insurance Group.
A wide range of cultural activities is being planned for Mexico City and the Olympic Games there this year.
ROME, July 15 -- The nicest thing is happening in the Italian winter couture collections here if, like most women, you feel your arms are too fat, too freckled, or flabby. Illusion sleeves are back.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 15 -Carlisle, the winner of the recent American Trotting Championship, was named just in time today for Friday night's $25,000 Gold Division of the Challenge Cup at Roosevelt Raceway.
A 23-year-old bride of three weeks who worked to upgrade her slum neighborhood was found shot dead yesterday in her East Village apartment at 621 East Sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The House passed and sent to the White House today a bill approving a Great Lakes Basin compact.
BOGOTA, Colombia, July 15 -- French archeologists will seek to determine whether wreckage under the sea floor of St. Ann's Bay, Jamaica, is that of two vessels abandoned by Columbus in 1503.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 15 -- The blind astrologer, Master Canh, stepped quickly across the street this afternon, led by a little boy.

BLOOMINGDALE'S seems to come up with a different assortment of model rooms every six weeks, but this is an illusion. The store actually changes them only four times a year -- literally with the seasons -- and in the spring and fall it could not take the rooms more seriously if it were trying to achieve a present-day equivalent of Mount Vernon or Malmaison.
Production of steel in the nation's mills dropped again last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. However, the drop was not as sharp as in the preceding week.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 15 (AP) -- Malaysia today rejected the Philippine claim to the North Borneo state of Sabah. The rejection angered the Filipino delegation and raised cries in Manila for a diplomatic break.
The Board of Estimate took preliminary action yesterday toward using capital budget funds for the first time for something other than construction, building improvements and equipment purchases.
BALTIMORE, July 15 -- The fans love Frank Robinson again, and all it took was a line-drive triple and a couple of jarring slides.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Food and Drug Administration is conducting tests with human volunteers that may answer, for all antibiotics, the big question: Is Brand X really as good as Brand Y?

The chairman of the National Citizens Committee for Public Broadcasting said yesterday that the existence of the fledging Corporation for Public Broadcasting is in jeopardy because Congress has not given it any money.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Treasury disclosed today that, after redeeming silver certificates and transferring silver to the strategic stockpile, it had 300 million ounces of the metal left.

BUCHAREST, July 15 (UPI) -- President Nicolae Ceausescu, who is also the Rumanian party leader, warned the Soviet bloc today that it icould not justify interference !in the internal affairs of [ Czechoslovakia.

WARSAW, July 15 -- The Soviet Union and four of its East European allies ended a two-day meeting today and sent a joint letter to the Czechoslovak Communist party, whose liberalization process prompted the conference here.

Christ, wearing a blue sports shirt, staggered with his cross up Calvary while the jeering crowd danced to a calypso beat. A bit earlier the chorus of fleeing Jews, some of them girls in miniskirts, socked out a freedom song written by Phil Ochs, the folk singer: "What's That I Hear Now?" ("It's the sound of freedom calling, it's the sound of the old ways a-falling."
LONDON, July 15 (UPI) -- Miniskirts are more than just provocative, according to British revenue authorities -- they are tax evaders as well.
PRAGUE, July 15 -- Czechoslovakia called today for a fundamental revision of the Warsaw Pact, the Soviet-led East European military alliance, to insure genuine equality for its members.
Stock prices closed slightly lower on balance yesterday as the market continued to follow a course of cautious consolidation.

Wall Street is a community that loves to package its own brand of universal truth in quaint little phrases. One of its hoariest aphorisms -- designed to demonstrate the ineffe ctiveness, if not the iniquity, of attempts by government to control the flow of funds in the financial market place -- is that "money, like water, will seek its own level."
WASHINGTON, July 15 -Vice President Humphrey backed today a proposed change in the military draft to induct men by random selection and take younger men first.
A photographic reproduction from the first folio of Shakespeare's plays, believed to provide the most nearly perfect text in existence, will be published on Oct. 11 by the W.W. Norton Company.

GLADSTONE, N.J., July 15 -- The three riders who led the United States to the silver medal in the 1964 Olympic Games, along with five others, were named today to the United States Equestrian Team's three-day squad.
Robert L. Rogers was held without bail yesterday on charges of having shot three persons to death on a South Bronx street last Thursday night.

In one of the most unusual sales of tax-exempt securities since passage of the income tax amendment in 1923, a $25.5-million issue of revenue bonds was offered yesterday to finance a motor speedway 35 miles southeast of Los Angeles.

TRAVEMUNDE, West Germany, July 15 (AP) -- An air search was ordered by the West German Navy today for the South African ketch Stormvogel, which was leading in the trans-Atlantic Bermuda-toTravemunde yacht race when radio contact was lost on Friday.
Grains and soybeans futures prices on the Chicago Board of Trades rose rather sharply yesterday following the end of the strike of Canadian seamen on the St. Lawrence Seaway.
About 50 5-year-old children assembled quietly in the murky morning air yesterday in Riverside Park in front of a simple granite urn set on a small pedestal and surrounded by a low iron fence.

Chanting "We want better housing," about 75 residents of the Lower East Side picketed the offices of the city's Housing and Development Administration yesterday to demand more low-income apartments in an urban renewal project planned for their neighborhood.

To the Editor: Your news articles of July 9 about the new Saigon alliance and the fight hard and wait strategy of American officials, vividly portrays the irony of the fight-talk strategy. We "talk" to find some "middle ground" for a settlement, while we "fight" to prop up a Government whose policy is to thwart the growth of any "middle-ground" leadership.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Three weeks of following politics from the sidelines raises the question whether any of the candidates can win. The political news leaves the impression that Humphrey is too close to Johnson, McCarthy is too far from the pros, Rockefeller is too liberal for the Republicans, and the new Nixon is too much like the old Nixon.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday a 14.6 per cent gain in profits for the second quarter on record sales.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 -There is only one thing that unites California Democrats at the moment, and that is the confident prediction of disaster for their party in November.

OTTAWA, July 15 (UPI) -Postmaster General Eric Kierans ordered Canadians today to stop posting second, third and fourth class mail by noon tomorrow because, in the event of a general postal strike, none of it would be sent.

CHICAGO, July 15 (UPI) -- The Democratic National Chairman said today that "we'll have to take another look" at whether to hold the party's convention in Chicago if a strike by Illinois Telephone electricians is not settled by the end of this week.

" I'm a little less confident that we're going to have a major summer rally," Mrs. Joy Gilmont said as she watched stock prices darting yesterday afternoon across a screen at the West 72d Street brokerage office of Francis I. duPont Co.
I. D. Robbins, whose report criticizing the Lindsay administration last fall was not supported by the board of the City Club, was re-elected chairman last night.
Richie Allen continued to explore the outer limits of Shea Stadium last night.
An organization that includes both moderate and militant Negro spokesmen has been formed to assist Governor Rockefeller's Presidential candidacy.
Paul O'Dwyer called yesterday for an end to American "material and moral support to the Greek military regime."
TOM GRIFFIN, Ray Brown, Tony Dionisi, Jim Linhart and Frank Silver, all of New York, won the Brooklyn Knockout Team Championship Sunday night at the New York Hilton.

OAKLAND, Calif., July 15 (UPI) -- Twenty-five hundred chanting, sign-carrying demonstrators ringed the courthouse where a leader of the Black Panther party, Huey P. Newton went on trial today on charges of murdering a policeman.

JERUSALEM, July 15 -- George W. Ball, the new United States representative at the United Nations, today handed Premier Levi Eshkol what Israeli sources described as a "warm, personal note" from President Johnson.
Opponents of a proposed section of the Richmond Parkway that would cut through Staten Island's so-called greenbelt supported Mayor Lindsay's plan yesterday to move the route three miles to the west.

The New York Generals announced yesterday that Alex Young, acquired over the week-end, would be in uniform tomorrow night when they play the Baltimore Bays in a North American Soccer League game at the Yankee Stadium.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- The Chicago Daily News said today in a copyrighted article that James Earl Ray wrote a letter to his brother that indicates that Ray is the man being held in a London jail in connection with the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. under the name of Ramon George Sneyd.

PARIS, July 15 -- North Vietnam's negotiators, who have accused the United States of conjuring up hopeful signs about the Vietnam talks here, acknowledged for the first time today that "serious questions" had come up during informal recess conversations.
DETROIT, July 15 -- The Chrysler Corporation reported today record sales and profits in the second quarter and first half of 1968, despite a new 10 per cent income-tax surcharge.
GENEVA, July 15 -- Britain will seek to break the impasse on the proposed ban on underground nuclear testing at the session of the 17-nation disarmament conference that begins here tomorrow.

Directors of the Allied Kid Company rejected yesterday a merger offer from the Standard Prudential United Corporation, and management of Kid said it had agreed in principle to merge with the Cudahy Company of Phoenix, Ariz.

BAASTAD, Sweden, July 15 (UPI) -- Marty Mulligan, the Italian-based Australian, won the men's singles title at the Swedish tennis championships for the second consecutive year today with an 8-6, 6-4 6-4 victory over Ion Tiriac of Rumania.
MEPHISTOPHELES looked up from the papers and eyed the applicant with new respect.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, July 16 -- United States and South Vietnamese troops fighting in the Mekong River delta killed 102 Vietcong in three actions yesterday.

WILD weather and floating debris combined to make the recent seventh annual Bay Shore, L. I., mako (after the mako shark) tournament a somewhat demanding affair, but John Paul Fensterer, chairman, although weary at its close was not despondent.
A representative of 5,000 nurses at 20 municipal hospitals here said yesterday that the nurses were "upset and angry" because the city had not made a counteroffer to their contract demands.
TOPEKA, Kan., July 15 -Demonstrators who picketed a mental hospital here yesterday were freed on bond today after spending a night in the Shawnee County jail.

A wide-ranging realignment of the North American management structure of the worldwide Bowater Paper Corporation was announced yesterday in London by the concern's chairman, Sir Christopher Chancellor.

THE Electric Circus is a hangout for the really advanced kids, and a lot of avant-garde music is unveiled there. So last night when Paul Zukofsky came out to play Michael Sahl's "Mitzvah for the Dead," with electronic accompaniment, everybody braced himself.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -President Johnson signed today a bill that doubles the Federal outlay for new parks and recreation areas during the next five years.
CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -Tommy Davis drove in two runs with a third-inning single today to pace the Chicago White Sox to a 3-2 triumph over the Washington Senators.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) -- The National Health Education Committee today gave a report to President Johnson showing that health benefits had improved markedly since he took office five years ago.
BRUSSELS, July 15 -- The Belgian Government decided today to cancel all arms deliveries to Nigeria even under current contracts.

To the Editor: If a hunter kills a cheetah and is able to sell the pelt to a very chic fashion designer such as Donald Brooks who is able to gain enormous publicity in The Times which is read by a woman with $6,000 to buy the coat he made from the pelt, where is the chain of irresponsible action against one of the world's most magnificent wild animals to be broken?

If neither snow nor rain nor heat nor gloom of night can stay the post office couriers from their appointed rounds, why should mere man -- in the person of Postmaster General W. Marvin Watson -- be allowed to? His ordered cutbacks in service beginning later this month, coming at a time when deliveries already leave much to be desired, would drag the United States mails straight back into the age of the pony express.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 15 -- The boys and girls of Larchmont Race Week began their portion of the big sailing carnival today with better wind than their elders had enjoyed the first two days and with two more afternoons exclusively theirs ahead.

LONDON, July 15 -- The World Council of Synagogues, representing the Conservative movement in Judaism, was urged today to consider ways to bridge the gap between the technical knowledge possessed by youth and the "permanent insights into life which we have inherited from our ancestors."
Mayor Lindsay praised the start yesterday of "Operation Better Block," a summer program designed to aid 100 neighborhood groups through a $40,000 gift by the Bristol-Myers Company.
IT'S a rare day when the shares of the Penn Central Company reach the New York Stock Exchange's most active list and even rarer when any issue tops the list after trading for less than a half hour.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -President Johnson emphasized today his desire to leave a legacy of better relations with the Soviet Union after his term of office. He said he believed that the United States could soon advance toward detente with the Soviet Union and toward an agreement to limit missile forces.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 15 -- The Jordanian royal court today announced the engagement of Crown Prince Hassan to Sarwat Ikram Ullah, a 20-year-old Pakistani girl.

Two hundred demonstrators disrupted two Brooklyn welfare centers yesterday, closing them for three hours in a demand for faster processing of special-grant claims. Four-fifths of the center caseworkers then stayed away the rest of the day.

Archibald Cox, chairman of the commission set up to investigate the causes of the disturbances that paralyzed the Columbia University campus, said one of the university's procedures to discipline the students could lead to unfair suspensions.
An eight-member committee of mayors has been formed to lobby for a Federal guaranteed annual income in Washington and at the Democratic and Republican National Conventions.

American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., failed again yesterday to stop the tender offer by Howard R. Hughes for 43 per cent of its stock. As a result, the $148.5-million tender offer expired on schedule at 3 P.M. yesterday. The results were not announced immediately but a source close to the industralist said that "the stock came in pretty good."

The increasing volume of air traffic in the New York area may force the Federal Government to regulate airline schedules if the airlines do not voluntarily limit their flights into and out of the city, an official of the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday.

Mayor Lindsay signed into law yesterday a bill that would make car-rental agencies jointly liable with their customers for the violation of all parking laws and regulations. Such violation, the Mayor said, "ranks high on the long list of New York City's major problems."
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 15 (AP) -The yawl Hilaria was declared the over-all winner today of the 44th annual Port Huron-to-Mackinac yacht race.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover has again attacked two of his favorite targets -- the academic quality of midshipmen turned out by the Naval Academy and the Pentagon's release of technical information.

The House of Representatives yesterday passed the lumbermen's bill to create a mockery of a Redwoods National Park. This pitiful measure now goes to a House-Senate conference where proponents of a genuine park will have their last chance.
BONN, July 15 -- The West German Government has asked its three major allies to join it in a clear affirmation of the Government's legal rights in West Berlin, Government sources disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Notice of intent to mount a proxy fight for control of Defiance Industries, Inc., apex of the business empire controlled by Victor Muscat, was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 15 -- Ronald Reagan said today that he was speaking this week and next in four Southern states to offset the strength of George C. Wallace.
About 200 operators who handle the overseas calls of the American Telephone Telegraph Company walked off their jobs in lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon to attend a 24-hour union meeting.
Following is the statement issued by the Polish press agency yesterday after the meeting in Warsaw.

Manhattan Borough President Percy E. Sutton and Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson announced yesterday that they were supporting Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota, for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

Defense Secretary Clifford recently urged resumption of full-scale arms aid to Greece, arguing that if the United States continues its military assistance "we can play a greater part in helping Greece to get constitutional government." This rationale has been demolished by the new "democratic" constitution that has been proposed at last by Greece's fourteen-month-old ruling military junta.

The New Yorker magazine lost more pages of advertising in the first six months than either Woman's Day, Nation's Business, National Geographic or True carried and still ended up with 2,408 pages. So don't feel too bad for them.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) -- House members worked a 13-hour day today as they struggled into the night to clear away the mountain of bills blocking the way to a pre-convention adjournment.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission agreed today to drop antimerger proceedings against a New York grocery chain in return for the company's promise to dispose of several outlets.
Arguments over a dish of homemade ice cream and whether a rifle should be brought into a house ended in two of The 192 fatal shootings that took place in the United States last week.
NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., July 15 -- At 9 A.M. the school bell rang, and 60 youngsters began their first lesson today at the New York Rangers' annual hockey clinic at Skateland here.

Trucks of the United Parcel Service moved through the streets of northern New Jersey yesterday for the first time since May 2, but the company's operations in the rest of the metropolitan area remained at a standstill.
NIAMEY, Niger, July 15 -- Leaders of sevet African countries assembled in this former French territory today to begin talks on the year-old civil war in neighboring Nigeria.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said today over-the-counter trading in common stock of Fastline, Inc., suspended since last November, will be allowed to resume July 22.

The Soviet Union, in a move that underlines its strengthened strategic role in the Mediterranean and in the Arab world, has arranged to post technicians in Mers-el-Kebir, the former French base in western Algeria, 260 miles from the Strait of Gibraltar.

The audience that packed Philharmonic Hall last night to hear the Preservation Hall Jazz Band could have filled for almost a month the small, dingy room in New Orleans where the band usually plays. The applause that greeted every solo, the avalanche of cheers that followed almost every number, might keep the rafters of Preservation Hall rocking for a year.

CAN you talk your way out of prejudice? The city of Houston has asked that question and is conducting an interesting community experiment to see if it can come up with the answer. The experimental program was the subject of "Prejudice and the Police," the fourth in the American Broadcasting Company's six-part series entitled "Time for Americans."
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Senate passage today completed Congressional action on a compromise bill extending the Food for Freedom program for two years beyond Dec. 31.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 15 (AP) -- Royal Comedian took the longest way home today, but carried the high weight of 119 pounds to victory in the $8,500 Tom Fool Purse at Monmouth Park.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- A $14-billion authorization to extend and expand Federal aid to higher education over the next four years was approved by the Senate today, 83 to O.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -Senator Eugene J. McCarthy made his strongest pledge tonight to reject an independent Presidential candidacy if he lost the Democratic nomination to Vice President Humphrey.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- President Johnson announced plans today to nominate new ambassadors to Canada and Bolivia.
Prices declined slightly on the American Stock Exchange yesterday after setting several records last week.
NEW DELHI, July 15 (Reuters) -At least 80 persons were killed in monsoon floods that ravaged six Indian states during the last week, leaving thousands homeless and crops damaged.
" IF it had gone off," Detective Andrew Sweeney said later, "we'd both have been dead. We didn't have time to put on protective clothing or anything. All we could do was dismantle it."
Increased sales and earnings were reported yesterday by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., for the quarter and six months ended June 30, compared with those of the year-earlier periods.

HONG KONG, July 15 -Reports of new battles between rival factions in Canton coincided today with an emotional appeal in the Nanfang Jih Pao, the official publication of the ruling Kwangtung Revolutionary Committee, calling on committee supporters to rally and defeat a new "frantic counter offensive launched by class enemies."

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, July 16 -- The historic Willard Hotel, where Julia Ward Howe set down the words to "The Battle Hymn of the Republic" in a rush of inspiration one morning in 1861, closed suddenly at midnight.
Scientists and wildlife officials in Ohio are developing a method of electronic "fleshprinting" to help trace the migration patterns of fish.
Yields on new corporate and municipal bond issues continued to decline yesterday, but prices of already outstanding issues also moved downward.
UPPSALA, Sweden, July 15 -- The World Council of Churches opened a drive among member churches today to raise an additional $3-million for relief activities in Nigeria and Biafra.

To the Editor: In "Aid to Cities" (letter July 9) G. B. Franklin displays lack of understanding of the home-rule relationships among Washington, the state capitals and City Hall. To ask what part of New York City has been rekindled or redeemed by Governor Rockefeller's leadership implies that the Governor single-handedly could step in and do for New York City what it has not been able, for one reason or another, to do for itself.
BERLIN, July 13 -- The East German Communist party newspaper has accused Prof. Zbigniew K. Brzezinski of Columbia University of seeking to influence developments in Czechoslovakia.

To the Editor: Your July 8 editorial "Money and Basic Research" was timely and to the point. I did, however, detect an air of scepticism and the implication that the scientific community is wont to "cry wolf." Perhaps a specific example of the havoc created by recent budget cuts will dispel any doubts as to the seriousness of the situation particularly for younger scientists.
The first direct airline service between the Soviet Union and the United States was opened yesterday by Aeroflot, the Soviet airline, and Pan American World Airways.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler said today he opposed an agreement among the leading nations for "artificial support" of the free-market gold price, but he did not rule out future purchases of gold from South Africa.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- The authorities at Kruger National Park, one of the world's greatest wild-game areas, have held out for many years against the temptation to put their "spare meat" up for public consumption.

A SNACK or a meal in a box from The Party Box, Inc., 63 West 90th Street, may be the answer to leisurely entertaining at the beach, in Central Park, in the office or on the terrace of a city apartment.

OTTAWA, July 15 (AP) -- Ships moved through the St. Lawrence Seaway again today after a 24-day strike that had made nearly 300 ships idle at an estimated cost of $20-million in wages, seaway tolls and other losses.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 15 (AP) -- Duke Sims's two-run homer helped Cleveland build an early four-run lead today and the Indians needed it as Mike Paul and Stan Williams put down a late Minnesota rally to give Sonny Siebert a 4-2 victory over the Twins.

CAPETOWN, July 15 (AP) -- Doctors at an international heart transplant symposium here agreed today that heart transplant patients should be allowed out of bed for the first time within 48 hours after undergoing the operation.
Two bomb squad detectives dismantled a live bomb hanging on the door of the French Government Tourist Office in Rockefeller Center yesterday morning, two minutes before it was set to go off.
A study of drug abusers admitted to a psychiatric hospital here showed that half of them had psychiatric problems before their use of drugs.
The cost of keeping the average American housewife in the style to which she has become accustomed increased again yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, July 15 -- The Los Angeles County District Attorney's Office confirmed today that it would seek the death penalty against Sirhan B. Sirhan, who is accused of assassinating Senator Robert F. Kennedy.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -The Treasury bill rate rose at today's auction from last week's levels, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Justice Abe Fortas testified today that since he joined the Supreme Court he had assisted President Johnson in strategy planning conferences on the Vietnam war and urban riots.
LONDON, July 16 (AP) -- John Lennon, who once contended that the Beattles were more popular than Jesus, is now squabbling with the church over acorns.

Following is the last of a series of articles on conditions and attitudes in the Arab world a year after the war with Israel. It is based on the correspondent's visits to 12 Arab countries and Israel during the course of a 13-week tour.
Six weeks after the death of Robert F. Kennedy, many of his former campaign workers are organizing a drive to deal with gun control, poverty and race relations in his name.
LONDON, July 16 -- The American Tobacco Company challenged Philip Morris, Inc., today to a $100-million battle for control of Britain's second largest tobacco company, Gallaher, Ltd.
Two men were wounded by pistol shots in separate, unrelated incidents after arguments over minor matters in Manhattan early yesterday.
Two announcements were made yesterday -- one over coffee and Danish in a posterfestooned midtown campaign office and the other over cocktails and mixed nuts in a plush East Side apartment.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits asked the Secretary of the Air Force today to suspend temporarily orders reassigning 4,900 Air National Guard and Air Force reservists called to active duty after the Pueblo crisis in January.
A simplified family-fare airline discount structure, submitted by the domestic trunk lines, becomes effective today.

The United States is fighting two wars against oppression, one in Vietnam and one at home. Of these, by far the most dangerous, difficult and honorable is the domestic war on racism and poverty and the economic factors that preserve them.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 (UPI) -- Military and civilian policemen were in a quandary today over nine servicemen who publicly "resigned" from the armed forces, chained themselves to ministers and took sanctuary in a church.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 16 -To hear Henri Levesque, the owner, and Jean-Rene Gougeon, the driver of the French mare, Roquepine, talk today about Friday's Gold Division of the Challenge Cup race at Roosevelt Raceway, one would walk away convinced that the mileand-a-half trot already had been wrapped up by their horse.
New York City sold a $106.88-million bond issue yesterday at an interest cost of 4.76 per cent, a somewhat lower rate than it paid in April.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- President Johnson and President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam are expected to discuss at Honolulu this week some of the questions they would face if the Paris talks on Vietnam began to achieve success an informed United States official said today.
As suddenly as he had made his tender offer 16 days ago, Howard R. Hughes dropped his bid yesterday for control of American Broadcasting Companies, Inc.

Your July 13 editorial "Senators vs. the Court" rightly concludes that the "irresponsibles in the Senate [are only] delaying the inevitable confirmation" of the Fortas-Thornberry designations. The argument against these appointees based on their friendship with the President is sophistical; the best appointees in our history were intimately known to the Executive.

It took the Grasshopper Gazette, a Washington school newspaper whose staff ranges in age from 11 to 14, to elicit from the Vice President his views on changing the Selective Service Act. Mr. Humphrey would induct men by lottery and take younger men first, as recommended last year by the National Advisory Commission on Selective Service.

The nose-tingling odors of camphor and pelt preservatives clung about the near-empty, steaming sidewalks of New York's fur market, now traversed only by an occasional porter with a pack of skins at his shoulder, a heavily-laden trundle cart or a cigar-chomping kibitzer on vacation.
A 26-story office building built at 111 John Street in 1928 has been sold to a group of investors in Cleveland -- the First Union Realty -- for about $9-million.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- President Johnson today appointed a special committee of private citizens and Government officials to assess the total Federal role and responsibility in population problems.
The Sun Oil Company showed sharp increases, yielding record earnings for the three and six months ended June 30.
A draft resister asked a Federal judge yesterday for a jury hearing on his claim that the military draft is unlawful because it applies only to men and not women.
Flip Wilson is the first comedian to play the Rainbow Grill, which up to now has specialized in music, and at first glance it is a fairly daring booking.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The Federal Government has been making huge profits from the nation's coinage since it replaced silver with copper and nickel in hard currency.

The National Maritime Union announced yesterday that it was setting up procedures for a new election under an order issued last April by a Federal court, but the United States Attorney's Office here said the union was wasting its time.
LOS ANGELES, July 16 (AP) -- Alan W. Livingston said today he has resigned as president and director of Capitol Industries, Inc.

The bells of Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church clanged across East 115th Street yesterday morning. A blaring band turned from Pleasant Avenue into the tenement-lined block. Then, on a float pulled and pushed by men and women, came the gold-crowned statue of the Virgin Mary, with the infant Jesus in her arms.

CAPT. Boris Semyonovich Yegorov, the chief pilot of the Soviet jetliner Ilyushin 62 that opened Soviet air service to the United States on Monday, is a smiling, friendly man who seems utterly convinced that everything in Moscow is better than anything anywhere else.

Rocky Colavito grew up in the Bronx and Joe Pepitone grew up in Brooklyn and they both grew up as Yankee fans. Last night they did what Yankees used to do -- they hit home runs to win a twilight-night double-header.
A 17-year-old youth, confined to a wheel chair since he was struck by a freight train five years ago, won a $162,500 settlement yesterday from the New York. New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

Stockholders of Esquire, Inc., at the annual meeting here yesterday elected a former Governor of North Carolina, Terry Sanford, as a director. Mr. Sanford is now a partner in the law firm of Sanford, Cannon, Adams McCullough of Raleigh, N. C.
BREAKING POINT, Alberta -- A torrential cloudburst a few days ago left Heather Stickney's parsnips, carrots, squash, onions, pumpkins, potatoes and peas under water.

WHITE PLAINS, July 16 -- A motion-picture actor in "The Detective," a film starring Frank Sinatra, was among four men arrested on narcotics charges today in the investigation of a $2-million cache of heroin seized in Yonkers at dawn.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Following are excerpts from an unofficial transcript, made for The New York Times, of testimony today before the Senate Judiciary Committee on the nomination of Abe Fortas to be Chief Justice of the United States:
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 16 -- The Republican National Convention of 1860 seemed over before it started.
Carbon monoxide from a coal-burning boiler seeped into a basement apartment in upper Manhattan last night, killing an 11-month-old baby and overcoming five other persons.

Sales of the B. F. Goodrich Company for the three and six months ended June 30 were reported yesterday at new peaks while earnings exceeded those of last year when the company's operations were hampered by strikes.

TOM ADDISON of the Boston Patriots learned the hard way that he was no longer wanted. A member of the team since its inception eight years before and the one-time defensive captain and player representative, Addison failed to receive a contract renewal in the mail in May. No "Dear Tom" letter.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 -- Richard M. Nixon declared today that if he were the Republican Presidential candidate, he would not make a deal with George C. Wallace, former Governor of Alabama, if the Presidential election were dead-locked and thrown into the House of Representatives.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., July 6 -- Mayor Lindsay conceded for the first time today that he was interested in another political office -- not President, not Vice President, not Senator, but Mayor of this pretty village of 2,700 people.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 16 (AP) -- Tony Oliva smashed[ a two-run triple and John Rose-[ boro a two-run homer as thet Minnesota Twins tallied sixJ runs against Gary Bell in theI first inning and went on to crush tile Boston Red Sox tonight. 12-3.
PARIS, July 16 (Reuters) -- Valery Giscard d'Estaing, the Independent Republican leader and a former Finance Minister, was removed today as chairman of the Finance Committee of the National Assembly.

The Indian Government is reported to be preparing a request for American help to save Calcutta, the subcontinent's largest city and major port, which is choking to death as a result of overcrowding and neglect.

The Taos Pueblo Indians of northern New Mexico recently held a celebration, complete with colorful Indian dances, to thank the U.S. House of Representatives for unanimously passing the bill (H.R. 3306) proposing to restore to the Indians some 48,000 acres of the sacred Blue Lake watershed in the Sangre de Cristo Mountains.

Boys with snare drums and girls with trumpets and bells backed up an appeal at City Hall yesterday for more funds for the Adventure Corps, a Lower East Side project for 400 youngsters aged 9 to 13 that is allegedly being "phased out" of city financing.

GREENSBORO, N. C., July 16 (AP) -- Edward Thompson Jr., a fugitive labeled an outlaw in court, was arrested today in a car belonging to a man whose body was found hours earlier in an abandoned house beside that of a woman.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Industrial production edged up in June from a May level that had been revised upward, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The owners of a six-story apartment house on the West Side filed suit yesterday in Federal Court to compel nine insurance companies to issue fire and risk insurance on properties in areas populated predominantly by Negroes and Puerto Ricans.

COTONOU, Dahomey, July 16 (Agence France-Presse) -- The need for an urgent solution to Dahomey's economic crisis is believed here to have prompted the military regime's decision to install Dr. Emile Zinsou as President two weeks early.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 16 -- Denny Lyons, a 5-foot-5-inch precision shotmaker from the Burning Tree Club in Greenwich, Conn., won the 16th annual Ike golf tournament today with a 54-hole total of three-under-par 213 over the parched course of the Wykagyl Country Club.

STOCKHOLM, July 16 -- United States-Swedish relations have improved somewhat from the strains of last March, when Ambassador William W. Heath was called home for five weeks as an American protest against demonstrative Swedish opposition to the war in Vietnam.

A Federal official yesterday asked Major Owens, head of the city's Community Development Agency, to "look into" conflict-of-interest charges at Haryou-Act, the oft-troubled Harlem antipoverty organization.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 (UPI) -- A bearded young sailor was discovered recently after he had hidden for more than three months in a cramped space above a barracks ceiling at Johnsville Naval Air Station.

LONDON, July 16 (AP) -- The first two autumn and winter collections in the season's fashion shows -- those of Mattli and Hardy Amies -- signaled one clear message: Don't be caught in a miniskirt this fall.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- President Johnson reacted non-committally today to a Presidential commission's proposals for converting the Post Office into a nonprofit Government corporation.
